('39', 0, 5, 12, 727) 2. LETTER TO V. S. SRINIVASA SASTRI
('39', 0, 6, 13, 763) NANDI HILLS, June 4, 1927
('39', 0, 7, 14, 789) MY DEAR BROTHER, I remain unaffected by the effusion which the Chronicle has passed on to you and you to me.
('39', 0, 7, 15, 898) Of course you do not expect absolute smooth sailing.
('39', 0, 7, 16, 951) Such imbecile opposition you will have.
('39', 0, 7, 17, 991) But I know that you will stand unmoved.
('39', 0, 7, 18, 1031) You will have the solid backing of the vast majority of the Indian population.
('39', 0, 7, 19, 1110) I sent you a little note 1 two three days ago, which I hope was duly delivered to you.
('39', 0, 7, 20, 1197) May God guide your footsteps.
('39', 0, 7, 21, 1227) Yours sincerely,

('39', 1, 1, 2, 1363) 3. LETTER TO S. D. NADKARNI 1
('39', 1, 2, 3, 1393) NANDI HILLS, June 4, 1927
('39', 1, 3, 4, 1419) DEAR FRIEND,
('39', 1, 4, 5, 1432) I am glad that you are moving our friends on your side to open a local public temple 2 to the so called untouchables.
('39', 1, 4, 6, 1550) I hope that the forthcoming meeting will pass the contemplated resolution unani mously, and if they do, they will be doing justice more to themselves than to whom we have so long held under suppression.
('39', 1, 4, 7, 1753) My opinion is our temples have been forsaken by God.
('39', 1, 4, 8, 1806) Because of our ungodly treatment of a portion of our countrymen, God has made Himself untouchable, unapproachable and unseeable.
('39', 1, 4, 9, 1935) God will re enter our temples only when we have opened not merely our temples but our hearts to these fellow countrymen and fellow religionists.
('39', 1, 4, 10, 2080) Though your letter for Young India does not seem to me to rise to the height of some of the former communications you have been good enough to send me, I propose to publish it 3 as soon as I can, if only for the well meaning and well meant hits at me which I know are intended to travel far beyond me, in the hope that they will produce some impression.
('39', 1, 4, 11, 2434) I hope my message will be in time for the meeting.
('39', 1, 4, 12, 2485) I got your letter only last evening and I am sending you the message by the return post.
('39', 1, 4, 13, 2574) Yours sincerely,
('39', 1, 5, 14, 2591) BAPU S. D. NADKARNI, ESQ.
('39', 1, 5, 15, 2617) KARWAR (N. KANARA)

('39', 2, 1, 2, 2980) 4. LETTER TO RAMDAS GANDHI
('39', 2, 2, 3, 3007) June 4, 1927 You will have to struggle.
('39', 2, 2, 4, 3047) Manliness consists in struggling.
('39', 2, 2, 5, 3081) It is such struggling that moulds us.
('39', 2, 2, 6, 3119) Hence be fearless and fight on.
('39', 2, 2, 7, 3151) Never lose heart, and, if the enemy succeeds in throwing you down though you may have fought with all your strength, do not get dejected in the least.
('39', 2, 2, 8, 3302) Be on your feet again and resume the fight.
('39', 2, 2, 9, 3346) When we do not share responsibility for our defeat, we have no cause at all for shame, for then our defeat is no defeat.
('39', 2, 2, 10, 3467) You should be very vigilant so that you may not have involuntary emission during sleep, and, if you feel the desire aroused at any hour during the night, you should without a moments delay, get out of bed immediately and drink some cold water, then sit in cold water and pour a jugful of cold water over the genitals.
('39', 2, 2, 11, 3785) Often we become calmed down by walking about for a while and repeating Ramanama.
('39', 2, 2, 12, 3866) Moreover, whenever we are unoccupied we should recall to mind perfect brahmacharis like Bhishma 1 and others, that is to say, we should think of their strength of mind.
('39', 2, 2, 13, 4035) If these seem too distant in time, we should reflect on the lives of Andrews, Pearson, Kitchin and others.
('39', 2, 2, 14, 4142) If even these seem too remote, at any rate we have with us the fiveVinoba, Balkrishna, Surendra, Chhotelal and Krishnadas.
('39', 2, 2, 15, 4265) We can cite other examples from India; you should tell yourself that you can certainly do what they can.
('39', 2, 2, 16, 4370) You should also reflect from time to time on daily readings from the Gita; that too can give us great peace of mind.
('39', 2, 3, 17, 4487) [From Gujarati]
('39', 2, 4, 18, 4503) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desais Diary.
('39', 2, 4, 19, 4548) Courtesy: Narayan Desai
('39', 2, 5, 20, 4572) 5. LETTER TO SHARADABEHN KOTAK
('39', 2, 6, 21, 4603) June 4, 1927 What you write about the problem of thieves is quite right.
('39', 2, 6, 22, 4676) My putting the question to you did not mean that I expected you to be able to find the solution immediately.
('39', 2, 6, 23, 4785) It was intended to make all the women think.
('39', 2, 6, 24, 4830) Men must do their duty of protecting women.
('39', 2, 6, 25, 4874) But after
('39', 2, 7, 26, 4884) 1 A character in the Mahabharata who early in life took a vow of celibacy and observed it throughout his long life.
('39', 3, 0, 1, 5000) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 3, 1, 2, 5040) all mens bodies are, like those of women, as brittle as glass bangles, though perhaps the male bangles are harder and can bear stronger blows.
('39', 3, 1, 3, 5183) What women should do when those bangles are broken, is a question which they themselves should consider.
('39', 3, 1, 4, 5288) There is the same atman in woman as in man.
('39', 3, 1, 5, 5332) It is not affected by differences of caste, sex or country.
('39', 3, 1, 6, 5392) The wide awake atman in a heroic woman can be a thousand times more powerful than the slumbering atman in a wicked man.
('39', 3, 1, 7, 5512) Hence, in the competition for displaying spiritual consciousness and strength of soul, all peoplethe maimed and the crippled, the strong and the weak, men and women, the old and the young and childrencan participate on equal terms if they wish.
('39', 3, 1, 8, 5757) Even a dense dark night obstructs only our natural eyes, but if we have developed divine eyes, what can a dense dark night or a long handled sickle or a large baton do to us?
('39', 3, 1, 9, 5932) And if, on such a dark night a giant of a man carrying a terrible weapon comes and stands before one of usthe others having either gone to sleep or been killed or run awayif at that time we do not remember the name of Rama, then our having chanted it morning and evening will have been in vain.
('39', 3, 1, 10, 6227) It is in the hope that it may come to us at such a dreadful time and help us that we unfailingly repeat Ramanama morning and evening even though we may feel lazy, or be tired or sleepy.
('39', 3, 1, 11, 6413) It is possible that after long practice, that name will come to our lips spontaneously every time we need it, will even be engraved in our hearts.
('39', 3, 1, 12, 6560) The women of the Raniparaj community are certainly more fearless than we.
('39', 3, 1, 13, 6634) They will go anywhere during night time.
('39', 3, 1, 14, 6675) They do not depend on being protected by men.
('39', 3, 1, 15, 6721) It is, however, true that they have other fears, but my statement is only about fear of thieves and the like.
('39', 3, 1, 16, 6831) It is not true to say that the Kaniparaj women do not care about their chastity.
('39', 3, 1, 17, 6912) It is not proper either, to believe that only those who care for their chastity are afraid.
('39', 3, 1, 18, 7004) The fear which afflicts us in the Ashram has nothing to do with outrage of modesty.
('39', 3, 1, 19, 7088) If we take count of cases of rape in the world, we shall discover that such incidents are very rare.
('39', 3, 1, 20, 7189) A womans virtue is violated through both the man and the woman acting voluntarily, and if a woman is self controlled and pure in mind, violation of her virtue is impossible.
('39', 3, 1, 21, 7363) This is true in two senses.
('39', 3, 1, 22, 7391) One is that the Shastras proclaim, and it must be believed, that the body of one whose mind is pure in every way is protected by the mind itself, just as Sitas mind protected her body.
('39', 3, 1, 23, 7576) As you know, Ravana could not outrage Sitas modesty, and the reason was not that he did not possess brute strength, but that he knew that if he tried to
('39', 4, 0, 1, 7729) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 5
('39', 4, 1, 2, 7772) assault her his body would be burnt to ashes that very moment; and so he tried to win her consent through all manner of means, deceptions and threats, but they were of no avail in the face of Sitas strength of mind.
('39', 4, 1, 3, 7988) And the second meaning is that, if a womans mind is pure, her virtue is not violated and she is not stained by sin, even though she may have been raped.
('39', 4, 1, 4, 8141) Neither will the world reproach her, nor will there be anything against her from the point of view of dharma.
('39', 4, 1, 5, 8251) A pure woman, therefore, should never be afraid of her modesty being violated.
('39', 4, 1, 6, 8330) On the contrary, she may remain confident that, if her mind is steadfast, her body will always remain inviolate.
('39', 4, 1, 7, 8443) Forest dwellers everywhere are less often overcome by evil desires than city dwellers.
('39', 4, 1, 8, 8530) They have not even the time to fall a prey to such thoughts.
('39', 4, 1, 9, 8591) I do not mean to say that they all remain pure through their own voluntary effort.
('39', 4, 1, 10, 8674) It is easy for them to live pure lives as it is easy for us to be vegetarians.
('39', 4, 1, 11, 8753) Wherever there is immorality in the forests, both the man and the woman fall through their own free will.
('39', 4, 2, 12, 8859) [From Gujarati]
('39', 4, 3, 13, 8875) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desais Diary: Courtesy: Narayan Desai

('39', 5, 1, 2, 9430) 7. LETTER TO RAMESHWARDAS PODDAR
('39', 5, 2, 3, 9463) NANDI DURG, MYSORE, [Before June 5, 1927] 1
('39', 5, 3, 4, 9507) BHAI RAMESHWARJI, Your letter to hand.
('39', 5, 3, 5, 9546) I am steadily improving.
('39', 5, 3, 6, 9571) There is no cause for worry.
('39', 5, 3, 7, 9600) You did right in informing me of the death of Shankarraos son.
('39', 5, 3, 8, 9663) I have sent a letter of consolation to him and his wife.
('39', 5, 3, 9, 9720) What can I write to bring you peace of mind?
('39', 5, 3, 10, 9765) Let us believe that the one aim of our life is to control our senses; it is the highest human achievement and therefore attainable with difficulty.
('39', 5, 3, 11, 9913) By constant effort we can conquer our passions.
('39', 5, 3, 12, 9961) You should be engaged in some noble work, mentally as well as physically.
('39', 5, 3, 13, 10035) Only when the mind is uncontrolled does it fall a prey to passion.
('39', 5, 3, 14, 10102) Why not make a painstaking study of the Gita?
('39', 5, 3, 15, 10148) And why not learn Sanskrit to understand the original work?
('39', 5, 3, 16, 10208) When you have not got to be at the shop or when you have to be there and have nothing to do, why not ply the charkha or the takli?
('39', 5, 3, 17, 10339) Just as man cuts through solid mountains with persistent effort, so can he cut through the barrier of passion.
('39', 5, 3, 18, 10450) Therefore you should always be diligent.
('39', 5, 3, 19, 10491) Blessings from
('39', 5, 5, 20, 10506) From a photostat of the Hindi: G.N. 205
('39', 5, 6, 21, 10546) 8. SWEET MUSIC IN SPINNING WHEEL
('39', 5, 7, 22, 10579) I have published this article 2 as I have received it.
('39', 5, 7, 23, 10634) It is one of those received in response to the public request, made by Shri Karsandas Chitaliya, for articles on the spinning wheel.
('39', 5, 7, 24, 10767) He gave me last year the one which he had considered to be the best and preserved.
('39', 5, 7, 25, 10850) I had intended to publish it on some occasion and I do so now.
('39', 5, 7, 26, 10913) This article is dated September 21, 1921. Those days were different from these.
('39', 5, 7, 27, 10993) In the intoxicating atmosphere of that age, many people used to sing praises of the spinning wheel.
('39', 5, 7, 28, 11093) If, therefore,
('39', 5, 8, 29, 11108) 1 Gandhiji descended from Nandi Hills to Bangalore on June 5, 1927. 2 Not translated here
('39', 6, 0, 1, 11198) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 7
('39', 6, 1, 2, 11241) Vanavasi still sees Navajivan and reads this note, I would ask whether he could say today what he did in 1921. Or does he also feel about the s pinning wheel as others do who were in love with it in 1921 but dislike it today?
('39', 6, 1, 3, 11467) If that is so, let him send in his criticism too.
('39', 6, 1, 4, 11517) If it is well written, I am prepared to publish it, for I do not wish to preserve a single certificate for the spinning wheel which is not genuine.
('39', 6, 1, 5, 11665) If the spinning wheel survives, it will be on its own merits.
('39', 6, 1, 6, 11727) Even if I get many people to write poems in praise of it and publish them, it will make no progress unless it has intrinsic merit.
('39', 6, 1, 7, 11858) If it has such merit, any spinners experiences narrated in his rustic language will suffice to support the cause.
('39', 6, 1, 8, 11972) Every reader of Navajivan knows that at present the cause of the spinning wheel is being advocated in rustic language.
('39', 6, 1, 9, 12091) It is making slow but steady progress.
('39', 6, 2, 10, 12130) [From Gujarati]
('39', 6, 3, 11, 12146) Navajivan, 5 6 1927
('39', 6, 4, 12, 12166) 9. NATIONAL EDUCATION
('39', 6, 5, 13, 12188) A friend writing from Nairobi about national education says what may be briefly stated thus: National education has failed to show any progress because students are not given an education which would train them to be self reliant.
('39', 6, 5, 14, 12419) The difficulty would be removed if agriculture is also taught along with charkha.
('39', 6, 5, 15, 12501) As in the life of the people so also in the school, agriculture should have the first place while Charkha should have the second.
('39', 6, 5, 16, 12631) We have considered this criticism in the columns of the Navajivan before.
('39', 6, 5, 17, 12705) But since people generally do not remember what they read in the newspapers, it is necessary to reconsider such questions whenever they are raised.
('39', 6, 5, 18, 12853) There is no reason for the belief that national education has ceased to make any progress, or that its pace has become very slow.
('39', 6, 5, 19, 12983) And to the extent that it has really become slow the responsibility is that of the teachers.
('39', 6, 5, 20, 13076) I have already said so many times and it is something which can be proved.
('39', 6, 5, 21, 13151) Where the teachers have had perseverance, faith and intelligence coupled with character, national schools are still going strong.
('39', 6, 5, 22, 13281) We have had occasions to refer to this fact many times.
('39', 6, 5, 23, 13337) Though the teachers are responsible for this slowness, they are not to be entirely blamed for it.
('39', 6, 5, 24, 13435) They were themselves the product of an alien Government and a system of education designed to produce
('39', 7, 0, 1, 13537) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 7, 1, 2, 13577) slaves, and had broken away from it with great difficulty.
('39', 7, 1, 3, 13636) They gave whatever help they could and then ropped out.
('39', 7, 1, 4, 13692) The existing national schools must first show their inner strength and brilliance before national education can march further ahead, and I am sure they could do it if they are going to last.
('39', 7, 1, 5, 13883) Government schools do not impart an education calculated to make the students independent; yet they exist because they have blinded our vision with their dazzle.
('39', 7, 1, 6, 14045) Besides, they hold out for some students the lure of lucrative jobs carrying four to five hundred rupees a month at the end of their studies.
('39', 7, 1, 7, 14187) And the students think as they do about a lottery: One of us is surely going to win the prize.
('39', 7, 1, 8, 14282) Who knows, I may be that lucky one! National education does not hold out any such allurement.
('39', 7, 1, 9, 14376) Let us now examine the suggestion made by the correspondent.
('39', 7, 1, 10, 14437) It is true that agriculture occupies a place of importance in our economic life.
('39', 7, 1, 11, 14518) But it has not disappeared; it is still there.
('39', 7, 1, 12, 14565) We have got to revive it.
('39', 7, 1, 13, 14591) There is in it scope for improvement.
('39', 7, 1, 14, 14629) But improving agriculture is beyond the capacity of those who are engaged in national education.
('39', 7, 1, 15, 14726) We can do nothing to improve it without the help of the State.
('39', 7, 1, 16, 14789) It will need lakhs of I rupees which will have to be spent merely on the preliminary experiments.
('39', 7, 1, 17, 14887) I am sure that this cannot be done without swaraj, for Government laws relating to agriculture should be in accord with the economic conditions of the country.
('39', 7, 1, 18, 15047) There should be model farms at numerous places throughtout the country for the dissemination of agricultural knowledge and the peasants and farmers should be provided various facilities to enable them to do their work more efficiently.
('39', 7, 1, 19, 15283) All these things are lacking today in India.
('39', 7, 1, 20, 15328) But in South Africa, Australia and other countries where there are popular Governments wedded to the welfare of the people, the peasants do enjoy all these advantages.
('39', 7, 1, 21, 15496) Therefore, the next best thing the national educationists haveis the charkha, as is admitted by the above correspondent.
('39', 7, 1, 22, 15617) And the institutions which have adopted charkha as the medium of national education can accommodate all the youths wishing to go in for national education, and can train them to become self reliant.
('39', 7, 1, 23, 15816) Bu their knowledge of the Charkha must be both comprehensive and scientific.
('39', 7, 1, 24, 15893) Such youths are being trained gradually, and as the movement for khadi advances national education will also expand and extend over a larger and larger field.
('39', 7, 2, 25, 16052) [From Gujarati]
('39', 7, 3, 26, 16068) Navajivan, 5 6 1927

('39', 8, 1, 2, 16131) 10. SPEECH AT CHIKBALLAPUR 1
('39', 8, 2, 3, 16160) June 5, I 927
('39', 8, 3, 4, 16174) FRIENDS, I thank you for your purse and address.
('39', 8, 3, 5, 16223) I thank the Reception commitee and the people of Chikballapur for having made my stay at Nandi so comfortable.
('39', 8, 3, 6, 16334) You have spent lavishly at your expense in order to anticipate every one of my wants.
('39', 8, 3, 7, 16420) I shall never forget this kindness.
('39', 8, 3, 8, 16456) But I must also say that the only reason for my stay in Mysore is to be able to give you my message on behalf of the poorest of the land, your labourers, and I hope that the message of the spinning wheel would receive an abiding place in your hearts.
('39', 8, 3, 9, 16707) I shall only be satisfied when I hear that you produce your own khaddar and wear your own khaddar.
('39', 8, 3, 10, 16806) I hope that in Chikballapur you have no untouchability.
('39', 8, 3, 11, 16862) I regard untouchabilitv as a blot on Hinduism.
('39', 8, 3, 12, 16909) I find no authorities in Hinduism for treating a portion of our countryrnen as untouchable.
('39', 8, 3, 13, 17001) I hope you will remember this.
('39', 8, 3, 14, 17032) I thank you once more for all your kindness.
('39', 8, 4, 15, 17077) The Hindu, 6 6 1927

('39', 9, 4, 8, 18215) DEAR SISTERS, Your letter.
('39', 9, 4, 9, 18242) I have come down to Bangalore today and am not fatigued.
('39', 9, 4, 10, 18299) Doctors examined me; they say that I shall be all right within a months time.
('39', 9, 4, 11, 18377) What Ramaniklalbhai says is quite true.
('39', 9, 4, 12, 18417) There are many books that are worth reading.
('39', 9, 4, 13, 18462) Let him choose what he likes.
('39', 9, 4, 14, 18492) After all everything depends upon the interest that one who reads to others can create in his listeners.
('39', 9, 4, 15, 18597) None of you should pass over any portion of the book which you do not understand.
('39', 9, 4, 16, 18679) You should ask for the meaning again and again, if necessary, till you understand it.
('39', 9, 4, 17, 18765) Many other things besides become clear if you understand even one thing thoroughly.
('39', 9, 4, 18, 18849) I like the bangles made by Manibehn Patel out of khadi cloth.
('39', 9, 4, 19, 18911) I have suggested that the bangles should be made, not of khaddar, but of yarn.
('39', 9, 4, 20, 18990) The raksha 1 is also a kind of bangle and it is always made of yarn.
('39', 9, 4, 21, 19059) One can put as much art and colour into a yarn bangle as one likes.
('39', 9, 4, 22, 19127) And I am sure that the innocent pleasure one gets from wearing a thing prepared with careful art by ones own hand can never be had by putting on even a jewel studded bangle costing thousands of rupees.
('39', 9, 4, 23, 19329) Tell Mirabehn that if she desires to study, she should go to Jekibehn regularly and not merely when it pleases her to do so.

('39', 10, 1, 2, 19636) 13. LETTER TO KUMI
('39', 10, 2, 3, 19655) BANGALORE, Jeth Sud 6 [June 5, 1927]
('39', 10, 4, 4, 19692) Your letter to hand.
('39', 10, 4, 5, 19713) I share your unhappiness.
('39', 10, 4, 6, 19739) But I can offer no consolation except to ask you to bear with it.
('39', 10, 4, 7, 19805) Harilals last letter is worse than even his previous ones.
('39', 10, 4, 8, 19864) You and I should look upon him as a sick man and take no notice what he writes.
('39', 10, 4, 9, 19944) I believe he will return to his senses some day.
('39', 10, 4, 10, 19993) I do hope neither of you two sisters thinks that I have said anything anywhere about you and him.
('39', 10, 4, 11, 20091) I do not remember having said anything about the plight you are in to anyone except Harilal himself.
('39', 10, 4, 12, 20192) And I am amazed at what he writes about Chanchi.
('39', 10, 4, 13, 20241) I have looked upon you all girls as my daughters.
('39', 10, 4, 14, 20291) Haridasbhai had discussed with me at length the question of Chanchis betrothal.
('39', 10, 4, 15, 20371) Where could we have found a more sober girl however much we tried?
('39', 10, 4, 16, 20438) I do not know if Harilal is still sore about my attitude to the marriage.
('39', 10, 4, 17, 20512) It is true I was against an early marriage.
('39', 10, 4, 18, 20556) But have I no business to tell you even this?
('39', 10, 4, 19, 20602) There is no question of my defending myself against Harilals attack.
('39', 10, 4, 20, 20671) But if you so much as feel that I have done something that adds to your unhappiness, please do not let such a thought ever cross your mind.

('39', 10, 4, 22, 20849) I do not worry because you sisters are both brave.

('39', 11, 1, 2, 21378) 14. LETTER TO ANASUYABEHN SARABHAI
('39', 11, 2, 3, 21413) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE CITY, [After, June 5, 1972] 1
('39', 11, 3, 4, 21466) ANASUYABEHN, Your letter.
('39', 11, 3, 5, 21492) We will have to resist the temptation of the T.S. money if the mill owners will not let us use it.
('39', 11, 3, 6, 21591) I do not believe that my writing to Mangaldas will help.
('39', 11, 3, 7, 21648) The better course would be for you to have frank talks with him and other mill owners and find out what their feelings are in the matter.
('39', 11, 3, 8, 21786) If you like I shall write to Gordhan bhai.
('39', 11, 3, 9, 21829) We must work even for the mill hands with detachment.
('39', 11, 3, 10, 21883) What can we do if they do not in any way understand what is good for them.
('39', 11, 3, 11, 21958) Money for the Antyaja school should come only from Antyaja work.
('39', 11, 3, 12, 22023) If it is necessary to collect funds for others that can be done but we do not want to reduce the workers to destitution or beggary.
('39', 11, 3, 13, 22155) They have money.
('39', 11, 3, 14, 22172) They should spend that money on the education and other needs of their children.
('39', 11, 3, 15, 22253) I know it is difficult to get them to do so.
('39', 11, 3, 16, 22298) For them raising funds is easy.
('39', 11, 3, 17, 22330) But we have begun our work knowing full well that it will be difficult.
('39', 11, 3, 18, 22402) Having sacrificed everything, if we fail, it is not failure but success.
('39', 11, 3, 19, 22475) Because in that failure lies our well being and that of others.
('39', 11, 3, 20, 22539) So after doing whatever we can if some schools close down, it cannot be helped.
('39', 11, 3, 21, 22619) Shankerlal will have to pay a visit here.
('39', 11, 3, 22, 22661) If you come along too at that time we can talk things over and you may feel somewhat reassured.

('39', 12, 1, 2, 23014) 15. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING, BANGALORE 1
('39', 12, 2, 3, 23056) [After June 5, 1927]
('39', 12, 3, 4, 23077) Ever since our arrival, a number of people have been gathering here every evening to take part in our evening prayers .
('39', 12, 3, 5, 23197) and one evening at the close of the prayer, Gandhiji had to address them a few words of appeal and advice.
('39', 12, 3, 6, 23304) He said: I want you to be patient with me.
('39', 12, 3, 7, 23347) That is to say, you will not crowd round me or follow me when I go out for my evening walk.
('39', 12, 3, 8, 23439) I am a patient and I have yet to recover my voice.
('39', 12, 3, 9, 23490) I have yet to recover my strength and I have come here to rest myself.
('39', 12, 3, 10, 23561) After I get better I hope to do what little service I can to the people of Mysore.
('39', 12, 3, 11, 23644) You will therefore give me all the rest I need and not disturb my quiet walks.
('39', 12, 3, 12, 23723) This is so far as I am concerned.
('39', 12, 3, 13, 23757) As for you, I may say that all of you, no matter to what faith you belong, are welcome to take part in the prayer.
('39', 12, 3, 14, 23872) But there are one or two conditions.
('39', 12, 3, 15, 23909) The first is that you should come with a prayerful mind, a prayerful heart and a prayerful attitude.
('39', 12, 3, 16, 24010) EveryoneHindu, Muslim, Christian, no matter to what faith he belongscan participate in the prayer.
('39', 12, 3, 17, 24109) After the repetition of the verses is done, we chant Raghupati Raghava Rajaram, Patitapavana Sitaram, in which all who have a voice may join, so that our prayer may gather volume, and please God if there is a God who listens to our prayers.
('39', 12, 3, 18, 24350) There is another condition.
('39', 12, 3, 19, 24378) You know what Patita Pavana Sitaram means.
('39', 12, 3, 20, 24421) We pray to God who saves the fallen and the downtrodden.
('39', 12, 3, 21, 24478) I would therefore ask you to come in khadi, for khadi links you with the fallen and the downtrodden.
('39', 12, 3, 22, 24579) As a visible token of your desire to help them I ask you allmen, women and children, young and old, of whatever faithto come dressed in khadi.
('39', 12, 3, 23, 24722) That is the least little that you can do to be fit to repeat the prayer: Raghupati Raghava Rajaram Patitapavana Sitaram It is a prayer in which everyone may join, not only the Hindus but Muslims, Christians and others, for it is an invocation not to a king, but the King of kings, the God of gods, whom we all adore.

('39', 15, 1, 2, 28655) 18. LETTER TO C. F. ANDREWS
('39', 15, 2, 3, 28683) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, June 6, 1927
('39', 15, 3, 4, 28720) MY DEAR CHARLIE, This will reach you the same time that Sastri reaches South Africa.
('39', 15, 3, 5, 28805) Though in one way his arrival will somewhat ease the terrible strain which you are undergoing, I can say that in the initial stages, his arrival will also add to your burdens.
('39', 15, 3, 6, 28981) For you will be wanting to protect him from both the Indian malcontents and Europeans.
('39', 15, 3, 7, 29068) I had your cablegram to one portion of which, that is, with reference to Pragji, I sent you a reply.
('39', 15, 3, 8, 29169) You have been this time so grandly economic in sending me cablegrams, and have I not shown my appreciation by dealing with your warning about rice mills and destruction of vitamins?
('39', 15, 3, 9, 29351) At first I thought I would deal with that part of your cablegram which referred to Sastris table allowance.
('39', 15, 3, 10, 29459) But I saw at once that this was one of your nervous mistakesif that is a proper expression to describe what you know I mean.
('39', 15, 3, 11, 29584) That cablegram was not from Charlie the man of God, but from C. F. Andrews the man of calculation whose calculation had told upon his brain and brought on all kinds of imaginary fears due to his nervousness.
('39', 15, 3, 12, 29792) After all have we not hit upon Sastri for his character and learning and for his simplicity and hatred of all pomp and ceremonial?
('39', 15, 3, 13, 29923) Just as if you become a Grandee and sought to win over people by entertaining them at fashionable hotels and moved about in first class motor cars you would lose all the magnificent influence which you have gained in South Africa, so I am sure will Sastri lose all his influence if he began to give lavish entertainments with a view to gaining friends not for himself but for his cause.
('39', 15, 3, 14, 30310) After all will it not be better that he appears in reality as a representative of a poor, exploited continent than that he should appear as an agent of a mighty foreign and expensive Government dependent for its lavishness upon the impoverishment of dumb millions?
('39', 15, 3, 15, 30575) Is not his agency of the Government subordinate to his agency of the Man within him?
('39', 15, 3, 16, 30660) I recall the controversy that was carried on in the public Press in 1889 or 1890 in London in connection with the expensive upkeep of the Bishop of London with his palace.
('39', 15, 3, 17, 30832) I remember also the sensation
('39', 16, 0, 1, 30862) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 17
('39', 16, 1, 2, 30906) that was created when the Bishop came out with his balance sheet in which he showed on the expenditure side the cost of liveried servants, a carriage in pair, etc., which he justified because he had to move among and affect the lives of lords and kings.
('39', 16, 1, 3, 31160) If I recollect rightly, this publication of the balance sheet and the defence exposed the Bishop to further ridicule.
('39', 16, 1, 4, 31278) Imagine Jesus wearing robes resplendent with diamonds and pearls and holding dinners served in golden plates with the choicest old wines and viands with a view to comforting epicures and millionaires of his age.
('39', 16, 1, 5, 31490) But I must stop here.
('39', 16, 1, 6, 31512) I think I have given you enough tonic for steadying your nerve and refreshing you.
('39', 16, 1, 7, 31595) Though I seem to be on the road to recovery, the head still remains silly and becomes refractory under the slightest pressure.
('39', 16, 1, 8, 31722) However, I pray and grin and bear it.
('39', 16, 1, 9, 31760) He gave me all the needed strength for all these years.
('39', 16, 1, 10, 31816) He might humble my pride by reducing me to helplessness.
('39', 16, 2, 11, 31873) From a photostat: S.N. 12347

('39', 18, 3, 12, 34801) Parents should speak to their grown up children as to friends and if the latter pay no heed they should keep quiet.

('39', 18, 3, 14, 34943) I put up with the fact that my eldest son does not listen to me nor do I grieve over it.

('39', 25, 8, 12, 44608) I shall try to increase the quantity of butter.

('39', 25, 8, 19, 45113) I forgot to mention the massage.
('39', 25, 8, 20, 45146) It has been continued without interruption.
('39', 25, 8, 21, 45190) But the abdominal and heart massage has been omitted for some time.
('39', 25, 8, 22, 45258) The abdominal was omitted for fear that continued massage might weaken the intestinal muscles and may render it a habit always to have that massage for inducing proper motion.
('39', 25, 8, 23, 45434) The heart massage I left off feeling it to be unnecessary arguing to myself, perhaps wrongly, that the massage could not possibly reach the heart which is floating in a solid case of ribs and flesh.

('39', 27, 4, 15, 47997) When in trouble one need not give ones prayer to be saved from pain, yet it is certainly no better than patiently enduring the pain.

('39', 27, 4, 18, 48233) We should not strive for happiness nor furnish the trappings of pain.
('39', 27, 4, 19, 48303) In all circumstances we should do our duty as we see it from time to time.
('39', 27, 4, 20, 48378) I hope you got my earlier letter.

('39', 28, 6, 8, 49059) 36. ASHRAM TANNERY
('39', 28, 7, 9, 49078) It is possible for me now to inform readers that they can get from the Sabarmati Satyagraha Ashram Tannery Department well prepared dead cattle hide.
('39', 28, 7, 10, 49228) Sandals, belts and such other things are already being made but not yet in quantities large enough for executing all the orders that may be received.
('39', 28, 7, 11, 49378) But it is possible now to meet a fair demand for prepared dead cattle hide in three colours, black, dark brown and yellow, and two qualities at Rs. 1 8 0 and Rs. 1 4 0 per pound.
('39', 28, 7, 12, 49557) Those who are interested in making this experiment a success and who desire to use only dead cattle hide should correspond with the Manager, Satyagraha Ashram Tannery Department, for all further information.
('39', 28, 7, 13, 49765) Till the Ashram is ready to execute orders for boots, shoes and other prepared leather articles, I suggest the purchase of dead cattle hide which is now available at the Ashram, and getting what they want prepared through their own shoe makers.
('39', 28, 7, 14, 50010) It is easier, cheaper and more expeditious for people to get used to buying hide as they buy khadi, and to get articles prepared for themselves as they get their clothes prepared from the khadi they purchase.
('39', 28, 7, 15, 50219) It is not easy to open many tanneries.
('39', 28, 7, 16, 50258) It would be a proper division of labour to take the work of manufacture off the hands of tanneries, if the work of taking possession of all the raw hide of dead cattle with a view to replacing the hide of slaughtered cattle is to be done with expedition.
('39', 28, 8, 17, 50513) Young India, 9 6 1927
('39', 28, 9, 18, 50535) 1 Not reproduced here
('39', 29, 0, 1, 50557) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 29, 1, 2, 50598) 37. KHADI FRANCHISE
('39', 29, 2, 3, 50618) Srinivasa Iyengar, who is endeavouring with might and main to signalize his year of office as President of the Congress by achieving, if human effort can, Hindu Muslim unity and by doing many other things, asked me when he kindly visited me at Nandi, whether I would relent in the matter of the obligation on every member of a Congress organization habitually to wear khadi.
('39', 29, 2, 4, 50993) I told him that there was nothing for me to relent about.
('39', 29, 2, 5, 51051) At Gauhati I was not insistent on the present clause.
('39', 29, 2, 6, 51105) When asked, I merely gave my opinion that experience had shown that either the khadi clause should go altogether, or it should be stiffened to mean habitual as distinguished from ceremonial wear.
('39', 29, 2, 7, 51301) I have seen nothing since to alter that opinion.
('39', 29, 2, 8, 51350) But if the members do not desire any discipline, or desiring discipline they do not want the clause about habitual khadi wear, and if they would laugh the khadi clause to scorn and break the rule on every occasion that offered itself to them, the clause should be undoubtedly removed.
('39', 29, 2, 9, 51635) In a popular institution, it must be the opinion of the majority that must count.
('39', 29, 2, 10, 51717) But I have always held that when a respectable minority objects to any rule of conduct, it would be dignified for the majority, and would conduce to the good of the Congress, for the majority to yield to the minority.
('39', 29, 2, 11, 51935) Numerical strength savours of violence when it acts in total disregard of any strongly felt opinion of a minority.
('39', 29, 2, 12, 52050) The rule of majority is perfectly sound, only where there is no rigid insistence on the part of the dissenters upon their dissent, and where there is on their behalf a sportsmanlike obedience to the opinion of the majority.
('39', 29, 2, 13, 52274) No organization can run smoothly when it is divided into camps, each growling at the other and each determined to have its own way by hook or by crook.
('39', 29, 2, 14, 52426) I had therefore no hesitation in telling the President, that he should assist the removal of the clause about khadi if that clause could not gain willing submission from the minority.
('39', 29, 2, 15, 52610) This, however, is totally different from the question of my opinion.
('39', 29, 2, 16, 52679) Any appeal to me to change my opinion, as has been done so often before, would be, to say the least, unfair to me.
('39', 29, 2, 17, 52794) I must be allowed to retain my opinion as to the khadi clause or as to the method of running the Congress organization.
('39', 29, 2, 18, 52914) All I can say is that my
('39', 30, 0, 1, 52939) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 31
('39', 30, 1, 2, 52983) opinion should have no greater weight than the opinion of any other member of the Congress.
('39', 30, 1, 3, 53075) My own opinion is emphatically that it will be wrong for the Congress, if it is to have an organic connection with the starving millions, to break this one and only bond between the classes and the masses.
('39', 30, 1, 4, 53281) But I know that there is another school of thought in our country which rejects khadi as any token of a bond between the classes and the masses, and regards it as a mere mahatmaic freak or fad.
('39', 30, 1, 5, 53475) That school is entitled to the same respect for its opinion as I venture to claim for my own.
('39', 30, 1, 6, 53569) The President and the other members of the Congress have really to decide the question upon its merits, and ask themselves what is good for the Congress and fearlessly decide accordingly.
('39', 30, 1, 7, 53757) After all khadi is a force to be reckoned with, if it has come to stay.
('39', 30, 1, 8, 53829) If it has staunch, true and self sacrificing workers to back it, and if it has intrinsic value, it will prosper even though the Congress should in its wisdom give it up as part of the franchise, or even give it up altogether.
('39', 30, 1, 9, 54055) The Congress will be the first to recognize anything that becomes a living force in the country.
('39', 30, 1, 10, 54152) It may legitimately ignore it till it has proved its vitality.
('39', 30, 1, 11, 54215) There may be and there are no doubt many things which are good in themselves.
('39', 30, 1, 12, 54293) But a vast popular organization like the Congress cannot possibly take up things merely because they are good.
('39', 30, 1, 13, 54404) It can only take up things that are good, provided they have popular backing.
('39', 30, 1, 14, 54482) Without such backing the Congress would cease to be representative of the people and would merely represent a body of reformers or faddists.
('39', 30, 1, 15, 54623) Let the members of the Congress therefore come to a decision untrammelled by my opinion or anybody elses.
('39', 30, 1, 16, 54729) If their experience tells them that khadi has no backing in the country, if they think that it has nothing to do with the masses, they should unhesitatingly repeal the offending clause.
('39', 30, 1, 17, 54915) I have repeatedly held, that in every matter of urgency the All India Congress Committee has not only the power but is bound to deal with the urgency as if it was itself the Congress, and run the risk of its decision being overturned at the next ordinary session of the Congress.
('39', 30, 1, 18, 55195) A special session becomes necessary only when on any matter of urgency opinion is sharply divided, or when on any such matter public opinion requires to be educated, or lastly, when a popular demonstration on an intensive scale on any given question is required.
('39', 30, 1, 19, 55458) In every other circumstance, and in every other matter of urgency, I venture to think that the All India Congress Committee will
('39', 31, 0, 1, 55587) 32 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 31, 1, 2, 55628) be abdicating its function if it does not give its decisive opinion and act upon it.
('39', 31, 2, 3, 55713) Young India, 9 6 1927
('39', 31, 3, 4, 55735) 38. STUDENTS IN CONFERENCE
('39', 31, 4, 5, 55762) The Secretary of the sixth Sind Students Conference sent me a printed circular asking for a message.
('39', 31, 4, 6, 55863) I received a wire also asking for the same thing.
('39', 31, 4, 7, 55913) But being in a somewhat inaccessible place, both the circular letter and the telegram were received too late for me to send a message.
('39', 31, 4, 8, 56048) Nor am I in a position to comply with numerous requests for messages, articles and what not.
('39', 31, 4, 9, 56141) But as I profess to be interested in everything connected with students as I am somewhat in touch with the student world all over India, I could not help criticizing within myself the programme sketched in the circular letter.
('39', 31, 4, 10, 56368) Thinking that it might be helpful, I reduce some of it to writing and present it to the student world.
('39', 31, 4, 11, 56471) I take the following from the circular letter which by the way is badly printed and contains mistakes which are hardly pardonable for a students society:
('39', 31, 5, 12, 56625) The organizers of this Conference are endeavouring their utmost to make this Conference as interesting and instructive as possible....
('39', 31, 5, 13, 56760) We intend organizing a series of educational discourses and we request you to give us the benefit....
('39', 31, 5, 14, 56862) The problem of female education here in Sind deserves a special consideration....
('39', 31, 5, 15, 56944) We are not blind to the other necessities of students.
('39', 31, 5, 16, 56999) Sports competitions are being organized and along with elocution competitions they will, it is hoped, make the Conference more interesting.
('39', 31, 5, 17, 57139) Nor have we eliminated drama and music from our programme.
('39', 31, 5, 18, 57198) Pieces in Urdu and English will also be staged.
('39', 31, 5, 19, 57246) I have not omitted a single operative sentence that would give one an idea of what the Conference was expected to do, and yet one fails to find a single reference to things of permanent interest to the student world.
('39', 31, 5, 20, 57463) I have no doubt that the dramatic and musical and gymnastic performances were all provided on a grand scale.
('39', 31, 5, 21, 57572) I take the phrase in inverted commas from the circular.
('39', 31, 5, 22, 57628) I have no doubt also that the Conference had attractive papers on female education.
('39', 31, 5, 23, 57712) But so far as the circular is concerned there is no mention of the disgraceful deti leti (dowry) practices, from which the students have not freed themselves and which in many respects makes the lives of Sindhi girls
('39', 32, 0, 1, 57929) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 33
('39', 32, 1, 2, 57973) a hell upon earth and of parents of daughters a torture.
('39', 32, 1, 3, 58030) There is nothing in the circular to show that the Conference intended to tackle the question of the morals of the students.
('39', 32, 1, 4, 58154) Nor is there anything to show that the Conference was to do anything to show the students the way to become fearless nation builders.
('39', 32, 1, 5, 58288) It is a matter of no small credit to Sind that it is supplying so many institutions with brilliant professors, but more is always expected from those who give much.
('39', 32, 1, 6, 58453) And I, who have every reason to be grateful to Sindhi friends for giving me fine co workers for the Gujarat Vidyaptith, am not going to be satisfied with getting professors and khadi workers.
('39', 32, 1, 7, 58645) Sind has got its Sadhu Vasvani.
('39', 32, 1, 8, 58677) It can boast of a number of great reformers.
('39', 32, 1, 9, 58722) But the students will put themselved in the wrong, if they will be contented with appropriation of the merit gained by the sadhus and reformers of Sind.
('39', 32, 1, 10, 58875) They have got to become nation builders.
('39', 32, 1, 11, 58916) The base imitation of the West, the ability to speak and write correct and polished English, will not add one brick to the temple of freedom.
('39', 32, 1, 12, 59058) The student world, which is receiving an education far too expensive for starving India and an education which only a microscopic minority can ever hope to receive, is expected to qualify itself for it by giving its life blood to the nation.
('39', 32, 1, 13, 59300) Students must become pioneers in conservative reform, conserving all that is good in the nation and fearlessly ridding society of the innumerable abuses that have crept into it.
('39', 32, 1, 14, 59478) These conferences should open the eyes of students to the realities before them.
('39', 32, 1, 15, 59559) They should result in making them think of things which, in the class room adapted to its foreign setting, they do not get an opportunity of learning.
('39', 32, 1, 16, 59710) They may not be able in these conferences to discuss questions regarded as purely political.
('39', 32, 1, 17, 59803) But they can and they must study and discuss social and economic questions which are as important to our generation as the highest political question.
('39', 32, 1, 18, 59954) A nation building programme can leave no part of the nation untouched.
('39', 32, 1, 19, 60025) Students have to react upon the dumb millions.
('39', 32, 1, 20, 60072) They have to learn to think not in terms of a province, or a town, or a class, or a caste, but in terms of a continent and of the millions who include untouchables, drunkards, hooligans and even prostitutes, for whose existence in our midst every one of us is responsible.
('39', 32, 1, 21, 60345) Students in olden times were called brahmacharis, that is, those who walked with and in the fear of God.
('39', 32, 1, 22, 60450) They were honoured by kings and elders.
('39', 32, 1, 23, 60490) They were a voluntary charge on the nation, and in return they gave to the nation a hundredfold strong souls, strong brains, strong arms.
('39', 32, 1, 24, 60628) Students in the modern world, wherever they are to be found among fallen nations, are considered to be their hope, and have become the
('39', 33, 0, 1, 60763) 34 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 33, 1, 2, 60804) self sacrificing leaders of reforms in every department.
('39', 33, 1, 3, 60861) Not that we have no such examples in India; but they are far too few.
('39', 33, 1, 4, 60931) What I plead for is that students conferences should stand for this kind of organized work befitting the status of brahmacharis.
('39', 33, 2, 5, 61060) Young India, 9 6 1927
('39', 33, 3, 6, 61082) 39. WHAT WE ARE LOSING
('39', 33, 4, 7, 61105) The readers of Young India are familiar with Mr. Greggs name.
('39', 33, 4, 8, 61167) He is studying in a very concrete manner and with a passion worthy of a patriotic son of the soil the many questions affecting this land.
('39', 33, 4, 9, 61305) His studies and experiments in hand spinning continue unabated.
('39', 33, 4, 10, 61369) He is experimenting in education of the children of backward classes.
('39', 33, 4, 11, 61439) He is interested in the welfare of these classes.
('39', 33, 4, 12, 61489) And in that connection, he is studying the question of agriculture.
('39', 33, 4, 13, 61557) Having watched the economic and highly hygienic disposal of night soil at the Satyagraha Ashram, Sabarmati, he is now studying that question in a methodical manner.
('39', 33, 4, 14, 61722) In the course of a letter suggesting the establishment of an experim ental farm he says:
('39', 33, 5, 15, 61811) The special feature of the farm would be its use of night soil as fertilizer, burying it as is done at the Satyagraha Ashram, or treating it as do the farmers of China and Japan.
('39', 33, 5, 16, 61990) 1 The whole body of sweepers in the entire area from which the collections would be made would need to be carefully organized and gradually trained into the best ways of handling the stuff.
('39', 33, 6, 17, 62180) In a very short time, such a farm would become wonderfully productive in either grain, cattle fodder, fruit or certain kinds of vegetables, all of which could be sold in the same locality, thus avoiding transportation charges in the marketing and yielding a fair profit for the further development of the scheme or the education and betterment of the whole sweeper community of the city or district.
('39', 33, 6, 18, 62580) Such use of the night soil would be an enormous saving of very valuable manurial material which is now not only almost entirely wasted, I believe, but a source of much illness and consequent economic loss to the entire community, through the breeding of flies and the carrying of all sorts of germs and filth.

('39', 39, 1, 2, 71049) Whist I agree with you that all religious dectrine has an economic aspect and that economic law is as much Gods law as religious laws, I profoundly differ from your application of the doctrine.
('39', 39, 1, 3, 71243) It can easily be shown that transmigration has nothing to do with poverty.
('39', 39, 1, 4, 71318) The present system of caste has certainly something to do with it.
('39', 39, 1, 5, 71385) The treatment of women again can be shown to have no connection with poverty.
('39', 39, 1, 6, 71463) But if you can spare the time, I would certainly value an article or two from your pen giving your views about cattle and their treatment and your argument in proof of your belief that the three things mentioned by you are in combination, the primary and fundamental causes of Indias poverty.
('39', 39, 1, 7, 71756) If you think that there is room for correcting your opinion about the fundamental causes of Indias poverty we may discuss the causes through private correspondence.
('39', 39, 1, 8, 71921) I know you to be a well wisher of the country and a searcher after truth.
('39', 39, 1, 9, 71995) I know also that you have great capacity for serving India.
('39', 39, 1, 10, 72055) I am therefore most anxious to take all the advantage I can of your love of the country and your great knowledge in the interest of a cause which is common to us both.
('39', 39, 1, 11, 72223) I am therefore anxious that so far as it is possible, there should be agreement between us about the fundamental cause of the great and growing poverty of India.

('39', 43, 4, 10, 78548) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, June, 12, 1927

('39', 43, 5, 12, 78641) Please do not apologize.

('39', 43, 5, 18, 79216) Practice evidently is just now your swadharma 1, and therefore the best for you.
('39', 43, 5, 19, 79297) But will you not make up your mind that no matter how much practice you get, you will no longer spend on marriages?
('39', 43, 5, 20, 79413) Whether it will come in my life or not, the time is coming when men like you will have again to give up practice, give up hearth and home and plunge into the struggle for liberty, Let this practice therefore be a trust for you.
('39', 43, 5, 21, 79641) But you and your family should live as the poorest of our people, and therefore you should bring up your daughters now to grow up without thinking of marriage, and when they are to be married, they are to be married without any expense whatsoever.

('39', 50, 5, 22, 90816) 64. LETTER TO GULZARILAL NANDA
('39', 50, 6, 23, 90847) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, June 15, 1927
('39', 50, 7, 24, 90885) MY DEAR GULZARILAL, I have your letter and your draft to the Secretary.
('39', 50, 7, 25, 90957) You may send the letter.
('39', 50, 7, 26, 90982) I do not want to suggest any alterations or improvements in it; but I will just state what I think about the whole thing and the extent to which we may rely upon mill owners help and to which they are themselves at the present stage likely to go.
('39', 50, 7, 27, 91229) So far as the Rs. 12,500 are concerned, I am afraid, we shall not get them unless Kasturbhai, who is insistent even to the extent of
('39', 51, 0, 1, 91362) 52 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 51, 1, 2, 91403) demanding his own quota back, as he might well do, invites the other donors to do likewise.
('39', 51, 1, 3, 91495) So far, therefore, as these funds are concerned, the way to work lies in that direction.
('39', 51, 1, 4, 91584) The ultimate decision will be taken by the mill owners on side issues and on personal likes and dislikes.
('39', 51, 1, 5, 91690) These aberrations we shall always have with us and we must suffer them with becoming calmness.
('39', 51, 1, 6, 91785) But the more important point for consideration is the principle which should guide us in our relations with the mill owners, or, more generally speaking, capitalists.
('39', 51, 1, 7, 91952) At the present moment, we shall do well to be satisfied with doing the right without expecting reciprocity and therefore without expecting any pecuniary help from the capitalists.
('39', 51, 1, 8, 92132) Inch by inch labour will have to make its position good and better its conditions independently of outside support.
('39', 51, 1, 9, 92248) The outside support may be divided into two parts: from the capitalists directly concerned, in this instance, therefore the mill owners, and secondly, from the general sympathetic public.
('39', 51, 1, 10, 92436) The second support we shall get more quickly and without in any way endangering our interests.
('39', 51, 1, 11, 92531) The support from capitalists directly concerned will come when labour has vindicated itself and has almost attained the position of being able to dictate its own terms.
('39', 51, 1, 12, 92700) It will be then and not till then that we shall get willing help from capital.
('39', 51, 1, 13, 92779) If my diagnosis is correct, we must then so order our affairs as to undertake just such work as we can do irrespective of outside assistance.
('39', 51, 1, 14, 92921) When its needs are to be supplemented, we should go to the independent outsiders and never go to the interested outsiders; but we do not need to refuse the help from the last source when it comes voluntarily.
('39', 51, 1, 15, 93130) And we must always be able to so shape our course as to feel independent of all outside help.
('39', 51, 1, 16, 93224) Our concentration therefore must be in educating labour from within and out of means chiefly supplied by labour itself.
('39', 51, 1, 17, 93344) This, in my opinion, is the shortest and the simplest way of serving labour.
('39', 51, 1, 18, 93421) It will undoubtedly cause in the initial stages great difficulty, great embarrassment and labour itself will be irresponsive.
('39', 51, 1, 19, 93547) But that is the very reason why we should persist in what we know to be the best course.
('39', 51, 1, 20, 93636) Any other way, labour becomes pauperized and demoralized as one sees happening all over India.
('39', 51, 1, 21, 93731) Applying the principle to the present case, my solution would be to carry on such negotiations with the mill owners as may be consistent with the dignity and self respect, but to be prepared to do without the assistance that is being received now.
('39', 51, 1, 22, 93979) You must stillfind ways and means of continuing the schools.
('39', 51, 1, 23, 94040) See what resources there are within ourselves.
('39', 51, 1, 24, 94087) Put the whole question
('39', 52, 0, 1, 94110) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 53
('39', 52, 1, 2, 94154) before the members of the Union, and at the same time canvass for subscriptions amongst private friends and then appeal to the public also.
('39', 52, 1, 3, 94294) I do not anticipate much difficulty in getting public help.
('39', 52, 1, 4, 94354) And, in any appeal that may be made to the public, the circumstances necessitating the appeal now should be briefly stated.
('39', 52, 1, 5, 94478) This will involve some criticism of the mill owners; but that is inevitable.
('39', 52, 1, 6, 94555) I wonder if I have made my position absolutely clear.
('39', 52, 1, 7, 94609) If I have not, please do not hesitate to write to me again.
('39', 52, 1, 8, 94669) Yours sincerely, GULZARILAL AHMEDABAD

('39', 52, 7, 18, 95172) 66. LETTER TO SECRETARY, A.I.S.A.
('39', 52, 8, 19, 95206) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, June 15, 1927 I have your letter.
('39', 52, 8, 20, 95264) I have gone through the agenda.
('39', 52, 8, 21, 95296) I cannot think of any addition.
('39', 52, 8, 22, 95328) The agenda seems to me to be exhaustive.
('39', 52, 8, 23, 95369) The draft rules for agencies seem to me to be quite good.
('39', 52, 8, 24, 95427) I cannot think of any improvement just now.
('39', 52, 8, 25, 95471) I do not want to concerntrate upon the work and tax my brain.
('39', 52, 8, 26, 95533) But they read all right.
('39', 52, 8, 27, 95558) If anything arising out of them is referred to me at the meeting in any
('39', 53, 0, 1, 95630) 54 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 53, 1, 2, 95671) definite form, I shall be able to give my opinion.
('39', 53, 1, 3, 95722) It will be premature to ask the several khadi centres to communicate with the Central office only through the respective agencies.
('39', 53, 1, 4, 95853) That would be an ideal to be reached but after we are better organized and the necessity for acting through agencies is generally recognized.
('39', 53, 1, 5, 95995) At the present moment we are trying to evolve organized order out of disorganized work.
('39', 53, 1, 6, 96083) We have therefore to act after the style of a family in which the paterfamilias is referred to by the respective members without any intervention.
('39', 53, 1, 7, 96230) But in order to establish the custom of dealing through agencies, we may refer all the communications we received to the agents wherever necessary and we may also refer all new correspondence to the agents.
('39', 53, 1, 8, 96437) And thirdly we may ask the agents to interest themselves in the several centres in their jurisdiction even though they may not be invited by respective centres.
('39', 53, 1, 9, 96598) The agents may thus create between the centres and themselves a living bond so that instead of referring to head office, the centres will of their own accord refer to the agents.
('39', 53, 1, 10, 96777) We may for the moment frustrate the end we have in view, if we impose the condition from above.
('39', 53, 1, 11, 96873) Also wherever any centre is recalcitrant and is causing trouble and insists upon dealing with the head office or not at all, we may impose the condition of coming through the agent.
('39', 53, 1, 12, 97055) As to the Council, I suggest the following without having given much thought to the thing: The Council should meet quarterly.
('39', 53, 1, 13, 97181) At least a weeks clear notice should be received by every member.
('39', 53, 1, 14, 97247) The week to count from the date of each member receiving notice at his registered address.
('39', 53, 1, 15, 97338) The agenda should contain just the items to be considered and where, in the opinion of the Secretary, papers are necessary to be sent, he may do so, and at the foot of the agenda he may have a general notice to the effect that any member who wants to have any information about any item on the agenda will be supplied with the information by the Secretary upon request.
('39', 53, 1, 16, 97708) In extaordinary emergencies the sanction of the members may be ascertained by correspondence whether telegraphic or postal.
('39', 53, 1, 17, 97832) Any such decision should be brought before the next ordinary meeting of the Council.
('39', 53, 1, 18, 97917) Where even this is not possible the Secretary and the Chairman may on their own responsibility dispose of matters and in those involving financial obligation, disburse not more than, say, Rs. 5,000. It would be certainly convenient for you to come a day or two
('39', 54, 0, 1, 98178) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 55
('39', 54, 1, 2, 98222) before the meeting.
('39', 54, 1, 3, 98242) There should be however enough time to give also in the meeting and after the meeting.
('39', 54, 1, 4, 98329) In any event, all the members will be in Bangalore up to the third of July at least.
('39', 54, 1, 5, 98414) I am assuming that I shall not be asked to be present at the meeting more than it is absolutely necessary.
('39', 54, 1, 6, 98521) Though even now I do considerable amount of work which is all done at my convenience with considerable rest during intervals, I am making steady progress.
('39', 54, 1, 7, 98676) I note and doctors advice also that the less concentrated the work the better it is for me, and in no case should there be concentrated work.
('39', 54, 1, 8, 98818) The Madras Flood Relief money can now be transferred.
('39', 54, 1, 9, 98872) Chhaganlal and Swami are being advised.
('39', 54, 1, 10, 98912) I suggest that the deposits should not be disturbed but should be adjusted on maturity so as not to forfeit the interest.
('39', 54, 1, 11, 99034) About Mithubehns letter, I am asking Rajagopalachari about it.
('39', 54, 1, 12, 99097) In may opinion, she should be paid as from the Exhibition Committee.
('39', 54, 1, 13, 99166) For, the Committee should be the best judge as to who should come and who should not come.
('39', 54, 1, 14, 99257) In this instance, the Committe having invited Mithubehn will most probably tell her that her expenses will be defrayed by them.
('39', 54, 1, 15, 99385) Yours sincerely,
('39', 54, 2, 16, 99402) From a microfilm: S.N. 19781

('39', 55, 1, 2, 99472) 67. LETTER TO GANGU
('39', 55, 2, 3, 99492) [After June 15, 1927] 1
('39', 55, 3, 4, 99516) GANGU, Your letter.
('39', 55, 3, 5, 99536) You write good Hindi.
('39', 55, 3, 6, 99558) You will soon be avoiding the mistakes you now make.
('39', 55, 3, 7, 99611) You should bear no resentment even in your heart against Lakshmibehn for what she said.
('39', 55, 3, 8, 99699) Doing the Vatapooja 2 was as much right for her as not doing it was for you.
('39', 55, 3, 9, 99776) You have no faith in these things; therefore it would have been useless for you to join; it might have looked like weakness or even hypocrisy.
('39', 55, 3, 10, 99919) We should have the same tolerance for other peoples conduct and beliefs as we may expect from them towards our own.
('39', 55, 3, 11, 100035) You need not be unhappy if Chi.
('39', 55, 3, 12, 100067) Maganlal did not give you the charkha.
('39', 55, 3, 13, 100106) If you ask him he will surely tell you the reason.
('39', 55, 3, 14, 100157) Even if we are not satisfied with the explanation, still we must not feel aggrieved.
('39', 55, 3, 15, 100242) We must not hastily conclude that a persons attitude or act is all wrong just because he himself or the elders cannot give us a satisfactory explanation of it.
('39', 55, 3, 16, 100402) Only by living in society can we learn to tolerate difference of opinion and the pairs of opposites such as happiness and unhappiness.
('39', 55, 3, 17, 100537) And as you want to dedicate yourself to service and observe brahmacharya, you must fully acquire the qualities of forbearance and tolerance.
('39', 55, 3, 18, 100678) Mirabehn thinks you need to improve your spinning, ginning, etc.
('39', 55, 3, 19, 100743) In spinning the thread .
('39', 55, 4, 20, 100768) Manibehn has been a brahmacharini till now, and proposes to remain one and she is making positive efforts towards it.
('39', 55, 4, 21, 100886) The other has entered married life but is aware of the nobility of brahmacharya and endeavours to observe it herself.
('39', 55, 4, 22, 101004) You must not suppress your feelings just because I write all this.
('39', 55, 4, 23, 101071) Do write to me whatever you think.
('39', 55, 4, 24, 101106) I shall try to point out the pitfalls ahead on your way.
('39', 55, 4, 25, 101163) Take from this whatever you find acceptable and go ahead.
('39', 55, 5, 26, 101221) From a microfilm of the Hindi : S.N. 12324
