('39', 56, 1, 2, 101556) 68. HINDU MUSLIM UNITY
('39', 56, 2, 3, 101579) When the President of the Congress 1 wired that a unanimous resolution on the Hindu Muslim question was reached by the All India Congress Committee 2, I could not enthuse over the information.
('39', 56, 2, 4, 101772) The wire told me enough about the contents of the resolution.
('39', 56, 2, 5, 101834) When the President paid me a visit at Nandi 3, he asked me whether I would write on it.
('39', 56, 2, 6, 101922) I told him I did not think I could write anything helpful.
('39', 56, 2, 7, 101981) A few days after the visit I got a message from a friend.
('39', 56, 2, 8, 102039) Its purport was : You are responsible for the mischief that is going on in our midst.
('39', 56, 2, 9, 102125) If you had not dragged the Hindus into the Khilafat agitation, the re cent tragic events would not have happened.
('39', 56, 2, 10, 102239) But you alone can now save us. In translating the message I have softened the bitterness of the language of the original.
('39', 56, 2, 11, 102361) It seems to me to call for a reiteration of my belief about Hindu Muslim unity.
('39', 56, 3, 12, 102441) I do not repent of my part in the Khilafat agitation.
('39', 56, 3, 13, 102495) It was a duty I discharged towards my Mussalman countrymen.
('39', 56, 3, 14, 102555) The Hindus would have been wrong, if they had not helped their brethren in their distress.
('39', 56, 3, 15, 102646) However ugly the present look of things may be, future generations of Mussalmans will recall with gratitude this great act of friendship on the part of Hindus.
('39', 56, 3, 16, 102806) But the future apart, as I believe in the proverb that virtue is its own reward, I should always defend my action on the Khilafat question.
('39', 56, 3, 17, 102946) I therefore received the friendss message of rebuke with perfect calmness.
('39', 56, 4, 18, 103021) But I wish I could fulfil his expectations and assist immediately and materially in bringing about peace.
('39', 56, 4, 19, 103127) For I am just as strong a believer as ever in unity and the necessity for it.
('39', 56, 4, 20, 103205) If it could be achieved by giving my life, I have the will to give it and I hope I have the strength for it.
('39', 56, 4, 21, 103314) I should with the greatest joy undertake an indefinite fast, as I very nearly did at Delhi, in 1924, 4 if it would melt and change the stony hearts of Hindus and Mussalmans.
('39', 56, 4, 22, 103488) But I have no sign from God within to undertake the penance.
('39', 56, 4, 23, 103549) If a penance is itself an act of purification, it has also to be preceded by an equal measure
('39', 56, 5, 24, 103643) 1 S. Srinivasa Iyengar 2 On May 15 and 16, 1927, at Bombay 3 The reference is to Nandi Hills near Bangalore where Gandhiji was resting from April 19 to June 4 after he had fallen ill on March 26, 1927. 4 From September 17 to October 8.
('39', 57, 0, 1, 103879) 58 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 57, 1, 2, 103920) of initial purification.
('39', 57, 1, 3, 103945) I am obviously not pure enough for that supreme penance.
('39', 57, 1, 4, 104002) If the reader does not see me now often refer to the question in these pages, it is because the sense of humiliation has gone too deep for words.
('39', 57, 1, 5, 104148) It matters little to me whether the perpetrators of shameful deeds are Hindus or Mussalmans.
('39', 57, 1, 6, 104241) It is enough to know that some of us are blaspheming a patient God and doing inhuman deeds in the sacred name of religion.
('39', 57, 1, 7, 104364) I know too that neither assassination nor fratricidal acts can possibly save religion.
('39', 57, 1, 8, 104451) Religion worth the name can only be saved by purity, humility and fearlessness of the uttermost type among its professors.
('39', 57, 1, 9, 104574) It is the only shuddhi 1 and only propaganda.
('39', 57, 1, 10, 104620) Hence has the resolution of the All India Congress Committee left me unmoved.
('39', 57, 1, 11, 104698) For I know that we have not yet changed our hearts.
('39', 57, 1, 12, 104750) We have not shed fear of one another.
('39', 57, 1, 13, 104788) Any compromise that is unaccompanied by these two conditions must be a mere make shift.
('39', 57, 1, 14, 104876) Moreover, I feel that any agreement between the component parts of the nation must be voluntary and must remain so for all time.
('39', 57, 1, 15, 105005) It must not, if it is conceived in terms of swaraj, depend for its final ratification or enforcement upon a legal enactment.
('39', 57, 1, 16, 105130) Ratification by our respective organizations must be held to be final and binding.
('39', 57, 1, 17, 105213) Enforcement must depend upon the honour of the leaders of respective parties and ultimately, in the absence of reliance on non violence, on the arbitrament of civil war fought decently or indecently as the case may be.
('39', 57, 1, 18, 105432) It is a sign of weakness, not of fitness for swaraj to go to the foreign ruling power to arbitrate between us or to enforce the peace between us at the point of the bayonet.
('39', 57, 1, 19, 105606) If we the so called leaders have no control over our fighting elements, our agreement must be held to be unreal and useless.
('39', 57, 1, 20, 105731) Before we think of real swaraj, we must gain control over the masses.
('39', 57, 1, 21, 105801) We must learn to behave ourselves.
('39', 57, 1, 22, 105836) The agreement had no effect on Delhi, and to our eternal shame the government has been the keeper of the peace on Bakr Id.
('39', 57, 1, 23, 105959) My creed of non violence is an extremely active force.
('39', 57, 1, 24, 106014) It has no room for cowardice or even weakness.
('39', 57, 1, 25, 106061) There is hope for a violent man to be some day non violent, but there is none for a coward.
('39', 57, 1, 26, 106153) I have therefore said more than once in these pages that if we do not know
('39', 57, 2, 27, 106228) 1 Reconversion to Hinduism; literally, purification
('39', 58, 0, 1, 106280) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 59
('39', 58, 1, 2, 106324) how to defend ourselves, our women and our places of worship by the force of suffering, i.e., non violence, we must, if we are men, be at least able to defend all these by fighting.
('39', 58, 1, 3, 106506) It is unmanly to ask or expect the Government to ensure the peace between rival parties or to defend our women against ourselves.
('39', 58, 1, 4, 106636) And while we remain so unmanly it is hopless to expect swaraj.
('39', 58, 1, 5, 106699) In well ordered societies, governments merely undertake the police work.
('39', 58, 1, 6, 106772) But the recent elaborate preparations at Delhi or Lahore were no part of police work.
('39', 58, 1, 7, 106858) Differences we shall always have.
('39', 58, 1, 8, 106892) But we must learn to settle them all, whether religious or other, by arbitration.
('39', 58, 1, 9, 106974) Before the rules we must be able to present a united front and demonstrate to the world our capacity for regulating our own manners if we would have swaraj.
('39', 58, 1, 10, 107131) If, however, we have no leaders whom we can elect as arbitrators who would give wise and impartial decisions, or, if we are too unruly and barbarous to wait for and abide by decisions of arbitrators of our choice, we must fight till we are exhausted and come to our senses.
('39', 58, 1, 11, 107405) The Government will no doubt always intervene, whether we will or no, either to keep the public peace or to preserve its safety.
('39', 58, 1, 12, 107534) But it will weaken us the least, if the rival factions will courageously and straightforwardly refrain from courting the protection or assistance of Government.
('39', 58, 1, 13, 107695) Why should a murderer in such warfare be defended?
('39', 58, 1, 14, 107746) Let him seek the gallows.
('39', 58, 1, 15, 107772) Let breakers of places of worship come forth boldly and say, we have done this for the sake of religion, punish us if you like!
('39', 58, 1, 16, 107900) Let those who kill innocent passers by deliver themselves to the police and say, we have done it all for Gods sake!
('39', 58, 1, 17, 108016) All this may read heartless.
('39', 58, 1, 18, 108045) But I have merely endeavoured to suggest a way that is straighter and less weak than the one we have hitherto adopted.
('39', 58, 1, 19, 108164) And if we cannot, after the manner of civilized men, resort to voluntary arbitration or, after the manner of brave barbarous races, fight out differences without seeking the intervention of British justice or bayonets, all we may expect to get in the shape of reforms is an increased agents share in the bureaucratic Government; in other words, an increasing share in the exploitation of the dumb millions.
('39', 58, 1, 20, 108571) Let us take care that any agreement we may come to does not reduce us to that unenviable condition.
('39', 58, 1, 21, 108671) Young India, 16 6 1927
('39', 59, 0, 1, 108694) 60 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 59, 1, 2, 108735) 69. NOTES
('39', 59, 2, 3, 108745) SARDAR KHARAK SINGH It must be a matter of joy to every patriot to find Sardar Kharak Singh once more free to take up national work outside the prison walls.
('39', 59, 2, 4, 108903) By his indomitable will and refusal to bend himself to authority in order gain his freedom he had risen in the estimation of his countrymen.
('39', 59, 2, 5, 109044) May he have long years of service to the country in its fight for freedom.
('39', 59, 3, 6, 109119) HAVE I BOYCOTTED ANDHRA?
('39', 59, 3, 7, 109144) When Deshabhakta Konda Venkatappayya saw me at Nandi and again at Bangalore, he told me that as Andhra was not on the tour list for the year, many Andhra friends had enquired of him whether I had boycotted Andhra.
('39', 59, 3, 8, 109358) My old love of the Andhra people and the happy memories of my connection with them will not let me boycott Andhra, even if I wish to, though some of the Andhra workers do sometimes vex one into wishing to boycott the province till they set themselves right.
('39', 59, 3, 9, 109616) They are fine men.
('39', 59, 3, 10, 109635) They have got the patriotic spirit.
('39', 59, 3, 11, 109671) But some of them are workers only so called.
('39', 59, 3, 12, 109716) They are all leaders and when everybody wants to lead there is nobody to serve, no one to obey and in the exercise of that false independence the people are neglected.
('39', 59, 3, 13, 109884) I hope the workers to whom these remarks may apply will not say to themselves or to me that they are no worse than other provinces.
('39', 59, 3, 14, 110016) It would be a wrong way of looking at the right thing.
('39', 59, 3, 15, 110071) After all Andhra men and women who at one time gave promise of being the first in the field for real civil disobedience must not be satisfied with being as bad as the rest.
('39', 59, 3, 16, 110244) Those who seek to compete for civil disobedience have to prove their capacity for exemplary obedience, restraint and discipline.
('39', 59, 3, 17, 110373) Andhra, which might have easily been first in khadi and every one of its departments, has yet to come up to the mark.
('39', 59, 3, 18, 110491) But I must not exhaust the whole of my battery of criticism.
('39', 59, 3, 19, 110552) I must reserve it for my forthcoming visit, as I had never given up the idea of visiting Andhradesh.
('39', 59, 3, 20, 110653) As a suitable month could not be set apart this year, the idea was to reserve Andhra for next year unless I could give it, as it was then thought, the first fortnight of December.
('39', 59, 3, 21, 110833) God has however upset all my plan and the whole of the programme for the second half of this year has been dislocated.
('39', 59, 3, 22, 110952) And if I am at all fit and well and there is no accident I would like to be in Andhradesh not for a few days but for a month or two next year.
('39', 59, 3, 23, 111095) I have therefore told Konda
('39', 60, 0, 1, 111123) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 61
('39', 60, 1, 2, 111167) Venkatappaya that if the people will still have me, I would like to visit Andhra early next year and combine rest with work.
('39', 60, 1, 3, 111292) I must not be expected to rush through space and programmes as before.
('39', 60, 1, 4, 111363) Let the workers also realize that I shall be devoting the stay in Andhra to khadi work alone.
('39', 60, 1, 5, 111457) Untouchability work is no doubt part of my being.
('39', 60, 1, 6, 111507) But that work is largely included in khadi work.
('39', 60, 1, 7, 111556) For, it is designed to level up those who occupy the lowest rung of the ladder with those who are at the top.
('39', 60, 1, 8, 111666) It is the cotton thread which beginning in the humblest cottage of India and reaching the highest in the land can alone indissolubly bind the two and make them feel akin.
('39', 60, 1, 9, 111837) I know that the Andhra workers are very ambitious.
('39', 60, 1, 10, 111888) Let their ambition percolate down to the lowest stratum of society and all will be well.
('39', 60, 2, 11, 111977) A WELCOME STEP A correspondent from Holakere in Mysore writes:
('39', 60, 3, 12, 112040) I am highly glad to inform you that the people belonging to Lambani community of my taluk have completely abstained from drinking today and other liquors since a month and a half.
('39', 60, 3, 13, 112220) It was in the Lambani Conference held in this town at the end of last April that they had taken an oath not to touch any liquor, prostrating themselves before the evening sun.
('39', 60, 3, 14, 112396) Since then they have not swerved from their oath.
('39', 60, 3, 15, 112446) If anyone of that community is seen near a toddy shop, he is strictly dealt with by the Naik, Yajaman and Karabhan of
('39', 60, 4, 16, 112564) that hamlet.
('39', 60, 4, 17, 112577) Their women carry to us every day the glad news, there are no broils at their hovel and that they lead a very peaceful life.
('39', 60, 4, 18, 112702) This is an instance to show that your movement of purification had entered our State even before your entering it.
('39', 60, 4, 19, 112817) I congratulate the Lambani community upon the great step they have taken, and hope that they will not slide back like many who did so after the exultation of 1921 had subsided.
('39', 60, 4, 20, 112994) Let me invite the attention of the leaders of the community to the case recorded in these pages 1 of the Raniparaj 2 people of whom those abstainers who took to the charkha as a means of occupying their time and attention not only had no hankering after liquor but were able to double their savings.
('39', 60, 4, 21, 113294) For, they not only saved what was spent upon the drink but they also added to their income by saving in the cost of clothing.
('39', 60, 4, 22, 113420) It is the universal experience of temperance reformers that if the people who
('39', 60, 5, 23, 113498) 1 In Young India, 26 5 1927, under the title Among Raniparaj People 2 Literally, hill people as renamed by Gandhiji; formerly known as Kaliparaj, which meant black people.
('39', 61, 0, 1, 113670) 62 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 61, 1, 2, 113711) take pledges do not usefully occupy their time, the hankering returns and it becomes too strong to resist the temptation.
('39', 61, 1, 3, 113833) I hope too that other villages will follow the example of Holakere and that when I am enabled to begin my tour in Mysore, I shall receive, side by side with glowing accounts which I have been promised of the progress of khadi, accounts also of eradication of the drink habit.
('39', 61, 1, 4, 114109) Young India, 16 6 1927
('39', 61, 2, 5, 114132) 70. RANIPARAJ INQUIRY COMMITTEE
('39', 61, 3, 6, 114164) Vallabhbhai Patel has lost no time in embarking upon the work of the Committee that was only recently appointed at the Raniparaj Conference 1 .
('39', 61, 3, 7, 114308) The following extracts 2 from the interim report of the second tour of the Committee will be read with interest:
('39', 61, 4, 8, 114421) The Committee visited eighteen villages recording statements of witnesses from 47 villages in the Chikhli and Bulsar Talukas and is in the State of Bansda.
('39', 61, 4, 9, 114577) It reflects credit upon the Bansda State that the Committee is able to give a glowing account of the interest that the Maharaja Saheb of Bansda is taking in his people.
('39', 61, 4, 10, 114746) But all the good that is undoubtedly being done by His Highness to his people is really undone so long as he considers it necessary to derive an income from the drink traffic.
('39', 61, 4, 11, 114922) No doubt the fact that the three neighbours adjacent to the Bansda territory, that is, the British, the Gaekwad and Dharampur have no prohibition makes it difficult for Bansda to carry out the policy of successful prohibition.
('39', 61, 4, 12, 115149) But great things can not be done without great sacrifice and geat measures.
('39', 61, 4, 13, 115225) Bansda can not only lead the way by declaring out and out prohibition, but can then agitate for prohibition in the neighbouring States.
('39', 61, 4, 14, 115361) The chief thing is to be prepared to sacrifice the drink revenue.
('39', 61, 4, 15, 115427) An immediate beginning can be made by deciding not to use that revenue for any purpose, however laudable it may be, save for that of carrying on an intensive anti drink propaganda amongst the tribes given to drink.
('39', 61, 4, 16, 115642) For, there is no doubt that any State that seriously wants its people to give up the evil habit cannot be satisfied merely with making it legally impossible to indulge in the evil habit, but to find out the cause of the habit and to educate the people to give it up.
('39', 61, 4, 17, 115909) In the end, no State need suffer by depriving itself of the drink revenue.
('39', 61, 4, 18, 115984) The inevitable outcome of any
('39', 61, 5, 19, 116014) 1 Held on March 16, 1927. 2 Not reproduced here
('39', 62, 0, 1, 116062) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 63
('39', 62, 1, 2, 116106) policy of prohibition carried out side by side with constructive work of the nature suggested by me must result in an ever increasing prosperity of the people and therefore of the State.
('39', 62, 1, 3, 116293) India is the most promising country in the world for carrying out total prohibition for the simple reason that addiction to drink is not considered respectable or fashionable and is confined only to a certain class of people.
('39', 62, 2, 4, 116519) Young India, 16 6 1927

('39', 63, 4, 14, 118241) But neither literacy nor wealth without the moral backing has any attraction for me.

('39', 67, 4, 10, 124200) We have so many limitations that people who know us will not care to apply, and if strangers in search of employment but not knowing what we are do apply, it would be a waste of time for them and us to trouble them.

('39', 67, 4, 17, 124821) I am entirely at one with you that Maganlalji should have all the assistance he needs and that whatever assistance we take should be of the best type available; and if I felt that advertising in the manner you suggest would do it, I should go in for it.

('39', 69, 1, 3, 127205) B. S. MOONJE
('39', 69, 2, 4, 127218) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, June 16, 1927
('39', 69, 3, 5, 127256) DEAR DR.
('39', 69, 3, 6, 127265) MOONJE, I am sincerly sorry for having given you offence.
('39', 69, 3, 7, 127323) I was certainly not unbalanced when I wrote to you.
('39', 69, 3, 8, 127375) I have really believed that it was part of your philosophy to beat an opponent in views with any stick that came your way.Indeed I can give you names of those who have valiantly defended that philosophy.
('39', 69, 3, 9, 127579) But I shall not argue with you.
('39', 69, 3, 10, 127611) If we meet, I shall give you chapter and verse for the belief I have held about you.
('39', 69, 3, 11, 127696) But of course I like your energetic contradiction.
('39', 69, 3, 12, 127747) For I can only like repudiation of a philosophy which I have considered to be morally indefensible and utterly false.
('39', 69, 3, 13, 127865) Only my philosophy has room for holding in respect those who have a false philosophy but who do not know that it is false.
('39', 69, 3, 14, 127988) You have quoted Jamnalalji in your support.
('39', 69, 3, 15, 128032) I hardly think he will assist you.
('39', 69, 3, 16, 128067) But I will preserve your letter and ask him about it.
('39', 69, 3, 17, 128121) Now for your question.
('39', 69, 3, 18, 128144) I have certainly said that untouchability as practised today in Hinduism is the darkest blot on it.
('39', 69, 3, 19, 128244) But that is different from saying that it is part of Hindu religion as you have made me say.
('39', 69, 3, 20, 128337) For you will find in my writings an emphatic statement to the effect that untouchability is no part of Hindu religion, and that if it was, I should renounce Hinduism.
('39', 69, 3, 21, 128504) Indeed, you will find in the cutting you have sent me the following sentence : I find no authority whatsoever in Hinduism for treating any portion of the human family as untouchable. I have called it an excrescence.
('39', 69, 4, 22, 128720) Yours sincerely,
('39', 69, 5, 23, 128737) B. S. MOONJE NAGPUR CITY

('39', 70, 1, 2, 128836) 80. LETTER TO KUVALAYANAND 1
('39', 70, 2, 3, 128865) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, June 17, 1927
('39', 70, 3, 4, 128903) DEAR FRIEND, I now understand all you say about the abdominal massage and massage of the heart.
('39', 70, 3, 5, 128999) Of course it has been continued ever since I wrote to you.
('39', 70, 3, 6, 129058) I simply wanted to clear what I did not understand.
('39', 70, 3, 7, 129110) I have told you that in the physical application of these exercises, I propose to go by faith in you.
('39', 70, 3, 8, 129212) Whilst I shall present my doubts to you so long as I do not understand your explanations, they shall be final for me.
('39', 70, 3, 9, 129330) I want to give the practice of these yogic exercises a full trial, if only because I regard them of all the methods of medical treatment to be the freest from danger.
('39', 70, 3, 10, 129497) After I wrote my letter of the 8th, I took a forward step which I hope you would not consider hasty.
('39', 70, 3, 11, 129598) On re reading your notes, I saw that you expected me to go up to 30 degrees angle.
('39', 70, 3, 12, 129681) So, after writing to you, I immediately broadened the angle but limited the duration to five minutes in accordance with the instructions.
('39', 70, 3, 13, 129819) But I have my own doubts as to the angle being 30, because I have not yet secured an accurate measuring instrument.
('39', 70, 3, 14, 129935) Not being satisfied with the raising of the cot, I looked about for a plank which I have now secured.
('39', 70, 3, 15, 130037) The cot has a wooden surface.
('39', 70, 3, 16, 130067) I spread on it not a mattress but a padded rug, and I take the sarvangasan on it with the help of the board.
('39', 70, 3, 17, 130176) It is now infinitely better than the previous exercises.
('39', 70, 3, 18, 130233) Mahadev has been measuring the thing, and he thinks that the angle at which I take it is nearer to 50 than 30. I am not satisfied that it is anything like 50. Be that as it may.
('39', 70, 3, 19, 130411) I am feeling no discomfort.
('39', 70, 3, 20, 130439) Today will be the 4th day, and the duration is only five minutes.
('39', 70, 3, 21, 130505) Blood pressure is taken every Sunday, and if I find that the pressure has at all gone up, I shall ascribe the rising to the angle and drop the exercise till I hear from you in reply to this.
('39', 70, 3, 22, 130696) And I shall drop it, in any case, if you think that I have gone too far.
('39', 70, 3, 23, 130769) There is another passive exercise which I have been taking, not very regularly but fairly regularly, which I used to take when I was convalescing after dysentery and when I was physically much weaker than I am today.
('39', 70, 3, 24, 130986) And it is to raise the legs at right angles to the trunk
('39', 70, 4, 25, 131043) 1 In reply to his letter dated June 14
('39', 71, 0, 1, 131082) 72 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 71, 1, 2, 131123) and keep them for two or three minutes there; that is for removing any fatigue there may be after the walk; and then, I have the legs in that straight condition bent as much as can be bent without any strain whatsoever towards the head, whilst the trunk is lying on the bed.
('39', 71, 1, 3, 131398) This I take to strengthen the muscular exercise for the abdomen.
('39', 71, 1, 4, 131463) I think I even mentioned to you that this was given to me by Dr. Kelkar whom, I understand, you know.
('39', 71, 1, 5, 131565) And he has been writing to me to press that exercise on me.
('39', 71, 1, 6, 131625) Both these things, keeping the legs straight and at right angles to the trunk and gently bending the legs towards the head seem to me to do good.
('39', 71, 1, 7, 131771) There is no fatigue left and there is felt after the bending exercise a forward movement about the bowels.
('39', 71, 1, 8, 131878) I am still not taking tepid water and salt in the morning; for, the enema continues and I am now able to retain the water for half an hour.
('39', 71, 1, 9, 132018) But I do take a tumbler full of water by the nose.
('39', 71, 1, 10, 132069) Less than half of the quantity is spilt in the process of drinking through the nose.
('39', 71, 1, 11, 132154) So I think about four ounces of cool water I take in this way just after the mouth wash.
('39', 71, 1, 12, 132243) The walking exercise in the morning and in the evening continues, 40 minutes each time.
('39', 71, 1, 13, 132331) But the distance covered is greater than when I began after coming to Bangalore.
('39', 71, 1, 14, 132412) It is nothing less than two miles every time.
('39', 71, 1, 15, 132458) I have not yet dared to go beyond two teaspoonfuls of melted butter.
('39', 71, 1, 16, 132527) Milk has been increased, I think I told you, from 30 to 40 ounces and bhakhari 1 or oatmeal two ounces remain.
('39', 71, 1, 17, 132638) I enclose your original notes which you need not return because I shall remember the contents.
('39', 71, 1, 18, 132733) You will please send me any further instructions you may think desirable.

('39', 72, 1, 2, 132993) 81. LETTER TO KANTI GANDHI
('39', 72, 2, 3, 133020) BANGALORE, Jeth Vad 2 [June 17, 1927]
('39', 72, 3, 4, 133058) KANTI, I got your letter.
('39', 72, 3, 5, 133084) You want my permission to go and see Chi.
('39', 72, 3, 6, 133126) Harilal.
('39', 72, 3, 7, 133135) A son need not seek his grandfathers permission to see his father.
('39', 72, 3, 8, 133202) No one can stand in the way of a sons wishes.
('39', 72, 3, 9, 133248) You have now come of age, and that is another reason why there should be no question of my giving you permission.
('39', 72, 3, 10, 133362) All I can do is to explain to you your responsibility, and this is my advice in regard to your seeing Chi.
('39', 72, 3, 11, 133469) Harilal.
('39', 72, 3, 12, 133478) I believe he is present following a wrong path.
('39', 72, 3, 13, 133526) He leads an immoral life.
('39', 72, 3, 14, 133552) He has become an addict.
('39', 72, 3, 15, 133577) He has forgotten his dharma, and, therefore, he is not fit to exercise his right as a father.
('39', 72, 3, 16, 133671) I regard him as suffering from a kind of disease.
('39', 72, 3, 17, 133721) His disease is not physical but spiritual, and spiritual disease is more dreadful than a physical ailment.
('39', 72, 3, 18, 133828) It is not, therefore, your duty to go to him to comfort him; on the contrary, it is your duty to keep away from him.
('39', 72, 3, 19, 133945) You, I and his friends and well wishers should employ spritual non co operation against him.
('39', 72, 3, 20, 134038) If you have intended to go to him to reform him I regard your idea as worthy of support, and in that case I would facilitate your going.
('39', 72, 3, 21, 134175) But just now it seeems that you wish to go because of that letter.
('39', 72, 3, 22, 134242) I feel, therefore, that your going to him will mean your encouraging him in his intention.
('39', 72, 3, 23, 134333) Moreover, if you wish to go to him in order to reform him, you are not yet, from a practical point of view, fit and sufficiently mature to undertake such a task.
('39', 72, 3, 24, 134495) From that point of view, you are yet a child.
('39', 72, 3, 25, 134541) You are still studying.
('39', 72, 3, 26, 134565) It is my desire, and also my effort to see that as you study, you should so develop your soul that you may acquire the power to do what I could not in regard to Harilal, and you should so impress him that the moment he sees you he would abjure his evil habits.
('39', 72, 3, 27, 134826) I have been bringing up both you brothers with that aim in view.
('39', 72, 3, 28, 134891) If you have the capacity, you will be able to benefit from such education.
('39', 72, 3, 29, 134966) I would, therefore, advise you to write to Harilal and tell him firmly that he gives up his addictions and his immoral life and is able to support you all, or until you are able by the power of your tapascharya 1 to awaken him from his slumber, you cannot go and see him.
('39', 72, 3, 30, 135238) I do not, however, insist that you should forthwith accept my
('39', 72, 4, 31, 135300) 1 Self suffering as moral discipline
('39', 73, 0, 1, 135337) 74 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 73, 1, 2, 135378) advice.
('39', 73, 1, 3, 135386) So far, Harilal used to admit his weaknesses, and has been saying that he would try to shake them off; but now he has started writing letters against me in the papers.

('39', 73, 1, 15, 136754) We should have faith in them, accept what they say as true and act accordingly.
('39', 73, 1, 16, 136834) I wish, and I advise you, that you should do what I have suggested.
('39', 73, 1, 17, 136902) Do not reach a hasty decision.
('39', 73, 1, 18, 136933) Do not act with childish immaturity.
('39', 73, 1, 19, 136970) Try to understand what your duty at the present moment is, and act with courage and determination in accordance with that duty.
('39', 73, 1, 20, 137098) Consider, not what you would like to do, but what you should do.
('39', 73, 1, 21, 137163) You may show this letter to anyone you may wish to consult.
('39', 73, 1, 22, 137223) I shall wait for your reply.
('39', 73, 1, 23, 137252) Let me know how both of you are.

('39', 76, 5, 7, 140813) 86. QUARRELLING IN THE NAME OF RELIGION
('39', 76, 6, 8, 140853) A gentleman has sent me newspaper cuttings regarding the dispute which occurred in Udaipur State between Shwetambars 1 and Digambars 2 and suggested that I should go through them and give my opinion about it.
('39', 76, 6, 9, 141062) For one thing, in my present state of health I cannot spare enough time to read so many newspapers carefully, and, even if I had the necessary time and energy, it is not my practice to form an opinion on any matterno one should, I believefrom what one reads in the papers.
('39', 76, 6, 10, 141335) I, therefore, do not know which party is at fault, or more at fault.
('39', 76, 6, 11, 141404) However, I shall express the thoughts which occured to me after a fairly close reading of the cuttings.
('39', 76, 6, 12, 141508) The language of the writers indicates their partisan spirit.
('39', 76, 6, 13, 141569) Each side blames the other and considers itself innocent.
('39', 76, 6, 14, 141627) I found no essential differences between this dispute and the writings about it, on the one hand, and the Hindu Muslim quarrel and the writings about it on the other.
('39', 76, 6, 15, 141794) There is more bitterness in the latter and the language of the writings is more venomous, but the difference is only of one degree.
('39', 76, 6, 16, 141926) The fact is that we have forgotten the very meaning of religion.
('39', 76, 6, 17, 141991) Everyone fights to prove that his own view is the right one.
('39', 76, 6, 18, 142052) There is no trace of any desire to understand what religion means, in what it consists, by what marks it can be recognized , and how it can be preserved.
('39', 76, 6, 19, 142206) We have a right to expect more wisdom from the Jains; they are votaries of syadvada 3 and claim themselves to be the only followers of the path of compassion.
('39', 76, 6, 20, 142365) They should display tolerance; that is, be liberal towards others who hold different views.
('39', 76, 6, 21, 142457) We should know that
('39', 76, 7, 22, 142477) 1 Sects of Jains 2 ibid.
('39', 76, 8, 23, 142502) 3 The doctrine of the plurality of truth
('39', 77, 0, 1, 142543) 78 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 77, 1, 2, 142584) other people will be attached to what they regard as truth quite as much as we will to what we regard as truth.
('39', 77, 1, 3, 142696) Even when we feel that our opponent is at fault, we should not get angry with him but should act towards him with charity.
('39', 77, 1, 4, 142819) As I read these articles, however, I felt that even in Jain homes and temples texts of syadvada and compassion merely decorate old books and no other significance.
('39', 77, 1, 5, 142983) I realize this in experience again and again.
('39', 77, 1, 6, 143029) Where the doctrine of compassion is followed in action, it seems to be limited to feeding ants and preventing people from catching fish.
('39', 77, 1, 7, 143166) I have also observed that if, in displaying compassion in this manner, cruelty is shown to human beings, that is regarded as dharma.
('39', 77, 1, 8, 143299) Raychandbhai often said that when Jainism was embraced by Vanias 1, it was interpreted in a Vania spirit, and knowledge and courage, which should be the signs of compassion, vanished almost completely; compassion became synonymous with cowardice and thus came to be despised.
('39', 77, 1, 9, 143575) Moreover, dharma and wealth are eternal enemies; but the Goddess Lakhmi took up her abode in Jain temples and the result was that religious issues, instead of being solved through tapascharya,came to be settled in courts of law through argument by lawyers.
('39', 77, 1, 10, 143832) That is, those who could pay more could get a point of religious principle interpreted in their favour.
('39', 77, 1, 11, 143936) This picture may appear somewhat exaggerated, but it is not so.
('39', 77, 1, 12, 144000) I know the Jains.
('39', 77, 1, 13, 144018) I know them and the principles of their religion as intimately as I do Vaishnavism and Vaishnavas.
('39', 77, 1, 14, 144117) Some in their anger believe me to be a Jain.
('39', 77, 1, 15, 144162) Others in their love wish that I should became a Jain.
('39', 77, 1, 16, 144217) Some Jains are pleased by my partiality for a few members of their community.
('39', 77, 1, 17, 144295) I have learnt much from their books.
('39', 77, 1, 18, 144332) My contact with many Jain friends has helped me much.
('39', 77, 1, 19, 144386) All this has prompted me to write what I have done above thereby awaken those Jains who love their religion.
('39', 77, 1, 20, 144495) Why should there be hatred between Shwetambars and Digambars?
('39', 77, 1, 21, 144557) Their religious principles are the same.
('39', 77, 1, 22, 144598) The few differences which exist are easy enough to tolerate.
('39', 77, 1, 23, 144659) They are such as can be resolved to the satisfaction of both parties, like the differences between the followers of the advaita 2 and the dvaita 3 doctrines.
('39', 77, 1, 24, 144817) There are numerous monks and nuns among Jains, and they
('39', 77, 2, 25, 144873) 1 Members of a community traditionally engaged in buisness and commerce 2 Identity of the individual self with the universal Self 3 Separateness of the individual self from the universal Self
('39', 78, 0, 1, 145065) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 79
('39', 78, 1, 2, 145109) have plenty of spare time.
('39', 78, 1, 3, 145136) Why should they not engage themselves in real tapascharya?
('39', 78, 1, 4, 145195) Why should they not acquire the highest knowledge?
('39', 78, 1, 5, 145246) Why should they not seek to impart to others the benefit of their experience?
('39', 78, 1, 6, 145324) Jain youths seem to be engrossed in earning wealth like their elders.
('39', 78, 1, 7, 145394) Why should they not, though living the life of householders, become like tapasvis 1, generous hearted and the very embodiment of the purest spirit of compassion?
('39', 78, 1, 8, 145556) I was asked to give my opinion about the Palitana 2 affairs, and now I am asked my opinion about the sorry dispute in Udaipur.
('39', 78, 1, 9, 145683) The correspondents on this occasion, too, are young friends.
('39', 78, 1, 10, 145744) This time I have given an opinion which probably they never expected.
('39', 78, 1, 11, 145814) I do not distinguish between Hindus and Jains.
('39', 78, 1, 12, 145861) I can establish the unity of Hinduism, that is, the Vedic doctrine, with Jainism, with the help of syadvada itself.
('39', 78, 1, 13, 145977) For myself personally, I established long ago the unity of all religions with its help.
('39', 78, 1, 14, 146065) The dispute between Shwetambars and Digambars cannot be settled through newspapers nor in a court of law.
('39', 78, 1, 15, 146171) Both parties should atone for their errors and purify themselves, or one party should do that on behalf of both.
('39', 78, 1, 16, 146284) Those who cannot do even this should stop talking about religion, be humble and keep silent.
('39', 78, 1, 17, 146377) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 19 6 1927
('39', 78, 2, 18, 146414) 87. SWADESHI v.
('39', 78, 2, 19, 146430) FOREIGN A friend from Kathiawar writes as follows : 3
('39', 78, 3, 20, 146484) Many readers will immediately see the fallacies in this letter.
('39', 78, 3, 21, 146548) Even so, since one often hears similar views expressed by others, it is necessary to explain again the meaning of swadeshi as clearly as one can.
('39', 78, 3, 22, 146694) Moreover, we suffer a great deal through an abuse of the idea of swadeshi.
('39', 78, 3, 23, 146769) If many of the activities which are being carried on in the name of swadeshi were stopped and the effort spent on true swadeshi, we should achieve our goal much earlier.
('39', 78, 4, 24, 146939) 1 Those who practise tapascharya
('39', 78, 5, 25, 146972) 2 A Jain centre of pilgrimage in Saurashtra 3 The letter is not translated here.
('39', 78, 5, 26, 147053) The correspondent had criticized Gandhijis view that foreign articles which could not be manufactured in India and which were useful should be readily accepted.
('39', 78, 5, 27, 147214) For Gandhijis views vide The Cow and the Buffalo, 22 5 1927.
('39', 79, 0, 1, 147275) 80 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 79, 1, 2, 147316) I am sure that I have become more and not less scrupulous in following the vow of swadeshi.
('39', 79, 1, 3, 147408) I have been following it, as I had conceived it in 1920, and am following it even more scrupulously today.
('39', 79, 1, 4, 147515) We may certainly accept a foreign needle, since it is a useful article and can be assimilated.
('39', 79, 1, 5, 147610) By accepting it, we harm no industry or craft in the country and its acceptance, therefore, does not throw anyone out of employment.
('39', 79, 1, 6, 147743) On the contrary, the needle provides work to hundreds, work which benefits the country.
('39', 79, 1, 7, 147831) Foreign cloth may be good in quality, and cheaper, may even be offered free; even then, it should be rejected, for its acceptance has ruined crores of our countrymen.
('39', 79, 1, 8, 147998) We had been producing cloth in our own villages, and have found no other work in place of that industry.
('39', 79, 1, 9, 148103) We committed a great sin in abandoning it.
('39', 79, 1, 10, 148146) Its abandonment resulted in starvation, and that led to an increase in disease, crime and immorality.
('39', 79, 1, 11, 148248) If ever the time comes when the people of this country will have another, more honest occupation [than spinning and weaving] and when the cotton cannot be grown on the soil of this land or when the cultivators themselves will prefer to grow another, more profitable crop, then the vow of swadeshi cloth may serve no useful purpose.
('39', 79, 1, 12, 148580) If future generations, reading the literature of this age, regard this vow as an immutable principle and even at that time apply the principle of swadeshi to cloth, they will show themselves foolish and will be acting like people who drown themselves in their ancestral well instead of swimming across it.
('39', 79, 1, 13, 148886) My reason cannot conceive of such a time ever coming.
('39', 79, 1, 14, 148940) Whether it comes or not, there can be no two opinions that in our present condition khadi is the purest form of swadeshi and we can even say that now there are no two opinions about it.
('39', 79, 1, 15, 149126) Raw materials worth crores of rupees are produced in this country and, thanks to our ignorance, lethargy and lack of invention, exported to foreign countries; the result is, as Shri Madhusudan Das has pointed out, that we remain ignorant like animals, our hands do not get the training which they ought to and our intellects do not develop as they should.
('39', 79, 1, 16, 149482) As a consequence, living art has disappeared from our land and we are content to imitate the West.
('39', 79, 1, 17, 149581) As long as we cannot make the machines required for utilizing the hide of dead cattle, worth nine crores, available in our country, I would be ready to import them from any part of the world and would still believe that I was scrupulously keeping of the world and would still believe that I scrupulously keeping the vow of swadeshi.
('39', 79, 1, 18, 149914) I would believe that I would be only discrediting that vow by refusing, out of obstinacy, to
('39', 80, 0, 1, 150007) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 81
('39', 80, 1, 2, 150051) import those machines.
('39', 80, 1, 3, 150074) Similarly our country produces a great many things with medicinal properties, and those come back to us in the form of a variety of drugs or other articles.
('39', 80, 1, 4, 150231) It is our duty to import any machines, and obtain any help, which will enable us to utilize these things in our own country.
('39', 80, 1, 5, 150356) Swadeshi is an eternal religious duty.
('39', 80, 1, 6, 150395) The manner of following it may, and ought to, change from age to age.
('39', 80, 1, 7, 150465) The principle of swadeshi is the soul and khadi is its body in this age and in this country.
('39', 80, 1, 8, 150558) If in the course of time this body perishes, swadeshi will assume a new body but the soul dwelling in it will be the same.
('39', 80, 1, 9, 150681) Swadeshi is service, and if we understand its nature we shall simultaneously benefit oursleves, our families, our country and the world.
('39', 80, 1, 10, 150818) Swadeshi is not intended to serve self interest but is pure altruism, and hence I call it a form of yajna.
('39', 80, 1, 11, 150925) It certainly benefits ourselves, but there is no room in it for hatred of others.
('39', 80, 1, 12, 151007) There can be no absolute duty of not importing anything at any time; only, we may not import anything which may harm the country.
('39', 80, 1, 13, 151137) Nor can it be accepted as an absolute principle that everything that belongs to or is produced by ones own country is good.
('39', 80, 1, 14, 151261) Anything, whether indigenous or foreign, which is good and serves our interest, should be readily accepted, and likewise anything, indigenous or foreign, which is bad and harmful should be rejected.
('39', 80, 1, 15, 151460) The country produces a huge quantity of liquor, but all of it deserves to be shunned.
('39', 80, 1, 16, 151546) There is no reason to believe that, if the whole country gives up drinking, those engaged in the liquor trade will be ruined.
('39', 80, 1, 17, 151672) Their present business harms themselves and the country and they will not starve if they lose it; there will be other, better occupations which they can follow.
('39', 80, 1, 18, 151833) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 19 6 1927
('39', 81, 0, 1, 151870) 82 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 81, 1, 2, 151911) 88. LETTER TO THE SECRETARY, A.I.S.A.
('39', 81, 2, 3, 151949) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, June 19, 1927
('39', 81, 3, 4, 151987) DEAR SIR, With reference to the collections made in Benares, it is quite correct to state that they were all made for the Gandhi Ashram, Benares.
('39', 81, 3, 5, 152133) They should therefore have the whole amount not as a loan but as a grant.
('39', 81, 3, 6, 152207) It ought to appear in our books because the collection was responsibly made.
('39', 81, 3, 7, 152284) It should be entered as ear marked for Gandhi Ashram, Benares, and there would be no need to get the sanction from the Council for the grant.
('39', 81, 3, 8, 152426) As to Laxmi Behn and Harjivan, my opinion is that the whole things should be left to Rajendra Babu to manage, such help being given to him as he may require for facilitating the execution of his decision.
('39', 81, 3, 9, 152631) This thing may be further discussed when we meet.
('39', 81, 3, 10, 152681) As to Gulbarga collection, I am conferring with Gangadharrao.
('39', 81, 3, 11, 152743) But the position generally is this.
('39', 81, 3, 12, 152779) Whilst it is convenient for us to know from which province collections have been received, all these collections are on behalf of the Association.
('39', 81, 3, 13, 152926) If the idea is that the whole of the Maharashtra collections should be necessarily spent for Maharashtra, and that other provincial collections should be similarly treated, the doctrine is untenable.
('39', 81, 3, 14, 153126) And I made it clear during the tour at all the places where the question was raised that whilst the places at which the amounts were collected wiil be borne in mind at the time of considering the allocation of funds, the Association could not undertake necessarily to spend funds in the place where they have been collected.
('39', 81, 3, 15, 153451) It is therefore a matter of little importance what description is given to the entry of Gulbarga collections in our books.
('39', 81, 3, 16, 153574) Theoretically, it is open to the Association to spend the whole of the Maharashtra collection, say in Orissa and vice versa.
('39', 81, 3, 17, 153699) That it would be gross abuse of authority and that such abuse would break the Associa tion is also true.
('39', 81, 3, 18, 153804) But I mention this merely to illustrate my meaning and to show that so far as ledger entry is concerned, it is a matter of no moment where a particular collection comes from.
('39', 81, 4, 19, 153979) Yours sincerely, THE SECRETARY ALL INDIA SPINNERS ASSOCIATION AHMEDABAD

('39', 82, 1, 2, 154125) 89. LETTER TO RAIHANA TYABJI
('39', 82, 2, 3, 154154) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, July 19, 1927
('39', 82, 3, 4, 154192) MY DEAR RAIHANA, I have your two letters.
('39', 82, 3, 5, 154234) I am glad you have opened your heart to me.
('39', 82, 3, 6, 154278) The very act of doing so often soothes one.
('39', 82, 3, 7, 154322) Do not therefore apologize for writing at length and in whatsover manner the spirit moves you.
('39', 82, 3, 8, 154417) I am glad you have got the permission from mother for taking to simpler dress.
('39', 82, 3, 9, 154496) I would like you to open out your heart to both father and mother as you have done to me.
('39', 82, 3, 10, 154586) Never mind their laughing you out or smothering you with ridicule or putting you down even in anger.
('39', 82, 3, 11, 154687) You will take it all in good part and with a smile on your lips.
('39', 82, 3, 12, 154752) They have a right to do all those things.
('39', 82, 3, 13, 154794) And when they recognize in you, in spite of ridicule, anger, etc., a seriousness and determination which shall not be moved, they will let you do what you like.
('39', 82, 3, 14, 154955) How often have not young men and women built castles in the air only to be destroyed later.
('39', 82, 3, 15, 155047) Why should you expect people to regard you as an exception?
('39', 82, 3, 16, 155107) If you are an exception, you will stand ridicule, contempt and worse, and come out better through the ordeal.
('39', 82, 3, 17, 155217) After all God must put us through the test.
('39', 82, 3, 18, 155261) I share your grief over your having to give up that dress on which mother has lavished so much time and so much love.
('39', 82, 3, 19, 155379) But love is its own reward.
('39', 82, 3, 20, 155407) And parents do not regret the trouble they have taken after things which their children outgrow.
('39', 82, 3, 21, 155504) Let all those things of yours go to Sohila when mother is satisfied that you will never be likely to want them.

('39', 90, 1, 2, 169050) 98. LETTER TO ABBAS TYABJI
('39', 90, 2, 3, 169077) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, June 21, 1927
('39', 90, 3, 4, 169115) MY DEAR BHRRRR, 1
('39', 90, 4, 5, 169133) Better late than never.
('39', 90, 4, 6, 169157) I have your letter at last.
('39', 90, 4, 7, 169185) Why should marriage ceremonies cost so much time, trouble, money, and make even 70 year young people look old for all the time and trouble taken over marriages of their children?
('39', 90, 4, 8, 169364) What is there extraordinary in a marriage to elate parents and their children and almost make them mad with joy?
('39', 90, 4, 9, 169477) Is it not an everyday occurrence like birth, youth, old age and death itself?
('39', 90, 4, 10, 169555) They are all necessary changes attendant upon life.
('39', 90, 4, 11, 169607) But of course all this is philosophy after the event.
('39', 90, 4, 12, 169661) If I had a marriage in prospect, perhaps, I should write differently.
('39', 90, 4, 13, 169731) But even if I intended to be married, there does not appear to be in existence a parent mad enough or sane enough to give me his girl in marriage.
('39', 90, 4, 14, 169878) I can therefore safely deliver lectures to young people and old people who take pleasure in wasting their time and money over marriages.
('39', 90, 4, 15, 170015) However I shall forgive all this extravagance, if Sohaila properly puts down her husband when he endeavours to restrain her freedom, and by sheer force of exemplary character breaks down the wretched purdah in Lucknow and the neighbourhood; and of course the propaganda of khaddar is the least I expect her to do.
('39', 90, 4, 16, 170329) I am still gathering strength and I am not likely to leave the South for another two months.
('39', 90, 4, 17, 170422) It must therefore be some time before I shall have the pleasure of hugging you and touching your silvery beard and chatting on all matters important and unimportant.
('39', 90, 4, 18, 170588) Raihana must be allowed to grow in her own way.
('39', 90, 4, 19, 170636) With love to you all,
('39', 90, 5, 20, 170658) Yours sincerely,
('39', 90, 6, 21, 170675) M. K. GANDHI

('39', 91, 1, 2, 170838) 99. LETTER TO DEBENDRA NATH MITRA
('39', 91, 2, 3, 170872) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, June 21, 1927
('39', 91, 3, 4, 170910) DEAR FRIEND, I must apologize to you for entirely forgetting to give you my suggestions regarding agriculture.
('39', 91, 3, 5, 171021) My impression is that unless improvements which are within the means of the poor are taken to their very farms as they were in South Africa, success will be slow.
('39', 91, 3, 6, 171184) My recent studies more and more demonstrate to me the necessity of the State taking virtual control of all the cattle.
('39', 91, 3, 7, 171303) It seems to me that unless the cattle problem is properly tackled, they will either be killed out mercilessly or we shall be.
('39', 91, 3, 8, 171429) And while things are allowed to take their course, we are both being ground down.
('39', 91, 3, 9, 171511) Destruction of uneconomic cattle, I hold to be impractical and criminal in our country.
('39', 91, 3, 10, 171599) We must therefore take charge of the uneconomic cattle and find ways and means of supporting them as economically as possible, getting what return we can out of their manure and out of their hide, bone, etc., after they die.
('39', 91, 3, 11, 171824) We should cease to allow a single calf to come into being except through proper bulls.
('39', 91, 3, 12, 171911) Your farm should therefore, in my opinion, contain facilities for proper dairying and tanning and there should be series of experiments to find out the relative value of manure in connection with the feed of unused and unuseful cattle.
('39', 91, 3, 13, 172147) I do not know whether you followed the series of articles that were published in Young India on the cattle problem.
('39', 91, 3, 14, 172263) There are of course other things I might mention; but they require legislation and [are] therefore outside your jurisdiction and control.
('39', 91, 4, 15, 172401) Yours sincerely,
('39', 91, 5, 16, 172418) DEBENDRA NATH MITRA GOVT.
('39', 91, 5, 17, 172444) AGRICULTURAL FARM FARIDPUR (EAST BENGAL)
('39', 91, 6, 18, 172485) From a microfilm : S.N. 12917

('39', 92, 7, 15, 173425) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, June 21, 1927

('39', 94, 9, 14, 175774) That I praised the bangles made of yarn does not mean that all of you should start wearing them.
('39', 94, 9, 15, 175871) Such innovations will endure only if they proceed from the heart.

('39', 94, 9, 23, 176449) We are already farmers, weavers and sweepers; we need to be cowherds too.

('39', 95, 1, 2, 176854) 105. LETTER TO J. P. BHANSALI
('39', 95, 2, 3, 176884) BANGALORE, Jeth Vad 7 [June 21, 1927] 1
('39', 95, 3, 4, 176924) BHAISHRI BHANSALI, I liked your letter very much because you had opened your heart in it.
('39', 95, 3, 5, 177014) Manibehn has today given me the news that your seven day fast is progressing well.
('39', 95, 3, 6, 177097) A seven day fast is childs play for you.
('39', 95, 3, 7, 177138) I had not, therefore, felt worried over it at all.
('39', 95, 3, 8, 177189) But I see an error in the argument you have advanced about the reason for the fast.
('39', 95, 3, 9, 177273) The best thing is not to do a thing about doing which we have a doubt.
('39', 95, 3, 10, 177344) If we have started doing a thing, and then we get a doubt about it, true expiation consists in abandoning it that very moment.
('39', 95, 3, 11, 177471) Any other atonement which excludes this is useless.
('39', 95, 3, 12, 177523) If your demand for a new house was wrong, you cannot atone for that error by means of a fast.
('39', 95, 3, 13, 177617) If you see no error in that demand, atonement is not called for at all.
('39', 95, 3, 14, 177689) If you have even the slightest doubt about having committed an error, to seek to cover it up by means of a fast amounts to committing a second error, because by undertaking a fast we banish the thought of error from our mind and we ought not to do this.
('39', 95, 3, 15, 177943) Expiation such as fasting is a form of self punishment and punishment can be only for a thing which we cannot undo.
('39', 95, 3, 16, 178059) If we abuse someone or beat him, we cannot take back the abuse or the beating.
('39', 95, 3, 17, 178138) We may, therefore, inflict on ourselves punishment like a fast; such punishment brings about self purification, and also restrains us from making a similar mistake again.
('39', 95, 3, 18, 178309) But suppose that we have stolen someones money.
('39', 95, 3, 19, 178357) At the time of doing so, we felt that there was nothing wrong in it but later on we got a doubt about what we had done and felt afraid lest we had done a wrong; then, at that very moment, we ought to return the money to the owner and threafter, if we so wish, we may undergo self punishment such as a fast.
('39', 95, 3, 20, 178664) Returning the money is like returning a loan and hence that does not amount even to punishment.
('39', 95, 3, 21, 178760) You may perhaps argue why you should return the goods so long as you are not sure that stealing is bad, and tell yourself that you will return them when you decide that it is indeed bad.
('39', 95, 3, 22, 178947) Many sins are, and have been committed in the world through such reasoning.
('39', 95, 3, 23, 179023) Being moral requires that wherever there is a doubt, we should decide against our own interest.
('39', 95, 3, 24, 179119) But we may go a step further and suppose that, so long as we have a
('39', 95, 4, 25, 179187) 1 From the reference to the addressees seven day fast
('39', 96, 0, 1, 179241) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 97
('39', 96, 1, 2, 179285) doubt about stealing being wrong, we shall also have a doubt about the desirability of returning the money.
('39', 96, 1, 3, 179393) Even then, in such circumstances a fast certainly is not a means of resolving such a doubt.
('39', 96, 1, 4, 179485) On the contrary, the fast may prove an obstacle in our effort to discover the truth.
('39', 96, 1, 5, 179570) Here I have only analysed the ethical principle for your benefit.
('39', 96, 1, 6, 179636) I myself have no doubt whatever in your case.
('39', 96, 1, 7, 179682) You had a right to ask for a roomier house in a quiet part, for the inmates of the Ashram regard your living in the Ashram as conducive to its progress.
('39', 96, 1, 8, 179835) The best place for the experiments which you have been making is the Ashram, and such experiments are an inseparable part of its life.
('39', 96, 1, 9, 179970) Hence any facilities which you consider necessary for those experiments and which others accept as necessary should be provided to you if the financial condition of the Ashram permits them, and it is because this was the position that a house has been got ready for you.
('39', 96, 1, 10, 180241) Moreover, if hereafter it is felt that such an arrangement ought not to have been made, you can move into another small house that may be vacant.
('39', 96, 1, 11, 180387) On that score, too, we need have no fear.
('39', 96, 1, 12, 180429) Moreover, Lilabehn may get more accustomed to the conditions there and come to like living in simplicity, and you may become so detached that the atmosphere round you will not affect you at all; then you yourself will decide to leave that house and ask for another.
('39', 96, 1, 13, 180695) And if I see that you or Lilabehn has become weak, I shall not, as an elder and guardian, hesitate to speak to you about it.
('39', 96, 1, 14, 180820) If I shrink from doing so, I shall fall from my dharma.
('39', 96, 1, 15, 180876) Thus you are safe in every way.
('39', 96, 1, 16, 180908) I could have explained all this in my reply to your very letter.
('39', 96, 1, 17, 180973) It even occurred to me to do so.
('39', 96, 1, 18, 181006) But I did not think it advisable to do that and stop your fast abruptly.
('39', 96, 1, 19, 181079) I was also afraid that I might shock you by advancing such an argument when you were about to start your fast.
('39', 96, 1, 20, 181190) Hence I deferred writing this.
('39', 96, 1, 21, 181221) Now you are in a position to appreciate my argument objectively, since the fast is now out of the way.
('39', 96, 1, 22, 181324) There is a sound reason behind my plea.
('39', 96, 1, 23, 181364) If you remain complacent because of the fast and believe that there is no reason now to feel doubtful about the propriety of having put up a new building, that would not be right.
('39', 96, 1, 24, 181544) The truth is that it is our duty to feel doubtful about the propriety of every one of our indulgences, and it is complacency to feel no such doubt.
('39', 96, 1, 25, 181692) If we do not feel doubtful in this manner, we shall never be able to practise complete renunciation.
('39', 96, 1, 26, 181793) Hence this caution.
('39', 96, 1, 27, 181813) I have also something to say about the other portions of your letter, but this is enough for the present.
('39', 96, 1, 28, 181919) I shall attend to those portions when I have
('39', 97, 0, 1, 181964) 98 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 97, 1, 2, 182005) the time.
('39', 97, 1, 3, 182015) The matter is certainly not urgent.
('39', 97, 1, 4, 182051) Please have no hesitaion in writing to me whatever you wish.
('39', 97, 2, 5, 182112) M. K. GANDHI
('39', 97, 3, 6, 182125) From a photostat of the Gujarati : S.N. 12194
('39', 97, 4, 7, 182171) 106. LETTER TO SATAVALEKAR June 21, 1927 It is the common experience that brahmacharya is not essential for the conservation and development of bodily strength and so on.
('39', 97, 4, 8, 182342) Hence there is the danger of overlooking the importance of brahmacharya in tracing the close association between brahmacharya and physical strength.
('39', 97, 4, 9, 182491) We have fallen lower than the asuri 1 countries.
('39', 97, 4, 10, 182540) The reason for it is the having fallen from our own position we are not able to attain another either.
('39', 97, 4, 11, 182643) We are afraid of accommodating all that the asuri tradition implies, whereas we lack the strength to translate into action the daivi 2 traditions.
('39', 97, 4, 12, 182790) It is for this reson that attempts are being made in the country today to bring in the asuri traditionsthis is what I see everywhere.
('39', 97, 4, 13, 182924) But these traditions simply cannot work.
('39', 97, 4, 14, 182965) The people cannot digest them.
('39', 97, 4, 15, 182996) And as they are lax in following the daivi tradition, they stand where they are.
('39', 97, 4, 16, 183077) Hence I believe that since we follow the daivi tradition our acts must be pure and we must somehow save ourselves from copying the asuri tradition.
('39', 97, 4, 17, 183225) [From Hindi]

('39', 99, 1, 2, 185492) struck the latters fist with his nose.
('39', 99, 1, 3, 185531) I have remembered that joke well because you have unwittingly summed up my own belief.
('39', 99, 1, 4, 185618) I have certainly run up my nose against many a fist, and have hitherto come out unhurt.
('39', 99, 1, 5, 185706) I have found in my experience that when instead of putting up your nose for the man with the fist to play with, you try to ward off his play by holding it back, you really get the knock out blow.
('39', 99, 1, 6, 185902) But I must not try to present you my philosophy of life if the method I stand for can possibly be described by such a dignified word.
('39', 99, 1, 7, 186036) But I would say one word with reference to your estimate of me.
('39', 99, 1, 8, 186100) I ask you to believe me when I assure you that I endeavoured to see myself in your looking glass.
('39', 99, 1, 9, 186198) But I have failed to recognize myself in it.
('39', 99, 1, 10, 186243) I do not wonder at the picture you have drawn of me.
('39', 99, 1, 11, 186296) I hope that I do not entertain any elongated notions about myself.
('39', 99, 1, 12, 186363) But I cannot help expressing my grief that a man so sincere like you should have failed to study an honest movement which somehow or other caught the imagination of thousands upon thousands of men and women who had hitherto been left untouched, with more attention than you evidently felt called upon to give.
('39', 99, 1, 13, 186673) Many English friends are now beginning to see that my movement was an honest attempt through non co operation to bring about hearty co operation of equals, instead of an enforced and superficial co operation between parties one of which regarded itself as superior to the other.
('39', 99, 1, 14, 186952) I shall await your letter 1 telling me what your challenge was.
('39', 99, 1, 15, 187016) And if I find it to be still capable of being taken up, and find myself equally capable of taking it up, you may depend upon me responding to it.

('39', 100, 1, 2, 187486) 109. LETTER TO G. K. DEVADHAR
('39', 100, 2, 3, 187516) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, June 22, 1927
('39', 100, 3, 4, 187554) MY DEAR DEVADHAR, I thank you for your letter.
('39', 100, 3, 5, 187601) I did read about your election in the papers.
('39', 100, 3, 6, 187647) It was a foregone conclusion.
('39', 100, 3, 7, 187677) I therefore did not send you my congratulations.
('39', 100, 3, 8, 187726) And though in the opinion of the outside world, it is an honour conferred upon you, I know as well as you do that for you it is a matter of greater responsibility and greater opportunity for service.
('39', 100, 3, 9, 187926) You call me a friend and supporter of the Society.
('39', 100, 3, 10, 187977) I regard myself as some friend and supporter of the Society.
('39', 100, 3, 11, 188038) I regard myself as something much more.
('39', 100, 3, 12, 188078) I have never considered myself as anything but a member of the Society.
('39', 100, 3, 13, 188150) Though I am not officially a member [and] am not taking any active part in its activities, [this] does not cause me the slightest worry.
('39', 100, 3, 14, 188287) My abstention is my quota of service.
('39', 100, 3, 15, 188325) When a member of a numerous family cannot see eye to eye with the rest although his heart is with them, he serves the family best by non interference, always wishing that his head may be where his heart is so that he can render active service.
('39', 100, 3, 16, 188569) Has it not been said that those also serve who wait and pray?
('39', 100, 3, 17, 188631) You have therefore a right to command my service whenever you think that with my limitations it can be of any use to you.
('39', 100, 3, 18, 188753) I do not expect to be a Sabarmati before the end of August, for doctors here tell me I shall be able to do a certain amount of touring from next month, and if I can do so, I shall want to finish as far as I can the Southern tour that was mapped out and over which immense trouble was taken by Rajagopalachari and Gangadharrao Deshpande.
('39', 100, 3, 19, 189090) If I must regard your headquarters as Poona, it is just as easy for you if not easier to come to Bangalore as to go to Sabarmati.
('39', 100, 3, 20, 189220) And I am here till about 10th of July.
('39', 100, 3, 21, 189259) You can come here therefore if you at all can and will.
('39', 100, 3, 22, 189315) I shall always have my grievance against Mrs. Devadhar, for she is under promise to come to Sabarmati and stay there a few days, a promise she has never yet fulfilled.
('39', 100, 3, 23, 189483) With love,
('39', 100, 4, 24, 189494) Yours sincerely,
('39', 100, 5, 25, 189511) M. K. GANDHI SJT.
('39', 100, 5, 26, 189529) G. K. DEVADHAR SERVANTS OF INDIA SOCIEY POONA

('39', 101, 1, 2, 189647) 110. LETTER TO G. D. BIRLA
('39', 101, 2, 3, 189674) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, June 22, 1927 I have your letter from Geneva.
('39', 101, 2, 4, 189744) I hope you have received all my previous letters including the last one which was in English.
('39', 101, 2, 5, 189838) I see that you are observing things with your customary keenness.
('39', 101, 2, 6, 189904) I hope however that you will form no hasty conclusions as so many of our superior men have often done.
('39', 101, 2, 7, 190007) All is not gold that glitters.
('39', 101, 2, 8, 190038) The converse of it is also equally true.
('39', 101, 2, 9, 190079) All is not dirt that appears dirty.
('39', 101, 2, 10, 190115) And how often do we not see the two co existing, riches and poverty, virtue and vice, Jekyll and Hyde, God and Satan?
('39', 101, 2, 11, 190233) The combination that you have described of wine drinking, womanizing, etc., with physical strength, orderliness, common honesty and ardent patriotism is not to be denied.
('39', 101, 2, 12, 190404) The fact seems to me to be that one virtue does not lead at any rate all at once to all the other virtues, and a particular quality ceases to be a virtue when it solidifies into a custom.
('39', 101, 2, 13, 190592) Vege tarianism with us is really no virtue.
('39', 101, 2, 14, 190636) We are vegetarians by custom.
('39', 101, 2, 15, 190666) It would be a sacrifice for us a large majority of vegetarians to be otherwise.
('39', 101, 2, 16, 190746) But vegetarianism in Europe will be a virtue.
('39', 101, 2, 17, 190792) It would be an active force in the life of a European vegetarian, and if he is a seeker of truth that one reform will lead him to many others.
('39', 101, 2, 18, 190935) Foreign visitors to India have remarked upon our general domestic happiness and family affection.
('39', 101, 2, 19, 191033) This quality is part of our being.
('39', 101, 2, 20, 191068) A father loves his children and children render willing obedience to parents without much effort on either side.
('39', 101, 2, 21, 191181) People in Europe have found by ex perience that it is necessary for them to extend the family idea and regard the society to which they belong as a nation.
('39', 101, 2, 22, 191337) Hence patriotism there is not a virtue which needs to be cultivated.
('39', 101, 2, 23, 191406) Want of it would be noticed as a strange thing and would lead to excommunication of the type familiar in Europe.
('39', 101, 2, 24, 191519) They have also understood the doctrine of honesty being the best policy and so up to a point, you will find that quality abundantly in evidence.
('39', 101, 2, 25, 191664) With us patriotism has got to be cultivated.
('39', 101, 2, 26, 191709) We have in practice not gone beyond family affection as a nation.
('39', 101, 2, 27, 191775) But I shall not elaborate this point further as I must keep an appointment which I have put off to finish this letter.
('39', 101, 2, 28, 191894) It will be an agreeable surprise to me if you succeed in enlisting 500 paying subscribers for Young India.
('39', 101, 2, 29, 192001) It would be further proof of European interest in what Young India stands for.
('39', 101, 2, 30, 192080) I am making steady progress.
('39', 101, 2, 31, 192109) And doctors are of opinion that I
('39', 102, 0, 1, 192143) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 103
('39', 102, 1, 2, 192188) should be able to resume touring on a moderate scale early next month.
('39', 102, 2, 3, 192259) Yours sincerely,

('39', 102, 5, 6, 192368) 111. LANCASHIRE BLOCK
('39', 102, 6, 7, 192390) The long delay which took place in the publication of the Tariff Board report was almost a certain indication of the rejection of any recommendation for granting further protection to the great mill industry.
('39', 102, 6, 8, 192599) The Government will not offend Japan by discriminating against it and favouring Lancashire.
('39', 102, 6, 9, 192691) And it dare not displease Lancashire by applying it any protective duty.
('39', 102, 6, 10, 192764) For Lancashire is the Government in substance; and to grant India effective protection against Lancashire would be almost like committing suicide.
('39', 102, 6, 11, 192911) This question of protection for the mill industry against Lancashire and other foreign competition is a question of life and death for India as it is supposedly one of life and death also for Lancashire.
('39', 102, 6, 12, 193115) To realize the truth of this statement, one has merely to look at the table of imports.
('39', 102, 6, 13, 193203) Imports from Lancashire are by far the largest of all the other imports, nearly half of all British imports.
('39', 102, 6, 14, 193312) Lancashire has risen on the ashes of Indias greatest cottage industry and it is sustained by the exploitation of the helpless millions of this land.
('39', 102, 6, 15, 193461) The indigenous mill industry is really regarded as an interloper, and if it could be decently squashed in the interest of Lancashire, it would be suppressed without ceremony.
('39', 102, 6, 16, 193636) The stupendous interest of Lancashire is allowed to override every moral consideration.
('39', 102, 6, 17, 193724) The existence of that industry harms both Lancashire and India.
('39', 102, 6, 18, 193788) It has reduced India to pauperism, and Indias pauperism reduces Lancashire to moral bankruptcy.
('39', 102, 6, 19, 193884) The mill owners of India will never be able to vindicate their position in the face of this almost insurmountable obstacle, unless they courageously make common cause with the people and force protection from the Government.
('39', 102, 6, 20, 194109) It is the countrys right.
('39', 102, 6, 21, 194135) If a country has the right to determine the composition of its inhabitants, and to exclude those whom it considers to be detrimental to its existence, it has a greater right to determine the composition of the
('39', 103, 0, 1, 194345) 104 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 103, 1, 2, 194387) goods that it would permit to be imported within its borders and to exclude those that it may consider to be harmful to its population.
('39', 103, 1, 3, 194523) There can be no doubt that foreign cloth is the most harmful among all our imports.
('39', 103, 1, 4, 194607) The mill industry may for a time flourish somehow, it may also show a temporary prosperity by various manipulations or by favourable accidents; but unless it secures effective protection against all foreign cloth, it is bound to go under sooner or later, and certainly much sooner than one expects.
('39', 103, 1, 5, 194906) Some day or other there is bound to be a real sustained mass awakening, whether mad and undisciplined but organized in its own madness, or (as I hope), disciplined and organized non violently.
('39', 103, 1, 6, 195099) And when it comes the indigenous mill industry, unless it is recognized as their own by the masses, will perish in the flames that must overtake foreign cloth.
('39', 103, 1, 7, 195259) It is time for the mill owners to make common cause with khadi and wrest protection from an unwilling Government.
('39', 103, 1, 8, 195373) There is room enough for years to come for both, if the province of each is now marked out and rigidly respected.
('39', 103, 1, 9, 195487) It is then possible for them to prosper in spite of Government aloofness and even insidious opposition.
('39', 103, 1, 10, 195591) But this presupposes intelligent sacrifice on the part of the mill owners, a vital combination amongst them and an iron determination to carry through their programme.
('39', 103, 1, 11, 195759) I was glad to notice an authoritative repudiation of the rumour that a cut in the wages of the mill hands was contemplated as a reply to the Governments decision.
('39', 103, 1, 12, 195922) It would have been suicidal.
('39', 103, 1, 13, 195951) What is wanted at this time is not antagonizing labour, but making common cause with labour and regarding mill hands as much proprietors of the mills as the shareholders and agents.
('39', 103, 1, 14, 196133) If the shareholders supply the capital, the labourers supply the muscle for the conversion of capital into cloth.
('39', 103, 1, 15, 196247) A combination, therefore, between the mill owners, the mill hands and the masses would be an irresistible combination which the Government dare not ignore.
('39', 103, 1, 16, 196403) Will the mill owners have enough foresight, courage and patriotism for the task?
('39', 103, 1, 17, 196484) The 1s.
('39', 103, 1, 18, 196492) ratio, it was contended (with a great degree of force in the contention), was a hit aginst that great industry and a gift to Lancashire.
('39', 103, 1, 19, 196629) The resolution on the Tariff Board report is another such hit and therefore another gift to Lancashire.
('39', 103, 1, 20, 196733) I wonder whether this last hit will stir the mill owners to right action.
('39', 103, 1, 21, 196807) No petition, no resolution in the Legislative Assembly will be of any use unless it is backed by effective mass action, and, in my humble opinion, it is not possible to conceive of any milder mass action than I have ventured to suggest.
('39', 103, 1, 22, 197044) Young India, 23 6 1927
