('39', 104, 1, 2, 197112) 112. NOTES
('39', 104, 2, 3, 197123) THE FORTHCOMING TOUR If the progress I am supposed to be making continues to the end of the month, Drs.
('39', 104, 2, 4, 197227) Subbarao and Krishnaswami Rao who have been kindly attending on me tell me that I should be able to resume a moderate amount of touring taken in easy stages.
('39', 104, 2, 5, 197385) In view, therefore, of the possible resumption, I would like the workers and all concerned to bear in mind that I shall not be able to sustain the strain to which I seemed to be equal up to the end of March.
('39', 104, 2, 6, 197593) Processions and noises must be abandoned and people should be repeatedly warned against crowding round me shouting and touching my feet; nor may I be expected to visit institutions in the places to which I may be taken.
('39', 104, 2, 7, 197813) One meeting and informal discussion with workers is about all I shall be able to manage per day.
('39', 104, 2, 8, 197910) It is, I know, ungracious to use Chikballapur as my illustration to show how not to do it.
('39', 104, 2, 9, 198001) The people of Chikballapur have been extraordinarily kind to me personally.
('39', 104, 2, 10, 198077) A friend who noticed the exquisite attention paid to me at Nandi Hills by the representatives who used to come from Chikballapur from time to time to see that everything was supplied and in order, and who noticed the loving attention of the volunteers all drawn from representative families of Mysore, could not help remarking that it was wonderful manifestation of selfless love that the people of Mysore exhibited, in that I had done nothing, specially for the people of Mysore, I had hardly even seen the country except for the flying visits to Bangalore.
('39', 104, 2, 11, 198636) I could not help endorsing the spontaneous remark made by this friend.
('39', 104, 2, 12, 198707) It was so true.
('39', 104, 2, 13, 198723) The reception committee of Chikba llapur left no stone unturned to anticipate my wants and supply them at considerable sacrifice of time and money.
('39', 104, 2, 14, 198871) I would therefore gladly have avoided using Chikballapur for an unfavourable illustration.
('39', 104, 2, 15, 198962) But what happened there was so typical that I must not omit to mention it.
('39', 104, 2, 16, 199037) Although there was to be no procession, and I was to be taken quickly and quietly to the place of the meeting 1 which was to be perfectly noiseless, the leaders and the people lost their heads when they saw my car, and though the sun was beating hot, Mr. Hamza Husain Saheb, who is the chairman of the general reception committee and who was escorting me, had to submit to the pain of seeing the hood taken off and the motor carried in procession at a snails pace.
('39', 104, 2, 17, 199502) Officiating Dewan and ex Police Commissioner though he was, he
('39', 104, 3, 18, 199565) 1 Vide Speech at Chikballapur, 5 6 1927.
('39', 105, 0, 1, 199606) 106 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 105, 1, 2, 199648) knew that at this moment he was connected with a representative of Indias paupers, and as such had meekly to submit to the risk of all the good that Nandi had done to his charge being undone.
('39', 105, 1, 3, 199840) I pleaded with the leaders whom I had seen in Nandi and who were near the car to restrain the enthusiasm and quickly take the motor to the meeting place.
('39', 105, 1, 4, 199994) We shall soon reach it, was the only reply I could get.
('39', 105, 1, 5, 200050) The meeting, too, was none too orderly, and on the top of that, though the majority of the audience did not understand Enlgish, the address was read to me in that language in spite of my repeated warning in these pages that it would be more in keeping with the surroundings, at least at meetings where poor people gather in thousands, to conduct proceedings in their mother tongue supplying me when necessary with a translation in Hindi.
('39', 105, 1, 6, 200488) But this much must be said for Chikballapur.
('39', 105, 1, 7, 200533) Its mistakes too were due to affection.
('39', 105, 1, 8, 200573) I was told that they never had a popular meeting of this character before.
('39', 105, 1, 9, 200648) They naturally did not wish to damp the enthusiasm of the people.
('39', 105, 1, 10, 200714) They lost their heads themselves for the moment, being caught in the wave of enthusiasm, and for the Hindi translation possibly they had not a single person in Chikballapur knowing Hindi.
('39', 105, 1, 11, 200902) But let the other local reception committees profit by the unavoidable mistakes of Chikballapur.
('39', 105, 1, 12, 200999) Let them have previous rehearsals in checking their enthusiasm.
('39', 105, 1, 13, 201063) Let them translate it into purchases and hard work at the spinning wheel.
('39', 105, 1, 14, 201137) That would be an intelligent, profitable and national application of the energy created by the enthusiasm, and it would not only gladden their guest but will also strengthen his body, mind and soul.
('39', 105, 2, 15, 201336) INDECENT ADVERTISEMENTS
('39', 105, 3, 16, 201360) Lying on my back and trying at times, in obedience to medical instructions, to take my mind off serious reading, I chance upon advertisement sheets of newspapers.
('39', 105, 3, 17, 201523) They are sometimes painfully instructive.
('39', 105, 3, 18, 201565) I see often in respectable papers advertisements of a lewd nature.
('39', 105, 3, 19, 201632) The headings are deceptive.
('39', 105, 3, 20, 201660) In one case, the heading was Books Relating to Yoga.
('39', 105, 3, 21, 201713) On looking at the contents of the advertisement, I discovered hardly one book out of ten having any reference to yoga; all the rest had reference to sex, suggesting that young men and women may indulge in sexual pleasures without coming to grief, promising to divulge secret remedies.
('39', 105, 3, 22, 201998) I came upon worse things which I do not propose to copy in these pages.
('39', 105, 3, 23, 202070) Hardly a newspaper is free from liquor advertisements, and advertisements regarding medicines designed to debase and corrupt youthful minds.
('39', 106, 0, 1, 202211) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 107
('39', 106, 1, 2, 202256) The editors and the proprietors who are themselves known to be pure and opposed to drink, to smoking and such other evils, are at times found not to be averse to deriving an income from advertisements which are obviously intended to spread the evils which they shun.
('39', 106, 1, 3, 202523) The argument sometimes advanced is that it is not possible to conduct a newspaper on any other condition.
('39', 106, 1, 4, 202629) But is it necessary to conduct newspapers at any cost?
('39', 106, 1, 5, 202684) Is the good that they do so great as to outweigh the evil that mischievous advertisements cause?
('39', 106, 1, 6, 202781) We have a journalists association.
('39', 106, 1, 7, 202816) Is it not possible through it to cultivate a uniform code of morals among them and to create a public opinion that would make it impossible for a respectable journal to violate the prescribed code?

('39', 107, 5, 8, 204215) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, June 23, 1927
('39', 107, 6, 9, 204253) DEAR FRIEND, I hope you duly received my previous letter 1. You sent me your book at an opportune moment.
('39', 107, 6, 10, 204359) Whilst I am convalescing, I have nothing to do but read what little I can and dictate a few letters and a few articles.
('39', 107, 6, 11, 204479) I therefore took up your book with a view to learn the central fact of your programme, policy or teaching whatever it might be described as.
('39', 107, 6, 12, 204620) I have just finished it and I am now dictating this letter.
('39', 107, 6, 13, 204680) I am sorry to say that the book has not made any appeal to me.
('39', 107, 6, 14, 204743) What is true in it, I began doing in 1909 10 when for the satyagrahis of the Transvaal a friend gave me the use of 1,100 acres of land which he and I called Tolstoy Farm.
('39', 107, 6, 15, 204914) There we were doing exactly what you have suggested.
('39', 107, 6, 16, 204967) Boys and their relatives everyone was expected to work, and boys had some tuition, plenty of work and plenty of play.
('39', 107, 6, 17, 205085) If they were examined today some of them might perhaps say they would have preferred all play and no work, and the more modest ones might say they would have preferred more play and less work.
('39', 107, 6, 18, 205278) But I was unable to advance any claim on behalf of that colony which you advance on behalf of yours.
('39', 107, 6, 19, 205379) I wish that your claim could be sustained.
('39', 107, 6, 20, 205422) I very carefully studied the associations appeal to busy people.

('39', 107, 6, 22, 205529) 1 of the future, I fear, for a long time to come will remain a mere picture.

('39', 107, 6, 24, 205792) On going through the chapters, I find nothing of what these three countries are doing except a bare

('39', 108, 1, 5, 206148) I suppose, if you succeed (say) in converting Calcutta into a second New York with moving platforms and fourfold railways, etc., etc., and take me there to witness the marvellous performance, I should fall dead at the very sight of the thing.

('39', 108, 1, 13, 207483) But unfortunately or fortunately you have to deal not with machines but with bony, intelligent muscle each having its own individuality and each pulling its own way.

('39', 112, 5, 10, 213631) Do you want me to make public use of your letter and the facts contained in it, especially the fact that cows or bullocks are every day slaughtered for providing food for lions and tigers?
('39', 112, 5, 11, 213820) What is your authority for saying that I am against legislation altogether regarding cow slaughter prohibition?
('39', 112, 5, 12, 213932) I would like you to show me the statement ascribing to me the opinion which I have never held.
('39', 112, 5, 13, 214027) What I have said what I adhere to is that such legislation ought not to be embarked upon even in a Hindu State if an intelligent majority of the Mussalmans oppose it.
('39', 112, 5, 14, 214194) I have also added that legislation alone will not save the cow.
('39', 112, 5, 15, 214258) But I propose to deal with this subject fairly fully in the pages of Young India, which I expect you will see.
('39', 112, 6, 16, 214369) If you are desirous of discussing the subject more fully with me, all the friends who are interested in the question may come any day at 4 p.m.
('39', 112, 6, 17, 214513) except Monday.
('39', 112, 6, 18, 214528) To avoid delay, I suggest your making an appointment beforehand so that I should be ready to talk to you precisely at the appointed time.
('39', 112, 6, 19, 214666) Yours sincerely, SJT.

('39', 113, 1, 2, 214868) 121. LETTER TO WILLIAM SMITH
('39', 113, 2, 3, 214897) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, June 25, 1927
('39', 113, 3, 4, 214935) DEAR MR. SMITH, I have carefully gone through both your papers 1. They are interesting and useful for a sceptic.
('39', 113, 3, 5, 215048) I am a confirmed believer, but ill equipped, ignorant man.
('39', 113, 3, 6, 215107) I therefore want you to draw up for me and persons like meof this there is a respectable numbera tangible business scheme which will enable the reader to immediately put it into practice, if he has skilled assistance and money.
('39', 113, 3, 7, 215335) Could you therefore please give me such a scheme un embellished with argument?
('39', 113, 3, 8, 215414) It would give plan and specifications, an estimate of the cost of plants, machinery, etc., and the probable working cost of and returns from the enterprise.
('39', 113, 3, 9, 215571) I have been thinking deeply over what you and your men so kindly showed me at the Imperial Dairy Institute.
('39', 113, 3, 10, 215679) 2 I have several questions to ask.
('39', 113, 3, 11, 215714) But for the present, I would like to say that in order to make the institution answer Indian requirements, it needs an addition of two things.
('39', 113, 3, 12, 215857) There seems to be no facility for studying methods of castration.
('39', 113, 3, 13, 215923) The raising of the standard of the breed all over India seems to me to be impossible until the promiscuous herding of cows with bulls is done away with.
('39', 113, 3, 14, 216076) Castration seems to be the only remedy.
('39', 113, 3, 15, 216116) The indigenous method is hideously cruel.
('39', 113, 3, 16, 216158) Secondly, it seems to me that a dairy to satisfy Indian requirements has necessarily to become a tannery also.
('39', 113, 3, 17, 216269) Countries of the West have found a short cut to economic success by killing cattle which they consider to be a burden.
('39', 113, 3, 18, 216388) We in India have to deal with the economics of the cattle question subject to the limitation that cattle have to be supported even when they give inadequate or no return for their upkeep.
('39', 113, 3, 19, 216576) Hence I feel that a dairy scheme, which does not provide for and against this necessary limitation, must be faulty from an economic standpoint.
('39', 113, 3, 20, 216720) Whether the Imperial Institution can be expanded to cover these points or not, is not for me to say.
('39', 113, 3, 21, 216821) But could
('39', 113, 4, 22, 216831) 1 Dairies as an Indian Village Industry, dated January 3, 1927, and The Need for a Village Dairy Factory System in India, dated June 10, 1927 (S. N. 12926) 2 Vide Appendix Gandhiji at the Imperial Dairy, Bangalore, 23 6 1927.
('39', 114, 0, 1, 217057) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 115
('39', 114, 1, 2, 217102) you give me any guidance or recommend any literature on these points?
('39', 114, 1, 3, 217172) And generally what books will you suggest my studying in order to enable me the better to digest the information I have gathered during the few days visit to the Dairy?
('39', 114, 1, 4, 217341) If you have any literature in connection with the activities of the Imperial Dairy, and if it is saleable, I should like to buy it.
('39', 114, 1, 5, 217473) I cannot conclude this letter without thanking you for all the facilities you kindly gave me in connection with my visits to the Dairy.

('39', 115, 0, 1, 218521) 116 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 115, 1, 2, 218563) 123. NAVAJIVAN IN DEVANAGARI SCRIPT
('39', 115, 2, 3, 218599) I draw the attention of readers to the following letter 1 : I had received this letter as far back as in February.
('39', 115, 2, 4, 218714) I had preserved it intending to publish it when I had time for it; then came my illness and there was more delay.
('39', 115, 2, 5, 218828) The correspondents object is praiseworthy.
('39', 115, 2, 6, 218871) I am of the view that all Indian languages should be written in the Devanagari script, and I do not except the Dravidian languages and Urdu from this.
('39', 115, 2, 7, 219022) But I see difficulties in getting people to carry out this suggestion.
('39', 115, 2, 8, 219093) So long as there is hostility between Hindus and Muslims, no Muslim will write Urdu in the Devanagari script.
('39', 115, 2, 9, 219203) I am not suggesting that the Persian script should be given up, my idea is that common books in Urdu should be written in the Devanagari script.
('39', 115, 2, 10, 219348) At present, however, even this is bound to remain a mere idea.
('39', 115, 2, 11, 219411) But, without waiting for unity of hearts to be established between Hindus and Muslims, Gujarat, Bengal and other provinces can make a start if they wish to.
('39', 115, 2, 12, 219568) All good causes cannot be taken up by one person.
('39', 115, 2, 13, 219618) Even if anyone tried to take them up, he would only render himself ridiculous.
('39', 115, 2, 14, 219697) Someone else, therefore, should make this cause his own and devote all his time and energy to it.
('39', 115, 2, 15, 219795) However, readers of Navajivan can certainly prevail upon me to act upon one of the suggestions made by this correspondent.
('39', 115, 2, 16, 219918) If a majority of them approve of Navajivan being printed in the Devanagari script, I would immediately discuss the matter with my co workers.
('39', 115, 2, 17, 220060) I do not have the courage to take the initiative about this without knowing readers views.
('39', 115, 2, 18, 220151) I attach greater importance to propagating my ideas about problems over which I have reflected for many years and which I regard as very urgent, than to the popularizing of a script.
('39', 115, 2, 19, 220334) Navajivan has taken many risks in the past, but all of them were for the sake of fundamental principles.
('39', 115, 2, 20, 220439) I would not take the risk of affecting the circulation of Navajivan for the sake of the Devanagari script.
('39', 115, 2, 21, 220546) Among readers of Navajivan there are many women, as also some Parsis and Muslims.
('39', 115, 2, 22, 220628) I am afraid that all of them would find it difficult, if not impossible, to read the Devanagari script.
('39', 115, 2, 23, 220732) If my view is
('39', 115, 3, 24, 220746) 1 Not translated here.
('39', 115, 3, 25, 220769) The correspondent had suggested that Gandhiji should advocate the adoption of Devanagari as the common script for languages of North India and himself publish the Gujarati Navajivan in that script.
('39', 116, 0, 1, 220967) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 117
('39', 116, 1, 2, 221012) correct, I cannot print Navajivan in that script.
('39', 116, 1, 3, 221062) Since popularizing this script is not my special field of work, I feel that I cannot take the risk of making a start in this regard.
('39', 116, 1, 4, 221195) Even if the Gujarati Navajivan were published in the Devanagari script, the need for Hindi Navajivan would remain, for its readers cannot follow Gujarati.
('39', 116, 1, 5, 221350) But the correspondents suggestion is worth being adopted and deserves the support of newspapers, etc., It is also worth ascertaining the views of Navajivans readers about it, and that is why I have published his letter.
('39', 116, 1, 6, 221570) I would advise him not to rest content with writing the letter but, if he has the necessary time, to dedicate his life to propagation of his idea.
('39', 116, 1, 7, 221717) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 26 6 1927
('39', 116, 2, 8, 221754) 124. PHILANTHROPIC DOCTOR
('39', 116, 3, 9, 221780) ANTYAJAS FIRST I give below almost the whole of a letter which Shri Amritlal Sheth 1 has written to me describing how Doctor Lala Mathurdas visited Wadhwan and cured the eye diseases of hundreds of sufferers.
('39', 116, 3, 10, 221989) In former times, vaids 2 practised only for sevice.
('39', 116, 3, 11, 222041) They got enough for their livelihood from what the rich paid them, but that was not looked upon as their fee.
('39', 116, 3, 12, 222151) They believed that vaids duty was to treat the patients for their diseases, and that God would provide for their livelihood.
('39', 116, 3, 13, 222276) These days, and that God would provide for their livelihood.
('39', 116, 3, 14, 222337) These days, like others the vaids, the hakims 3 and the doctors, all the three classes, by and large, practise to make money.
('39', 116, 3, 15, 222463) But philanthropic doctors like Lala Mathurdas prove that all among them are not of that type.
('39', 116, 3, 16, 222557) The Arya Samaj has accepted the service of Antyajas as their special field of work; it is, therefore, not at all surprising that this good doctor felt very happy in serving them.
('39', 116, 3, 17, 222736) The workers in Wadhwan deserve commendation for giving priority to Antyajas.
('39', 116, 3, 18, 222813) As for Lala Mathurdas, what commendation can I offer him?
('39', 116, 3, 19, 222871) The account given in the following letter proves that the satisfaction he felt in serving others is his best reward.
('39', 116, 3, 20, 222988) I publish Shri Amritlals letter in the hope

('39', 118, 5, 10, 225472) 127. A LETTER [Before June 27, 1927] 1
('39', 118, 6, 11, 225511) Just as it is useless to brood over the past, even so, it is useless to speculate about the future.
('39', 118, 6, 12, 225611) One step enough for me, says the voice of wisdom.
('39', 118, 6, 13, 225661) What does it avail us to know the future?
('39', 118, 6, 14, 225703) Or why not merge both the past and the future into the present?
('39', 118, 6, 15, 225767) The present or the past does have a future.
('39', 118, 6, 16, 225811) And when change confronts us from moment to moment, to think of some remote future is buildng castles in the air.
('39', 118, 6, 17, 225925) And only a fool builds castles in the air.
('39', 118, 6, 18, 225968) The present means our duty at this moment.
('39', 118, 6, 19, 226011) If we put all our strength into doing our duty, as we know it at this moment, we shall have made the highest human effort.
('39', 118, 6, 20, 226134) Sorrow springs from dreaming of the future and from lamenting the past.
('39', 118, 6, 21, 226206) Hence one who concerns himself with the present and does his duty has neither birth nor death.
('39', 118, 7, 22, 226301) [From Gujarati]

('39', 120, 3, 6, 228133) Of course when I refer to the increase of distance between us, it will only mean the distance in our methods of thinking, never in feeling.

('39', 120, 3, 8, 228386) Of course I know that you are as much a seeker after Truth as I am.

('39', 120, 3, 10, 228701) So far as I know from discussions with you, I do not think you have such data for claiming finality about your conclusions or even [to] warrant preliminary inference.
('39', 120, 3, 11, 228868) Do you not think that we have got to be far more exacting about things which men equally earnest as ourselves have rejected after trial?

('39', 125, 3, 4, 236567) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter 1 for which I thank you.
('39', 125, 3, 5, 236624) I am sorry to have to report to you that the blood pressure taken on last Sunday week had been found to have risen from 150 to 160. The doctors could not make out why the increase had taken place.
('39', 125, 3, 6, 236821) I then gave them an ocular demonstration of what I had been doing in the way of sarvangasana, as also halasana, as you have termed the practice I described to you.
('39', 125, 3, 7, 236985) They urged me to stop the two practices for the time being.
('39', 125, 3, 8, 237045) 2 I therefore stopped them.

('39', 125, 3, 10, 237214) Last Sunday the blood pressure was taken again, and it was found to have gone down by five degrees.
('39', 125, 3, 11, 237314) I suppose, therefore, it is best for me to continue the suspension of the two practices for a while.
('39', 125, 3, 12, 237415) In any event, they will remain suspended till I hear from you.

('39', 125, 3, 17, 237778) Milk stands at 30 ounces.
('39', 125, 3, 18, 237804) I am now weighing the bhakharis I take, and the quantity I take weighs three ounces in a cooked condition.
('39', 125, 3, 19, 237911) In view of the tendency of the system towards an increase in blood pressure on the slightest provocation, do you want me to start bhujangasana?

('39', 125, 3, 23, 238402) It would be well if you could say which asanas are positively harmless, so far as blood pressure is concerned.

('39', 126, 1, 2, 238739) 138. LETTER TO ALVI
('39', 126, 2, 3, 238759) June 29, 1927 I have your straightforward letter.
('39', 126, 2, 4, 238809) 1 Of course, you have addressed it to the Editor but I shall not reply to it in Navajivan because the question you have raised is not likely to occur to many.
('39', 126, 2, 5, 238968) I suspect from your letter that your study of the Gita is not deep enough.
('39', 126, 2, 6, 239043) There is no difference, between nishkama karma 2 and tatastha karma 3 .
('39', 126, 2, 7, 239115) You take it for granted that a benevolent act is an unattached one.But non attachment and benevolence are two distinct qualities.
('39', 126, 2, 8, 239245) In this world one sees attachment in benevolence everywhere and hence numberless sins have been,are being and will be committed in the name of benevolence.
('39', 126, 2, 9, 239401) The reason why the Gita is dear to me is that the divine author has seen this distinction through experience and has in the course of his work endeavoured to explain it minutely and repeatedly in varying words and also in identical terms.
('39', 126, 2, 10, 239640) It was certainly no selfish act on my part to have helped the vegetarian movement, but despite this fact I looked upon it as my own rather than Gods; and where personal attachment develops there is no impartiality and no detachment.
('39', 126, 2, 11, 239873) Today I clearly see my attachment and desire in having been emboldened to deploy my clients money for that work because I regarded that work as my own.
('39', 126, 2, 12, 240025) Khadi work certainly is benevolent.
('39', 126, 2, 13, 240061) Suppose I have some money belonging to you and of course I intend to return it to you.
('39', 126, 2, 14, 240148) I may even be able to return it forthwith.
('39', 126, 2, 15, 240191) Now if I am carrying on khadi work without personal attachment, I would never use your money.
('39', 126, 2, 16, 240285) It should be my dharma to carry on the business of khadi only with the money specifically received for it.
('39', 126, 2, 17, 240392) And as long as that work can be carried on without attachment and desire, I would not make use of any other money.
('39', 126, 2, 18, 240507) Now you must have seen how in that case I lost my impartiality.
('39', 126, 2, 19, 240571) Had I used my own money, there would have been no difficulty.
('39', 126, 2, 20, 240633) Staying impartial does not mean withholding help.
('39', 126, 2, 21, 240683) Where one feels one should help and if one has the capacity, one should certainly do so; one should not however press into service anothers resources without his permission.
('39', 126, 2, 22, 240857) And even in seeking such permission one ought to be discreet.

('39', 130, 2, 6, 248554) 142. CHITTARANJAN SEVA SADAN Dr. Bidhan Chandra Roy, the celebrated physician of Calcutta and one of the trustees of the All Bengal Deshbandhu Memorial Trust, has issued an appeal for five lakhs of rupees for the Seva Sadan.
('39', 130, 2, 7, 248779) It will be remembered that this institution is situated on the ground which Deshbandhu in his lifetime had made over to the trustees.
('39', 130, 2, 8, 248913) The ground was partly encumbered.
('39', 130, 2, 9, 248947) It was redeemed out of the memorial funds that were collected immediately after Deshbandhus death, and for over a year, a well equipped and well managed hospital and a dispensary have been going on there.
('39', 130, 2, 10, 249152) The total number of the cases treated at the outdoor during the year was 22,000, new cases being 7,023. The total number of indoor patients was 579 with only 23 beds.
('39', 130, 2, 11, 249319) The trustees now propose to add 32 beds.
('39', 130, 2, 12, 249360) There can be no doubt that the institution supplies a felt want, and that it needs expansion.
('39', 130, 2, 13, 249454) Expansion means more money.
('39', 130, 2, 14, 249482) Those, who revere the memory of Deshbandhu, and who appreciate the necessity of rendering aid to the ailing, will not lose time in responding to the appeal issued on behalf of the Board of Trustees.

('39', 131, 1, 2, 250209) 143. BANGALORE KHADI EXHIBITION
('39', 131, 2, 3, 250241) C. Rajagopalachari and Gangadharrao Deshpande are making great preparations to make the forthcoming Khadi Exhibition at Bangalore a thorough success.
('39', 131, 2, 4, 250391) They are aiming not at quantity but quality, and so they have purposely restricted the scope.
('39', 131, 2, 5, 250485) It is to be therefore not an all India, but a South India Exhibition.
('39', 131, 2, 6, 250555) But they are inviting from all the provinces the assistance that may be necessary in order to complete the technical demonstration, and in order to make the Exhibition an instructive object lesson.
('39', 131, 2, 7, 250753) Those, therefore, who would learn all about the technique of khadi from hand ginning to hand weaving, and study the instruments used in the processes and to see them at work by skilled hands, will not fail to attend the Exhibition.
('39', 131, 2, 8, 250985) It is a happy augury for the future of khadi in Mysore that the State has given a donation of Rs. 500/ towards the expenses of the Exhibition, and that the Director of Industries has become a member of the Exhibition Committee.
('39', 131, 2, 9, 251213) Indeed the economic and the philanthropic side of khadi is so overwhelmingly important that it is a wonder that Rajas and Maharajas have not given the movement the support that it deserves.
('39', 131, 2, 10, 251403) Everybody agrees that millions of villagers require a supplementary occupation.
('39', 131, 2, 11, 251483) Scores of paper schemes are being hawked about the country for achieving village reconstruction.
('39', 131, 2, 12, 251580) But not one scheme has the universal application that khadi has.
('39', 131, 2, 13, 251645) And so far as I am aware, not one scheme is being tried on the scale that khadi is being tried.
('39', 131, 2, 14, 251741) It is not a small achievement to be able to show that the khadi scheme is at work in at least 1,500 villages.
('39', 131, 2, 15, 251851) That khadi has a political side to it need not frighten a single person, even though he may be an official.
('39', 131, 2, 16, 251959) Indeed many learned politicians laugh at khadi, when any political consequence is ascribed to it; and they would be right if the word political was used in connection with khadi in the same sense that it is used in connection with Councils.
('39', 131, 2, 17, 252200) Khadi has a political consequence precisely in the same sense that education has, co operative schemes have, temperance reform has.
('39', 131, 2, 18, 252332) It is impossible to avoid the political effect of any progressive measure that a nation may adopt.
('39', 131, 2, 19, 252431) The Viceroy, and the Rajas, Maharajas and everybody must, if they are not traitors to the country, take an active part in promoting Hindu Muslim unity, and yet nobody has ventured to laugh at the idea of Hindu Muslim unity having a tremendous political consequence; nor have I known anybody keeping himself aloof from the movement for promoting
('39', 132, 0, 1, 252776) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 133
('39', 132, 1, 2, 252821) that unity on the ground that it has a tremendous political consequence.
('39', 132, 1, 3, 252894) Indeed the full success of khadi and therewith its political effect depend upon the support of all, politicians and non politicians, the prince and the pauper, the zamindar and the ryot.
('39', 132, 1, 4, 253081) Every attempt is therefore being made to keep khadi above political turmoil.
('39', 132, 1, 5, 253158) It is not an emblem of revolt; but it is an emblem of self assertion, self reliance and determination to abolish artificial distinctions between rich and poor, between capital and labour, and establish a living bond between the two.
('39', 132, 1, 6, 253391) I am hoping, therefore, that the forthcoming Exhibition will receive the solid support of all classes of people, including the numerous European settlements in the cantonment of Bangalore.
('39', 132, 1, 7, 253580) That large population will be equally welcome with the rest.
('39', 132, 1, 8, 253641) Indeed in my talks with the European friends, who have kindly visited me during my convalescence at Nandi and at Bangalore,I have not hesitated to present the message of khadi, that is the message of Indias starving millions, for their acceptance.
('39', 132, 1, 9, 253889) One word to the fashionable people of Bangalore.
('39', 132, 1, 10, 253938) I observe a teacher of Trichinopoly has been pleading for the adoption of a minimum in sartorial matters.
('39', 132, 1, 11, 254044) I observed, also, that Sjt.
('39', 132, 1, 12, 254072) Srinivasa Sastri the other day at a public meeting remarked upon what might almost be called the over dress of the fashionable people of Bangalore.
('39', 132, 1, 13, 254220) And I have noticed on the part of those who believe in khadi a timid hesitation to adopt it in the face of the Bangalore fashion.
('39', 132, 1, 14, 254350) I plead for the necessary courage to set aside fashion, which can only be sustained at the expense of our starving neighbours.
('39', 132, 1, 15, 254477) By all means let monied people have tasteful ornamentation, whether in dress or in other surroundings; but I do plead for an observance, as between themselves and their starving brethren, of a due sense of proportion, such as is always observed in well ordered society.
('39', 132, 1, 16, 254747) Indias minimum is a langoti requiring less than 1/6th of a square yard.
('39', 132, 1, 17, 254819) Let our fashion have some correspondence to this minimum.
('39', 132, 1, 18, 254877) Let not those, who would raise this minimum, and multiply Indias wants in order to wake her up to action, think that they would achieve the end by first multiplying their own wants at the expense of the poor, and without in the same proportion enabling and inducing the latter to raise their standard of living.
('39', 132, 1, 19, 255189) One universal and effective and immediate way to enable and induce these millions to raise their standard of living is for the fashionable middle class to adopt khadi, and thereby put a few coppers into their pockets.
('39', 132, 1, 20, 255407) Many in Bangalore have given pecuniary contributions to khadi work.
('39', 132, 1, 21, 255475) But this is not enough.
('39', 132, 1, 22, 255499) Khadi cannot
('39', 133, 0, 1, 255512) 134 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 133, 1, 2, 255554) make real progress, unless there are people to wear it.
('39', 133, 1, 3, 255610) I therefore ask the people of Bangalore and neighbouring districts not merely to visit the Exhibition, and give the movement pecuniary support, but also to identify themselves with the poor by adopting khadi for their dress.

('39', 133, 3, 6, 255869) IN JUSTICE TO HER MEMORY The Modern Review 1 has a paragraph on what occurs in The Story of My Experiments with Truth, Chapter 19, Part III, 2 on Sister Nivedita.
('39', 133, 3, 7, 256032) After quoting my remarks, The Modern Review has :
('39', 133, 4, 8, 256082) The mention of the splendour that surrounded her without any other details conveys a wrong idea of Sister Niveditas mode of living.
('39', 133, 4, 9, 256214) The fact is, at the time when Mr. Gandhi saw her, she was the guest of Mrs. Ole Bull and Miss Josephine MacLeod at the American Consulate, and, as such, was not responsible for the splendour.
('39', 133, 4, 10, 256406) Her ascetic and very simple style of living in a tumbledown house in Bossepara Lane, Baghbazar, is well known to all her friends and acquaintances.
('39', 133, 5, 11, 256554) We do not know whether Mr. Gokhale spoke to Mr. Gandhi in English and actually used the word volatile to describe her; for what has appeared in Young India is translated from the Gujarati Navajivan.
('39', 133, 5, 12, 256753) But whoever may be
('39', 133, 6, 13, 256772) responsible for the use of the word volatile has wronged her memory.
('39', 133, 6, 14, 256841) Sister Nivedita had her defects, as in fact even the greatest of mankind had and have, but volatile she was not in any sense of that word.
('39', 133, 6, 15, 256980) As English is not our vernacular, we have consulted two dictionaries on our table to find out its exact meaning as applied to human beings.
('39', 133, 6, 16, 257120) The Pocket Oxford Dictionary defined it to mean of gay temperament, mercurial.
('39', 133, 6, 17, 257199) In Websters New International Dictionary the explanation given is, light hearted; airy; lively; hence, changeable; fickle.
('39', 133, 6, 18, 257322) Sister Nivedita was a very serious minded person, noted for her constancy and steadfast devotion to the cause of Hinduism and India.
('39', 133, 7, 19, 257455) The reference to her overflowing love for Hinduism is quite just and accurate.
('39', 133, 7, 20, 257534) I gladly reproduce this correction.
('39', 133, 7, 21, 257570) For I never knew the fact, till I saw the note in The Modern Review that I had met the deceased not at her own place but at a guests.
('39', 133, 7, 22, 257704) The reader has to recognize my

('39', 134, 1, 3, 257860) My reading is so poor that I have not read, much though I should like to have, the lives even of those who have contributed to the making of modern India.
('39', 134, 1, 4, 258015) My only consolation is that the poverty of my reading is not due to any laziness on my part, but a life of ceaseless action and full of tempest from early youth left not time for much reading.

('39', 134, 1, 9, 258609) I am therefore leaving out innumerable instances in life, which would be certainly otherwise interesting, as also references to several men and women.

('39', 134, 1, 12, 259069) I introduced Sister Nivedita, Swami Vivekananda, Maharshi Devendranath and others in the story simply to illustrate my desperate search, and to illustrate the point, that even then my political work in South Africa was an integral part of that search, which was never once subordinated to the political work.
('39', 134, 1, 13, 259378) It has therefore given me pleasure to reproduce the paragraph in The Modern Review at the very first opportunity after reading it.

('39', 141, 7, 16, 271357) 156. LETTER TO SANTOJI MAHARAJ
('39', 141, 8, 17, 271388) BANGALORE, Ashadh Sud 3 [July 2, 1927]
('39', 141, 9, 18, 271427) SHRI SANTOJI MAHARAJ, I have carefully preserved your questions, and with Gods grace I shall try to answer them now.
('39', 141, 9, 19, 271544) I enclose the question with this answer so that you may not have to take the trouble of recalling them and I may not have to copy them.
('39', 141, 9, 20, 271680) I have numbered them serially, and there should be, therefore, no confusion.
('39', 141, 9, 21, 271757) 1. Only he can interpret the Gita correctly who tries to follow its teaching in practice, and the correctness of the interpretation will be in proportion to his success in living according to the teaching.
('39', 141, 9, 22, 271963) The Gita was not composed as a learned treatise.
('39', 141, 9, 23, 272012) It may be a profound one, but in my view the realization of its profound quality depends on the depth of ones sincerity in puting its teaching into practice.
('39', 141, 9, 24, 272170) I have read Lokamanya Tilaks and Shankaracharyas commentaries and tried to understand them as well as I could.
('39', 141, 9, 25, 272281) I am not qualified to pronounce judgement on their learning.
('39', 141, 9, 26, 272342) If we accept the point of view
('39', 141, 10, 27, 272373) 1 Gandhiji was in Bangalore on this date in 1927.
('39', 142, 0, 1, 272423) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 143
('39', 142, 1, 2, 272468) I have suggested, the question of expressing an opinion on their learning does not arise.
('39', 142, 1, 3, 272558) The Gita is related to the Vedas and the Upanishads, for it gives the essence of both.
('39', 142, 1, 4, 272645) 2. The Gita teaches that one should cultivate the state of samatva 1 and explains with every manner of argument the means of doing so, namely, bhakti 2 accompanied with jnana 3 , that is, service of every living creature without thought of reward.
('39', 142, 1, 5, 272893) 3. The godly heritage, according to the Gita, is that which helps one to attain self realization.

('39', 151, 3, 12, 294909) Literacy, i.e., learning of books, acquisition of intellectual knowledge and useful manual work in various crafts are not different, though they may seem so.
('39', 151, 3, 13, 295067) Efforts to separate them and break the link that binds them together results in the misuse of knowledge.
('39', 151, 3, 14, 295172) The intellectual side of it is like husband and manual labour like his wife.
('39', 151, 3, 15, 295249) The bond between the two is indissoluble.
('39', 151, 3, 16, 295291) Divorced from manual labour this husband is today acting like a libertine.
('39', 151, 3, 17, 295366) He casts his evil eye here, there and everywhere and yet remains unsatisfied and in the end falls down tired and spent.
('39', 151, 3, 18, 295486) Indeed, if a comparison has to be made between the two, the first place will have to be given to manual work, for a child does not use his intelligence first but his hands and feet.
('39', 151, 3, 19, 295668) Gradually, he learns to use his eyes and ears and begins to understand things only when he is four or five years of age.
('39', 151, 3, 20, 295789) But this does not mean that with greater power of understanding he can neglect his body.
('39', 151, 3, 21, 295878) If he does so he will destory both the body and the mind.
('39', 151, 3, 22, 295936) The intellect finds its expression in action by the body.
('39', 151, 3, 23, 295994) Today the exercise of the body has come to be confined merely to gymnastics.
('39', 151, 3, 24, 296071) Formerly this need was satisfied by useful labour.
('39', 151, 3, 25, 296122) There is no suggestion that boys should not play games or take part in sports, etc.

('39', 151, 3, 27, 296280) Rather, there should be rest and relaxation of both the body and the mind.
('39', 151, 3, 28, 296355) There is no place for indolence in education.

('39', 152, 0, 1, 296439) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 153
('39', 152, 1, 2, 296484) knowledge of the three Rs, education must always be interesting.
('39', 152, 1, 3, 296549) If a boy gets bored either with reading and writing or craft work, the fault does not lie with him but with the method of education and the teacher.

('39', 152, 1, 5, 296824) An institution has been set up there which will start centres imparting literary education along with training in craft work.
('39', 152, 1, 6, 296950) Among the list of the sponsors of this institution I find the names of almost all the eminent British educationists.

('39', 152, 2, 13, 297812) To the extent that I could see how to carry them out and actually did carry them out they succeeded well.

('39', 153, 2, 3, 298779) The tragedy with us is that all of us teachers have been born and have grown up in an age when the accent is on literary education, and training in crafts is very much neglected.
('39', 153, 2, 4, 298958) And yet, some of us have detected this fatal flaw.

('39', 156, 1, 5, 304801) Let me then summarize the conclusions of workers in the service of Daridranarayana which you may test for yourselves if you will patiently study the literature that you will find on the Exhibition stalls as also the results of khadi activity which you will find demonstrated at those stalls.
('39', 156, 1, 6, 305093) The Prize Essay on Hand spinning by Messrs S. V. Puntambekar and N. S. Varadachari traces for you the history of the ruin of the only national and universal cottage industry of India as also the possibilities of its revival.
('39', 156, 1, 7, 305318) You will find it proved there that in this country there are millions of peasants who have no occupation for at least four months in the year, and that the only possible occupation for them in their own cottages in nothing but hand spinning.
('39', 156, 1, 8, 305560) Many good and well intentioned people have suggested most ambitious and attractive schemes of village reorganization.
('39', 156, 1, 9, 305678) But I make bold to say that not one of these schemes is at present in operation and that it is not possible to enforce any of them, at least during the lifetime of this generation; whereas, the spinning wheel has been making its silent but slow progress throughout the length and breadth of India.
('39', 156, 1, 10, 305976) Its revival dates from 1920 during which year, in spite of the forest of white caps one saw in the principal streets of cities, in reality there was not to be found khadi more than one lakh at the outside.
('39', 156, 1, 11, 306182) But the carefully prepared report of the All India Spinners Association for the last year will show you that during the year 1926 alone over Rs. 23 lakhs worth of khadi was produced throughout India and that the sales amounted to Rs. 28 lakhs.
('39', 156, 1, 12, 306426) Capital investment by the Association amounts to over Rs. 18 lakhs.
('39', 156, 1, 13, 306494) Fifty thousand spinners worked during the year under review for the production of this khadi.These spinners, before they took to hand spinning, had no other earnings or occupation during the time that they gave to spinning.
('39', 156, 1, 14, 306718) Their earnings have ranged from one pice to two annas per day according to the time they gave and the skill they put in it.
('39', 156, 1, 15, 306842) The very fact that fifty thousand women were eager to do this work for what may appear to us to be a miserable wage should be sufficient workable demonstration that hand spinning is not an uneconomic, profitless or unpractical

('39', 157, 1, 2, 307111) proposition.
('39', 157, 1, 3, 307124) In many instances women walk four miles to receive their cotton.
('39', 157, 1, 4, 307189) Round hand spinning as the centre have been built up many other occupations.
('39', 157, 1, 5, 307266) Weavers, dhobis, dyers, printers and carders who had either died out or were dying out have found in the revival of hand spinning a new hope.
('39', 157, 1, 6, 307408) One new weaver and one new carder comes into being against ten spinners and their wages are anything between four annas and one and a half rupees per day.

('39', 166, 3, 4, 325065) MANILAL AND SUSHILA, I got your cable.
('39', 166, 3, 5, 325104) You must have received my reply to it.
('39', 166, 3, 6, 325143) You must have got my letters even before my reply to the cable.
('39', 166, 3, 7, 325207) But I sent the cable as I thought that would make both of you happier, especially Sushila.
('39', 166, 3, 8, 325298) If Manilal alone were there, I would not have spent money on a cable and would have rebuked him for wasting money on one.
('39', 166, 3, 9, 325420) But considering that Sushila was in foreign country, that she has never been abroad before now and that, therefore, she would be happy to hear from me, I thought it proper to send a cable.
('39', 166, 3, 10, 325609) I am glad to know that both of you would like to receive letters from me, but at the same time I should like to make it clear that, if you do not receive one, you should not suppose that my failure to write was due to indifference or carelessness.
('39', 166, 3, 11, 325857) It may be that I cannot find the time to write because of pressure of work, or that I miss writing because I do not remember the date on which the mail leaves.
('39', 166, 3, 12, 326017) If I am ill, you will have somehow heard about it.
('39', 166, 3, 13, 326068) But now I shall be more careful about writing.
('39', 166, 3, 14, 326115) Sushila should forget her attachment to her parental home.
('39', 166, 3, 15, 326174) We ought always to remember our parents, but it is not possible to live for ever with them.
('39', 166, 3, 16, 326266) A son cannot do so.
('39', 166, 3, 17, 326286) How, then, is it possible for a daughter?
('39', 166, 3, 18, 326328) Her home is with her husband.
('39', 166, 3, 19, 326358) Sushila should, therefore, understand that her home is where Manilal is and learn to live like Savitri 2 .
('39', 166, 3, 20, 326465) She should protect herself and also protect Manilal.
('39', 166, 3, 21, 326518) In both of you maintaining simplicity, truthfulness, compassion and patriotism, despite the many temptations surrounding you, in your observing self restraint as befits you and protecting each others body and character lies the success of your marriage.
('39', 166, 3, 22, 326772) Sushilas physical strength does not seem to have increased in proportion to the increase in her weight.
('39', 166, 3, 23, 326876) There is only one way of increasing it : that she should eat nothing but wholesome food, and only as much as can be digested, and take as much physical exercise in the open air as she can without getting exhausted, and that both of you should refrain, as much as possible, from sexual indulgence.

('39', 168, 2, 3, 329241) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, July 6, 1927
('39', 168, 3, 4, 329278) DEAR FRIEND, I have your confidential letter of the 13th June last with the enclosures.
('39', 168, 3, 5, 329366) I appreciate the honour you have done me by sending me your draft Bill, and I beg to tender my thanks to those members of the Independent Labour Party who have worked at the Bill.
('39', 168, 3, 6, 329546) I am however unable to give any effective advice or guidance as my work for the present lies in a different direction.
('39', 168, 3, 7, 329665) I am devoting the whole of my energy to developing internal strength.
('39', 168, 3, 8, 329735) I have therefore very little time left for studying the question what form the final constitution should take.
('39', 168, 3, 9, 329846) I do not in any shape or form discount the importance of that question.
('39', 168, 3, 10, 329918) But I know my own limitations, and so, as far as possible, I help the movement towards arriving at a suitable constitution by non interference and sympathetic watch.
('39', 168, 3, 11, 330084) But I take it that you have circulated the draft Bill among many other public men in India and invited their opinion.
('39', 168, 3, 12, 330202) If at any time I feel that I can do any useful work in this connection, I shall not hesitate to correspond with you.

('39', 168, 7, 17, 330429) 172. LETTER TO GIRIRAJ KISHORE
('39', 168, 8, 18, 330460) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, July 6, 1927
('39', 168, 9, 19, 330497) MY DEAR GIRIRAJ, I have your letter.
('39', 168, 9, 20, 330534) I like your heart searching.
('39', 168, 9, 21, 330563) There is always one danger in this process.
('39', 168, 9, 22, 330607) A man who is not self possessed becomes morose and imagines all kinds of things about himself.
('39', 168, 9, 23, 330702) This is the state of a hypochondriac.
('39', 168, 9, 24, 330740) Do you know what that would means in the medical world?
('39', 168, 9, 25, 330796) It means a person who imagines every disease to be in
('39', 169, 0, 1, 330850) 170 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 169, 1, 2, 330892) himself of which he reads a description.
('39', 169, 1, 3, 330933) Whilst, therefore, it is the most proper thing to rid oneself of any weakness of which one is conscious there must be nothing imagined and there should be no brooding.
('39', 169, 1, 4, 331101) Instead of saying to yourself, I am wretched, so evil and I shall never be good, the proper formula is, I will be good; for, God is good and merciful; He will make me good. The first formula is weakening and the second is invigorating.
('39', 169, 1, 5, 331337) Your statement that an ideal cook is he who feels about the diners as a mother does for her children is perfect.
('39', 169, 1, 6, 331450) It is of course difficult to feel like that; but by practice everything becomes easy.
('39', 169, 1, 7, 331536) Be patient with everybody, return a kind answer to every enquiry and give up the last chapati and the last spoonful of dal, even though there may be nothing left for you and those who may be the last to dine being waiters.
('39', 169, 1, 8, 331759) You may prepare something for yourself to satisfy hunger.
('39', 169, 1, 9, 331817) This may mean additional time.
('39', 169, 1, 10, 331848) Never mind it.
('39', 169, 1, 11, 331863) And, therefore, cooks and waiters should never have any fixed appointments after the completion of kitchen work.
('39', 169, 1, 12, 331976) There must always be wide margin left for emergencies.
('39', 169, 1, 13, 332031) You must not regard yourself as unfit for the work.
('39', 169, 1, 14, 332083) A man who wants to do work for society and in society, that is, in company with others, has to have practically the same qualities whether it is in the kitchen or in the sanitary yard or in the weaving shed, and no man becomes a worthy human being unless he has gone through these purifying fires.
('39', 169, 1, 15, 332381) I, therefore, want you to compose yourself completely, and find your satisfaction in your work, dealing with every emergency that may arise.
('39', 169, 1, 16, 332522) I know that all this is esay enough to say.
('39', 169, 1, 17, 332566) It is not so easy to practise.
('39', 169, 1, 18, 332597) Nevertheless all our learning and everything we do has to be done in order to arrive at this equableness.
('39', 169, 1, 19, 332703) I hope, therefore, you will never accept defeat.
('39', 169, 1, 20, 332752) Do please write to me whenever you like.
('39', 169, 1, 21, 332793) Always try to cultivate a compact style.
('39', 169, 1, 22, 332834) But if you cannot say what you want to, briefly, I do not mind even your long letters.
('39', 169, 1, 23, 332921) But it will be a good practice for you after having written your long letter to reduce it to a quarter and see whether you cannot say the same thing in quarter length.
('39', 169, 2, 24, 333089) Yours sincerely, GIRIRAJ KISHORE ASHRAM SABARMATI

('39', 170, 7, 17, 334192) 174. LETTER TO LILIAN EDGER
('39', 170, 8, 18, 334220) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, July 6, 1927
('39', 170, 9, 19, 334257) DEAR FRIEND, Krishnadas has handed your letter to me and the yarn sent with it.
('39', 170, 9, 20, 334337) The yarn is not at all bad.
('39', 170, 9, 21, 334365) It can of course be more even.
('39', 170, 9, 22, 334396) I do not think that age is a bar.
('39', 170, 9, 23, 334430) I know many as old as you who have taken to spinning and who have become very good spinners.
('39', 170, 9, 24, 334523) No doubt it requires much patience in the beginning.
('39', 170, 9, 25, 334576) You have asked me whether the small quantities that you spin can be of any help to the poor.
('39', 170, 9, 26, 334669) I say unhesitatingly, Yes. This does not mean that the yarn you may be sending will be separately woven into khadi and sent to the poor.
('39', 170, 9, 27, 334806) That is not what we are doing with the yarn contribution we are receiving.
('39', 170, 9, 28, 334881) But what we are doing is to convert such yarn into khadi, and utilize the proceeds of the sale of that khadi for providing spinning and other ancillary work to the poor
('39', 171, 0, 1, 335050) 172 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 171, 1, 2, 335092) people.
('39', 171, 1, 3, 335100) This is the very best help can be rendered to them.
('39', 171, 1, 4, 335152) I quite agree with you that it is difficult for individuals to distribute their charity judiciously.
('39', 171, 1, 5, 335253) The vast majority of street beggars are mere professional idlers when they are not much worse, and those who have money to spare do an ill service to these beggars and to the country by giving them money, food or clothing.
('39', 171, 1, 6, 335476) We have found by experience that we do no service by distributing amongst poor people khadi prepared from yarn contributions.
('39', 171, 1, 7, 335602) The chief need is neither food nor clothing but work which they can do in their cottages.
('39', 171, 1, 8, 335692) But where it becomes necessary to provide clothing side by side with work, we do not hesitate to do so.
('39', 171, 1, 9, 335796) But that happens only in rare cases.
('39', 171, 1, 10, 335833) The chief value, in my opinion, of any person spinning by way of sacrifice lies in the work itself, and in the promotion of the work atmosphere that is created in the country and in the promotion of a tangible feeling for the poorest in the land.
('39', 171, 1, 11, 336080) Now for your questions : 1. It is wrong to draw the thread and the twist.
('39', 171, 1, 12, 336154) The thread must be drawn whilst the spindle is revolving rapidly round its own centre.
('39', 171, 1, 13, 336241) This movement ensures the proper twist.
('39', 171, 1, 14, 336281) Drawing of the yarn and the movement of the spindle go on simultaneously so that there is no difficulty about continuously drawing the thread with ease.
('39', 171, 1, 15, 336434) And whilst the thread is being drawn the sliver is held fairly tight between the fingers so that the twist does not reach the thread up to the very end which is held between the fingers.
('39', 171, 1, 16, 336621) 2. Wax has to be used occasionally for the mal, that is the chord that goes round the wheel and the spindle.
('39', 171, 1, 17, 336730) 3. Oil has not to be used very often.
('39', 171, 1, 18, 336768) The ordinary machine oil [can] serve the purpose.
('39', 171, 1, 19, 336818) But in the absence of that, a drop of the ordinary cooking oil is quite serviceable.
('39', 171, 1, 20, 336903) An occasional drop on the axle where it touches the uprights and on the holders which hold the spindle makes for smooth movement.
('39', 171, 1, 21, 337033) 4. It will be better to wind off after an hours spinning.
('39', 171, 1, 22, 337091) Those who can spin very rapidly unwind every 20 minutes.
('39', 171, 1, 23, 337148) When in unwinding the thread tangles, you know that the cone has not been made tight.
('39', 171, 1, 24, 337234) If your yarn is well twisted, you can wind it round the spindle each time fairly tight and the cone should feel hard to the touch and not at all soft.
('39', 171, 1, 25, 337385) 5. When the chord breaks and if you cannot twist a chord out of your own yarn, you can use any bazaar twine of the diameter of your chord.
('39', 172, 0, 1, 337524) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 173
('39', 172, 1, 2, 337569) Lastly, if you will become a good spinner and if you will spin for sacrifice, it is really necessary for you to watch someone who spins well.
('39', 172, 1, 3, 337711) Wherever you may be whether in Kashi or Darbhanga, there is no difficulty about your getting proper assistance.
('39', 172, 1, 4, 337823) Wishing you every success in your effort,
('39', 172, 2, 5, 337865) Yours sincerely,

('39', 173, 2, 3, 339461) [Before July 7, 1927] 1
('39', 173, 3, 4, 339485) Your questions are really very good but among the readers of Young India and Navajivan few would be eager for a casuistical enquiry into this question.
('39', 173, 3, 5, 339637) I shall therfore rest content with answering you alone.
('39', 173, 3, 6, 339693) Sir Jagadish Chandra Boses theory is not new.
('39', 173, 3, 7, 339739) Our Shastras recognize the presence of life in plants as in human beings.
('39', 173, 3, 8, 339813) Certainly therefore the statement that life lives on life is established by facts.
('39', 173, 3, 9, 339896) And this is the one reason why the body is regarded as an appendage of the atman and its absence essential for the supreme state of the atman.
('39', 173, 3, 10, 340039) Although all life must be embodied only through some sort of violence, the question still remains what form of life should comprise lifes food.
('39', 173, 3, 11, 340183) Human physiology as well as the experience of the wise shows that the right food for us is the fruit ripened on the tree and suchlike.
('39', 173, 3, 12, 340318) The pure seeker will not use even fire.
('39', 173, 3, 13, 340358) We may not reach this ideal state, yet it is our duty to strive for it as far as we can, and in this our endeavour meat eating can have no place.
('39', 173, 3, 14, 340504) [Feeding on] plant life should be the limit for us.
('39', 173, 3, 15, 340556) 2. I can say from my own experience and that of others that there is absolutely no danger of tuberculosis and such other diseases resulting from vegetarian diet even in countries like England.
('39', 173, 3, 16, 340749) Today thousands of Englishmen are vegetarians, [though] usually they do take eggs.
('39', 173, 3, 17, 340832) 3. Vegetarian restaurants make use of egg and milk; they neither serve nor cook meat.
('39', 173, 3, 18, 340918) They place eggs and milk in the same category and agree that it would be better to give up both as neither is a vegetable.
('39', 173, 3, 19, 341041) This is my opinion too.
('39', 173, 3, 20, 341065) Barring mothers milk during infancy man has no right to take milk.
('39', 173, 3, 21, 341132) I shall say something about this in Young India.
('39', 173, 3, 22, 341181) You will find it in the course of the autobiography.
('39', 173, 3, 23, 341234) Till now it was my belief that every egg could be hatched.
('39', 173, 3, 24, 341293) Now I learn from experts that a hen lays eggs even without mating and that such eggs cannot be hatched.
('39', 173, 3, 25, 341397) These eggs are as much without life and therefore as unobjectionable as milk.
('39', 173, 3, 26, 341475) Now I am wondering whether eggs may not have a place in a vegetarian diet since milk is included.
('39', 173, 3, 27, 341573) But this much I do know that from the
('39', 173, 4, 28, 341611) 1 From the reference to the discussion about milk in the Autobiography (Pt. IV, Ch. VIII), which appeared in Young India, 7 7 1927

('39', 174, 1, 2, 341787) standpoint of brahmacharya eggs are to be eschewed as are many vegetables too.
('39', 174, 1, 3, 341866) But this is a digression.
('39', 174, 1, 4, 341892) Today I am considering eggs purely from the point of view of vegetarian diet.

('39', 174, 5, 8, 342064) DESHBANDHU DAY AT DARJEELING The reader will be glad to share the following with me from Mrs. Blair from Darjeeling :

('39', 174, 6, 12, 342670) Later on they may feel worthy to become members of the A.I.S.A. 1 At present they are going to spin wool in order to be able to give warm clothes in the winter to the Baby Clinic and the Hospital.

('39', 175, 1, 8, 344601) ADI KARNATAKAS All the readers of Young India may not know who Adi Karnatakas are.
('39', 175, 1, 9, 344684) They are the suppressed classes of Karnatak.
('39', 175, 1, 10, 344729) Just as at the Raniparaj Conference, friends of the Raniparaj altered the name Kaliparaj to the more appropriate name Raniparaj, so the suppressed classes all over India have been not unnaturally taking for themselves names which have no bad odour about them.
('39', 175, 1, 11, 344989) In this spirit the suppressed classes in Karnatak describe themselves as Adi Karnatakas.

('39', 175, 2, 16, 345635) There are altogether 16,575 students of this class receiving tuition in Mysore.
('39', 175, 2, 17, 345715) An attempt is being made to organize a co operative agricultural scheme with due provision of land, live stock and direction.
('39', 175, 2, 18, 345841) The paragraphs end with the following suggestion :
('39', 175, 3, 19, 345892) These people ought to be the strength of our strength.

('39', 175, 4, 23, 346054) The aim should be to Hinduize them more and more, for they belong to the Hindu community, and to offer them every facility to remain within the fold.
('39', 175, 4, 24, 346204) They will be a mighty accession to the strength of our body politic; if not, they will be an equally heavy subtraction from it.
('39', 175, 4, 25, 346332) Alienated, they will introduce an additional element of heterogeneity which will further complicate the already difficult problems of administration.

('39', 176, 2, 6, 347116) 178. THE COW IN MYSORE
('39', 176, 3, 7, 347139) I have received letters from Cow protection Societies in Mysore, protesting against my letter 1 to the Mysore Cow protection Committee appointed by the State.
('39', 176, 3, 8, 347298) My letter was in answer to a questionnaire issued by that Committee.
('39', 176, 3, 9, 347367) Extracts from that letter published in the Madras Press led the Cow protection Societies in question to think that I was totally against legal prohibtion of cow slaughter under any circumstances whatsoever.
('39', 176, 3, 10, 347574) I was surprised to receive these letters, and I wondered whether, in a moment of inadvertence, I had ever said that there should never be any legislation against cow slaughter.
('39', 176, 3, 11, 347751) I therefore asked for a copy of my letter from the Cow protection Committee, which they have kindly sent me.
('39', 176, 3, 12, 347860) As the letter represents my considered opinion, and as it has been given some importance by the Committee and has caused misunderstanding among the public of Mysore interested in this every important question, I reproduce the whole of it below : 2
('39', 176, 4, 13, 348108) Neither the discussion with the members of the several Cow protection Societies, nor the correspondence before me warrants any alteration of the opinion expressed in this letter.
('39', 176, 4, 14, 348287) The reader will observe that I have nowhere said that there should never be any legislation against cow slaughter.
('39', 176, 4, 15, 348402) But what I have said is that there should be no prohibition of cow slaughter by legislation without the consent of the intelligent majority of the subjects adversely affected by it.
('39', 176, 4, 16, 348584) Therefore, the Mysore State will be perfectly justified, and, indeed, bound to undertake legislation prohibiting cow slaughter, if it has the
('39', 176, 5, 17, 348726) 1 Vide Letter to Cow Protection Committee, Mysore, 11 1 1927.
('39', 176, 6, 18, 348788) 2 Not reproduced here
('39', 177, 0, 1, 348810) 178 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 177, 1, 2, 348852) consent of the intelligent majority of its Mussalman population.
('39', 177, 1, 3, 348917) The members of the Cow protection Societies that met me assured me that the relations between Hindus and Mussalmans in Mysore were cordial, and that a majority of Mussalmans in Mysore were as much in favour of legislative prohibition as Hindus, and I was glad to be assured by them that many Europeans, especially missionaries, were in favour of such prohibition.
('39', 177, 1, 4, 349281) So far, therefore, as the question of legislation in Mysore is concerned, if the statements made to me are correct, the way is clear for legislative prohibition.
('39', 177, 1, 5, 349443) But let me reiterate what I have pointed out in my letter, and what I have emphasized so often in these columns, namely, that legislative prohibition is the smallest part of any programme of cow protection.
('39', 177, 1, 6, 349650) The trend of the letters received by me, and the activity of most Cow protection Societies, however, show, that they would be satisfied with mere legal prohibition.
('39', 177, 1, 7, 349815) I wish to warn all such societies against staking their all on legislation.
('39', 177, 1, 8, 349891) We have already too much of it in this law ridden country.
('39', 177, 1, 9, 349950) People seem to think that when a law is passed against any evil, it will die without any further effort.
('39', 177, 1, 10, 350055) There never was a grosser self deception.
('39', 177, 1, 11, 350097) Legislation is intended and is effective against an ignorant or a small evil minded minority; but no legislation which is opposed by an intelligent and organized public opinion, or under cover of religion by a fanatical minority, can ever succeed.
('39', 177, 1, 12, 350345) The more I study the question of cow protection, the stronger the conviction grows upon me, that protection of the cow and her progeny can be attained, only if there is continuous and sustained constructive effort along the lines suggested by me.
('39', 177, 1, 13, 350592) There may be, probably there is, room for supplementing or amending the constructive programme sketched by me.
('39', 177, 1, 14, 350703) But there is no room for doubting the absolute necessity of a vast constructive programme if Indias cattle are to be saved from destruction.
('39', 177, 1, 15, 350844) And the preservation of cattle really means also a step towards the preservation of the starving millions of Indias men and women who have also been reduced to the condition of her cattle.
('39', 177, 1, 16, 351033) The Indian States undoubtedly can in this as in many such matters give the lead to the rest of India.
('39', 177, 1, 17, 351135) And among the States, probably, there is none better fitted, or better able, to make the right beginning than Mysore.
('39', 177, 1, 18, 351253) It has, from all accounts received by me, a popular prince, an enlightened public opinion, no Hindu Mussalman question, and a sympathetic Dewan.
('39', 177, 1, 19, 351398) Mysore has also the Imperial Institute of Dairying and Animal Husbandry, and Mr. William Smith, the Imperial Dairy Expert, is himself stationed at Bangalore.
('39', 177, 1, 20, 351556) The State has, therefore, all the
('39', 178, 0, 1, 351590) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 179
('39', 178, 1, 2, 351635) materials necessary for evolving a constructive policy.
('39', 178, 1, 3, 351691) Add to this the fact that Nature has endowed Mysore with a glorious climate.
('39', 178, 1, 4, 351768) The title a Hindu king dearly cherishes is that of defender of the cow and the Brahmin.
('39', 178, 1, 5, 351856) The cow means not merely the animal, the giver of milk and innumerable other things to India, but it means also the helpless, the downtrodden and the poor.
('39', 178, 1, 6, 352012) Brahmin means the representative of divine knowledge and experience.
('39', 178, 1, 7, 352081) But today, alas!
('39', 178, 1, 8, 352098) Hindu princes are powerless, and in many cases even indifferent, if not unwilling, to ensure this full protection.
('39', 178, 1, 9, 352213) Unless the States and the people co operate with one another to control and regulate the breeding of cattle, the production of milk supply, and the disposal of dead cattle, for the benefit of the people as a whole, the cattle of India will be bred but to die an unnatrual death at the hands of the butcher, notwithstanding all the legislation that may be passed against cow slaughter.
('39', 178, 1, 10, 352598) The ignorance of Natures Law will be accepted as no excuse when men and women of India appear before the Throne of Judgment.
('39', 178, 1, 11, 352723) I was shocked to learn from the members of the Cow protection Society that beef slaughtered in Bangalore and in Mysore was given to the animals in the State gardens, that beef was much cheaper than any other meat, and that the Adi Karnatakas, who claimed to be and were recognized as Hindus, and who knew the Ramayana and the Mahabharata as well as any other Hindu, were addicted to beef eating.
('39', 178, 1, 12, 353119) If all this is true, the better placed Hindus are clearly to blame for such a state of things.

('39', 178, 1, 14, 353311) But what is to be said of the Hindus who have so criminally neglected their brethren as to omit to acquaint them with a fundamental truth of Hinduism?

('39', 178, 2, 16, 353484) 179. WHAT IS A POLITICAL ASSOCIATION?
('39', 178, 2, 17, 353522) I read the following in The Hindu of the 25th June last :
('39', 178, 3, 18, 353580) Under Rule 23 (1) of Government Servants Conduct Rules, Government have, I understand, prohibited Government servants from subscribing to the Khadi Fund, which is in aid of the All India Spinners Association.
('39', 178, 3, 19, 353789) The reasons for this prohibition are stated to be, (1) that it is an association, established with the consent of the All India Congress Committee, as an integral part of the Congress organization, (2) that it declares itself prepared to receive and acknowledge yarn subscriptions for membership of the Congress and (3) that therefore it must be regarded as a political association.
('39', 179, 0, 1, 354172) 180 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 179, 1, 2, 354214) If the information supplied by the special correspondent of The Hindu is correct, the ruling of the Madras Government appears to me to be a case of perverted judgement,and a gross interference with the private liberty of its servants.
('39', 179, 1, 3, 354449) If it is intended merely as an attack upon khadi or the All India Spinners Association, I have no doubt that both will survive the shock.
('39', 179, 1, 4, 354587) And if it is an invitation to the All India Spinners Association to sever its connection with the Congress, I should be extremely sorry if I discovered that the Association had done anything to deserve such an invitation.
('39', 179, 1, 5, 354809) The Association is proud of its being an integral part of the Congress organization, and it will deem it an honour and a privilege to work under the Congress banner, so long as that venerable national institution regards it as worthy of its patronage.
('39', 179, 1, 6, 355061) But if by merely owning the parentage and patronage of the Congress an institution becomes a political association, the interpretation would involve most awkward conequences, which I hope no self respecting Government servant will tolerate.
('39', 179, 1, 7, 355302) There are many schools for suppressed class children run in several provinces under the Congress aegis, and with Congress funds, to which Government servants also have been known to contribute without any secrecy.
('39', 179, 1, 8, 355516) Was it wrong for them to do so?
('39', 179, 1, 9, 355548) And are schools for untouchables political bodies, because they are run with Congress funds and by Congressmen?
('39', 179, 1, 10, 355660) Provincial Congress Committees have been known to open famine relief funds, and invite subscriptions to which Government servants have subscribed.
('39', 179, 1, 11, 355807) Was it a breach of Government Servants Conduct Rules?
('39', 179, 1, 12, 355861) These relief committees were and the suppressed class committees are integral parts of the Congress organization.
('39', 179, 1, 13, 355975) Are they, therefore, political associations?
('39', 179, 1, 14, 356020) The Congress may open hospitals as an integral part of the Congress organization and its activity.
('39', 179, 1, 15, 356119) Will the hospitals therefore become political associations?
('39', 179, 1, 16, 356179) Khadi is at the present moment an integral part of the Congress franchise.
('39', 179, 1, 17, 356254) Is it a crime therefore for Government servants to wear it?
('39', 179, 1, 18, 356314) Is it not possible for the Congress to have its political, its social, its moral, its economic, medical, sociological and such other departments, all integral parts of that organization, and yet wholly self governing and wholly independent each of the others?
('39', 179, 1, 19, 356574) Every Congressman regrets that the Congress, although among all the national bodies it is the most influential and the most important, is not yet able to command men and money enough to organize every department of national life.
('39', 179, 1, 20, 356804) But as time goes on, and as it is able to draw to it men of the right stamp, as well as
('39', 180, 0, 1, 356892) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 181
('39', 180, 1, 2, 356937) money, it will certainly touch every part of our national life.
('39', 180, 1, 3, 357001) It would be ridiculous then to say that all its non political activities became tainted with politics, and were therefore taboo to the Government servants.
('39', 180, 1, 4, 357157) And if the Government dared to issue such a boycott, it would prove to be its own death warrant.
('39', 180, 1, 5, 357254) I am painfully conscious of the fact that the Congress is a long way off from attaining that height.
('39', 180, 1, 6, 357355) But when it does, the Government, will be absorbed by it, and there will be nobody to resent, resist, or in terfere with the Congress influence.
('39', 180, 1, 7, 357500) That the Government has been ableassuming that the information given in The Hindu is correct to regard the All India Spinners Association as a political association, shows that the Congress influence is at a discount at the present moment, that the public voice is ineffective, and that therefore it is open for the Government to issue any ruling, no matter how insulting or how ridiculous it may be.
('39', 180, 1, 8, 357901) I can only hope that there will be Government servants courageous enough to disregard this monstrous ruling and openly help the Spinners Association this monstrous ruling and openly help the Spinners Association which in spite of the Government order, I submit, is entirely a non political body, and was in so many words intended by the Congress to be and to remain, for the reasons stated in the resolution which brought the Association into being.
('39', 180, 1, 9, 358351) Here are the words of the resolution which is part of the constitution of the All India Spinners Association :
('39', 180, 2, 10, 358462) Whereas the time has arrived for the establishment of an expert organization for the development of hand spinning and khaddar, and whereas experience has shown that such development is not possible without a permanent organization, unaffected and uncontrolled by politics, by political changes or political bodies, an organization called the All India Spinners
('39', 180, 3, 11, 358823) Association is hereby established with the consent of the All India Congress Committee, as an intergral part of the Congress organization, but with independent existence and powers.
