('39', 181, 2, 4, 359961) 180. WORK BEFORE PINJRAPOLES
('39', 181, 3, 5, 359990) Y. M. Parnerkar, whose services have been engaged on behalf of the All India Cow protection Association, has sent me notes of his impressions gathered from his visit to Kathiawar where he went in search of good cows.
('39', 181, 3, 6, 360207) In the hope that his plea for the expansion of pinjrapoles into model dairies and cattle breeding farms on a moderate scale and under skilled management will not fall upon deaf ears, I condense them below.
('39', 181, 3, 7, 360413) One thing that strikes most a lover of cattle when he visits Kathiawar, the home of the well known Gir animals, is the enormous number of charitable institutions, run as retiring plac es for desabled cattle, chiefly cows.
('39', 181, 3, 8, 360635) They are known as pinjrapoles.
('39', 181, 3, 9, 360666) When they were first started there was not the deep poverty that faces us today.
('39', 181, 3, 10, 360747) It was then a matter of little importance, whether they were economically managed or not.
('39', 181, 3, 11, 360837) But today the condition is altered.
('39', 181, 3, 12, 360873) No such institution can now hope for long to stand well, unless it is put on a sound financial basis.
('39', 181, 3, 13, 360975) The longevity of pinjrapoles could only be guaranteed if they became self supporting.
('39', 181, 3, 14, 361061) It was found that nearly eight lakhs of rupees per year were spent as recurring expenses only in Kathiawar on these institutions.
('39', 181, 3, 15, 361191) Yet it is difficult, if not impossible, to secure even a few good cows in home for the best milk producing cow in all India.
('39', 181, 3, 16, 361316) This tract, once overflowing with milk, produces now hardly any pure and hygienic cows milk.
('39', 181, 3, 17, 361409) The once warlike race of Kathis is now deteriorating for want of proper nourishment, notwithstanding plentiful grazing facilities for cattle breeding.
('39', 181, 3, 18, 361560) Bullocks for agricultural labour are imported by the cultivators from outside.
('39', 181, 3, 19, 361639) The buffalo is over powering the cow in the production of milk and ghee, and so driving her off the stage.
('39', 181, 3, 20, 361746) Time has come for the best brains of the country to take up this very important problem.
('39', 181, 3, 21, 361835) There can be no two opinions on the point that the duty of
('39', 182, 0, 1, 361894) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 183
('39', 182, 1, 2, 361939) the gosevak does not end with merely saving the cow from the butchers knife, but he has to stop the deterioration and try to raise the standard of milk production.
('39', 182, 1, 3, 362103) It could be said that the surest way of saving the cow from going to the slaughter house is to make it so expensive that the butcher cannot afford to purchase it.
('39', 182, 1, 4, 362266) This could only be done, when the cow finds a good place among the paying heads in a dairymans or a cattle breeders ledger.
('39', 182, 1, 5, 362390) The productive power of an average Indian cow has gone down so low that it is difficult for a business man to take up the work.
('39', 182, 1, 6, 362518) The problem has therefore to be handled on a religious or national basis.
('39', 182, 1, 7, 362592) The work can be accomplished by the existing pinjrapoles.
('39', 182, 1, 8, 362650) They have capital, buildings, and above all, public sympathy.
('39', 182, 1, 9, 362712) What is needed is good management and enterprise.
('39', 182, 1, 10, 362762) When a pinjrapole maintains about 100 or 200 retired cattle, it can add a few good cows that will support themselves and leave a margin for the other heads.
('39', 182, 1, 11, 362919) If the cows are well kept, regularly bred to good bulls, and the calves well cared for, during a short period these should become places where the dairyman can purchase his foundation stock, the agriculturist may get his draft cattle, the fancy cattle keeper the use of a good bull, the needy man his sick animals well treated, the ignorant cow owner guidance in the best way of maintaining his live stock, and what is more important, all from the child in the cradle to the old man on the deathbed may get pure milk and its nourishing products at moderate rate.

('39', 182, 2, 13, 363504) 181. AGES OLD PROBLEM A sannyasi from Almora writes as follows : In replying to a correspondent, you have said in Young India of 14th
('39', 182, 3, 14, 363638) April last that, even if you were attacked by a snake, you would not wish to kill it.
('39', 182, 3, 15, 363724) 1 In my opinion, this would be improper; for in the first place, you would be thereby killing yourself, and secondly, by letting such a venomous reptile free, you would be instrumental in causing injury to others.
('39', 182, 3, 16, 363938) Take another instance.
('39', 182, 3, 17, 363961) If the owner of a house, in which a snake has entered, removed the snake without killing it from his house, it is sure to enter some other house and injure its inmates.
('39', 182, 3, 18, 364130) Surely, the responsibility for the injury, it
('39', 182, 4, 19, 364176) 1 Vide Faith v.
('39', 182, 4, 20, 364192) Reason, 14 4 1927.
('39', 183, 0, 1, 364211) 184 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 183, 1, 2, 364253) may fatal, to the inmates of the other house, done by the snake that was let off, will be on the head of him who has under a false notion of pity let the snake off.
('39', 183, 1, 3, 364418) There are many other reptiles, beasts and insects who injure human beings or spread disease.
('39', 183, 1, 4, 364511) Surely, if the destruction of this life be considered himsa, then it is infinitely less than the destruction wrought by these creatures.
('39', 183, 1, 5, 364648) Let it be granted that when a man kills for his own sake, it is himsa;
('39', 183, 2, 6, 364719) but it cannot be when destruction is resorted to for the sake of saving many other precious lives.
('39', 183, 2, 7, 364818) After all, the quality of an act is determined by the motive prompting it, and when the motive for destruction is the higher good, such desctruction becomes a duty and ceases to be himsa.
('39', 183, 2, 8, 365006) I would like you to answer this argument in the pages of Young India.
('39', 183, 3, 9, 365076) The Sannyasis argument is ages old.
('39', 183, 3, 10, 365112) There is no doubt that there is very considerable force in it.
('39', 183, 3, 11, 365175) Had it not been so, destruction would not have gone on as it has from ancient times.
('39', 183, 3, 12, 365260) Few men are wantonly wicked.
('39', 183, 3, 13, 365289) The most heinous and the most cruel crimes of which history has record have been committed under cover of religion or equally other noble motive.
('39', 183, 3, 14, 365435) But in my opinion, we are no better off for the destruction that has gone on even under the highest sanction, that is, or religion.
('39', 183, 3, 15, 365567) No doubt destruction in some form or other of some life is inevitable.
('39', 183, 3, 16, 365638) Life lived upon life.
('39', 183, 3, 17, 365660) Hence only is the highest bliss attainable ascribed by seers to a state, in which life is possible without the necessity of a perishable case, for whose sustenance destruction becomes at all necessary.
('39', 183, 3, 18, 365862) And it is possible for man whilst in the body to hope to attain that state, only if he confines himself to the least possible destruction, such as is caused in his taking of vegetable life.
('39', 183, 3, 19, 366052) The freer he is, consciously and deliberately, from the necessity of living upon the destruction of other life, the nearer he is to Truth and God.
('39', 183, 3, 20, 366199) That all mankind is not likely to accept what may appear to be an unattractive existence does not affect the validity of my argument.
('39', 183, 3, 21, 366333) Men, who lead this life of utter selflessness and of pity for the meanest creature that lives, enable us to understand the power of God, and serve as leaven to lift up humanity, and light its path towards its goal.
('39', 183, 3, 22, 366548) We have no right to destroy life that we cannot create.
('39', 183, 3, 23, 366604) It seems to me to be atheistical to think that God has created some life only to be destroyed by man, either for his pleasure or for sustaining a body, which he knows, is after all doomed to death any moment.
('39', 183, 3, 24, 366813) We do not know what part the many so called noxious creatures play in the economy of Nature.
('39', 183, 3, 25, 366906) We shall never know the laws of Nature by destruction.
('39', 183, 3, 26, 366961) We have records of men, whose love has travelled beyond their kind, living in perfect safety even in the midst of ferocious
('39', 184, 0, 1, 367085) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 185
('39', 184, 1, 2, 367130) beasts.
('39', 184, 1, 3, 367138) There seems to be so much affinity between all life, that tigers, lions and snakes have refrained from harming men, who have shed all fear of them and will approach them as friends.
('39', 184, 1, 4, 367320) The argument that if I do not destroy a snake known to be venomous, he will cause the death of many men and women is deceptive.
('39', 184, 1, 5, 367448) It is no part of my duty to set about seeking out all the venomous creatures and destroying them.
('39', 184, 1, 6, 367546) Nor need I take it for granted, that if I do not destroy a snake I encounter, it is bound to bite the next passer by.
('39', 184, 1, 7, 367664) I must not be the judge between the snake and my neighbours.
('39', 184, 1, 8, 367725) I have sufficiently discharged my duty to my neighbours if I do unto them as I would that they should do unto me, and if I do not expose them to any greater risk than I do myself, and if I do not better my own condition in any way whatsoever at their expense.
('39', 184, 1, 9, 367985) I may not therefore leave the snake in my neighbours compound as is very often done.

('39', 189, 7, 17, 379929) 185. SPEECH AT KHADI EXHIBITION, BANGALORE 1
('39', 189, 8, 18, 379974) July 8, 1927
('39', 189, 9, 19, 379987) Distribution of prizes over, amidst an impressive silence, Mahatmaji spoke as follows :
('39', 189, 10, 20, 380075) FRIENDS, Perhaps the best demonstration that you can all give of your interest in these proceedings is as soon as this function is over for you to proceed to the Exhibition Court and empty the stalls.

('39', 190, 1, 8, 381679) Just think for one moment what our country is : 700,000 villages, in a vast continent, 1,900 miles long, 1,500 miles broad, and these villages even according to Western pandits handed down to us from times immemorial.
('39', 190, 1, 9, 381897) America is a new continent.
('39', 190, 1, 10, 381925) They have millions of acres of land lying absolutely fallow and a sparse population.
('39', 190, 1, 11, 382010) There were no villages when the people from old England went to America, when Columbus went to America, not of the type you find here, and they brought into being a new civilization.
('39', 190, 1, 12, 382193) It may be that it is the most per fect of its kind for that soil, but what is good for the virgin soil of America need not, cannot, in my opinion is not, good for this ancient soil, watered by its mighty rivers, protected by the highest mountain peaks, and inhabited by people, the most conservative on the face of the globe, having traditions of their own, habits and customs which cannot be eradicated on the spur of the moment.
('39', 190, 1, 13, 382624) Then I say that if you think that you will import the city civilization from the West and eradicate your villages you can do so on one condition, the condition of Chengizkhan, fabled in history.
('39', 190, 1, 14, 382819) I do not know what Chengizkhan did or did not do.

('39', 190, 1, 16, 383304) But if you want to keep your villages intact, if you want to assimilate the best that we may

('39', 191, 1, 3, 383627) I do not know whether you have been touched as I have been by the sight of these prize winners who do not know the distinctions bet ween Brahmin and non Brahmin, Hindus and Mussalmans, rich and poor.

('39', 193, 7, 15, 388365) He thanked them for the threefold pleasure of having given to the self appointed representative of Daridranarayana a purse not to be counted, of listening in South
('39', 193, 8, 16, 388529) India to Hindi exquisitely pronounced and rendered and of seeing the majority of actors dressed in khadi, and said : The actors have realized the pain I feel when I do not see a single countryman of mine in khadi, be he a prince or a peasant, a lawyer, a doctor or a business man, be the person a man or woman, belonging to the highest or the lowest strata of society.

('39', 193, 8, 19, 389280) Young India, 21 7 1927
('39', 193, 9, 20, 389303) 1 From Mahadev Desais Weekly Letter 2 According to Mahadev Desais Diary
('39', 194, 0, 1, 389375) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 195
('39', 194, 1, 2, 389420) 189. TWO SCALES Writing about a girl, who had been married by her thoughtless parents while she was still a child and had never come to know her husband, and who had later become a widow, I had expressed the view that I would not regard her as married at all, and that, apart from the question whether she should be regarded as married or not, it was the duty of her parents to get her married again.
('39', 194, 1, 3, 389821) Reading about this view in newspapers, a gentleman has written a long letter to me in Hindi to the following effect : The reasons which you advance to justify the remarriage of child widows will also apply to other widows.
('39', 194, 1, 4, 390044) Would you, then, encourage all widows to remarry?
('39', 194, 1, 5, 390094) I would urge that we should prohibit even widowers from remarrying and should not in any case permit widows to remarry.
('39', 194, 1, 6, 390214) Men have committed through the ages a great many sins with the help of arguments such as these.
('39', 194, 1, 7, 390310) I have come across meat eaters who argue that, since man is obliged to eat meat in the region of the North Pole where the land is snow bound all through the year, it is not sinful to eat meat in this country too, despite the heat here.
('39', 194, 1, 8, 390546) We easily find arguments to justify sinful practices.
('39', 194, 1, 9, 390600) Widowers will not refrain from remarrying, but under cover of the argument that they should, we are urged to withhold justice from widows.
('39', 194, 1, 10, 390739) Those who have made us unfit for swaraj now tell us: You will get swaraj when you are fit for it. We who have suppressed and degraded the untouchables say : Let reform themselves and then mix with us. Like a dishonest Vania, men keep two scales, one for buying and another for selling things with.
('39', 194, 1, 11, 391037) They feel their own weaknesses, huge as hills, to be as small as mustard seed and regard the weaknesses of others, small like grains, to be as big as hills.
('39', 194, 1, 12, 391194) If men use reason, they will see that they have no right to suppress widows.
('39', 194, 1, 13, 391271) Enforced widowhood is not virtue but sin.
('39', 194, 1, 14, 391313) It covers up a disease which breaks out with the opportunity for contact with a man.
('39', 194, 1, 15, 391398) If a grown up woman who has become a widow does not even feel the desire to remarry, she deserves to be revered by the whole world, she is a pillar of dharma.
('39', 194, 1, 16, 391557) But one who wishes to remarry and refrains from doing so out of fear of society or is restrained by law, has already remarried in thought.
('39', 194, 1, 17, 391696) She deserves not reverence but
('39', 195, 0, 1, 391727) 196 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 195, 1, 2, 391769) compassion and should be free to remarry.
('39', 195, 1, 3, 391811) In former times she was free.
('39', 195, 1, 4, 391841) Following custom slavishly, so called high caste Hindus turned this voluntary dharma into a law and introduced coercion in dharma.
('39', 195, 1, 5, 391972) Justice required that, so long as widowers have the right to remarry, widows too should have it.
('39', 195, 1, 6, 392069) Certain restrictions are necessary for the protection of society, but they should be the same for both men and women and should command the willing consent of all thinking women as of all thinking men.
('39', 195, 1, 7, 392271) We should not forget the difference between child widows and other widows.
('39', 195, 1, 8, 392346) It is the duty of parents and of society to get the former married again, but they have no such duty towards other widows.
('39', 195, 1, 9, 392469) In their case, all that is necessary is to remove the present restraint enforced by custom or law.
('39', 195, 1, 10, 392568) In other words, if such widows wish to remarry they should be free to do so.
('39', 195, 1, 11, 392645) The only restraint over the remarriage of grown up widowers and widows can be that exercised by public opinion.
('39', 195, 1, 12, 392757) That public opinion is now flowing in the opposite direction.
('39', 195, 1, 13, 392819) Where, however, respect for dharma, discipline and self control is widespread, very few men and women will violate them.
('39', 195, 1, 14, 392940) As things are, people who respect them are exceptions rather than the rule.
('39', 195, 1, 15, 393016) A rich old man of sixty feels no shame in marrying a girl of ten or twelve, the marriage being the third in his life, and society tolerates this.
('39', 195, 1, 16, 393162) When on the other hand, a helpless widow of twenty wishes to remarry because she cannot observe self control, despite her efforts, she is despised by society.
('39', 195, 1, 17, 393321) This is not dharma but adharma 1. It is useless and irrelevant to point to immorality and like evils prevailing in other countries as an argument against the removal of this coercion, this adharma.
('39', 195, 1, 18, 393519) Even if all widows, from child widows to widows of sixty, were as pure as the immaculate Sita, I would say that if any of them wanted to remarry nobody had the right to stop them from doing so.
('39', 195, 1, 19, 393713) Society may plead with them with love, but it has no right to restrain them by force.
('39', 195, 1, 20, 393799) If we apply to others the yardstick which we use for ourselves, the world would be freed of the threefold suffering and dharma would prevail once again.
('39', 195, 1, 21, 393952) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 10 7 1927
('39', 195, 2, 22, 393989) 1 The opposite of dharma

('39', 199, 1, 2, 399756) 192. SPEECH AT ALL KARNATAKA HINDI CONFERENCE, BANGALORE 1
('39', 199, 2, 3, 399815) July 10, 1927
('39', 199, 3, 4, 399829) The All Karnataka Hindi Sammelan held its session this afternoon at the Majestic Theatre before a vast concourse of people.
('39', 199, 3, 5, 399953) At about 3 p.m.
('39', 199, 3, 6, 399969) Mahatmaji arrived and conducted the proceedingss of the day.
('39', 199, 3, 7, 400030) He then distributed the diplomas to the successful candidates at the last Hindi examination, one of whom was a lady who had obtained a I Class.
('39', 199, 3, 8, 400174) After distribution of prizes Mahatmaji, before speaking in Hindi, wanted to know how many would like the speech to be in English.
('39', 199, 3, 9, 400304) The audience to a man raised their hands and Mahatmaji smiling next asked them by the same means to signify whether they wanted Kanarese translation to which also there was assent even from the ladies gallery.
('39', 199, 3, 10, 400514) He then spoke in Hindi and his speech was translated to the audience by Mr. Gangadharrao Deshpande.
('39', 199, 3, 11, 400614) After dealing with the usefulness of the movement, Mahatmaji [said :] 2
('39', 199, 4, 12, 400686) India is divided into two parts today, and the portion north of the Vindhya has no heart relations with the southern portions.
('39', 199, 4, 13, 400813) It is the duty of the South to learn the language of the North which is far larger.
('39', 199, 4, 14, 400897) When I find it easy to travel from Sind to Bengal with the little bit of my knowledge of Hindi, it is impossible in these parts to get along without English.
('39', 199, 4, 15, 401055) Unless you learn Hindi, you will not break through the Vindhya that stands between the South and the North.
('39', 199, 4, 16, 401163) I do not want you to ignore your vernacularsyou may be as proud of them as I am of minebut if we would be Indians and not merely Gujaratis, Bengalis, Tamilians or Karnatakas, we ought to learn Hindi.
('39', 199, 4, 17, 401363) It is not difficult to learn.
('39', 199, 4, 18, 401393) Those who have learnt it have not taken more than six months studying two hours a week.
('39', 199, 4, 19, 401481) I appeal to you to devote that brief period to the service of the motherland.
('39', 199, 4, 20, 401559) Different from the question of a lingua franca is that of a common script.

('39', 201, 2, 3, 403770) Silence Day, July 11, 1927 Your letter.
('39', 201, 2, 4, 403810) You will, of course, have to consider what Kakasaheb says.
('39', 201, 2, 5, 403869) You want to enjoy the full bliss of brahmacharya immediately but this cannot be done.
('39', 201, 2, 6, 403955) If you are content with forgoing marriage then do not marry.
('39', 201, 2, 7, 404016) If not, make arrangements for getting married.
('39', 201, 2, 8, 404063) You are no stranger to the difference between contentment and bliss.
('39', 201, 2, 9, 404132) The idea of merging into each other if you find an ideal wife is itself a great illusion.
('39', 201, 2, 10, 404222) Many have been deluded by it and it will be no wonder if you too are lost.
('39', 201, 2, 11, 404297) If you will escape it till the end, that would be a matter for wonder.
('39', 201, 2, 12, 404368) Having seen us all married people, if you are convinced that it is not worth while following suitand convinced you ought to begive up for the present the desire to taste the joy of brahmacharya and ponder over the joylessness of marriage, if you have observed it.
('39', 201, 2, 13, 404632) Continue to think on this lineGod alone knows what bliss there is to be enjoyed in brahmacharya, but because there is no joy in marriage, I am not going to marry at all. Here is an argument on a lower level : I would not say I dont want to marry.
('39', 201, 2, 14, 404879) Indeed, under certain circumstances I may marry.
('39', 201, 2, 15, 404928) But today my country is in bondage; plight of the women is miserable.
('39', 201, 2, 16, 404998) As I am engaged in this work, how can I marry?
('39', 201, 2, 17, 405045) I must take this vow that until we attain the swaraj of my conception, I shall not marry even if Rambha 1 were to solicit me. Try to think in this way if you can.
('39', 201, 2, 18, 405208) Formulate your definition of swaraj.
('39', 201, 2, 19, 405245) I suggest a simple one : The day when the spinning wheel spreads throughout India and there is complete boycott of foreign cloth. If you find this hard to work upon, write out one you like and vow not to marry until that is attained and put up a copy in your room where everyone can see it.
('39', 201, 2, 20, 405536) Send one to Kakasaheb and one to me.
('39', 201, 2, 21, 405573) If you can do neither try this thought.
('39', 201, 2, 22, 405613) I do have a desire to marry and it cannot be suppressed.
('39', 201, 2, 23, 405670) But I will not marry a girl of my caste as I would not marry my own sister.
('39', 201, 2, 24, 405746) I will insist on breaking the barriers of caste.
('39', 201, 2, 25, 405795) The girl must know Sanskrit, Marathi, Hindi and Gujarati; she should not hanker after money; if her parents are alive
('39', 201, 3, 26, 405913) 1 A celestial nymph
('39', 202, 0, 1, 405933) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 203
('39', 202, 1, 2, 405978) we must have their consent.
('39', 202, 1, 3, 406006) She must have absolute love of khadi; she must appreciate and have faith in my other ideals and love the untouchables, be strong of body and prepared to live in some remote village and be willing to honour the well known discipline of brahmacharya in marriage. If you cannot do even this, know that you will not be able to observe brahmacharya and therefore marry at the first opportunity.
('39', 202, 1, 4, 406396) If you resolve to observe the above discipline, write down the vow and proceed as before.
('39', 202, 1, 5, 406486) But then what I have suggested to you is only the way of worshipping a Deity conceived with form and attributes.
('39', 202, 1, 6, 406599) Observance of brahmacharya for the sake of attaining inviolate brahmacharya is like worshipping One without attributes.
('39', 202, 1, 7, 406719) It is difficult for all of us.
('39', 202, 1, 8, 406750) I have pointed out to you the path that I myself took.

('39', 202, 1, 13, 407315) Only the perfect can give a perfect account.

('39', 202, 1, 16, 407512) Neither Kakasaheb nor I, in fact no one who has known married life, is competent to answer your question from personal experience.

('39', 203, 9, 15, 408694) MY DEAR RAIHANA, In the abstract, there can be no doubt that you have a right to wear whatever you like and to see or be seen by any friends you like.
('39', 203, 9, 16, 408845) But when it comes to reducing an abstract right to concrete practice, innumerable things present themselves for consideration.
('39', 203, 9, 17, 408972) And my advice is that in everything you do, you should possess confidence enough to bear down all opposition and to be able to convince everybody around you of the justice of your action.
('39', 203, 9, 18, 409160) Do you reason with mother with the same frankness that you show in your letters to me?

('39', 203, 9, 23, 409432) The last one I am preserving till I receive your answer.
('39', 203, 9, 24, 409489) From what I know of them and the manner in which they have brought up their children, it seems to me that they are most considerate, liberal minded parents and will not interfere with the independence of their grown up children.

('39', 205, 1, 14, 413020) I am showing my scheme at work in 1,500 villages and I can only wish that it was multiplied so as to reach 700 thousand and still the result will be constant.

('39', 209, 2, 8, 420636) 201. SPEECH AT INDIAN INSTITUTE OF SCIENCE, BANGALORE [July 12, 1927] 1
('39', 209, 3, 9, 420708) I was wondering where do I come in?

('39', 209, 3, 11, 420839) I am not in a mood to say much.
('39', 209, 3, 12, 420871) All I can say is that all these huge laboratories and electrical apparatus you see here are due to the labourunwilling and forcedof millions.
('39', 209, 3, 13, 421013) For Tatas thirty lakhs did not come from outside, nor does the Mysore contribution come from anywhere else but this begar 2 world.
('39', 209, 3, 14, 421144) If we were to meet the villagers and to explain to them how we are utilizing their money on buildings and plants which will never benefit them, but might perhaps benefit their posterity, they will not understand it.
('39', 209, 3, 15, 421360) They will turn a cold shoulder.
('39', 209, 3, 16, 421392) But we never take them into our confidence, we take it as a matter of right, and forge that the rule of no taxation without representation applies to them too.
('39', 209, 3, 17, 421552) If you will really apply it to them, and realize your responsibility to render them an account, you will see that there is another side to all these appointments.
('39', 209, 3, 18, 421715) You will then find not a little but a big corner in your hearts for them, and if you will keep it in a good, nice condition, you will utilize your knowledge for the benefit of the millions on whose labour your education depends.
('39', 209, 3, 19, 421944) I shall utilize the purse you have given me for Daridranarayana.
('39', 209, 3, 20, 422009) The real Daridranarayana even I have not seen, but know only through my imagiation.
('39', 209, 3, 21, 422093) Even the spinners who will get this money are not the real Daridranarayana who live in remote corners of distant villages which have yet to be explored.
('39', 209, 3, 22, 422246) I was told by your professor that the properties of some of the chemicals will take years of experiments to explore.
('39', 209, 3, 23, 422363) But who will try to explore these villages?
('39', 209, 3, 24, 422407) Just as some of the experiments in your laboratories go on
('39', 209, 4, 25, 422466) 1 From The Hindu, 13 7 1927
('39', 209, 5, 26, 422494) 2 Forced labour
('39', 210, 0, 1, 422510) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 211
('39', 210, 1, 2, 422555) for all the twenty four hours, let the big corner in your heart remain perpetually warm for the benefit of the poor millions.
('39', 210, 1, 3, 422681) I expect far more from you than from the ordinary man in the street.
('39', 210, 1, 4, 422750) Dont be satisfied with having given the little you have done, and say, We have done what we could, let us now play tennis and billiards. I tell you, in the billiard room and on the tennis court think of the big debt that is being piled against you from day to day.
('39', 210, 1, 5, 423015) But beggars cannot be choosers.
('39', 210, 1, 6, 423047) I thank you for what you have given me.
('39', 210, 1, 7, 423087) Think of the prayer I have made and translate it into action.
('39', 210, 1, 8, 423149) Dont be afraid of wearing the cloth the poor women make for you, dont be afraid of your employers showing you the door if you wear khadi.
('39', 210, 1, 9, 423287) I would like you to be men, and stand up before the world firm in your convictions.
('39', 210, 1, 10, 423371) Let your zeal for the dumb millions be not stifled in the search for wealth.
('39', 210, 1, 11, 423448) I tell you, you can devise a far greater wireless instrument, which does not require external research, but internal and all research will be useless if it is not allied to internal research which can link your hearts with those of the millions.
('39', 210, 1, 12, 423694) Unless all the discoveries that you make have the welfare of the poor as the end in view, all your workshops will be really no better than Satans workshops, as Rajagopalachari said in a joke.
('39', 210, 1, 13, 423886) Well I have given you enough food for thought, if you are in a reflective mood, as all research students ought to be.
('39', 210, 2, 14, 424004) In concluding, he [said that] they must keep the lamp of their love for the
('39', 210, 3, 15, 424080) motherland and her children always bright, trim, and steady.

('39', 210, 4, 17, 424166) they deserved the knowledge and the advantage they were deriving from the Institute.

('39', 211, 2, 3, 424397) July 13, 1927 Those who want a message from me must not be surprised to receive the same message again and again; for, I have nothing new.
('39', 211, 2, 4, 424536) Let the editor, the proprietor and the staff of The Searchlight as also the readers do their quota of work for the millions, that it, let them wear nothing but khadi; let them exclude all foreign cloth from their use; let them give as much as they can towards khadi work; and let them spin at least for half an hour good, even and weavable yarn and make a present of it to the All India Spinners Association in the name of and on behalf of Daridranarayana.

('39', 216, 5, 9, 432913) 210. A LETTER
('39', 216, 6, 10, 432927) Ashadh Shukla 14 [July 13, 1927] 1
('39', 216, 7, 11, 432962) Tulsidas has left nothing unsaid about the greatness of His name.
('39', 216, 7, 12, 433028) The Dwadasha mantra, 2 the Ashtakshara 3, etc., bring peace to the victim of infatuation, and one should rely upon whatever mantra brings one peace.
('39', 216, 7, 13, 433177) But for one who has never experienced peace and is in quest of it, Ramanama will certainly prove a parasmani 4. God has been given a thousand names which only means that he can be called by any name and that his qualities are infinite.
('39', 216, 7, 14, 433413) That is why God is also beyond nomenclature and free from attributes.
('39', 216, 7, 15, 433483) But for us mortals the support of His name is absolutely essential to fall back upon and in this age even the ignorant and the illiterate can have recourse to an Ekakshara mantra 5 in the form of Ramanama.
('39', 216, 7, 16, 433689) In fact, uttering Ramanama covers the Ekakshara and there is no difference between Om and Rama.
('39', 216, 7, 17, 433785) But the value of reciting His name cannot be established by reasoning, it can only be experienced if one does it with faith.
('39', 216, 8, 18, 433910) MOHANDAS GANDHI

('39', 217, 3, 7, 434582) 212. INTERVIEW TO MR. AND MRS.
('39', 217, 3, 8, 434613) BJERRUM 2
('39', 217, 4, 9, 434623) [Before July 14, 1927]
('39', 217, 5, 10, 434646) Among the new missionary friends is a Danish couple Mr. and Mrs. Bjerrum .
('39', 217, 5, 11, 434721) Gandhiji was at his wheel when the friends came.
('39', 217, 6, 12, 434770) MR. BJERRUM : This is a new wheel different from the ones we saw at the Exhibition.
('39', 217, 7, 13, 434854) GANDHIJI : Yes, it is a travelling charkha.
('39', 217, 7, 14, 434898) When you fold it, it looks like a medicine chest, and a medicine chest it is for our poor people.
('39', 217, 8, 15, 434996) After giving their pleasant impressions of the Exhibition, Mr. Bjerrum began to talk of the students of his college.
('39', 217, 8, 16, 435113) The dress of most of our students is Europeanized, he informed Gandhiji not without some sorrow.
('39', 217, 9, 17, 435210) GANDHIJI : It is a great pity that Christianity should be mixed up with foreign dress and foreign ways of eating and drinking.
('39', 217, 10, 18, 435337) BJERRUM : It is indeed.
('39', 217, 10, 19, 435361) But dont you think a change has already begun?
('39', 217, 11, 20, 435408) GANDHIJI : Well, a change in thought is certainly coming over, but not a corresponding change in conduct.
('39', 217, 12, 21, 435514) And with this he narrated some of his experiences with the friends of the Y.M.C.A. of Calcutta.
('39', 217, 13, 22, 435610) MR. BJERRUM : May we know what form in your opinion missionary work
('39', 217, 14, 23, 435678) should take if the missionaries are to stay in India?
('39', 217, 14, 24, 435732) [GANDHIJI] : Yes.
('39', 217, 14, 25, 435750) They have to alter their attitude.
('39', 217, 14, 26, 435785) Today they tell people that there is no salvation for them expcept through the
('39', 217, 15, 27, 435864) 1 From Mahadev Desais Weekly Letter 2 ibid.
('39', 218, 0, 1, 435908) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 219
('39', 218, 1, 2, 435953) Bible and through Christianity.
('39', 218, 1, 3, 435985) It is customary to decry other religions and to offer their own as the only that can bring deliverance.
('39', 218, 1, 4, 436089) That attitude should be radically changed.
('39', 218, 1, 5, 436132) Let them appear before the people as they are, and try to rejoice in seeing Hindus become better Hindus and Mussalmans better Mussalmans.
('39', 218, 1, 6, 436270) Let them start work at the bottom, let them enter into what is best in their life and offer nothing inconsistent with it.
('39', 218, 1, 7, 436392) That will make their work far more efficacious, and what they will say and offer to the people not as patrons, but as one of them, not to oblige them but to serve them and to work among them.
('39', 218, 2, 8, 436584) MR. BJERRUM : Thank you.
('39', 218, 2, 9, 436609) We are going to Denmark next year and would like to take some message from you.
('39', 218, 2, 10, 436689) [GANDHIJI] : The external is always an expression of the internal, and if the people of Denmark would serve us, let them teach us their life giving industry of co operative dairy and cattle breeding.
('39', 218, 2, 11, 436889) Young India, 14 7 1927
('39', 218, 3, 12, 436912) 213. REFORM OF PINJRAPOLE
('39', 218, 4, 13, 436938) It has been my privilege during my convalescence at Bangalore to pay regular visits to the Imperial Animal Husbandry and Dairy Institute, and to take there, what may be called, regular lessons.
('39', 218, 4, 14, 437132) Mr. William Smith, who is the Imperial Dairy Expert and Head of this Institute, and his assistants have most carefully shown me the working of the Institute and the different departments into which it is divided.
('39', 218, 4, 15, 437345) I trust I shall make use of the knowledge thus gained in conducting the dairying experiment at the Satyagraha Ashram on behalf of the All India Cow protection Association.
('39', 218, 4, 16, 437517) As a result of several discussions with Mr. Smith I asked him kindly to prepare for me notes on the working of pinjrapoles and on methods of cattle improvement in our villages, which he very kindly and promptly undertook to do.
('39', 218, 4, 17, 437745) I am already in possession of two valuable notes.
('39', 218, 4, 18, 437795) I give below his note on pinjrapoles.
('39', 218, 5, 19, 437833) Some of the existing pinjrapoles with more or less permanent and
('39', 218, 6, 20, 437898) assured incomes are fairly well managed,and do provide a comfortable refuge
('39', 218, 7, 21, 437974) for a certain number of cattle which have to be economically useful in their old
('39', 218, 8, 22, 438055) In many of these institutions it is however not an uncommon thing, when
('39', 218, 9, 23, 438127) trade is bad and subscriptions are slow in coming in, to find cattle being kept
('39', 218, 10, 24, 438207) in these places in a state of starvation which must mean great suffering to the
('39', 219, 0, 1, 438287) 220 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 219, 1, 2, 438329) animals and which eventually kills them.
('39', 219, 1, 3, 438370) In cases like this instead of being a
('39', 219, 2, 4, 438408) refuge for the animals the goshala becomes a cow killing institution, the
('39', 219, 3, 5, 438482) method of killing being a cruel death by starvation.
('39', 219, 3, 6, 438535) In at least six cases have I
('39', 219, 4, 7, 438564) seen the cattle in goshalas being starved to death.
('39', 219, 4, 8, 438616) The first thing then to be
('39', 219, 5, 9, 438643) done with the existing pinjrapoles is to see they do not under any
('39', 219, 6, 10, 438710) circumstances whatever admit to their shelters a larger number of animals than
('39', 219, 7, 11, 438789) they can feed properly, house comfortably and take care of until they die a
('39', 219, 8, 12, 438865) really natural death.
('39', 219, 9, 13, 438887) All the larger pinjrapoles with an assured income, and which can command capital, should in my opinion be divided into three departments, the whole being managed by a trained dairy farm manager.
('39', 219, 10, 14, 439082) 1. The refuge department where old and economically useless cattle excluding buffaloes should be comfortably fed and cared for until they die naturally.
('39', 219, 11, 15, 439235) 2. A dairy department where all cows sent to the pinjrapole to escape slaughter and capable of breeding and all other cows capable of bearing calves and yielding milk should be fed, housed and milked as a commercial dairy herd with careful milk recording, and the milk sold to the best advantage.
('39', 219, 11, 16, 439532) The very best class of stud bulls should be used in this herd and all calves carefully reared, males not good enough for issue as stud bulls to be castrated and those considered good enough for breeding either transferred to the stud department or issued to villages as breeding bulls.
('39', 219, 11, 17, 439818) All female stock to be reared as milkers and breeders.
('39', 219, 11, 18, 439873) When the home bred progeny of this department gets too numerous for the pinjrapole to deal with, they could be sold to reputable Hindu owners on the distinct understanding that they are to be returned to the refuge department of the pinjrapole when too old to work or milk.
('39', 219, 12, 19, 440147) 3. A stud department where the very best of the right class of breeding bulls should be kept as stud for the use of the breeders in the district.
('39', 219, 12, 20, 440293) The service of these animals could be given free for all cows passed by the expert manager as suitable for breeding with the pinjrapoles stud animals and careful records of all servings kept.
('39', 219, 12, 21, 440485) This department might also undertake the castration of all unsuitable animals in the district free of charge.
('39', 219, 13, 22, 440595) It is not necessary to take any specific steps to improve the quality of buffaloes.
('39', 219, 13, 23, 440679) India cannot afford to keep any class or bovine which does not possess dual purpose qualities, i.e., milk in the case of the female and draught in the case of the male.
('39', 219, 13, 24, 440848) Generally speaking the male buffalo is unsuitable for field or cart work, and consequently unless the males, except those required for stud purposes, are slaughtered at birth, they remain an incubus in the country.
('39', 219, 13, 25, 441063) The majority of the people in India do not aprove of the the killing of any
('39', 220, 0, 1, 441139) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 221
('39', 220, 1, 2, 441184) kind of animals, and in any case it is not an economic proposition to rear and kill these animals for beef, as the value of this class of meat in India is far below cost of production.
('39', 220, 2, 3, 441369) The buffalo exists and increases in India owing to the poor milking
('39', 220, 3, 4, 441437) quality of the cows, and the aim of all cattle breeding propaganda ought to be
('39', 220, 4, 5, 441516) so to increase the milk yielding capacity of all classes of cows, that they will
('39', 220, 5, 6, 441597) not only provide sufficient milk to rear a strong, healthy calf, but in addition
('39', 220, 6, 7, 441678) to this give as much milk as pay the cost of their feed.
('39', 220, 6, 8, 441735) If and when we attain to
('39', 220, 7, 9, 441760) this standard there will be no need for the buffalo which will be automatically
('39', 220, 8, 10, 441840) eliminated by economic forces.
('39', 220, 8, 11, 441871) The existing conditions prevailing in many
('39', 220, 9, 12, 441914) parts of India today, where a cultivator keeps two or three cows to rear
('39', 220, 10, 13, 441987) bullocks from and one or two buffaloes to provide milk and ghee for his
('39', 220, 11, 14, 442059) houshold, cannot continue.
('39', 220, 11, 15, 442086) It is too costly and there is no reason whatever
('39', 220, 12, 16, 442135) why the cows now kept for breeding should not in the future rear their calves
('39', 220, 13, 17, 442213) and provide in addition all the milk and ghee required by the houshold.
('39', 220, 14, 18, 442285) cattle have little or no beef value and we cannot afford to keep cows for draught
('39', 220, 15, 19, 442367) cattle production and buffaloes for milk.
('39', 220, 15, 20, 442409) The cow alone can and must do both
('39', 220, 16, 21, 442444) duties.
('39', 220, 16, 22, 442452) For these reasons the pinjrapole societies should confine themselves
('39', 220, 17, 23, 442521) to caring for and improving the cow.
('39', 220, 17, 24, 442558) Agriculture in India depends upon the
('39', 220, 18, 25, 442596) efficiency of the cow as a bullock producer not the buffalo; and the health of
('39', 220, 19, 26, 442675) the people can be maintained and improved by the milk of the cow.
('39', 220, 19, 27, 442741) In a sense
('39', 220, 20, 28, 442752) the buffalo is an interloper introduced because of the poor milking qualities of
('39', 220, 21, 29, 442833) the cow.
('39', 220, 21, 30, 442842) If all pinjrapoles employed really qualified men capable of managing the pinjrapoles on the foregoing lines, they could undoubtedly do a great work for India.
('39', 220, 21, 31, 443001) The reader will observe from the foregoing that Mr. Smith has written with a knowledge of the existing pinjrapoles.
('39', 220, 21, 32, 443117) He told me that he had visited many of them.
('39', 220, 21, 33, 443162) In his opinion the pinjrapoles should serve the purpose not merely of being a home for aged and otherwise disabled cattle, but also for protecting the cow, and educating the people in the art of such protection.
('39', 220, 21, 34, 443374) To that end they must have a properly equipped model dairy and a stud department.
('39', 220, 21, 35, 443456) I add to these conditions a tannery department.
('39', 220, 21, 36, 443504) I discussed with Mr. Smith the question of adding tanneries.
('39', 220, 21, 37, 443565) The idea appeared attractive to him, but being a specialist he naturally did not want to travel beyond his province.
('39', 220, 21, 38, 443682) Mr. Smiths cautious remarks about the buffalo are worthy of attention.
('39', 220, 21, 39, 443753) He has not, and he cannot be expected to have, the same feeling about animal slaughter, but he recognizes that in India any
('39', 221, 0, 1, 443877) 222 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 221, 1, 2, 443919) proposition suggesting slaughter of useless animals would be just as much out of place as a proposition for the destruction of aged and disabled parents would be anywhere.
('39', 221, 1, 3, 444091) He has, therefore, endeavoured to enter into the Hindu feeling as much as possible, and suggested means of protection and conservation of cattle consistently with Indian traditions.
('39', 221, 1, 4, 444273) I hope that managers of pinjrapoles will study the suggestions made in Mr. Smiths important note and make the necessary alterations in their management, which, I am certain, can be made with very little extra cost in the beginning, and with much profit in the end.

('39', 221, 2, 7, 444661) 214. AN ALL INDIA SCRIPT
('39', 221, 3, 8, 444686) A Gujarati correspondent wrote some time ago to Navajivan a letter advising that I should print Navajivan in Devanagari script, so as to give a practical demonstration of my belief in the necessity of there being one script for all India.
('39', 221, 3, 9, 444925) Although it is my firm conviction that there should be one script for all the Indian languages, and that that script can only be Devanagari, I could not follow the correspondents advice for the reasons stated in my note 2 in Navajivan, and which I need not reiterate here.
('39', 221, 3, 10, 445198) But there is no doubt that we ought to seize the opportunity that the great national awakening gives us, of not merely popularizing the idea but of doing something concrete in that direction.
('39', 221, 3, 11, 445390) The Hindu Muslim madness no doubt stands in the way of a thorough reform.
('39', 221, 3, 12, 445464) But before the acceptance of Devanagari script becomes a universal fact in India, Hindu India has got to be converted to the idea of one script for all the languages derived from Sanskrit and the Dravidian stock.
('39', 221, 3, 13, 445677) At the present moment we have Bengali script in Bengal, Gurmukhi in the Punjab, Sindhi in Sind, Oriya in Utkal, Gujarati in Gujrat, Telugu in Andhradesha, Tamil in Tamilnad, Malayalam in Kerala, Kanarese in Karnatak, not to speak of Kaithi in Bihar and Modi in the Deccan.
('39', 221, 3, 14, 445950) If all these scripts could be replaced by Devanagari for all practical and national purposes, it would mean a tremendous step forward.
('39', 221, 3, 15, 446085) It will help to solidify Hindu India and bring the different provinces in closer touch.
('39', 221, 3, 16, 446173) Anyone who has any
('39', 221, 4, 17, 446192) 1 Vide Village Cattle Improvement, 4 8 1927. 2 Vide Navajivan in Devanagari Script, 26 6 1927.
('39', 222, 0, 1, 446287) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 223
('39', 222, 1, 2, 446332) knowledge of the different Indian languages and scripts knows to his cost what time it takes to master a new script.
('39', 222, 1, 3, 446449) For the love of his country, no doubt, nothing is difficult, and time spent in mastering the different scripts, some of which are very beautiful, is in no way idly spent.
('39', 222, 1, 4, 446620) But this spirit of abandon is not to be expected of millions.
('39', 222, 1, 5, 446682) National leaders have to make things esay for them.
('39', 222, 1, 6, 446734) Therefore, we must have an easily adaptable universal script for all India, and there is nothing so adaptable and readymade as Devanagari script.
('39', 222, 1, 7, 446880) There is, or there used to be, an all India organization for this very purpose.
('39', 222, 1, 8, 446960) I do not know what its activities are at present.
('39', 222, 1, 9, 447010) But if the work has to be done, either the original association should be strengthened, or a new one formed for this purpose.
('39', 222, 1, 10, 447136) The movement should in no way be confused with the spread of Hindi or Hindustani as the lingua franca.
('39', 222, 1, 11, 447239) The latter work is going on very slowly, but steadily.
('39', 222, 1, 12, 447294) Use of one script will facilitate the spread of one language.
('39', 222, 1, 13, 447356) But the functions of the two run parallel only up to a point.
('39', 222, 1, 14, 447418) Hindi or Hindustani is not designed to replace the provincial languages, but is intended to supplement them, and to be used for inter provincial contact.
('39', 222, 1, 15, 447572) And till the Hindu Muslim tension lasts it takes the form either of Urdu written in the Persian script, and containing a preponderance of Persian or Arabic words, or Hindi written in Devanagari, and containing a preponderance of Sanskrit words.
('39', 222, 1, 16, 447817) When the hearts of the two meet, the two forms of the same language will be fused together, and we shall have a resultant of the two, containing as many Sanskrit, Persian, Arabic or other words as may be necessary for its full growth and full expression.
('39', 222, 1, 17, 448072) But one script is undoubtedly designed to displace all the different scripts so as to render it easy for people belonging to different provinces to learn provincial languages.
('39', 222, 1, 18, 448248) The best way of achieving the purpose is first to make the learning of Devanagari script compulsory at least for Hindus in all the schools, as it is in Gujarat, and secondly to print the important literature in different Indian languages in Devanagari script.
('39', 222, 1, 19, 448508) Such effort has already been made to a certain extent.
('39', 222, 1, 20, 448563) I have seen Gitanjali printed in Devanagari script.
('39', 222, 1, 21, 448615) But the effort requires to be made on a large scale, and there should be propaganda carried on for the spread of such books.
('39', 222, 1, 22, 448740) Though I know that it is out of fashion just now to suggest anything along constructive lines that may bring Hindus and Mussalmans together, I cannot help repeating what I have said in these columns and elsewhere, that Hindus must learn Urdu if they will come nearer their Mussalman brethren, and Mussalmans must learn Hindi if they
('39', 223, 0, 1, 449073) 224 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 223, 1, 2, 449115) will come nearer their Hindu brethren.
('39', 223, 1, 3, 449154) Those who have faith in real unity between Hindus and Mussalmans need not be disconcerted by the present terrible expression of mutual hatred.
('39', 223, 1, 4, 449297) Their faith, if it is of any value, must make them actively but unobtrusively perform, whenever possible, all acts of mutual toleration, affection and courtesy, and learning of one anothers language is the least that one can do in that direction.
('39', 223, 1, 5, 449544) Is it not better for Hindus to learn through the many ably written Urdu books by devout Mussalmans what Mussalmans think of the Koran and the Prophet, and for Mussalmans to learn through equally well written Hindi books by devout Hindus what Hindus think of the Gita and Krishna than that the respective parties should learn all the bad things that might have been said about their respective religious books and their inspirers through their ignorant or fanatical detractors?

('39', 223, 2, 7, 450044) 215. LIMITATIONS OF SATYAGRAHA An innocent paragraph, occurring in a letter 1 in reply to one covering other subjects, has led to what I venture to call a thoughtless misrepresentation of satyagraha and its author.
('39', 223, 2, 8, 450259) The paragraph is part of a private letter written in Gujarati to Mr. Bharucha.
('39', 223, 2, 9, 450338) It is no thesis on satyagraha, and like every letter it contains many things understood between the writer of the original letter and that of the reply.
('39', 223, 2, 10, 450491) It was not meant for publication.
('39', 223, 2, 11, 450525) But when Mr. Bharucha telegraphed asking for permission to publish the paragraph, I had no hesitation in wiring permission.
('39', 223, 2, 12, 450649) It appears from the newspaper report before me that the speakers at the Nagpur meeting suggested that I should have explained at the time the Nagpur Satyagraha was launched out what I have explained in my letter to Mr. Bharucha.
('39', 223, 2, 13, 450878) I must dissent from the view.
('39', 223, 2, 14, 450908) Had Mr. Awari not ascribed to me endorsement of his campaign, I should not even have written the article I did in repudiation.
('39', 223, 2, 15, 451035) Where I cannot help, it is my rule not to hinder by any unnecessary or uncalled for interference on my part.
('39', 223, 2, 16, 451144) Instead, therefore, of giving an exhaustive opinion on what I then knew of Nagpur Satyagraha, I confined myself to a repudiation and an opinion on the general atmosphere of violence prevalent in the country.
('39', 223, 2, 17, 451352) And I cannot help saying that it was an unlawful use to make of my private letter for suspending Nagpur Satyagraha, if those who were permitted to see the
('39', 223, 3, 18, 451507) 1 Vide Letter to B. F. Bharucha, before 2 7 1927.
('39', 224, 0, 1, 451557) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 225
('39', 224, 1, 2, 451602) letter did not accept the reasoning contained in it.
('39', 224, 1, 3, 451655) Moreover, when they decided to make public use of the letter, they owed it to me to have made clear to them the points which they could not understand, or which appeared to them to be inconsistent with my previous writings.
('39', 224, 1, 4, 451879) They owed it to the enthusiastic young men in Nagpur neither to damp their zeal nor to disconcert them by hurling in their midst an opinion which the receivers did not understand and did not accept.
('39', 224, 1, 5, 452078) For myself I do not consider it to be any part of my duty to express an opinion upon the many insane things that are going on in this country, for I am humble enough to recognize that what may appear to me to be insane need not appear so to those who are doing those acts, and may even be in reality an epitome of wisdom.
('39', 224, 1, 6, 452400) Though, therefore, things are being done in the name of satyagraha in several places, I have not felt called upon to say one word about them.
('39', 224, 1, 7, 452542) And I do suggest to the young men in Nagpur and to all concerned that they are not in any way bound to receive the permission of the Congress to offer satyagraha or any other resistance to any unjust act so long as they do not use the Congress name.
('39', 224, 1, 8, 452792) And if they are really of opinion that the Nagpur Satyagraha was justified, that it was really satyagraha, it would amount to a desertion on the part of their commander and other comrades in jail not to immediately re embark upon their campaign, unless they think with me that what they thought was satyagraha was not so in fact.
('39', 224, 1, 9, 453122) Having cleared the ground so far, let me now try to remove the confusion that the well meaning friends who have undertaken to criticize the letter in question have created about satyagraha.
('39', 224, 1, 10, 453312) I do maintain that the Arms Act could not be broken in terms of satyagraha in the way it was in Nagpur.
('39', 224, 1, 11, 453416) Let it be remembered that the bone of contention between the Republican Army of Nagpur and the Government was not the Arms Act but the unjust and lawless detention of many patriotic young Bengalis.
('39', 224, 1, 12, 453614) It was in every way wrong, therefore, to select the Arms Act for civil disobedience.
('39', 224, 1, 13, 453699) Several speakers have read into my letter a meaning which I hold it does not bear and was never intended to bear.
('39', 224, 1, 14, 453813) As long ago as 1917 or 1918, I said that amongst the many black deeds of the Government, disarmament was the blackest.
('39', 224, 1, 15, 453932) And out and out believer in non violence though I am, I hold that it is right of any Indian who wishes to bear arms to do so under lawful permission.
('39', 224, 1, 16, 454082) I do submit that an Arms Act is now and will ever be a necessity of good government.
('39', 224, 1, 17, 454167) I do not believe in the inherent right of every citizen to possess as many
('39', 225, 0, 1, 454242) 226 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 225, 1, 2, 454284) arms as he chooses without a licence.
('39', 225, 1, 3, 454322) On the contrary, I hold it to be absolutely necessary for good government that the State should have the authority to prohibit the holding of arms except under prescribed conditions.
('39', 225, 1, 4, 454505) I can also conceive the possibility of satyagraha being offered against an unjust Arms Act or its unjust administration, as I can justify satyagraha against an unjust Arms Act for preventing thefts or other crimes.
('39', 225, 1, 5, 454720) But I do maintain that just as satyagraha cannot be offered against an unjust Crimes Act by committing the specific crimes, so can satyagraha not be offered against an unjust Arms Act by carrying arms.
('39', 225, 1, 6, 454922) Let us also appreciate the distinction between satyagraha and civil disobedience All civil disobedience is a part or branch of satyagraha, but all satyagraha is not civil disobedience.
('39', 225, 1, 7, 455107) And seeing that the Nagpur friends have suspended what they were pleased to call satyagraha or civil disobedience, let me suggest for their information and that of others how satyagraha can be legitimately offered with reference to the Bengal detenus.
('39', 225, 1, 8, 455359) If they will not be angry with me or laugh at me, let me commence by saying that they can offer satyagraha by developing the power of the people through khadi, and through khadi achieving boycott of foreign cloth.They can offer satyagraha by becoming precursors of Hindu Muslim unity, by allowing their heads to be broken whenever there is a quarrel between the two, and whilst there is no active quarrel in their parts by performing silent acts of service to those of the opposite faith to theirs.
('39', 225, 1, 9, 455858) If such constructive methods are too flat for them, and if they will be satisfied by nothing less than civil disobedience in spite of the violence of thought, word and deed raging round us, I suggest the following prescription of individual civil disobedience, which even one man can offer, not indeed in the hope of securing immediate release of detenus, but certainly in the hope of the individual sacrifice ultimately eventuating in such release.
('39', 225, 1, 10, 456308) Let a batch, or only one person, say from Nagpur, march on foot to the Government House in Calcutta, and if a march is irksome or impossible then let him, her, or them beg enough money for train fare from friends, and having reached Calcutta let only one satyagrahi march to the Government House and walk on to the point where he or she is stopped.
('39', 225, 1, 11, 456657) There let him or her stop and demand the release of detenus or his or her own arrest.
('39', 225, 1, 12, 456743) To preserve intact the civil nature of this disobedience the satyagrahi must be wholly unarmed, and in spite of insults, kicks or worse must meekly stand the ground, and be arrested without the
('39', 226, 0, 1, 456937) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 227
('39', 226, 1, 2, 456982) slightest opposition.
('39', 226, 1, 3, 457004) He may carry his own food in his pocket, a bottleful of water, take his Gita, the Koran, the Bible, the Zend Avesta or the Granth Sahib, as the case may be, and his takli.
('39', 226, 1, 4, 457176) If there are many such real satyagrahis, they will certainly transform the atmoshpere in an immensely short time, even as one gentle shower transforms the plains of India into a beautiful green carpet in one single day.
('39', 226, 1, 5, 457396) The question will legitimately be asked, If you really mean what you say, why dont you take lead, never mind whether anyone follows you or not? My answerr is : I do not regard myself as pure enough to undertake such a heroic mission.
('39', 226, 1, 6, 457630) I am trying every moment of my life to attain the requisite purity of thought, word and deed.
('39', 226, 1, 7, 457724) As it is, I confess that I am swayed by many passions.
('39', 226, 1, 8, 457779) Anger wells up in my breast when I see or hear about what I consider to be misdeeds.
('39', 226, 1, 9, 457864) All I can humbly claim for myself is that I can keep these passions and moods under fair subjection, and prevent them from gaining mastery over me.
('39', 226, 1, 10, 458012) But the standard of purity that I want for any such heroic measure is not to have such passions at all and yet to hate the wrong.
('39', 226, 1, 11, 458142) When I feel that I have become incapable even of thinking evil, and I hold it to be possible for every God fearing man to attain that state, I shall wait for no mans advice, and even at the risk of being called the maddest of men, I shall not hesitate to knock at the Viceregal gate or go wherever God leads me, and demand what is due to this country which is being ground to dust today.
('39', 226, 1, 12, 458530) Meanwhile let no man mock at satyagraha.
('39', 226, 1, 13, 458571) Let no man parody it.
('39', 226, 1, 14, 458593) If it is at all possible, leave satyagraha alone, and the whole field is open for unchecked action.
('39', 226, 1, 15, 458693) On a chartless sea in which there is no lighthouse a captain dares whither he wills.
('39', 226, 1, 16, 458778) But a captain who knowing the existence of a lighthouse and its position, sails anyhow, or takes no precaution for knowing the lighthouse from deceiving stars, will be considered unfit for his post.
('39', 226, 1, 17, 458977) If the reader can bear with me, let him understand that I claim to be the keeper of the lighthouse called satyagraha in the otherwise chartless sea of Indian politics.
('39', 226, 1, 18, 459145) And, therefore, it is that I have suggested that those who make for satyagraha will do well to go to its keeper.
('39', 226, 1, 19, 459258) I can, therefore, merely rely upon the indulgence of fellow workers for recognition of my office.

('39', 229, 2, 5, 464963) 217. SPEECH IN REPLY TO MUNICIPAL ADDRESS, TUMKUR 1
('39', 229, 3, 6, 465015) July 14, 1927
('39', 229, 4, 7, 465029) FRIENDS, I thank you for this address but I wish it had not been presented to me in English.
('39', 229, 4, 8, 465122) I see before me so many of my Mussalman and Hindu brothers and sisters and if you would have used either your own mother tongue or used the national language, Hindi, they would have heard and understood and I would have been pleased to receive that address.
('39', 229, 4, 9, 465380) I hope you realize that it is they, the masses, that should understand the significance of all this.
('39', 229, 4, 10, 465481) They must understand this and understand one another well.
('39', 229, 4, 11, 465540) They are brothers and they are the right and left eye of our motherland.
('39', 229, 4, 12, 465613) To make them understand we must use the language they understand very well.
('39', 229, 4, 13, 465689) I am pleased to see that many of you are clad in khadi.
('39', 229, 4, 14, 465745) But I want you not only to wear khadi today for this function only but to continue to use it always, all your life and make your brothers and sisters in the villages also, when you go to them, use khadi.
('39', 229, 4, 15, 465949) A khadi vastralaya is going to be opened here for you today.
('39', 229, 4, 16, 466010) I want you all to go there and empty the depot.
('39', 229, 4, 17, 466058) I am aware that our khadi work is increasing in your place.
('39', 229, 4, 18, 466118) I pray to God that He may bless you with the strength and wisdom to continue that work.
('39', 229, 4, 19, 466206) I hope you realize that you must all help in this cause for the sake of the poor of the country.
('39', 229, 4, 20, 466303) I want to speak to you one word today.
('39', 229, 4, 21, 466342) I want to know how many amongst you who have gathered today are Adi Karnatakas?
('39', 229, 5, 22, 466422) Many of your brothers and sisters have not come here.
('39', 229, 5, 23, 466476) To you and to those who have not come I will say this.
('39', 229, 5, 24, 466531) Much is being done for the uplift of your community.
('39', 229, 5, 25, 466584) In your Mysore Parliament (the

('39', 230, 1, 3, 466858) I am also glad to hear that His Highness takes a great interest in the cause of the downtrodden of your province.
('39', 230, 1, 4, 466972) I feel for your position.
('39', 230, 1, 5, 466998) We have to consider ourselves Panchamas as prayaschitta for what we have done to a portion of our own brothers and sisters.
('39', 230, 1, 6, 467122) But I want to speak to you, the representatives or members of the Adi Karnataka community here.
('39', 230, 1, 7, 467218) Wherever I go I have seen them in the grip of very bad habits, as eating the flesh of cow and mutton.
('39', 230, 1, 8, 467320) They must know they belong to the great Hindu fold and that they must not eat cows flesh.
('39', 230, 1, 9, 467410) Many friends, many true and good men, in order to promote love and brotherliness among the communities of India have given up this habit.
('39', 230, 1, 10, 467548) Hundreds of my friends, Mussalmans and Englishmen, have given up this habit.
('39', 230, 1, 11, 467625) Many a high placed Mussalman, I know, does not countenance the slaughter of cows.
('39', 230, 1, 12, 467707) In your own State you have a society to protect cows and there is a movement to prevent their slaughter.
('39', 230, 1, 13, 467812) I am glad your ruler is interested in this movement.
('39', 230, 1, 14, 467865) In great numbers you have assembled here today but what is the number of cows that are living and how many are slaughtered?
('39', 230, 1, 15, 467989) Mr. William Smith of the Dairy Farm in Bangalore has stated that there was much animal slughter in Mysore State, it is much more than necessary.
('39', 230, 1, 16, 468134) But I want to know why you do that at all?
('39', 230, 1, 17, 468177) We are an agricultural people and we are as a nation dependent upon our cattle from ancient times.
('39', 230, 1, 18, 468276) When I was in the Nandi Hills my friends supplied me with good milk but I know the difficulty of good milk supply that is to be observed everywhere in our land.
('39', 230, 1, 19, 468437) How many children there are in our land and can we say that we have enough good pure cows milk for them all?
('39', 230, 1, 20, 468546) In our own interest, in the interest of our country I want to appeal to them not to indulge in this habit of flesh eating.
('39', 230, 1, 21, 468669) You have stated in your address that you are going to get water supply and electricity.
('39', 230, 1, 22, 468757) Whilst I congratulate you on this, I may tell you that I expected you to give me assurances in other matters.
('39', 230, 1, 23, 468867) Can you assure me that the children in the town will be ensured a liberal supply of clean and cheap milk?
('39', 230, 1, 24, 468973) You have not told me that you have done all you can for cow protection, short of legislation prohibiting it.
('39', 230, 1, 25, 469082) You have told me that you have a population of 15,000, but you have omitted to give me the strength of your livestock.
('39', 230, 1, 26, 469201) There was a time in our land, when the wealth and prosperity of the people was measured by the number
('39', 231, 0, 1, 469303) 232 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 231, 1, 2, 469345) of children in the family and the head of cattle that it possessed.
('39', 231, 1, 3, 469413) I assure you that you could have an ideal dairy here for much less than three lakhs you will spend on water works or even less than Rs. 50,000 that you will invest in electricity.
('39', 231, 1, 4, 469593) For much less money you can have a dairy so as to make it possible for people to have milk as easily as water.
('39', 231, 1, 5, 469704) Have you persuaded your Panchamas to give up beef and liquor?
('39', 231, 1, 6, 469766) And what have you done for hygiene and sanitation?
('39', 231, 1, 7, 469817) The West has come in for much blame from me, but its hygiene and sanitation are object lessons for us.
('39', 231, 1, 8, 469920) To me, the test of a peoples knowledge of sanitation is the condition of their latrines, and I am told that the state of things here is scandalous.
('39', 231, 1, 9, 470068) The most orthodox and learned amongst us do not scruple to infringe the laws of sanitation, though all scriptures say that every infringement of a law of health or hygiene or sanitation is a sin.
('39', 231, 1, 10, 470264) I ask you to study this question deeply and to aim at being ideal scavengers.
('39', 231, 1, 11, 470342) So long as you do not take the broom and the bucket in your hands, you cannot make your town and cities clean.
('39', 231, 2, 12, 470453) Do you know what great advance in these matters the cities of the West have made?
('39', 231, 2, 13, 470535) You must copy them and keep your own place clean and healthy if you want your citizens to have a clean and healthy life.
('39', 231, 2, 14, 470656) I have gone to so many cities but I am not satisfied in this matter.
('39', 231, 2, 15, 470725) You must all cultivate the habit of cleanliness and sanitation and you must all help to be scavengers of your town if you want to live without disease and dirt.
('39', 231, 2, 16, 470886) Lastly I will say one work.
('39', 231, 2, 17, 470914) For the poor of the country, I appeal to you to take to spinning at the charkha.
('39', 231, 2, 18, 470995) Do not say you have no time.
('39', 231, 2, 19, 471024) If you are rising from your bed at seven in the morning I request you, I beg of you to rise at five and give the two hours for spinning at the charkha.
('39', 231, 2, 20, 471176) Well, I tell you that the spinning wheel I am placing before you is a symbol of industry, and lazy people cannot work it.
('39', 231, 2, 21, 471298) Time is wealth, and the Gita says the Great Annihilator annihilates those who waste time.
('39', 231, 3, 22, 471388) Two hours a day at the charkha would do a very great deal for the country and its poor millions.
('39', 231, 3, 23, 471485) I have come to you today to ask this

('39', 232, 2, 6, 471766) 218. SPEECH AT PRANI DAYA SANGHA, TUMKUR 1
('39', 232, 3, 7, 471809) July 14, 1927
('39', 232, 4, 8, 471823) FRIENDS, I thank you for address and purse.
('39', 232, 4, 9, 471867) It also gives me pleasure to receive your address in your own mother tongue.
('39', 232, 4, 10, 471944) You gave me an English translation of it but I have not read it.
('39', 232, 4, 11, 472009) Instead, I have listened to the reading of your beautiful Kanarese and I understood much because, Kanarese, Tamil, Telugu and every other vernacular in the country are as sisters to our national language, Hindi.
('39', 232, 4, 12, 472221) This morning in reply to your Municipal Address I have spoken at length on cow protection and I hope and wish you will remember my appeal on behalf of the poor cows of our country.
('39', 232, 4, 13, 472402) Perhaps you might know there is a big Sangha for the purpose in Belgaum and they have asked me to be its president.
('39', 232, 4, 14, 472518) We have also a similar society at Sabarmati Ashram.
('39', 232, 4, 15, 472570) The money you have given me today wuld go to that society for the protection of cows.
('39', 232, 4, 16, 472656) But, I want you in Mysore to do in Mysore itself what we are doing there.
('39', 232, 4, 17, 472730) You will have known of our work in the pages of Young India and Navajivan.
('39', 232, 4, 18, 472805) I want you to do that work.
('39', 232, 4, 19, 472833) You must do it here and you must all do it.
('39', 232, 4, 20, 472877) For remember, friends, that whether it is khadi work or cow protection work it is not going to be accomplished by one man alone.
('39', 232, 4, 21, 473006) Also remember that in the protection of your cattle lies the wealth of your country.
('39', 232, 4, 22, 473091) Cow is the mother of the land and if you understand the full significance of the term mother you will realize the importance of cow protection in the progress and welfare of our motherland.
('39', 232, 4, 23, 473281) I thank you once more your kindness.
('39', 232, 4, 24, 473318) The Hindu, 18 7 1927
('39', 232, 5, 25, 473339) 1 Gandhiji spoke in Hindi.

('39', 233, 1, 2, 473408) 219. SPEECH AT MADDAGIRI 1
('39', 233, 2, 3, 473435) July 15, 1927
('39', 233, 3, 4, 473449) FRIENDS, In order to serve the poor of the country you have given me a purse and address for which I thank you all.
('39', 233, 3, 5, 473565) You know that this service of the poor is very vast, the poor menDaridranarayana has a big body, the biggest stomach.
('39', 233, 3, 6, 473683) This Daridranarayana lives in the heart and the breath of the lowest and the poorest in the village huts.
('39', 233, 3, 7, 473789) He lives far away from the towns, in the interior of your villages, he does not have even one single meal a day and yet you are raising your cities and towns from his money, from his toil and his earnings.
('39', 233, 3, 8, 473995) You dont get money from outside, from foreign trade; you only send it outside by your trade.
('39', 233, 3, 9, 474088) Do you know how much cotton trade is being carried on, and how much cotton is being grown here; its cost in Egypt for instance and its cost here?
('39', 233, 3, 10, 474234) It has been said that when a country sends out its raw materials to a foreign country there is no improvement for that country.
('39', 233, 3, 11, 474362) There is one way however for some improvement of this grinding poverty and that is by khadi work.
('39', 233, 3, 12, 474460) You may not send out your cotton.
('39', 233, 3, 13, 474494) You may spin it and weave it into cloth and wear it.
('39', 233, 3, 14, 474547) I know it is for this purpose you have given me this purse but you could have given more.
('39', 233, 3, 15, 474637) If I were well I would at this moment go amongst you with the charkha and appeal to you to spin along with me always.
('39', 233, 3, 16, 474755) Some of you, many of you today have worn khadi.
('39', 233, 3, 17, 474803) I am thankful that you have given some money to the poor weavers but I ask you if you are going to wear it always?
('39', 233, 3, 18, 474918) If not your giving me this purse is of no value.
('39', 233, 3, 19, 474967) If you are to help the poor, if you are to perform your dharma irrespective of caste or creed, if you think and hope that your motherland should prosper, if you think of God, then wearing khadi is your duty, it is your dharma.
('39', 233, 3, 20, 475194) Will you do it?
('39', 233, 3, 21, 475210) In yesterdays meetings at Tumkur I have pleaded with my Panchama brethren not to take cow flesh or eat any flesh whatsoever.
('39', 233, 3, 22, 475335) I will not say further today to my Panchama brethren here.
('39', 233, 3, 23, 475394) Do not eat cows flesh, do not drink, live a clean and pure life without sin and disease.
('39', 233, 3, 24, 475483) I am glad you have a hall called after Lokamanya Tilak.
('39', 233, 3, 25, 475539) I hope you will remember the life of that great son of India, and act up to his principles.
('39', 233, 3, 26, 475631) Friends, I thank you all.
('39', 233, 3, 27, 475657) The Hindi, 18 7 1927
('39', 233, 4, 28, 475678) 1 Gandhiji spoke in Hindi.

('39', 234, 3, 18, 476439) If you agree to have Shankaran instead of Pyarelal, then Pyarelal can be sent to the Ashram.
('39', 234, 3, 19, 476532) If I have your letter saying yes, I will send Shankaran to you.
('39', 234, 3, 20, 476596) When he gets into the routine there, Pyarelal can leave.
('39', 234, 3, 21, 476653) But if for some reason you find that it cannot be done, do not hesitate to write to me.
('39', 234, 3, 22, 476741) Show this letter to Pyarelal if you are in a position to relieve Pyarelal and also tell him that he has not written to me for a long time.
('39', 234, 3, 23, 476880) Write to me about your health.

('39', 236, 3, 6, 480640) The negative participle should always go with the verb, when the verb is to be negative and when the subject has to be qualified by a long phrase, the qualifying phrase should precede the subject.

('39', 236, 4, 8, 480879) should read as follows :
('39', 236, 5, 9, 480904) Whilst you can say is better.

('39', 236, 6, 13, 481075) You cannot say you must say
('39', 236, 7, 14, 481103) Do tell me for my information whatever improvement you would suggest about spinning, prayer, kitchen, etc.
('39', 236, 7, 15, 481210) I would then be able to correct you if you have come to a hasty judgment; or if I accept your judgment, I might suggest the improvement.
('39', 236, 7, 16, 481347) One earns the right of fiercest criticism when one has convinced ones neighbours of ones affection for them and ones sound judgment, and when one is sure of not being in the slightest degree ruffled if ones judgment is not accepted or enforced.
('39', 236, 7, 17, 481592) In other words, there should be love, faculty for clear perception and complete toleration to enable one to criticize.

('39', 236, 8, 20, 481826) will not do.

('39', 237, 5, 14, 483032) AS AT THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, July 17, 1927
('39', 237, 6, 15, 483075) MY DEAR KAJEE, I was delighted to receive your letter after a long absence.

('39', 238, 3, 4, 483794) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('39', 238, 3, 5, 483827) I mentioned almonds and grapes by way of example.
('39', 238, 3, 6, 483877) Undoubtedly local fruits and nuts would be that best.
('39', 238, 3, 7, 483931) But so far as the nutritive value is concerned, nothing is lost in taking the fruits sun dried in other climates except, perhaps, the vitamins which can be easily supplied by adding fresh lemons.
('39', 238, 3, 8, 484127) For we, poor people, groundnuts, coconut and the green which are to be had everywhere are perhaps an ideal diet.
('39', 238, 3, 9, 484240) But I speak without any definite experience.I,therefore, dissuade people from being entirely guided by me in making dietetic experiment.But, if those who have independent experience and have some scientific training would conduct experiments in order to find physical and spiritual values of different fruits, they would no doubt render service in a field which is capable of limitless exploration.
('39', 238, 3, 10, 484639) In fasting for healths sake, copious draughts of water are necessary.
('39', 238, 3, 11, 484709) I used salt and soda as neat water created nausea.
('39', 238, 3, 12, 484760) For my fasts previous to the one in Delhi, I had nothing but water of which because of nausea, I was able to drink very little.
('39', 238, 3, 13, 484888) I have a friend who only the other day fasted for full 40 days and drank fresh water only copiously, and he kept excellent health.
