('39', 240, 10, 16, 488213) July 17, 1927
('39', 240, 11, 17, 488227) FRIENDS, I thank you for the address you have given me on behalf of your Municipal Council.
('39', 240, 11, 18, 488319) I am sorry I cannot speak loud enough so that every one of you might hear me.
('39', 240, 11, 19, 488397) You have dwelt on what you are doing as members of the Municipal Council in your address.
('39', 240, 11, 20, 488487) I am very much pleased with your work and I congratulate you on it.
('39', 240, 11, 21, 488555) I must thank you for having introduced compulsory education in your city for your youths and I must also congratulate you for your having in your beautiful city such big roads and lights.
('39', 240, 11, 22, 488743) It appears to me from what you have stated in your address that your municipal work is on right lines and that your record is one that would afford satisfaction to
('39', 240, 12, 23, 488907) 1 Gandhiji spoke in Hindi.
('39', 241, 0, 1, 488934) 242 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 241, 1, 2, 488976) I might tell you the true germ of swaraj lies in municipal work, and I want you to recognize it.
('39', 241, 1, 3, 489073) I have been amidst you for some time but because I could not go out on account of health, I could not personally find out your municipal work especially in regard to public health.
('39', 241, 1, 4, 489254) But I take it, it is generally good.
('39', 241, 1, 5, 489291) I have been told that your upper classes and middle classes are healthy.
('39', 241, 1, 6, 489364) If so, I want to ask you a question.
('39', 241, 1, 7, 489401) Have you got poor people in your city?
('39', 241, 1, 8, 489440) If you have, I want to ask you as members of the Municipality whether you have kept their houses healthy and tidy?
('39', 241, 1, 9, 489555) Do you take any interest in their houses?
('39', 241, 1, 10, 489597) In your address you have not told me of the state of your scavengers, nor have you informed me anything as to how you supply good milk to your children, the old and the sick of your town.
('39', 241, 1, 11, 489785) You have many merchants and traders who pay you taxes but have you ascertained anything about them?
('39', 241, 1, 12, 489885) Are they selling good flour and rations to the poor who come from the villages to purchase from them?
('39', 241, 1, 13, 489987) Your market gets supplied with things from distant villages and you purchase them as you like but have you stopped to enquire of their conditions in their distant homes in the villages?
('39', 241, 1, 14, 490173) I cannot gather anything from your address as to how many drunkards there are in your city and how many wanton sinners there are and what steps you have taken to prevent them from poisoning your city life.
('39', 241, 1, 15, 490379) I want also to know what the state of your cows and cattle is and what you as a municipal body have been doing in this direction.
('39', 241, 1, 16, 490509) Can you answer these questions?
('39', 241, 1, 17, 490541) If so, I can talk to you still more.
('39', 241, 1, 18, 490578) But if you cannot, I want you, I request you to consider all these questions and think of them always in your active municipal work.
('39', 241, 1, 19, 490711) I must say I am very grateful for your Municipality for giving a place to the charkha.
('39', 241, 1, 20, 490798) To me, it seems that you are thinking of your poor.
('39', 241, 1, 21, 490850) By this, I am sure you are aware that if you want to keep the land from getting poorer, if you want to help the poor sisters and brothers of your place, charkha is the only way.
('39', 241, 1, 22, 491028) I feel truly grateful to you for this.
('39', 241, 1, 23, 491067) I am also glad that you are supplying khadi to your employees.
('39', 241, 1, 24, 491130) There are so many of you here today who know that if you have to help in the only way you could it is by purchasing khadi.
('39', 241, 1, 25, 491253) Have some consideration for the poor, take the cloth they weave for you and let them be sure of their wages and your purchase.
('39', 241, 1, 26, 491380) I pray to God that the city which gave me health may grow ever more in wealth.
('39', 241, 1, 27, 491459) You have all given me of your love and I thank you all for this.
('39', 241, 1, 28, 491524) May God bless you and your Municipality with a great future.
('39', 241, 1, 29, 491585) The Hindu, 18 7 1927

('39', 242, 1, 2, 491651) 229. SPEECH TO LABOURERS, BANGALORE 1
('39', 242, 2, 3, 491689) July 17, 1927
('39', 242, 3, 4, 491703) FRIENDS, You have given my your addresses in the national language, Hindi, in the Mysore mother tongue, Kanarese, and also in Tamil and you have also given me a purse to serve the poor people of your country.
('39', 242, 3, 5, 491912) I am deeply grateful to you all for this.
('39', 242, 3, 6, 491954) Your offering for the cause of the poor does not bring to me any wonder because I have been a labourer myself for the past 35 years.
('39', 242, 3, 7, 492087) Ever since I went to South Africa, I have known the woes of labour intimately.
('39', 242, 3, 8, 492166) Having experienced some of them myself I also know that help in these matters seldom comes from outside.
('39', 242, 3, 9, 492271) We must help ourselves and then only God will help us.
('39', 242, 3, 10, 492326) That has been my experience.
('39', 242, 3, 11, 492355) In South Africa when this burden of suffering was weighing heavily we found out that nobody could help us so well as we ourselves and we went on making our own efforts steadily and always on the right path.
('39', 242, 3, 12, 492562) Then only relief came to us.
('39', 242, 3, 13, 492591) In Ahmedabad also it was the same experience.
('39', 242, 3, 14, 492637) The labourers did not set fire to property, they did not bully the employers, they harmed nobody and they went on fighting their cause in all just ways and right paths.
('39', 242, 3, 15, 492806) They carried on in peace and suffering; they told their masters : We are groaning under suffering, and you are happy, may you live more happily. This went home and truth triumphed.
('39', 242, 3, 16, 492987) This is the spirit of the silent and bold path of suffering; it is called satyagraha.
('39', 242, 3, 17, 493073) It means that you take your stand on truth and never swerve from the path of right in fighting your cause.
('39', 242, 3, 18, 493180) It means success of truth, it means self help.
('39', 242, 3, 19, 493227) Remember that you must help yourselves.
('39', 242, 3, 20, 493267) This path is open to every one of you, young and old.
('39', 242, 3, 21, 493321) You have stated in your address that conditions in your mills are more hard than in other mills.
('39', 242, 3, 22, 493418) I do not know if it is true, but if it is, then I am sorry to hear of it.
('39', 242, 3, 23, 493492) But I know one thing, and that is, your director is the son in law of my friend, Chandavarkar, and he would be very sympathetic to you.
('39', 242, 3, 24, 493628) He invited me to the mills and agreed to any suggestions to be made.
('39', 242, 3, 25, 493697) I sent Mr. Rajagopalachari who came to
('39', 242, 4, 26, 493736) 1 Of the Malleswaram Labour Union of the Maharaja Mills.
('39', 242, 4, 27, 493793) Illustrating the case of a dismissed labourer, the address mentioned the unfortunate position of labour in Mysore State, the indifference of Government and lack of public sympathy for labour movement in general.
('39', 242, 4, 28, 494005) Gandhijis speech in Hindi was rendered into Kanarese by Gangadharrao Deshpande.
('39', 243, 0, 1, 494085) 244 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 243, 1, 2, 494127) you and ascertained the matter.
('39', 243, 1, 3, 494159) This was at the time of your strike.
('39', 243, 1, 4, 494196) Since then I do not know what your state is but whatever it is, always remember that you must help yourselves in this and that you must learn to depend upon your own selves.
('39', 243, 1, 5, 494370) I want to ask you if you can do so.
('39', 243, 1, 6, 494406) You are quarrelling amongst yourselves, you do not make any co operative and united effort, you have not all thought about bettering your conditions in real earnest, many of you waste your time.
('39', 243, 1, 7, 494601) You do not feel that the sorrow of one of you is the sorrow of you all.
('39', 243, 1, 8, 494673) You go to drink and you go to play cards or gamble.
('39', 243, 1, 9, 494725) You should not do that if you have to better your conditions, if you have to help yourselves as men.
('39', 243, 1, 10, 494826) You must be aware of all this.
('39', 243, 1, 11, 494857) You have given me this purse and it is because you know there are millions who are much poorer than you, more hungry than you.
('39', 243, 1, 12, 494984) You must know that you must help these poor souls.
('39', 243, 1, 13, 495035) You must not forget that the cloth you produce in your own mills is not for you or for your people but for trade purposes.
('39', 243, 1, 14, 495158) It is for the benefit of your people but for trade purposes.
('39', 243, 1, 15, 495219) It is for the benefit of your masters and it is not for protecting the poor of your land, to help them get a morsel of food in the villages.
('39', 243, 1, 16, 495360) You must wear khadi and help poor men and women who weave it for you.
('39', 243, 1, 17, 495430) It is you who must help them first, for the rich do not come as quickly.
('39', 243, 1, 18, 495503) You must help them by wearing and purchasing khadi.
('39', 243, 1, 19, 495555) I know that the present troubles arise because the mill owners and the shareholders consider they are one and that you workers are separate.
('39', 243, 1, 20, 495696) It is only on the day they are going to consider that the workers also are one of them, that their interests are also the labourers interests, on that day it is that this problem is going to be solved.
('39', 243, 1, 21, 495898) When this recognition comes the mills would prosper for there would be no division of interests as between capital and labour.
('39', 243, 1, 22, 496025) This day must come for that is dharma.
('39', 243, 1, 23, 496064) But till that day comes it is your duty to go on fighting for your cause but fight for it as dharma and never swerve from the path of right and justice.
('39', 243, 1, 24, 496217) Think well on what I have said to you today.
('39', 243, 1, 25, 496262) Do not think there is any other path of bettering your condition or achieving success for efforts.
('39', 243, 1, 26, 496361) There is no other path than dharma or the path of righteousness.
('39', 243, 1, 27, 496426) Never forget this.
('39', 243, 1, 28, 496445) May God bless you all in your efforts with strength and success.
('39', 243, 2, 29, 496510) The Hindu, 18 7 1927

('39', 244, 1, 2, 496576) 230. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('39', 244, 2, 3, 496600) Half revised July 18, 1927
('39', 244, 3, 4, 496627) MIRA, I sent you a letter yesterday.
('39', 244, 3, 5, 496664) I therefore do not want to say much today.
('39', 244, 3, 6, 496707) You have done well in explaining your position fully to Valunjkar and it is a correct position.
('39', 244, 3, 7, 496803) You must be free to do the work that comes to your lot.
('39', 244, 3, 8, 496859) Nor must Gangu hang on to your skirt.
('39', 244, 3, 9, 496897) She must be taught to grow independently.
('39', 244, 3, 10, 496939) But seeing that she wants to come under your influence you will handle her lovingly and give her what you can.
('39', 244, 3, 11, 497050) You will not experiment there with your health but eat what you need.
('39', 244, 3, 12, 497120) Order the quantity of fruit you need as you used to at the Ashram and if anybody sends any fruit to you keep what you need and send the rest to the kitchen, i.e., Vinoba.
('39', 244, 3, 13, 497291) Do not think that the others need it because you need it.
('39', 244, 3, 14, 497349) You do not need the jowari that the others need.
('39', 244, 3, 15, 497398) That fruit happens to be a delicacy as well as food is perhaps unfortunate.
('39', 244, 3, 16, 497474) It is enough if we learn to take delicacies too as we would medicine in their proper measure and then we may harden our hearts and eat them although the others may not get them.
('39', 244, 3, 17, 497652) The dangers surrounding this position are too patent to require mention.
('39', 244, 3, 18, 497725) People have accommodated themselves to even vices under the plea of necessity.
('39', 244, 3, 19, 497804) But we need not be afraid of such awkward consequences, if we would keep a ceaseless watch over ourselves.
('39', 244, 3, 20, 497911) There are dangers every way we turn.
('39', 244, 3, 21, 497948) But we must obey our fundamental natures be the cost what it may.
('39', 244, 3, 22, 498014) This has been a longer letter than I had wanted it to be.
('39', 244, 3, 23, 498072) With love,
('39', 244, 4, 24, 498083) BAPU [PS.] I am quite well.

('39', 246, 1, 2, 499740) 233. LETTER TO J. B. PETIT 1
('39', 246, 2, 3, 499769) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, July 19, 1927
('39', 246, 3, 4, 499807) DEAR MR. PETIT, I thank you for your prompt attention to my letter 2 about Mr. Sastri.
('39', 246, 3, 5, 499894) Of course, in my opinion, nothing has to be said against the Government.
('39', 246, 3, 6, 499967) The point raised by you is, I think, debatable.
('39', 246, 3, 7, 500015) What the service regulations come to is that no servant of the Crown should receive a single farthing from those whom he has to serve.
('39', 246, 3, 8, 500150) But it seems to me that a Viceroy who, for example, may wish to do good to India beyond his province and receives aid from his friends and relatives in England will not be debarred from openly receiving such aid.
('39', 246, 3, 9, 500363) I have no doubt whatsoever about the Government playing the game 3 in the matter of Mr. Sastri.
('39', 246, 3, 10, 500459) The point of my letter went deeper.
('39', 246, 3, 11, 500495) I hold that the Government may not go beyond a certain point.
('39', 246, 3, 12, 500557) However, I do not wish to labour the point any further.
('39', 246, 4, 13, 500613) Yours sincerely, JEHANGIR B. PETIT, ESQ.
('39', 246, 4, 14, 500654) PETIT BUILDING 359, HORNBY ROAD FORT BOMBAY
('39', 246, 5, 15, 500698) From a photostat : S.N. 12367

('39', 247, 1, 2, 501867) 234. LETTER TO N. V. THADANI
('39', 247, 2, 3, 501896) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, July 19, 1927
('39', 247, 3, 4, 501934) MY DEAR THADANI, I have your letter.
('39', 247, 3, 5, 501971) You have entirely missed my point.
('39', 247, 3, 6, 502006) I did not even know that your college was national merely in name.
('39', 247, 3, 7, 502073) My complaint was not that Malkani went from a national college to a Government college.
('39', 247, 3, 8, 502161) My complaint would have had the same force, if Malkani, instead of going from the Mahavidyalaya to a Government college, had deserted the Mahavidyalaya for a selfless expedition to the North Pole in search of knowledge, or say, had gone to Kashi Vidyapith or Bihar Vidyapith both of which are direct offspring of non co operation and with both of which I am more or less connected.
('39', 247, 3, 9, 502543) And I should have considered the conduct of Sriprakash Babu and Rajendra Babu, respectively, as ungentlemanly if they had seduced Malkani behind the back of the authorities of the Mahavidyalaya as you have done.
('39', 247, 3, 10, 502755) And I have felt it so keenly in this case because of my high opinion about Malkani.

('39', 252, 3, 4, 511519) DEAR FRIEND,
('39', 252, 4, 5, 511532) I thank you for your letter and the pains you have taken to answer my questions.
('39', 252, 4, 6, 511613) Do you claim cheapness, simplicity and efficacy for Ayurvedic medicine as we find it at present?
('39', 252, 4, 7, 511710) After my own fashion, I have been interested in its success ever since 1891, and have even spent what little I was capable of and induced friends to spend on behalf of Ayurvedic physicians.
('39', 252, 4, 8, 511900) But so far, I have found it to be neither cheap nor simple nor efficacious.
('39', 252, 4, 9, 511976) Some of the prescriptions are most complicated.
('39', 252, 4, 10, 512024) Ayurvedic physicians have been known to charge as much as men with medical degrees.

('39', 252, 4, 12, 512188) The best of them are beyond the reach of the poor.

('39', 252, 4, 14, 512429) I am aware of the converse also having happened.
('39', 252, 4, 15, 512478) But the scales seem to me to weigh in favour of Allopathy.
('39', 252, 4, 16, 512537) My own desire has been and is now also to find Ayurveda practice successful, if only because I am probably fanatically vegetarian and because I have a horror of Allopathy for many reasons I need not go into.
('39', 252, 4, 17, 512745) Even for simple home treatment, having studied something of both Ayurvedic and Allopathic drugs, I have been obliged to use Allopathic drugs instead of Ayurvedic.
('39', 252, 4, 18, 512908) For instance, I have found nothing so efficacious as quinine for malaria or iodine for simple pains or Condys fluid as a disinfectant.
('39', 252, 4, 19, 513043) I must not, however, worry you with my own experience.

('39', 262, 6, 10, 531522) After distributing the certificates to the successful students .
('39', 262, 6, 11, 531587) Mahatmaji delivered his address in Hindi.
('39', 262, 6, 12, 531629) The address was translated into Kannada by Desabhakta Gangadharrao sentence by sentence.
('39', 262, 6, 13, 531718) Mahatmaji observed that their President, Mr. M. Venkatakrishnaiya, was called by them all the grand old man of Mysore.
('39', 262, 6, 14, 531837) The expression grand old man was doubtless dear to him.
('39', 262, 6, 15, 531893) But he would ask them to call Mr. Venkatakrishnaiya the aged grandfather of Mysore, vriddhapitamaha, as Mr. Gangadharrao called, or they
('39', 262, 7, 16, 532030) might call him by any other better name in Hindi, Sanskrit or Kannada.
('39', 262, 7, 17, 532101) The addess they had presented him had a message behind it.
('39', 262, 7, 18, 532160) It was that Hindi should become the common language of India, that the people living in India, of whatever community, should all become united as a nation.
('39', 262, 7, 19, 532316) Today they had not a language which was the language of all their countrymen.
('39', 262, 7, 20, 532394) Their hearts too were not united.
('39', 262, 7, 21, 532428) There were differences between Brahmins and non Brahmins, between Hindus and Mussalmans, and in the Hindu fold itself there were the untouchables who have been kept aloof, as though they were not part of it.
('39', 262, 7, 22, 532636) Their hearts, instead of being united, had been drawn away from each other.
('39', 262, 7, 23, 532712) The object of a common language for the whole country was to unite them all.
('39', 262, 7, 24, 532789) When they were all thus united by this bond of a common language they would all understand the meaning of grand old man.
('39', 262, 7, 25, 532910) Let them imagine for a moment that they were living in the time of the Pandavas.
('39', 262, 7, 26, 532991) If aged Bhishma came there, and they all said that the grand old man came, how ludicrous it would be.
('39', 262, 7, 27, 533093) They must ever remember Bhishma and his vows.
('39', 262, 7, 28, 533139) Whenever they thought of Bhishma, every one of them would be thrilled with certain courage and heroic spirit, and everyone would be reminded of Bhishmas vows, and would receive an awakening.

('39', 263, 1, 2, 533419) they but put themselves in mind of Bhishma every morning, he was sure they would develop courage and heroism, so essential for national regeneration.

('39', 263, 5, 21, 535054) 249. SPEECH IN REPLY TO ADDRESSES, MYSORE
('39', 263, 6, 22, 535096) July 20, 1927
('39', 263, 7, 23, 535110) Mahatmaji, in the course of his joint reply to the several addresses presented to him 1, said that their love for him was so great that to save his time and to afford him relief, they had arranged to present them all together.
('39', 263, 7, 24, 535337) He was thankful to them for it.
('39', 263, 7, 25, 535369) It pleased him to learn that His Highnesss Government had shown their sympathy for the khaddar movement, and had agreed to the abolition of octroi on khadi imported into the city.
('39', 263, 7, 26, 535549) All the addresses had alluded to the khadi and charkha
('39', 263, 8, 27, 535604) 1 By the Mysore City Municipal Council, the Mysore District Board, the Mysore Congress Committee, the Dattatreya Gorakshana Mandali, the Kaniyars and other citizens of Mysore.
('39', 263, 8, 28, 535780) Gandhijis reply in Hindi was rendered into Kanarese by Gangadharrao Deshpande.
('39', 264, 0, 1, 535859) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 265
('39', 264, 1, 2, 535904) movements.
('39', 264, 1, 3, 535915) He was pleased to note that the people of Mysore liked khadi and the charkha, but his experience told him that he was not to be deceived by such praise as they showered in the addresses, for they had not gone far beyond the region of praise and entered the practical region.
('39', 264, 2, 4, 536190) He was delighted to see the beautiful city of Mysore with its palaces and mansions, is broad and well kept roads, gardens and parks.
('39', 264, 2, 5, 536323) This was one side of the view.
('39', 264, 2, 6, 536354) When he considered the other side, the poor in the city and in the villages steeped in misery and pain, his heart was touched.
('39', 264, 2, 7, 536481) He wished to see the day when the Maharajas in India and their advisers showed love and pity to the poor, who were grovelling in poverty and misery, so that the gulf between them, between the rich and the poor, may be bridged.
('39', 264, 2, 8, 536708) It was not that he hated palaces and mansions, or gardens and parks.
('39', 264, 2, 9, 536777) It was his desire to see that in India, the rich and the poor were united at heart.
('39', 264, 2, 10, 536861) It was to bridge the gulf that was between them, it was to bring about contact between the rich and the poor that his efforts were directed these seven years.
('39', 264, 2, 11, 537020) The gulf could not be bridged by such works as the Bhadravati Works and the gold mines of Kolar.
('39', 264, 2, 12, 537117) The Bhadravati Works and the gold mines were doubtless necessary.
('39', 264, 2, 13, 537183) The mines of contact between the rich and the poor was possible only by means of the hand spun yarn.
('39', 264, 2, 14, 537284) They might know that the bridge between Rishikesh and Gangotri called the Lakshmanjhula was constructed out of hand spun yarn.
('39', 264, 2, 15, 537411) Let none despise it.
('39', 264, 2, 16, 537432) When once they worked at the charkha, they would see that it was what he represented it to be.
('39', 264, 2, 17, 537527) He was overjoyed to learn that His Highness the Maharaja of Mysore also worked at the spinning wheel and had thereby set an example to his people.
('39', 264, 3, 18, 537674) To the Kaniyars he said that he shared their grief.
('39', 264, 3, 19, 537726) As long as Hindu society, observed Mahatmaji, kept even one Hindu outside its pale, he would also consider himself as a Panchama.
('39', 264, 3, 20, 537856) He could not conceive of swaraj without the removal of the
('39', 264, 4, 21, 537915) taint of untouchability.
('39', 264, 5, 22, 537940) He would, however, ask the Kaniyars why it was that they should think they were better than the Panchamas, and why they should desire to be included in the four varnas.
('39', 264, 5, 23, 538109) His understanding of the Shastras told him that no one varna was superior to
('39', 264, 6, 24, 538186) another.
('39', 264, 6, 25, 538195) His impression was that the Brahmin was superior to the others when he maintained his own dharma, which was that of service.
('39', 264, 6, 26, 538320) The Kshatriyas were likewise superior in their own dharma, of protecting the weak against the strong.
('39', 264, 6, 27, 538422) There was no superiority by those of one varna preying upon those of the others.
('39', 264, 6, 28, 538503) The Kaniyars
('39', 264, 7, 29, 538516) should follow the example of Yudhishthira who, until his dog was allowed to enter swarga, would not enter it.
('39', 264, 7, 30, 538626) Until the Adi Karnatakas also secured their proper place
('39', 264, 8, 31, 538683) in Hindu society, they should not be anxious for their own rights.
('39', 264, 8, 32, 538750) He was glad that the Kaniyars did not eat beef and drink intoxicating liquors.

('39', 264, 9, 34, 538968) It grieved him to learn
('39', 265, 0, 1, 538992) 266 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 265, 1, 2, 539034) that the Kaniyars were kept out of temples.
('39', 265, 1, 3, 539078) They had however to bear their difficulties patiently.
('39', 265, 1, 4, 539133) Mahatmaji assured the Kaniyars that His Highness the Maharaja and Government had been doing their utmost to improve the condition of the Kaniyars.
('39', 265, 1, 5, 539280) One thing which they, along with other Hindus, ought to do was tapascharya and thereby attain atma shuddhi.
('39', 265, 1, 6, 539388) The Hindu Shastras told them that even Brahma was able to undertake the task of creation by means of tapascharya.

('39', 265, 2, 9, 539647) In reply to the address of the Gorakshana Mandali, Mahatmaji said he was pleased to learn that in Mysore Hindus and Muslims were living in perfect amity and concord.
('39', 265, 2, 10, 539813) It pleased him also to learn that the majority of the Muslims were also with the Hindus on the question of the prevention of cow slaughter.

('39', 265, 2, 12, 540128) He had already stated his views on the question of legislation for cow protection.

('39', 265, 2, 14, 540383) So long as those who espoused the cause of cow protection did no constructive work for preventing cow slaughter, they could not be said doing any useful work.

('39', 265, 6, 23, 541074) 250. NOTES
('39', 265, 7, 24, 541085) THE LATE SIR GANGA RAM The death of Sir Ganga Ram removes from our midst an able and practical agriculturist, a great philanthropist and a friend of the widow.
('39', 265, 7, 25, 541245) Though advanced in years, Sir Ganga Ram had the energy of youth.
('39', 265, 7, 26, 541310) His optimism was equal to the obstinacy with which he held on to his views.
('39', 265, 7, 27, 541386) I had the privilege of coming in fair contact with him recently.
('39', 265, 7, 28, 541451) And though we could not agree on several matters, I recognized in him a sincere reformer and a great worker.
('39', 265, 7, 29, 541560) And although, with all the respect due to his age and experience, I
('39', 266, 0, 1, 541628) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 267
('39', 266, 1, 2, 541673) expressed my dissent from many of his views with energy and insistence, his affection for me, whom he regarded comparatively to him as a young man of but yesterday, grew with my opposition to some of his extraordinary views on Indian poverty.
('39', 266, 1, 3, 541916) He was so eager for long discussions with me, and so hopeful of weaning me from the error of my ways, that he offered to take me to England at his own expense, and promised to drive all the nonsense out of my head.
('39', 266, 1, 4, 542131) Though I could not accept the offer which he had seriously meant, I wrote to him on the eve of his departure, promising to see him and undertaking to convert him to the creed of the spinning wheel, which he thought was fit only to be burnt as firewood.
('39', 266, 1, 5, 542384) The reader may well imagine my grief therefore over the news of his sudden death.
('39', 266, 1, 6, 542466) But it is a death which we could all wish to have.
('39', 266, 1, 7, 542517) For he went to England not on a pleasure trip, but on what he considered to be a peremptory duty.
('39', 266, 1, 8, 542615) He has therefore died in harness.
('39', 266, 1, 9, 542649) India has every reason to be proud of having a man like Sir Ganga Ram as one of her distinguished sons.
('39', 266, 1, 10, 542753) I tender both my congratulations and condolences to the family of the deceased reformer.
('39', 266, 2, 11, 542842) CONGRESS PRESIDENT FOR 1928 The election of Dr. Ansari as President of the National Assembly for the coming year is a foregone conclusion.
('39', 266, 2, 12, 542981) There is no one on the national horizon to challenge the election.
('39', 266, 2, 13, 543048) Dr. Ansari is as good an Indian as he is a Mussalman.
('39', 266, 2, 14, 543102) He has been never suspected of fanaticism.
('39', 266, 2, 15, 543145) He has been continuously Joint Secretary of the Congress for years.
('39', 266, 2, 16, 543213) His recent efforts to promote union are well known.
('39', 266, 2, 17, 543265) And as a matter of fact, had I not stood in the way at Belgaum, Shrimati Sarojini Devi at Cawnpore and Sjt.
('39', 266, 2, 18, 543373) Srinivasa Iyengar at Gauhati, Dr. Ansari would have been elected on any of these occasions.
('39', 266, 2, 19, 543465) For his name was on everybodys lips when these elections took place.
('39', 266, 2, 20, 543534) But special reasons postponed Dr. Ansaris claim, and it now seems that fates had conspired to postpone the election so that he might come in when he was most wanted.
('39', 266, 2, 21, 543700) If any possible scheme of Hindu Mulsim unity is to be found acceptable to both the parties, Dr. Ansari undoubtedly is the man to pilot such a scheme through the Congress.
('39', 266, 2, 22, 543871) I respectfully dissent from the view that in a Congress which is predominantly Hindu, a Hindu should be the President, so that such a scheme might be claimed to have whole hearted acceptance by the Hindus.
('39', 266, 2, 23, 544077) On the contrary, nothing can be more auspicious for the inauguration of such a scheme than that, in spite of the poisonous atmosphere prevailing in the country, a national association
('39', 267, 0, 1, 544261) 268 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 267, 1, 2, 544303) containing a preponderating majority of Hindus shoud unanimously and whole heartedly elect a Mussalman as its President.
('39', 267, 1, 3, 544424) That fact by itself would be an earnest of the Hindu desire for such unity.
('39', 267, 1, 4, 544500) And of all the Mussalman nationalists, there is no Musalman more respected than Dr. Ansari by the Mussalmans in general.
('39', 267, 1, 5, 544621) It is, therefore, in my opinion, in every way desirable, that Dr. Ansari should guide the National Congress during the coming year.
('39', 267, 1, 6, 544753) Fot it is not merely the passing of a scheme that is wanted, but a proper working of it is, perhaps, more necessary than its aceptance by the two parties.
('39', 267, 1, 7, 544908) And assuming that a scheme acceptable to both is passed, ceaseless watch will be required during the coming year as to its operation.

('39', 267, 1, 9, 545087) I hope, therefore, that all the provinces will unanimously recommend Dr. Ansaris name for the highest honour that is in the gift of the National Assembly.
('39', 267, 1, 10, 545242) KHADI IN UDAIPUR Some time ago the daily Press published the news that khadi workers in Bijolia were arrested and that the manager of the khadi organization there was required to give an undertaking that he would give notice to the authorities of any person coming to him.
('39', 267, 1, 11, 545515) On receiving this information Sheth Jamnalalji proceeded to Udaipur to ascertain the true situation.
('39', 267, 1, 12, 545616) Having seen the authorities in Udaipur and then having gone to Bijolia, Jamnalalji came to Bangalore for attending the meeting of the Council of the All India Spinners Association, and the South India Khadi Exhibition.
('39', 267, 1, 13, 545835) During the Bangalore visit, he told me that it was quite true that two khadi workers had been arrested in Bijolia, and that they were arrested not for doing khadi work, but under the suspicion that they were meddling with the politics of the State.
('39', 267, 1, 14, 546084) The authorities assured Jamnalalji that they not only did not wish to interfere with khadi work, but that they welcomed khadi workers, and that they were even prepared to give khadi work substantial help under well defined conditions.
('39', 267, 1, 15, 546319) Jamnalalji then saw the local authorities in Bijolia, and it has now been arranged, that no undertaking is to be taken from the khadi workers, it being understood between Jamnalalji and the local authorities, that the khadi workers will not directly or indirectly take part in or interfere with the politics of the State, and that they will confine themselves merely to the organization of the people for khadi production and sales.
('39', 267, 1, 16, 546752) Jamnalalji had no hesitation in giving the undertaking for the simple reason that it has been the uniform and invariable practice of the Charkha Sangh to confine its work in the Indian States purely to khadi work.

('39', 268, 1, 2, 547034) 251. STARVING MUNICIPAL BOARDS
('39', 268, 2, 3, 547065) The brief address, that Sjt.
('39', 268, 2, 4, 547094) Vallabhbhai Patel delivered before the First Conference held in Gujarat of its Municipalities and Local Boards, is worthy of study by everyone interested in the efficient working of Municipalities, Local Boards and District Boards.
('39', 268, 2, 5, 547326) It is packed with facts as startling as they are disturbing.
('39', 268, 2, 6, 547387) On the one hand, he says, the responsibilities of these bodies have been increased by conferring on them larger rights, and on the other, the means of discharging those responsibilities have been somehow or other curtailed.
('39', 268, 2, 7, 547611) Himself being President of one of the first class Municipalities of India, he has a long record of municipal service behind him.
('39', 268, 2, 8, 547740) Even the Government have been obliged to give his administration of Ahmedabad Municipality unstinted and unmixed praise.
('39', 268, 2, 9, 547861) He has slaved for his Municipality as few persons have done.
('39', 268, 2, 10, 547922) Like Phirozeshah Mehta, having accepted the chair, he has held the work of his office to be far more important for him than any other national work, no matter how urgent or greater in extent it might be.
('39', 268, 2, 11, 548126) Having made the choice of his dharma, he has preferred it, even though a superior has often called for the exercise of his singular abilities and powers of application.
('39', 268, 2, 12, 548295) His address, therefore, needs to be studied carefully by everyone concerned.
('39', 268, 2, 13, 548372) He backs his assertions with concrete facts which anybody may challenge.
('39', 268, 2, 14, 548445) He thinks that the 157 Municipalities of the Bombay Presidency are economically in straightened circumstances.
('39', 268, 2, 15, 548556) In some cases, he says, the salaries of municipal teachers are in arrears.
('39', 268, 2, 16, 548631) Their incomes are really inadequate for the work before them.
('39', 268, 2, 17, 548693) Their sanitary measures have to be held in abeyance for want of funds.
('39', 268, 2, 18, 548764) Compulsory education schemes are shelved for similar reasons.
('39', 268, 2, 19, 548826) He adduces in support of many of his statements his own painful experience, and he severely criticizes the Governments niggardly policy in connection with Municipalities.
('39', 268, 2, 20, 548997) The President is as unsparing of the citizens as he is of the Government.
('39', 268, 2, 21, 549071) He exclaims:
('39', 268, 3, 22, 549084) Citizens of our cities regulate their lives as if they were living not in cities but in villages, and therefore, many houses have no sanitary accommodation or receptacle reserved for collection of rubbish.
('39', 268, 3, 23, 549290) They do not hesitate to keep their cattle anyhow, though living in crowded quarters.
('39', 268, 3, 24, 549375) Shepherds bring their droves of cattle and plant them in the midst of cities with the greatest unconcern.
('39', 268, 3, 25, 549481) Generally speaking, people are indifferent about observing simple
('39', 269, 0, 1, 549547) 270 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 269, 1, 2, 549589) rules of health and sanitation.
('39', 269, 1, 3, 549621) They neither know how to observe them for themselves or for the sake of their neighbours.
('39', 269, 1, 4, 549711) It is common experience to see them shoving rubbish on to their neighbours yards.
('39', 269, 1, 5, 549793) They do not hesitate to throw from their heights rubbish or water on to the streets heedless of the passers by.
('39', 269, 1, 6, 549905) They would spit anywhere, they would perform their natural functions anywhere.
('39', 269, 1, 7, 549984) The condition of villages is no better.
('39', 269, 1, 8, 550024) Rubbish heaps meet your gaze on approaching them.
('39', 269, 1, 9, 550074) Village ponds become stinking cess pools, and soaking dirt near village wells is a common feature.
('39', 269, 1, 10, 550173) Vallabhbhai Patel says, and most people would agree with him, that it would be criminal to look to the Government for help in such matters.
('39', 269, 1, 11, 550313) I suppose that he has purposely refrained from touching in his address upon the petty intrigues that go on in Municipalities, and make the work of the real worker and reformer almost an impossibility.
('39', 269, 1, 12, 550514) Some of the foremost workers tried, but to meet severe disappointment.
('39', 269, 1, 13, 550585) Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru in Allahabad, Babu Rajendra Prasad in Patna found intrigue to be too trying for them.
('39', 269, 1, 14, 550695) Deshbandhu Chittaranjan Das strove manfully against heavy odds, and the responsibility nearly crushed him.
('39', 269, 1, 15, 550802) The fact is that the municipal voter has not yet become alive to a sense of his civic responsibility.
('39', 269, 1, 16, 550904) He does not regard himself as in any way responsible for the well being of all the citizens.
('39', 269, 1, 17, 550997) Our educational system is not designed to give an object lesson in corporate responsibility.
('39', 269, 1, 18, 551090) Municipal councillors therefore need feel responsible to no one.
('39', 269, 1, 19, 551155) In the heyday of Non co operation, I ventured to suggest that if the people had really developed a sense of civic responsibility, three fourths of the municipal work could be done without Governments assistance or patronage.
('39', 269, 1, 20, 551380) I showed by taking facts and figures of municipal work in Mehmadabad, that the citizens could manage their municipal work with half the cost without having a statutory Municipality.
('39', 269, 1, 21, 551562) And I showed too that a statutory Municipality became a necessity only when the councillors had no co operation from the people, or when they wished to force their reform schemes down the throats of unwilling citizens.
('39', 269, 1, 22, 551781) They needed in a small place like Mehmadabad no elaborate machinery to light their streets, to clean their latrines, and their roads, and to manage their schools, and there could be no questions of police, if the citizens were all good and pure, or if they had a citizen guard for guarding peaceful citizens against thieves, loafers or hooligans.
('39', 269, 1, 23, 552128) Those men who are real servants of the
('39', 270, 0, 1, 552167) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 271
('39', 270, 1, 2, 552212) people, would become municipal councillors for the sake of service and not for the sake of gaining fame or engaging in intrigues and finding employment for their needy friends or relatives.
('39', 270, 1, 3, 552402) What is wanted, therefore, is zealous education of the people on the part of workers, not merely by means of speeches, but through silent social service rendered without the slightest expectation of reward, even in the shape of thanks, but on the contrary, with every expectation of receiving the execration and worse of a public enraged over any attempt to make it give up its superstitions or insanitary habits.
('39', 270, 1, 4, 552816) I know of a poor sanitary inspector, who was very nearly lynched for his zeal in impartially getting hold of all the culprits who with criminal indifference dirtied the streets of the town, whose sanitation the poor man was paid to guard.
('39', 270, 1, 5, 553055) Young India, 21 7 1927

('39', 271, 8, 15, 554875) The tour was undertaken also purely in the interest of khadi.
('39', 271, 8, 16, 554937) I had neither the desire nor the capacity for doing general propaganda work in the existing state of the country.
('39', 271, 8, 17, 555051) For me, khadi is my propaganda.
('39', 271, 8, 18, 555083) For if that one thing can be shown to be a thorough success, everthing else will follow.
('39', 271, 8, 19, 555172) My idea is that we must have at least one constructive item made a demonstrable success on a wide scale.
('39', 271, 8, 20, 555277) As it is, the people seem to have lost confidence in themselves, and have made up their minds that they can succeed in no constructive effort.

('39', 271, 8, 24, 555803) Mysore will take me up to the end of August, and if I feel at all strong enough, I shall do the Tamil Districts after.

('39', 274, 5, 7, 558694) 258. SPEECH TO ADI KARNATAKAS, MYSORE
('39', 274, 6, 8, 558732) [July 21, 1927] 1
('39', 274, 7, 9, 558750) I am both happy and unhappy to meet you.
('39', 274, 7, 10, 558791) I am happy because I have had occasion to purify myself by having met you, but I am unhappy that for health and other reasons I have to reconcile myself to staying in palaces, although I know full well the miserable conditions in which you live.
('39', 274, 7, 11, 559037) Truth or God whose votary I am tells me every moment that my place is not in palaces but among you.
('39', 274, 7, 12, 559137) But this may be a temporary fit of desire for renunciation.
('39', 274, 7, 13, 559197) It may be that the moment I leave these surrounding I will forget you and your cottages, but it is also possible, and let me hope that a day will come, when God will give me the strength to do the thing I prize so much.
('39', 274, 7, 14, 559417) Today I have just come to assure you that there is an ever increasing band of workers interested in and striving for your welfare.
('39', 274, 7, 15, 559548) I congratulate the Brahmin lady who has dedicated herself to your service.
('39', 274, 7, 16, 559623) It is my firm faith that in the near future Hinduism will be purged of the stain of untouchability.
('39', 274, 7, 17, 559723) There is no one high or low in the sight of God, and he who considers himself superior to another is described by the Shastras as foolish.
('39', 274, 7, 18, 559862) But so far as you are concerned, I am quite sure that your salvation is in your hands.
('39', 274, 7, 19, 559949) How can you, being Hindus, whose duty it is to protect the cow, eat beef and carrion?
('39', 274, 7, 20, 560035) It is because it is cheap, I am told.
('39', 274, 7, 21, 560073) Well, nothing is cheap that holds religion cheap, nothing is dear that holds religion dear.
('39', 274, 7, 22, 560165) I tell you I find it difficult to persuade the othodox to mix with you, for they tell me, that you are given to beef eating, liquor and the like.
('39', 274, 7, 23, 560311) If you will therefore cleanse yourselves you will make work easy for me.
('39', 274, 7, 24, 560384) Dont retort that the touchables are no better.
('39', 274, 7, 25, 560431) They are no better, I know, but they may not listen through their pride, you need not imitate them.
('39', 274, 7, 26, 560531) You have to raise yourselves.
('39', 274, 7, 27, 560561) You therefore have to purify yourselves.
('39', 274, 7, 28, 560602) And if you do, no power on earth can stop your onward march.

('39', 276, 8, 12, 562425) July 23, 1927
('39', 276, 9, 13, 562439) In the course of his speech, Mahatmaji thanked the citizens of Mysore for their contribution and proceeded to observe that their leading citizen, Sowcar D. Banumaiya, had given Rs. 1,501 and to him he had given his word that his contribution would be used only for the poor in this State.
('39', 276, 9, 14, 562728) It was his desire and that of his co workers that whatever was collected in Mysore should if possible be spent in Mysore.
('39', 276, 9, 15, 562850) It was however the usual thing, where there was not an adequate number of the poor, or where there was no scope for encouraging the manufacture of khadi, to spend the amount collected in another part of the country, where poverty was acute, and where they could not raise any fund.
('39', 276, 9, 16, 563132) For example, in Utkal Province, where the people were extremely poor and miserable, and where consequently they could not raise any fund, funds raised elsewhere had to be spent on khadi work and thereby for feeding the poor of Utkal.
('39', 276, 10, 17, 563366) Bombay and Cutch had subscribed large sums, but not a pie could be spent in Bombay.
('39', 276, 10, 18, 563450) All that was collected there was spent elsewhere.
('39', 276, 10, 19, 563500) He had collected lakhs of rupees from his Marwari friends in Marwar, but they were not spent there.

('39', 284, 4, 9, 578515) 272. SPEECH AT CIVIC AND SOCIAL PROGRESS ASSOCIATION, BANGALORE 1
('39', 284, 5, 10, 578581) July 24, 1927
('39', 284, 6, 11, 578595) FRIENDS,
('39', 284, 7, 12, 578604) I have heard of the work of your Association and I am very much pleased.
('39', 284, 7, 13, 578677) You have today given me an opportunity to learn of your activities and I am gratified to find that one of the prominent among them is the effort that you are making towards the betterment of your Adi Karnatakas here.
('39', 284, 7, 14, 578894) Though one of the chief ways of achieving the progress of your city is by means of an association such as yours, I can tell you, there is no other punya karma 2 than this work of uplifting your own brothers and sisters known as Adi Karnatakas.
('39', 284, 7, 15, 579138) But as you yourselves have stated in your address, you have done much in this direction, but much more, very much more remains to be done.
('39', 284, 7, 16, 579277) You know fully well, the work would never be complete, would
('39', 284, 8, 17, 579338) 1 Gandhijis speech in Hindi was rendered into Kanarese by Gangadharrao Deshpande.
('39', 284, 8, 18, 579420) 2 Meritorious deed
('39', 285, 0, 1, 579439) 286 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 285, 1, 2, 579481) never be perfect so long as there is a temple in this land which shuts out your Adi Karnataka brother, and so long as there is one person amongst you who would not allow the Adi Karnataka to approach him as a brother.
('39', 285, 1, 3, 579699) Of course you know the condition of the poor Adi Karnataka and you also know that it is not part of the Hindu dharma to eat the flesh of the cow.
('39', 285, 1, 4, 579845) On the other hand protection of the cow is enjoined on all by the Hindu dharma.
('39', 285, 1, 5, 579925) And you who know of this, have you taught this to your brethren in the villages?
('39', 285, 1, 6, 580006) Ignorance of this Hindu dharma had bred evil habits amongst them who are also Hindus, but they must be made to understand that you are really anxious to help them better their lives according to Hindu dharma.
('39', 285, 1, 7, 580215) You must all open out your hearts to make them understand that.
('39', 285, 1, 8, 580279) You must do your duty by them if you are true members of the society to which you belong.
('39', 285, 1, 9, 580369) Do not think that you have only one duty, the duty to your country to perform.
('39', 285, 1, 10, 580448) There is also the duty to society and these two are interdependent.
('39', 285, 1, 11, 580516) You cannot perform the one and neglect the other.
('39', 285, 1, 12, 580566) You cannot hold them as apart from each other.
('39', 285, 1, 13, 580613) You will realize that in the uplift of your brethren, in the reform of your social evils, in making your society a real force in the country and in establishing communal harmony, perfect and long lasting friendship between Hindus and Mussalmansin all these lies also your duty to country.

('39', 289, 3, 7, 587171) I do not know what happened to the Khilafat Funds, except that the banker with whom the funds were placed failed.
('39', 289, 3, 8, 587285) But I may state that I never had anything to do with the management of the Khilafat Fund.
('39', 289, 3, 9, 587375) For the Khadi Funds, I am certainly responsible.
('39', 289, 3, 10, 587424) There is a Council of the All India Spinners Association which is entrusted with these Funds and their management.
('39', 289, 3, 11, 587539) Seth Jamnalal Bajaj who is a very well known merchant of long standing and a director of several important concerns is the treasurer of the Association.
('39', 289, 3, 12, 587692) Shankerlal Banker who is the son of late Ghelabhai Banker of the Bank of Bombay is the Secretary.
('39', 289, 3, 13, 587790) The moneys are kept in well known banks.
('39', 289, 3, 14, 587831) Proper books of account are kept and they are audited by chartered accountants from time to time.
('39', 289, 3, 15, 587929) The are inspectors appointed to inspect the accounts of subordinate organizations.
('39', 289, 3, 16, 588012) Everything that is humanly possible to safeguard the Funds and their proper distribution is being done.
('39', 289, 3, 17, 588116) I enclose herewith a copy of the printed report published by the All India Spinners Association in which you will find the audited accounts also.
('39', 289, 3, 18, 588262) If, after perusal of the report or even before, you have any suggestions to make for further safeguarding the Funds, I shall be thankful to receive them.
('39', 289, 3, 19, 588416) With reference to my appeal 2 at the Mahila Samaj for ornaments and calling them streedhan, I do hold very strong views.
('39', 289, 3, 20, 588537) Ever since I have been in India, and even in South Africa, I have not hesitated to induce sisters both Indian and European to part with their jewellery.
('39', 289, 3, 21, 588690) As long ago as 1906, I remember the late Surendranath Banerjea having also appealed to the ladies at Lahore, and I remember too that ornaments were showered upon him.
('39', 289, 3, 22, 588857) I do not feel that in my appeal I am doing anything out of the way.
('39', 289, 3, 23, 588925) Indeed yours is the first note of
('39', 289, 4, 24, 588959) 1 In reply to his letter dated July 21 in which the addressee had asked if any committee had been appointed to manage the Khadi Funds.

('39', 290, 1, 2, 589245) dissent I have yet had.
('39', 290, 1, 3, 589269) In fact, many well to do friends have been glad of my appeal, and some of them even took me to their homes when I was appealing on behalf of the Tilak Swaraj Fund and asked me to appeal to their womenfolk to part with their ornaments, their intention being to wean the latter from a craving for hoarding and wearing costly jewels.
('39', 290, 1, 4, 589600) I have been often publicly thanked for having succeeded to some slight extent in introducing simplicity in the households of the rich people of the land.

('39', 290, 1, 8, 590036) Nevertheless, I have believed that it is wrong on the part of husbands to arrogate to themselves the right of dictating what their wives shall or shall not do with their jewellery.
('39', 290, 1, 9, 590217) It is the one thing which is in their exclusive possession, and I think that they should have the freest right to dispose of them how they will.
('39', 290, 1, 10, 590362) But this is my own personal opinion and has nothing to do with what has actually happened in practice.
('39', 290, 1, 11, 590465) Do you think that because some people, who in their en thusiasm parted with their foreign cloth and allowed them to be burnt, now repent, I should also repent with them for having asked them to do what they did in a moment of lucidity and what it was their sacred duty to have done.

('39', 295, 1, 3, 599269) I wish that the learned men of Mysore, amongst whom there are some of the finest scholars, could find out authorities to show that untouchability could be no part of the Hindu religion, and that our remote ancestors through whom we received the inspiration of the Vedas and who gave us the rich heritage of the Upanishads never believed in untouchability, even as I dont, and that it is merely a vicious excrescence upon Hinduism.
('39', 295, 1, 4, 599700) And I tell you that if you can do so, among the many services you have already rendered this will not be by any means the least.
('39', 295, 1, 5, 599829) Workers like myself say on their own authority that this thing is no part of Hinduism.
('39', 295, 1, 6, 599916) I am no scholar and have to read the Shastras in the original, by my Hindu soul rises up in revolt against such an abomination.
('39', 295, 1, 7, 600044) However, I look to you scholars and research students to arm workers like myself with authoritative declarations that would command the attention of pundits, and to furnish workers with evidence so forceful and masterly as would dissolve the orthodox opposition.
('39', 295, 1, 8, 600307) It should be the proud privilege of your Society to furnish workers with authoritative texts which they could not get anywhere else, and fortify them in their work.

('39', 296, 0, 1, 600495) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 297
('39', 296, 1, 2, 600540) 283. LETTER TO J. P. BHANSALI [After July 26, 1927] 1
('39', 296, 2, 3, 600594) I have your letter intended for Young India.
('39', 296, 2, 4, 600639) At first I laughed over it and dictated a brief note on it and sent it to be typed for Young India.
('39', 296, 2, 5, 600739) But today I woke up to find myself sorry at the thought of your letter and my laughter disappeared because I see in it a lack of restraint and understanding.
('39', 296, 2, 6, 600897) I cannot now recall your expressing a difference of opinion with me.
('39', 296, 2, 7, 600966) I know there were discussions between us but I had thought that in the end you were convinced.
('39', 296, 2, 8, 601061) But if that is not so, the certificate you grant me in your letter is out of place, and your letter suggests that the mental weakness you mention has been with me from the moment we knew each other.
('39', 296, 2, 9, 601260) The publicity you have given to my mental weakness does not pain me.
('39', 296, 2, 10, 601329) But I am hurt because you kept your knowledge of it from me till today and because I see that some matters have been twisted in your letter.
('39', 296, 2, 11, 601470) Moreover, a telegram from Ahmedabad today says that many activities are at a standstill because of unusually heavy rain and if Young India cannot come out this time the matter already sent is enough to fill the next issue.
('39', 296, 2, 12, 601693) Nature has, therefore, provided me with enough respite to await your reply.
('39', 296, 2, 13, 601769) Where you blame me for scribbling away in haste, I do not see even a trace of hurry, but since your letter has hurt me I do feel that I should be in no hurry to write about it.
('39', 296, 2, 14, 601946) I understand from your last letter that you did not, as usual, hasten to meet me because of your mothers illness.
('39', 296, 2, 15, 602060) I want you therefore to call on me if her condition has improved.
('39', 296, 2, 16, 602126) If you feel that you are not likely to misunderstand me at any point, I do not think you need see me.
('39', 296, 2, 17, 602228) Write to me if you hold the latter view or send me a telegram, so that I shall certainly publish your letter.
('39', 296, 2, 18, 602338) [From Gujarati]
('39', 296, 3, 19, 602354) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desais Diary.
('39', 296, 3, 20, 602399) Courtesy : Narayan Desai
('39', 296, 4, 21, 602424) 1 The source has this letter after the entries for July 26, 1927.

('39', 297, 7, 16, 603156) 285. LETTER TO J. P. BHANSALI [July 27, 1927] 2
('39', 297, 8, 17, 603204) Your letter (or ultimatum?) to hand.
('39', 297, 8, 18, 603241) My letter appears to have crossed yours.
('39', 297, 8, 19, 603282) I urge you not to act in haste.
('39', 297, 8, 20, 603314) You do not think you are in a hurry because you are impatient to start your fast.
('39', 297, 8, 21, 603396) However, I do feel that you are in too great a hurry.
('39', 297, 8, 22, 603450) If you accept the moral position at any rate that when you take such a step you should do so in my presence, please withdraw your ultimatum.
('39', 297, 8, 23, 603591) I have received three strong letters urging me to dissuade you from undertaking this fast.
('39', 297, 8, 24, 603682) One is from Bhai Kishorelal, another from Ramniklal and the third from Mirabehn.
('39', 297, 8, 25, 603763) Mirabehn met you after a long interval, became very sad on seeing you and found your countenance queer.
('39', 297, 8, 26, 603867) She found even your talk queer and felt that you had become extremely emotional.
('39', 297, 8, 27, 603948) All these words in quotes are hers.
('39', 297, 8, 28, 603984) The letter was in Hindi but she had used the English words in it.
('39', 297, 8, 29, 604050) I suggested to her that she write to you directly.
('39', 297, 8, 30, 604101) 3 I have received her reply also and she says that she dare not go to that extent lest she should hurt you.
('39', 297, 8, 31, 604209) In spite of my reporting all these three opinions, if I were near you and you could persuade me,I would grant you permission to undertake the fast
('39', 297, 9, 32, 604356) 1 The addressee received the letter on July 27, 1927 2 Vide the succeeding item.
('39', 297, 9, 33, 604437) 3 Vide Letter to Mirabehn, 17 7 1927.
('39', 298, 0, 1, 604475) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 299
('39', 298, 1, 2, 604520) and also bless you.
('39', 298, 1, 3, 604540) But since I am so far away, I must also let these three letters make their impact on my mind.
('39', 298, 1, 4, 604634) Your letter appears to contradict your own earlier letter because you were till now hoping for my permission, and I presumed that you would not undertake the fast if you do not have it.
('39', 298, 1, 5, 604820) But in your last letter you say nothing about my permission, you no more expect it but seek my blessings.
('39', 298, 1, 6, 604926) If you are hoping for my permission, I shall not be able to grant it.
('39', 298, 1, 7, 604996) How could I permit what I do not consider right?
('39', 298, 1, 8, 605045) Personally I think even if you have my permission for your course of action, both you and I must obtain the permission of the Managing Committee.
('39', 298, 1, 9, 605191) If there is anyone who can be free to do such things after obtaining such permission, it is perhaps myself because, being the founder of the Ashram and initiator of the new and vital experiments in satyagraha, I may be expected to have such privilege, but I do have some doubt in this regard too.
('39', 298, 1, 10, 605488) Even I should not have the right to take any steps that might harm the institution once it has been founded.
('39', 298, 1, 11, 605597) I was mindful of this also when I had undertaken the seven dayss fast.
('39', 298, 1, 12, 605668) And even about that, there was some talk.
('39', 298, 1, 13, 605710) I have indulged in so much autobiography in order to make you see your duty.
('39', 298, 1, 14, 605787) I am one of those who believe that there is a place for a fast like yours in certain situations.
('39', 298, 1, 15, 605884) But I see clearly from this distance that yours is not such a situation and how can I bless a thing which I regard as improper?
('39', 298, 1, 16, 606012) Hence if you would be persistent I can only say that I shall bear with your persistence and acquiesce in the inevitable unwillingly and painfully.
('39', 298, 1, 17, 606159) Before you take any step, discuss the matter with the Managing Committee with a calm mind and also with those whom you regard as your personal friends.
('39', 298, 1, 18, 606311) Consider your duty towards Lilabehn; if she consents to your step, I would not value her consent; but if she opposes, I would value it greatly because you have sheltered her.
('39', 298, 1, 19, 606486) If you can and will withdraw your ultimatum and give me an assurance that without my permission you will never embark on a fast, I am ready, at present through correspondence and personally if necessary and when an occasion offers, to discuss the ethics of fasting and whetever points you have raised in your earlier letter.
('39', 298, 1, 20, 606811) I wish our friends and the Managing Committee to read this letter and you should give it to them for reading.
('39', 298, 1, 21, 606921) May God help you.

('39', 299, 1, 2, 607067) 286. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('39', 299, 2, 3, 607091) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, July 27, 1927
('39', 299, 4, 4, 607129) I have your letter.
('39', 299, 4, 5, 607149) Of course you know that Wardha is but a branch of Sabarmati.
('39', 299, 4, 6, 607210) But Wardha has to specialize for discipline and Vinoba is developing it without troubling me and without being hampered by me.
('39', 299, 4, 7, 607337) Nor has Wardha the same changes to face or new experiments to make as Sabarmati has.
('39', 299, 4, 8, 607422) And then Sabarmati has no one mind uncontrolled by outside force to change it as Wardha has.
('39', 299, 4, 9, 607515) But for all practical purposes, Sabarmati and Wardha must be considered as one and indivisible.
('39', 299, 4, 10, 607611) But now your mind must be freed for the next two months from even having to think of these places.
('39', 299, 4, 11, 607710) Your sole concern during these precious two months is to concentrate on your work and on your health.
('39', 299, 4, 12, 607812) I have an ultimatum from Bhansali that he proposes to commence his long fast as from the 6th of August.
('39', 299, 4, 13, 607916) I have warned him against it and implored him not to undertake it at least till I have gone to the Ashram and had an opportunity of discussing the thing with him.
('39', 299, 4, 14, 608079) The letter goes today.
('39', 299, 4, 15, 608102) I have mentioned your opinion also about his proposed fast and about his appearance.
('39', 299, 4, 16, 608187) I hope he will listen to my entreaty.
('39', 299, 4, 17, 608225) What food are you taking daily?
('39', 299, 4, 18, 608257) With love, BAPU SRIMATI MIRABAI SATYAGRAHASHRAM WARDHA

('39', 300, 1, 2, 608408) 287. LETTER TO FRANCISCA STANDENATH 1
('39', 300, 2, 3, 608446) AS AT THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, July 27, 1927
('39', 300, 3, 4, 608489) MY DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('39', 300, 3, 5, 608525) I am glad you have come in such close touch with the friends 2 to whom I gave an introduction note for you.
('39', 300, 3, 6, 608633) I have regarded them as among the best of the wealthy people of my acquaintance.
('39', 300, 3, 7, 608714) From your letter I suspect that you regard cotton spinning as the only spinning.
('39', 300, 3, 8, 608795) But it is not so.
('39', 300, 3, 9, 608813) Wool spinning is also important, though nothing like cotton spinning, for the simple reason that millions live on the plains and hardly require woollen clothing.
('39', 300, 3, 10, 608975) By all means do cotton spinning when you can; but why not wool spinning in the absence of cotton spinning.
('39', 300, 3, 11, 609082) And then the woollen yarn may be woven for your own use.
('39', 300, 3, 12, 609139) You must know that I myself do use hand spun wool without the slightest compunction.
('39', 300, 3, 13, 609224) Even as I am dictating this letter, I have covered myself with a woollen blanket, hand spun of course.
('39', 300, 3, 14, 609327) It is fairly cold where I am recuperating.
('39', 300, 3, 15, 609370) I am asking Swami Anand to send your some hand spun wool, and I am also asking him to send you a blanket piece which you can either use as a blanket or for making blouses, etc.
('39', 300, 3, 16, 609547) It wont be smooth to the touch, but then you wont need to wear it next to the skin.
('39', 300, 3, 17, 609631) I note that you are persevering in your study of Sanskrit and other languages.
('39', 300, 3, 18, 609710) Whenever you can spare some money, you should both come to India, if only for a season and see things for yourself.
('39', 300, 3, 19, 609826) You will then perhaps get a true perspective and probably be enabled to modify some of the exaggerated notions you might have about India in general and the Ashram and myself in particular.
('39', 300, 3, 20, 610016) I am anxious that you should know things as they are, or at least as they appear to you at close quarters and not as they seem to you from a distance.
('39', 300, 4, 21, 610167) Yours sincerely,
('39', 300, 5, 22, 610184) From a photostat : S.N. 12527

('39', 301, 6, 13, 611105) 289. LETTER TO SHAPURJI SAKLATVALA
('39', 301, 7, 14, 611140) AS AT THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, July 27, 1927
('39', 301, 8, 15, 611183) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('39', 301, 8, 16, 611216) I should love to respond, as I know you would like me to, to your earnest call; but I see that we look at things differently.
('39', 301, 8, 17, 611342) Pray do not think that my labour work unlike khaddar work is merely confined to Ahmedabad.
('39', 301, 8, 18, 611433) If labour elsewhere will accept my guidance, I would certainly organize it all over.
('39', 301, 8, 19, 611518) But I am content with guiding Ahmedabad and hope that if Ahmedabad proves successful, it will be copied by the whole of India.
('39', 301, 8, 20, 611645) There is no analogy between the khaddar movement and the labour movement.
('39', 301, 8, 21, 611719) If khaddar like labour were conducted by several distinct organizations, probably I would be compelled to restrict my activities to those organizations only that would listen to me.
('39', 301, 8, 22, 611901) I have no magical power for bringing labour organization out of disorgani zation.
('39', 301, 8, 23, 611983) The organic touch with labour all over India I have because
('39', 301, 9, 24, 612043) 1 The addressee had passed on to Gandhiji a suggestion of E. W. Dickes that the title of The Story of My Experiments with Truth be changed into The Story of My Schooling with Truth.
('39', 302, 0, 1, 612225) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 303
('39', 302, 1, 2, 612270) wherever I go labour flocks round me.
('39', 302, 1, 3, 612308) But that touch is not strong enough to enable me to organize it after my own fashion.
('39', 302, 1, 4, 612394) I give you my assurance that the moment I feel that I can usefully come in, I shall not hesitate to offer my services to the all India organization.
('39', 302, 1, 5, 612543) About the Khaddar Fund, I can only say you have written without knowledge.
('39', 302, 1, 6, 612618) Even law will prevent me from using the Khaddar Fund for any other than the advertised purpose even if my conscience becomes elastic enough to permit me to use it otherwise.
('39', 302, 1, 7, 612792) I read the other day in the papers that you had a slight operation performed on you and that you were already on the road to recovery.
('39', 302, 1, 8, 612927) I hope that you have now fully recovered.
('39', 302, 1, 9, 612969) I wrote to you only the other day about your own personal affairs which shall not escape my attention.

('39', 302, 4, 12, 613119) 290. LETTER TO C. V. VAIDYA
('39', 302, 5, 13, 613147) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, July 27, 1927
('39', 302, 6, 14, 613185) DEAR MR. VAIDYA, I must thank you for your delightful letter with its humorous touches.
('39', 302, 6, 15, 613273) I am not sending it to Pandit Satavalekar, but drinking in the facts, or what is a better term, your opinionsfor are not facts stated but opinions,all for myself.
('39', 302, 6, 16, 613436) In the course of my practice, I have so often envied the poor judges who, if they were honest, I knew, must have been hard put to it for coming to a just decision.
('39', 302, 6, 17, 613600) And in spite of knowing this thing, I have become a self constituted judge and much trying on account of my ignorance of the originals to know the correct interpretation or practice of the Vedas or practice of our remote forefathers.
('39', 302, 6, 18, 613834) Of course I dont go so far remote as to the monkeys as Darwin would have as our remote ancestors.
('39', 302, 6, 19, 613932) And I am safe from destruction in the midst of the war of opposite opinions by my sane belief that it is our right irrespective of the interpretation of the written Vedas or the practice of our ancestors to regulate our practice in the light of modern research and the behest of our own conscience.
('39', 302, 7, 20, 614231) Yours sincerely,
('39', 302, 8, 21, 614248) C. V. VAIDYA POONA CITY
('39', 302, 9, 22, 614272) From a microfilm : S.N. 12621

('39', 303, 8, 12, 614775) 292. LETTER TO NARGIS CAPTAIN
('39', 303, 9, 13, 614805) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, July 27, 1927 I know why you have not written to me all these long long days.
('39', 303, 9, 14, 614907) But all the same I have got to write to you.
('39', 303, 9, 15, 614952) I saw your letters both to Jammabehn and Mithubehn.
('39', 303, 9, 16, 615004) I had long chats with the latter, and I see that whilst she is most lovable and a woman having immense capacity for work and service, she has an awful temper and a highly suspicious nature.
('39', 303, 9, 17, 615194) She has developed, what seems to me to be utterly groundless, suspicion of Yashwantprasad whom she has come to regard as her determined enemy.
('39', 303, 9, 18, 615337) This makes it practically impossible for Jamnabehn to work with her.
('39', 303, 9, 19, 615406) On the whole, therefore, it seems to me that it would be better to leave her alone in the development of fashionable khadi which has made her speciality and to which she gives the whole of her time.
('39', 303, 9, 20, 615605) After all her accounts are perfect in the sense that every penny received and spent is accounted for.
('39', 303, 9, 21, 615707) The account keeping is not in the orthodox style.
('39', 303, 9, 22, 615757) That I suppose is now being done.
('39', 303, 9, 23, 615791) The accounts can also be regularly audited.
('39', 303, 9, 24, 615835) And so long as she does that, there is no reason why her work should not be treated as an independent branch of the Stree Sabha.
('39', 303, 9, 25, 615964) You may all still hold
('39', 304, 0, 1, 615987) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 305
('39', 304, 1, 2, 616032) yourselves ready for services whenever she wants them.
('39', 304, 1, 3, 616087) I say you all because Mithubehn does not want interference from anybody except when she requires it.
('39', 304, 1, 4, 616188) I sympathize with her in this attitude because with her highly suspicious nature of which she has no knowledge, she cannot take up any other attitude if she is to work in peace.
('39', 304, 1, 5, 616366) I endeavoured to show her that Yeshwantprasad had no axe to grind and that he was interested in her work because Jamnabehn was in it, and every one of you appreciated his help.
('39', 304, 1, 6, 616543) But I could not remove her suspicion.
('39', 304, 1, 7, 616581) On the contrary, she reiterated it and said that like hers my eyes would in course of time be opened to Yeshwantprasads intriguing nature as she called it.
('39', 304, 1, 8, 616737) This is unfortunate.
('39', 304, 1, 9, 616758) But we have to make the best of it.
('39', 304, 1, 10, 616794) Unfortunately the women of India have not before now worked in an organized fashion.
('39', 304, 1, 11, 616879) It will therefore be some time before they can do so.
('39', 304, 1, 12, 616933) As a matter of fact even the men of India are not yet able to run many successful organizations without friction and without mutual suspicion.
('39', 304, 1, 13, 617076) I do not want you to overtax yourself about this matter.
('39', 304, 1, 14, 617133) But if you can send for Mithubehn and others and, seeing that they accept you as their commander in chief, pull them all by the ear and make them work together, it would be very nice.
('39', 304, 1, 15, 617317) I see that since your return home, you have not kept first class health.
('39', 304, 1, 16, 617390) But you must really be strong.
('39', 304, 1, 17, 617421) I shant be satisfied till you have gone to Kashmir.
('39', 304, 1, 18, 617473) Though I have never seen it, I have heard a lot about it.
('39', 304, 1, 19, 617531) It is highly likely that the bracing air of Kashmir will suit you admirably.
('39', 304, 1, 20, 617608) Do write to me and tell me all about your health.
('39', 304, 1, 21, 617658) How I wish you could have come here.
('39', 304, 1, 22, 617695) The weather is really superb and quite cool for us, but of course it may not be for you.
('39', 304, 2, 23, 617784) NARGIS CAPTAIN
('39', 304, 3, 24, 617799) COMRA HALL PANCHGANI

('39', 305, 0, 1, 617850) 306 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 305, 1, 2, 617892) 293. LETTER TO S. V. KAUJALGI
('39', 305, 2, 3, 617922) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, July 27, 1927
('39', 305, 3, 4, 617960) DEAR FRIEND, I see my letter has hurt you.
('39', 305, 3, 5, 618003) But I do not know what else I could have done in the circumstances.
('39', 305, 3, 6, 618071) The verse you have quoted is perfect.
('39', 305, 3, 7, 618109) As a woman I should feel pride in nestling myself in the bosom of my husband.
('39', 305, 3, 8, 618187) As a creeper I should be faithful to the immovable tree which lies near me and affords me protection and feel pride in circling myself round it.
('39', 305, 3, 9, 618332) And as a leader or president of the Spinners Association I should be false to my trust if I do not depend upon those co workers whom I ever find near me and ready to do the work entrusted to them.
('39', 305, 3, 10, 618529) Is it not the essential condition of the very existence of the three named by the poet in the verse quoted by you?
('39', 305, 3, 11, 618644) Come near me, woo me and I shall be a faithful wife.
('39', 305, 3, 12, 618697) Be like an immovable tree near me, and I shall circle round you.
('39', 305, 3, 13, 618762) Merge yourself in khadi work and lead me by the nose.
('39', 305, 3, 14, 618816) But if you will not occupy any of the three positions, then I shall accept you with quiet resignation as a candid critic offering explanations to the Press.
('39', 305, 3, 15, 618973) You shall still remain a friend and fellow worker, and I shall demand from you such quota of service as, in my opinion, you can render.

('39', 306, 8, 20, 620797) DEAR FRIEND, I do not propose to publish your letter suggesting the adoption of Devanagari as the all India script.

('39', 306, 8, 22, 621064) The reform of Devanagari, however desirable it may be, is a side issue.

('39', 307, 0, 1, 621325) 308 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 307, 1, 2, 621367) caps as I would call them.
('39', 307, 1, 3, 621394) Kakasaheb goes one better and suggests the Gujarati script which is really reformed Nagari.
('39', 307, 1, 4, 621486) But I have suppressed Kakasahebs proposal because it would simply lead to an interminable controversy and take the mind of thinking India away from the main issue.
('39', 307, 1, 5, 621650) Whilst I believe that the reformation of Devanagari in some shape or other is necessary, I am only indifferent to it at present.
('39', 307, 1, 6, 621779) It would be a tremendous saving of national energy and a move on the part of different linguistic provinces towards one another to adopt one script however imperfect it may be.
('39', 307, 1, 7, 621956) For your information I give you the reason for not printing Navajivan in Devanagari.
('39', 307, 1, 8, 622041) Navajivan has its own work cut out.
('39', 307, 1, 9, 622077) In order to make good its message it has submitted to a curtailment of its subscription list.
('39', 307, 1, 10, 622171) You may not know that at one time it and Young India had each nearly 30,000 subscribers.
('39', 307, 1, 11, 622260) But today it has come down to less than 7,000. I do not mind its coming to zero for enforcement of the mission for which the papers were brought into being.
('39', 307, 1, 12, 622417) Adoption of Devanagari was not part of that mission.
('39', 307, 1, 13, 622470) I have a large number of women readers and Parsis and Mussalmans who can struggle even through Gujarati type with some labour.
('39', 307, 1, 14, 622597) They find it difficult even to understand the moderate number of Sanskrit words that have got to be used in editing Navajivan.
('39', 307, 1, 15, 622724) If I adopt Devanagari all these would be helpless and give up Navajivan and me in sheer disgust.
('39', 307, 1, 16, 622821) Amongst what may be called the upper ten, I have, I fear, very few readers of Navajivan.
('39', 307, 2, 17, 622910) Yours sincerely,

('39', 310, 3, 14, 626793) Nor did I contemplate that if there were any profits made from the sale of the books they were to go to A.I.S.A. So far as I recollect our conversation I did not contemplate making any profits.
('39', 310, 3, 15, 626987) But if there were any, they should go towards the upkeep of the Swarajya which after all is as much Mr. Kanitkars concern as any other.
('39', 310, 3, 16, 627123) You may make use of this letter in your communication with Jamnalalji, and if necessary, the resolution will be altered accordingly at the next meeting of the Council.
('39', 310, 3, 17, 627291) But, even as the resolution stands, I do not think that for your purposes it needs any alteration.

('39', 310, 3, 19, 627567) The pronote required should of course be sent without delay by you even if you wish for any alterations in the resolution.
('39', 310, 3, 20, 627690) I do not think that the charge against the Council of lukwarmness towards Maharashtra is correct.
