('39', 313, 0, 1, 631056) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 313, 1, 2, 631098) 303. DISCUSSION WITH MISSIONARIES 1
('39', 313, 2, 3, 631134) [July 29, 1927] 2
('39', 313, 3, 4, 631152) Gandhiji opened the discussion by claiming himself to be a friend of the missionaries, ever since his close contact with them in South Africa.
('39', 313, 3, 5, 631295) Though I have been a friend, I have always been a critic, not from any desire to be critical, but because I have felt that I would be a better friend if I opened out my heart, even at the risk of wounding their feelings.
('39', 313, 3, 6, 631516) They never allowed me to think that they felt hurt, they certainly never resented my criticism.
('39', 313, 4, 7, 631612) Then he referred to his first speech before the missionaries in India on swadeshi, since which twelve years had rolled away and with them much of the mists also.
('39', 313, 4, 8, 631774) The first distinction I would like to make, after these prefatory remarks, between your missionary work and mine, is that while I am strengthening the faith of the people, you are undermining it.
('39', 313, 4, 9, 631970) Your work, I have always held, will be all the richer, if you accept as settled facts the faiths of the people you come to servefaiths which, however crude, are valuable to them.
('39', 313, 4, 10, 632149) And in order to appreciate what I say, it becomes perhaps necessary to re read the message of the Bible in terms of what is happening around us.
('39', 313, 4, 11, 632294) The world is the same, but the spirit ever broadens intensively and extensively, and it might be that many things in the Bible will have to be re interpreted in the light of discoveriesnot of modern sciencebut in the spiritual world in the shape of direct experiences common to all faiths.
('39', 313, 4, 12, 632584) The fundamental verses of St. John do require to be re read and re interpreted.
('39', 313, 4, 13, 632664) I have come to feel that like us human beings words have their evolution from stage to stage in the contents they hold.
('39', 313, 4, 14, 632784) For instance the contents of the richest wordGodare not the same to every one of us.
('39', 313, 4, 15, 632869) They will vary with the experience of each.
('39', 313, 4, 16, 632913) They will mean one thing to the Santhal and another to his next door neighbour Ravindranath Tagore.
('39', 313, 4, 17, 633013) The sanatani may reject my interpretation of God and Hinduism.
('39', 313, 4, 18, 633076) But God Himself is a long suffering God who puts up with any amount of abuse and misinterpretations.
('39', 313, 4, 19, 633177) If we were to put the spiritual experiences together we would find a resultant which would answer the cravings of human nature.
('39', 313, 4, 20, 633305) Christianity is
('39', 313, 5, 21, 633321) 1 From Mahadev Desais article, Talks with Missionaries 2 From Mahadev Desais Weekly Letter
('39', 314, 0, 1, 633412) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 315
('39', 314, 1, 2, 633457) 1,900 years old, Islam is 1,300 years old, who knows the possibility of either?
('39', 314, 1, 3, 633537) I have not read the Vedas in the original, but have tried to assimilate their spirit and have not hesitated to say that though the Vedas may be 13,000 years oldor even a million years old, as they well may be, for the word of God is as old as God Himselfeven the Vedas must be interpreted in the light of our experience.
('39', 314, 1, 4, 633858) The powers of God should not be limited by the limitations of our understanding.
('39', 314, 1, 5, 633939) To you who have come to teach India, I therefore say, you cannot give without taking.
('39', 314, 1, 6, 634025) If you have come to give rich treasures of experiences, open your hearts out to receive the treasures of this land, and you will not be disappointed, neither will you have misread the message of the Bible.
('39', 314, 2, 7, 634231) Interesting questions and answers followed, which I summarize below :
('39', 314, 3, 8, 634301) Q. What then are we doing?
('39', 314, 3, 9, 634328) Are we doing the right thing?
('39', 314, 4, 10, 634358) A. You are trying to do the right thing in the wrong way.
('39', 314, 4, 11, 634416) I want you to complement the faith of the people instead of undermining it.
('39', 314, 4, 12, 634492) As the Dewan of Mysore said in his address to the Assembly, the Adi Karnatakas should be made better Hindus, as they belong to Hindusim.
('39', 314, 4, 13, 634629) I would similarly say to you, make us better Hindus, i.e., better men or women.
('39', 314, 4, 14, 634709) Why should a man, even if he becomes a Christian, be torn from his surroundings?
('39', 314, 4, 15, 634790) Whilst a boy I heard it being said, that to become a Christian was to have a brandy bottle in one hand and beef in the other.
('39', 314, 4, 16, 634916) Things are better now, but it is not unusual to find Christianity synonymous with denationalization and Europeanization.
('39', 314, 4, 17, 635037) Must we give up our simplicity, to become better people?
('39', 314, 4, 18, 635094) Do not lay the axe at our simplicity.
('39', 314, 5, 19, 635132) There are not only two issues before us, viz., to serve and to teach, there is a third issue, viz., evangelizing, declaring the glad tidings of the coming of Jesus and his death in redemption for our sins.
('39', 314, 5, 20, 635338) What is the right way of giving the good news?
('39', 314, 5, 21, 635385) We need not undermine the faith but we may make people lose their faith in lesser things.
('39', 314, 5, 22, 635475) That lands me into the region of interpretation.
('39', 314, 5, 23, 635524) Whilst I must not enter into it.
('39', 314, 5, 24, 635557) I may suggest that God did not bear the Cross only 1,900 years ago, but He bears it today, and He dies and is resurrected from day to day.
('39', 314, 5, 25, 635696) It would be poor comfort to the world if it had to depend upon a historical God who died 2,000 years ago.
('39', 314, 5, 26, 635802) Do not then preach the God of history, but show Him as He lives today through you.
('39', 314, 5, 27, 635885) In South Africa I met a number of friends, and read a number of booksPearson, Parker and Butlerall giving their own
('39', 315, 0, 1, 636001) 316 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 315, 1, 2, 636043) interpretations, and I said to myself I must not bother myself with these conflicting interpretations.
('39', 315, 1, 3, 636146) It is better to allow our lives to speak for us than our words.
('39', 315, 1, 4, 636210) C.F. Andrews never preaches.
('39', 315, 1, 5, 636239) He is incessantly doing his work.
('39', 315, 1, 6, 636273) He finds enough work and stays where he finds it and takes no credit for bearing the Cross.
('39', 315, 1, 7, 636365) I have the honour to know hundreds of honest Christians, but I have not known one better than Andrews.
('39', 315, 2, 8, 636468) But what about animistic beliefs?
('39', 315, 2, 9, 636502) Should they not be corrected?
('39', 315, 2, 10, 636532) Well, we have been working amongst the so called untouchables and backward classes, and we have never bothered ourselves with their beliefs, animistic or otherwise.
('39', 315, 2, 11, 636697) Superstitions and undesirable things go as soon as we begin to live the correct life.
('39', 315, 2, 12, 636783) I concern myself not with their belief but with asking them to do the right thing.
('39', 315, 2, 13, 636866) As soon as they do it, their belief rights itself.
('39', 315, 3, 14, 636917) You speak of simplicity.
('39', 315, 3, 15, 636942) But what are we to do in this age of motor cars?
('39', 315, 3, 16, 636991) You could not have come here without a motor car!
('39', 315, 3, 17, 637041) Well, a motor car is not a necessity.
('39', 315, 3, 18, 637079) I certainly did not need it to come here.
('39', 315, 3, 19, 637121) If God wants you to be useful he should find the means to make you useful.
('39', 315, 3, 20, 637196) Motor cars do not mean the sum of our spiritual experience.
('39', 315, 3, 21, 637256) There was no motor car in Jesus or Mahomeds time, and yet they did not need them for their work.
('39', 315, 3, 22, 637353) I do not hold them to be essential for real progress.
('39', 315, 3, 23, 637407) We need to be humble.
('39', 315, 3, 24, 637429) And humility and simplicity are not mere outward expressions.
('39', 315, 3, 25, 637491) When Paul speaks of humility he means heart humility.
('39', 315, 3, 26, 637545) A true Christian has little need to speak.
('39', 315, 3, 27, 637588) He goes about his Fathers business.
('39', 315, 3, 28, 637624) May I cite my own case?
('39', 315, 3, 29, 637648) Speeches were the least part of my work in South Africa.
('39', 315, 3, 30, 637705) Most of the 16,000 people who rose like one man and joined me had not even seen me, much less heard me speak.
('39', 315, 4, 31, 637815) How can we help condemning if we feel that our Christian truth is the only reality?
('39', 315, 4, 32, 637899) That brings me to the duty of tolerance.
('39', 315, 4, 33, 637940) If you cannot feel that the other faith is as true as yours, you should feel at least that the men are as true as you.
('39', 315, 4, 34, 638059) The intolerance of the Christian missionaries does not, I am glad to say, take the ugly shape it used to take some years ago.
('39', 315, 4, 35, 638185) Think of the caricature of Hinduism, which one finds in so many publications of the Christian Literature Society.
('39', 315, 4, 36, 638299) A lady wrote to me the other day saying that unless I embraced Christianity all my work would be nothing worth.
('39', 315, 4, 37, 638411) And of course that Christianity must mean what she understands as such!
('39', 315, 4, 38, 638483) Well, all I can say is that it is a wrong attitude.
('39', 315, 4, 39, 638535) Young India, 11 8 1927

('39', 316, 1, 2, 638603) 304. LETTER TO KAMALA DAS GUPTA
('39', 316, 2, 3, 638635) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, July 30, 1927
('39', 316, 3, 4, 638673) MY DEAR FRIEND, I hope you will not mind my dictating what is a reply to a personal letter.
('39', 316, 3, 5, 638765) You are not the only girl with the difficulties mentioned by you.
('39', 316, 3, 6, 638831) But if you have patience, perseverance in your ideals and humility, you will have no difficulty in conquering your parents pressure.
('39', 316, 3, 7, 638964) For, after all,they have to go by the ordinary experience and the ordinary experience is that both young men and young women have often entertained lofty ideas in moments of enthusiasm which they are not able to carry out to the end.
('39', 316, 3, 8, 639198) I myself know many such instances.
('39', 316, 3, 9, 639233) Parents are therefore cautious and chary of taking seriously their childrens lofty ideals.
('39', 316, 3, 10, 639324) If your parents insist upon your marriage how could they permit you to go to the Sabarmati Ashram?
('39', 316, 3, 11, 639423) And then I must warn you against drawing a flattering picture of the Ashram.
('39', 316, 3, 12, 639500) It is a place for toilers, those who believe in the necessity and the moral value of labouring with their hands and feet.Then English is rarely spoken there.
('39', 316, 3, 13, 639658) Knowledge of Hindi is an absolute necessity.
('39', 316, 3, 14, 639703) I know the standard of Bethune College girls.
('39', 316, 3, 15, 639749) If you have learnt to consider what is provided in that college and what the girls provide themselves with there to be your necessaries, you are hardly likely to be satisfied with the simplicity of the Ashram life.
('39', 316, 3, 16, 639964) But in spite of my warning, if you still feel drawn to the Ashram and your parents permit you, I shall send your name to the Managing Board.
('39', 316, 3, 17, 640105) In your next letter please give me some more particulars about you.
('39', 316, 3, 18, 640173) Give me your age, the occupation of your father and such other things that you think I should know.

('39', 318, 9, 19, 643103) 308. SPEECH AT CHAMARAJENDRA SANSKRIT PATHASHALA, BANGALORE July 30, 1927
('39', 318, 10, 20, 643177) I appreciate the honour you have done me in giving me a Sanskrit address.
('39', 318, 10, 21, 643251) I hold that every Hindu boy and girl must acquire a knowledge of Sanskrit, and that every Hindu should have enough knowledge of Sanskrit to be able to express himself in that language whenever an occasion arises.
('39', 318, 10, 22, 643464) I was pained to hear that there were pundits in the Mysore State who fought shy of teaching Sanskrit to Sudras and Panchamas.
('39', 319, 0, 1, 643590) 320 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 319, 1, 2, 643632) not know how far the contention that the Sudras have no right to learn Sanskrit and hence to read the Vedas is supported by the authority of scriptures, but as a sanatani Hindu I am firmly of opinion that even if there is any authority we must not kill the spirit of our religion by a literal interpretation of the texts.
('39', 319, 1, 3, 643954) Words have, like man himself, an evolution, and even a Vedic text must be rejected if it is repugnant to reason and contrary to experience.
('39', 319, 1, 4, 644094) Thus so far as I understand the Shastras I think that there is no authority in them for untouchability as we understand it today, and my experience of the so called untouchables in different parts of India has shown me that man to man the untouchable is in no way inferior to his touchable brother either intellectually or morally.
('39', 319, 1, 5, 644426) I know suppressed class people who are leading as clean and moral lives as any one of us, and I have seen Adi Karnataka boys who read and recite Sanskrit verses as well as any of the Brahmin boys and girls here.
('39', 319, 1, 6, 644638) I am grateful therefore that you should have thought fit to invite a man of such radical views in your midst, and even to vote an address to him, and to approve of those views in the address.
('39', 319, 1, 7, 644830) I am glad to see so many Brahmins plying their taklis, but I want you not to confine yourselves to making your sacred threads out of the yarn.
('39', 319, 1, 8, 644973) The yajnopavits 1 of course will continue to be of takli yarn, but you will make your clothes also from that yarn or charkha yarn.
('39', 319, 1, 9, 645104) I tell you I was pained to see boys and girls dressed in foreign clothes reciting verses from scriptures.
('39', 319, 1, 10, 645210) To say the least, it struck me to be incongruous.
('39', 319, 1, 11, 645260) The external is in no way the essence of religion, but the external oft proclaims the internal, and whenever therefore I go to a Sanskrit college or an institution where Aryan culture is taught, I look forward to being reminded of the simple and sacred surroundings of our ancient rishis.
('39', 319, 1, 12, 645549) I am sorry that you have not fulfilled my expectation, and I appeal to the teachers and the parents of these children to make the children true representatives of ancient culture.
('39', 319, 2, 13, 645729) Young India, 18 8 1927

('39', 320, 1, 2, 645832) 309. NATURES WRATH
('39', 320, 2, 3, 645851) Nature never acts in anger.
('39', 320, 2, 4, 645879) Its laws work unfailingly, like good clock.
('39', 320, 2, 5, 645923) No changes ever occur in them.
('39', 320, 2, 6, 645954) In fact Nature has not even reserved the right to change them, nor does it need to do so.
('39', 320, 2, 7, 646044) Nature is perfect, and her laws too are perfect.
('39', 320, 2, 8, 646093) But we do not know these laws and, therefore, when they surprise us by their working we describe them as Natures wrath.
('39', 320, 2, 9, 646213) She has just shown such wrath against Gujarat.
('39', 320, 2, 10, 646260) How can I, staying in far away Bangalore, form a true idea of this miniature pralaya 1?
('39', 320, 2, 11, 646348) My only means of knowing its magnitude are the reports appearing in newspapers and one wire from Vallabhbhai and another from the Ashram.
('39', 320, 2, 12, 646486) God alone knows whether this flood is a punishment for some sins of ours or some event which, on certain conditions being fulfilled, may give us some needed benefit.
('39', 320, 2, 13, 646652) We would do well to regard it as a punishment for our sins.
('39', 320, 2, 14, 646712) There is not only no great difference between moral sins and economic sins, but on the contrary the two kinds of sins are closely related.
('39', 320, 2, 15, 646851) Among the three classes of sins, telling lies, dirtying the river water and raising an opium or tobacco crop in the fields in place of wheat there is only a difference of degree, none of kind.
('39', 320, 2, 16, 647044) It is not true that one who tells a lie suffers spiritually but he who dirties the water does not, or that the soul of him who raises an opium crop prospers.
('39', 320, 2, 17, 647202) As our discrimination improves, we understand the nature of our sins better.
('39', 320, 2, 18, 647279) If, however, we wait doing nothing till we know our sins better and take no steps to relieve the peoples losses which we see with our naked eyes, we would be reckoned fools.
('39', 320, 2, 19, 647453) Vallabhbhai has started a fund on behalf of the Provincial Committee 2 , and Manilal Kothari 3 is going round to meet people to collect contributions to it.
('39', 320, 2, 20, 647610) There was a telegram from him to say that philanthropic rich men have already contributed Rs. 30,000. Let people contribute as much as they can.
('39', 320, 2, 21, 647755) Though it avails little to try to mend a rent in the sky, 4 if everyone helps to the best of his ability the
('39', 320, 3, 22, 647864) 1 The universal flood which is believed to end a cycle of creation.
('39', 320, 3, 23, 647932) Gandhiji here refers to the unprecedented floods in Gujarat in July 1927. 2 Gujarat Provincial Congress Committee 3 A Congress worker of Saurashtra who worked for many years as Secretary of the Gujarat Provincial Congress Committee 4 A Gujarati saying
('39', 321, 0, 1, 648184) 322 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 321, 1, 2, 648226) people cannot but feel cheered by the sympathy thus shown.
('39', 321, 1, 3, 648285) The Committee will try to reach as many people as it can.
('39', 321, 1, 4, 648343) As yet, it is not even likely to have an idea of how many people have suffered, or how much they have suffered and in what manner.
('39', 321, 1, 5, 648474) Some details, which I do not know at the moment of writing this (on August 1) will have become known by the time this appears in print.
('39', 321, 1, 6, 648610) On knowing them, those who have paid nothing as yet should pay something and so contribute to this essential relief work.
('39', 321, 1, 7, 648732) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 7 8 1927

('39', 326, 1, 2, 656173) 316. SPEECH TO LAMBANIS, ARSIKERE JUNCTION 1
('39', 326, 2, 3, 656218) August 2, 1927 You must all wear khaddar; it is made by your people, and the cost goes to feed them.
('39', 326, 2, 4, 656319) You must all completely give up drinking and flesh eating.

('39', 328, 5, 11, 659590) 320. LETTER TO V. V. DASTANE
('39', 328, 6, 12, 659619) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, August 3, 1927
('39', 328, 7, 13, 659658) MY DEAR DASTANE, I have your letter.
('39', 328, 7, 14, 659695) I like the idea of Malaviyaji touring Maharashtra in the interest of khadi.
('39', 328, 7, 15, 659771) But I do not want you to trouble him just now.
('39', 328, 7, 16, 659818) He is himself in a weak state of health, and we must not be party to putting any strain upon it.
('39', 328, 7, 17, 659915) Then again the workers do not now need the stimulation of further awakening and spectacular meetings.
('39', 328, 7, 18, 660017) You have hardly yet time to consolidate the energy set free during my tour.
('39', 328, 7, 19, 660093) You have to build up and put on a solid basis all the different centres that have been brought into existence.
('39', 328, 7, 20, 660204) Watch the work in the different centres and put Pimparala itself on a solid foundation.
('39', 328, 7, 21, 660292) All this means that you should be free from having to organize any big tours at present.
('39', 328, 7, 22, 660381) And, thirdly, if Professor Kale, the Kesari people and others who have hitherto stood aside from khadi are inclined to view it with favour, let that sentiment silently grow.
('39', 328, 7, 23, 660555) It does not need any encouragment from you or me; but it is bound to be encouraged by any solid achievement we may show in the shape of larger production, regular silent improvement in quality, reduction in prices and steady employment of young men.
('39', 328, 7, 24, 660805) You must learn not to live on stimulants.
('39', 328, 7, 25, 660847) Do you not agree?
('39', 328, 8, 26, 660865) Yours sincerely,

('39', 332, 1, 2, 664435) 326. SPEECH AT TOWN HALL, HASSAN 1
('39', 332, 2, 3, 664470) August 3, 1927
('39', 332, 3, 4, 664485) FRIENDS, You have given me addresses of welcome and you have given me a purse, and I thank you for the same.
('39', 332, 3, 5, 664594) I am also pleased to hear of your khadi work and your invitation to open your Khaddar Co operative Society.
('39', 332, 3, 6, 664702) I must also thank you for your work in the uplift of the Adi Karnatakas.
('39', 332, 3, 7, 664775) In doing so, let me remind you that this great work cannot be fully accomplished merely by the establishment of a school, etc.
('39', 332, 3, 8, 664902) You must do the work in your heart.
('39', 332, 3, 9, 664938) You must get rid of the untouchability feeling from your thoughts.
('39', 332, 3, 10, 665005) You must know that there is no sanction in the Shastras for such thinking.
('39', 332, 3, 11, 665080) When you get that feeling of brotherliness, when you get that oneness of feeling between you all, Hindus and Mussalmans, and both sexes, when you get that feeling by using khadi, every one of you, then only our condition, and the conditition of our country is going to improve and not until then.
('39', 332, 3, 12, 665377) That is the force of khadi and, in establishing your Khadi Co operative Society, you must all co operate in this great task.
('39', 332, 3, 13, 665502) That task is to give food to the starving poor of your place, for, when you take khaddar and make others purchase it, the weavers who wove and the spinners who spun are sure of their wages and of their food.
('39', 332, 3, 14, 665710) Are you going to help this cause?
('39', 332, 3, 15, 665744) I am appealing to you for your help.
('39', 332, 3, 16, 665781) I once more express my satisfaction at your efforts to establish an institute for the Adi Karnatakas on the lines of the Tuskegee Institute of Booker T. Washington.
('39', 332, 3, 17, 665946) Friends, now, the need is for many such institutions all over the country.
('39', 332, 3, 18, 666021) The names of General Armstrong and Booker T. Washington are very great names of service and sacrifice; I want you to understand and realize the amount of their work.
('39', 332, 3, 19, 666187) I want our educated friends to realize this.
('39', 332, 3, 20, 666232) I want them also to realize that when they are propagating intellectual culture, they must also inculcate the principle of dignity of labour as is done in those institutions.
('39', 332, 3, 21, 666407) Please remember this.
('39', 332, 3, 22, 666429) I thank you all for your reception.
('39', 332, 3, 23, 666465) The Hindu, 5 8 1927

('39', 333, 6, 8, 667003) 328. INDIAN SHIPPING The ceremony performed by Sjt.
('39', 333, 6, 9, 667055) Vithalbhai Patel at the launching of Jalabala, the Scindia Steam Navigation Companys new ship, does not evoke any feeling of national pride or rejoicing.
('39', 333, 6, 10, 667209) It only serves as a reminder of our fallen state.
('39', 333, 6, 11, 667259) What is the addition of one little ship to our microscopic fleet?
('39', 333, 6, 12, 667325) The sadness of the reminder is heightened by the fact that our mercantile fleet may at any moment be turned into a fleet warring against our own liberty or against that of nations with which India has no quarrel and with whose aspirations India may even have every sympathy, as for instance, China.
('39', 333, 6, 13, 667624) There is nothing to prevent the Government from commandeering any one of the ships belonging to the swadeshi companies for carrying soldiers to punish China for daring to fight for liberty.
('39', 333, 6, 14, 667814) There is no wonder, therefore, that Vithalbhai Patel, who in spite of his being the Speaker of the Legislative Assembly cannot cease to be an ardent nationalist, recalled the history of the calculated destruction of Indias mercantile marine.
('39', 333, 6, 15, 668056) He pointed out to his audience that there was a time when first rate vessels built, owned, manned and managed by Indians used to carry the rich products of India to distant lands. A combination of circumstances, which the speaker did not think it worth while to mention, made it extremely difficult for Indians to pursue it, killed that industry outright, and subsequently made it extremely difficult for Indians to revive their past glory. Sjt.
('39', 333, 6, 16, 668502) Vithalbhai went on : It is again interesting to note that shipping companies were started during the last 50 years in India, but they were all wiped out of existence by the rate war and other methods, about which the less said the better. But even as a patient derives comfort, if anything gives him a
('39', 334, 0, 1, 668804) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 335
('39', 334, 1, 2, 668849) little hope and a little energy, and the whole family joins him rejoicing over the acquisition of slight unexpected strength, so did Vithalbhai Patel derive joy and hope from the launching of this new enterprise of the Scindia Steam Navigation Company.
('39', 334, 1, 3, 669102) Let us hope that Jalabala will be a precursor of many other steamers and that in the near future it would be possible to revive the old ship building trade of India, and for some patriot to perform the ceremony of launching an India built ship on Indian waters free of the fear of its being used for warring against ourselves or any other nation and free from the greed of exploitation of any other country.
('39', 334, 1, 4, 669510) Young India, 4 8 1927

('39', 334, 4, 12, 670009) 330. VILLAGE CATTLE IMPROVEMENT
('39', 334, 5, 13, 670041) This week I give Mr. Smiths note 2 on a co operative scheme for the improvement of village cattle.
('39', 334, 5, 14, 670140) The pinjrapole scheme published in the issue of July 7th 3 is capable of being enforced almost immediately, because the machinery is ready and only requires supplementary improvement, whereas the proposed scheme for the villages outside the ghee producing tract and remote from cities is comparatively difficult of operation.
('39', 334, 5, 15, 670466) But real improvement has to begin from these numerous villages, which, on account of economic pressure and the ignorance of people in cattle breeding, helplessly become centres for slaughter houses to draw upon.
('39', 334, 5, 16, 670678) If a careful student were to study the movement of cattle that find themselves in the numerous slaughter 
('39', 334, 6, 17, 670784) 1 Not reproduced here.
('39', 334, 6, 18, 670807) The lecturer spoke highly of the value of spinning in the education of temperamental children.
('39', 334, 6, 19, 670902) 2 Not reproduced here 3 By Y. M. Parnerkar; vide Work before Pinjrapoles, 7 7 1927
('39', 335, 0, 1, 670985) 336 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 335, 1, 2, 671027) houses of India, he will find that agents who know no principle save that of making money as fast as possible and anyhow purchase cattle from these remote villages for the slaughter houses.
('39', 335, 1, 3, 671217) A gosevak is not easily made, certainly never for the wishing.
('39', 335, 1, 4, 671280) He has to study his art as much as an engineer or a lawyer or a doctor, and has to take more pains than any of them.
('39', 335, 1, 5, 671397) Mr. Smiths scheme should, therefore, be studied by those who desire the welfare of cattle and of Indian villages, with a view to putting it into operation in select villages.
('39', 335, 1, 6, 671572) There is nothing sacrosanct about the scheme.
('39', 335, 1, 7, 671618) It serves as a model for one who knows nothing about cattle breeding or co operative schemes.
('39', 335, 1, 8, 671712) Nor need a non co operator be frightened of it, because of the mention of Government co operative department.
('39', 335, 1, 9, 671822) There is no such thing as national non co operation at the present moment.
('39', 335, 1, 10, 671897) When it was in vogue, it did not touch all Government departments.
('39', 335, 1, 11, 671964) There were non co operators who did not taboo co operative societies, and I know several today who call themselves non co operators although they belong to active co operative organizations.
('39', 335, 1, 12, 672155) But a gosevak who does not wish to take advantage of a statutory co operative society may still utilize the scheme.
('39', 335, 1, 13, 672271) Indeed I do not know that on the whole it would not be better to do without seeking the shelter of a statutory society.
('39', 335, 1, 14, 672391) He may take the advice of the co operative department if it will whole heartedly give it to him, and may also make use of studs if any are available.
('39', 335, 1, 15, 672541) The chief thing is to make a beginning in the matter of the education of villagers in cattle improvement.
('39', 335, 1, 16, 672647) The proposed scheme is a help in that direction.
('39', 335, 1, 17, 672696) Mr. Smith promises a double increase in the value of cattle and the yield of milk if the scheme is properly worked.

('39', 336, 1, 2, 672879) 331. HELP GUJARAT Proud Gujarat is laid low and she who has hitherto filled the beggars bowl is now obliged to take the bowl herself.
('39', 336, 1, 3, 673013) I have had up to now nothing to go by except the newspaper reports.
('39', 336, 1, 4, 673081) Though Sjt.
('39', 336, 1, 5, 673093) Vallabhbhai Patel was preparing me for the worst through his private wires he was unable to give details.
('39', 336, 1, 6, 673199) I give below his telegram just received on my return from Hassan : 1
('39', 336, 2, 7, 673268) Most part Gujarat North of Narmada and Kathiawar devastated.
('39', 336, 2, 8, 673329) People rendered homeless.
('39', 336, 2, 9, 673355) Cattle and belongings washed away.
('39', 336, 2, 10, 673390) Total damage in crores.
('39', 336, 2, 11, 673414) Loss of life small except in Baroda.
('39', 336, 2, 12, 673451) Kheda district is worst with 100 inches of rain.
('39', 336, 2, 13, 673500) Borsad still isolated.
('39', 336, 2, 14, 673523) Piteous appeals for help coming from all parts of Gujarat and Kathiawar.
('39', 336, 2, 15, 673596) Public meeting was held on August 2nd, Relief Committees formed.
('39', 336, 2, 16, 673661) Three lakhs for food relief Ahmedabad district and ten lakhs for advancing loans reconstruction of houses to be raised.
('39', 336, 2, 17, 673781) Provincial relief to be separately conducted under Prantik Samiti.
('39', 336, 2, 18, 673848) Relief centres have been opened under Amritlal Thakkar, Lakshmidas Purushottam and Narahari Parikh respectively at Anand, Nadiad and Mehmedabad.
('39', 336, 2, 19, 673993) Maganlal Gandhi will reach Borsad and establish communications.
('39', 336, 2, 20, 674057) Other centres are also being reached and relief operations started.
('39', 336, 2, 21, 674125) Amritlal Sheth is trying to reach areas of Kathiawar and is organizing relief.
('39', 336, 2, 22, 674204) The immediate problem is one of saving life by the timely supply of foodstuffs.
('39', 336, 2, 23, 674284) Local resources are inadequate.
('39', 336, 2, 24, 674316) Pray issue a general appeal to all India for succour without delay.
('39', 336, 2, 25, 674384) Fulchand Shah sends a detailed wire from Nadiad about Kheda.
('39', 336, 2, 26, 674445) Dr. Chandulal of Broach sends an angry wire asking me what I intend doing towards the relief of the distress in Gujarat.
('39', 336, 2, 27, 674566) I have been dumbstruck by the newspaper reports.
('39', 336, 2, 28, 674615) Those who know anything of the devastating floods in the South can somewhat realize what a howling wilderness parts of Gujarat must have become.
('39', 336, 2, 29, 674760) Kheda owes its fertility to the industry of its resourceful farmers.
('39', 336, 2, 30, 674829) It is no joke for them to find the whole of their crops washed away and their fields stinking with the stench of the carcasses of their valuable and splendid cattle.
('39', 336, 2, 31, 674995) I know that no human effort can possibly make up for the loss of crores worth of crops, cattle and belongings, together with rich manure washed away into the ocean, but human sympathy can do much to relieve the mental agony of the people who have lost their all.
('39', 336, 3, 32, 675258) 1 Gandhiji returned from Hassan on 4th evening.

('39', 337, 2, 11, 676079) 332. LETTER TO H. HARCOURT 1
('39', 337, 3, 12, 676108) AS AT THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, August 4, 1927
('39', 337, 4, 13, 676152) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your warm letter.
('39', 337, 4, 14, 676199) You may not know that I expressed before the trying judge the same sentiments that you express, namely, that my viewpoint not being accepted, the Government was bound to arrest and imprison me.
('39', 337, 4, 15, 676393) The challenge to Government to do either the one or the other was for me the only honourable course, and, in my opinion, the only alternative to violent rebellion on the part of those who rightly or wrongly feel oppressed.
('39', 337, 4, 16, 676616) But the largest part of my life has been devoted and is still being devoted to finding points of contact rather than difference.
('39', 337, 4, 17, 676745) But experience has abundantly proved to me that to every honest man there come in his life occasions for parting of ways which I have termed Non co operation.
('39', 337, 5, 18, 676904) Yours sincerely, H. HARCOURT, ESQ.
('39', 337, 5, 19, 676939) 119, GIPSY HILL LONDON S.E. 19

('39', 338, 1, 2, 677101) 333. LETTER TO G. A. PATKAR
('39', 338, 2, 3, 677129) AS AT THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, August 4, 1927
('39', 338, 3, 4, 677173) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('39', 338, 3, 5, 677206) Your idea of starting a fund is praiseworthy; but I am afraid it will not work.
('39', 338, 3, 6, 677286) It is not a small thing for one who draws a salary of Rs. 50 to save Rs. 5 out of it every month, and I have found even amongst those who can afford, very few steadily paying.
('39', 338, 3, 7, 677462) Nor, when the capital required is collected in the manner you suggest, is it an easy thing to start industries.
('39', 338, 3, 8, 677574) The starting of industries requires more than mere capital.
('39', 338, 3, 9, 677634) And, thirdly, my own time which owing to my failing health is limited is entirely absorbed by the industry of khadi, and if your friends would be content to pay their quota to this national industry, I shall be pleased to receive it, but not for any other industry.
('39', 338, 4, 10, 677900) Yours sincerely,

('39', 341, 1, 2, 684069) 335. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('39', 341, 2, 3, 684093) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, August 5, 1927
('39', 341, 3, 4, 684132) MIRA, I have your letter.
('39', 341, 3, 5, 684158) I understand and do not mind the distinction you draw between Wardha and Sabarmati.
('39', 341, 3, 6, 684242) I am glad you have written to Bhansali.
('39', 341, 3, 7, 684282) There is nothing further about the Ashram beyond what I wrote to you.
('39', 341, 3, 8, 684352) The learning of Hindi must not be a strain upon you.
('39', 341, 3, 9, 684405) You must not do it as a task.
('39', 341, 3, 10, 684435) Immediately it gets on your nerves, you must let it go.
('39', 341, 3, 11, 684491) I have told you that I have infinite patience and I shall certainly not take you to task if you cant finish your programme in two months time.
('39', 341, 3, 12, 684634) The work must give you pleasure, and it must be left off as soon as it fatigues you.
('39', 341, 3, 13, 684719) If I knew what work is to be given to you as soon as you go to the Ashram, I would certainly tell you; but I do not know it myself.
('39', 341, 3, 14, 684851) I quite agree with your argument against teaching English, and I shall certainly avoid giving that work.
('39', 341, 3, 15, 684956) So far as I can see at present, it will be some work to be done in company.
('39', 341, 3, 16, 685032) For, I want you to be accustomed to different temperaments and working under circumstances no matter how adverse they may be.
('39', 341, 3, 17, 685158) But if you have any choice, by no means tell me.
('39', 341, 3, 18, 685207) My own habit is never to tax myself about things which I need not decide at the moment.
('39', 341, 3, 19, 685295) But if you will begin to think of it from now, by all means do, and discuss with me through your letters.
('39', 341, 3, 20, 685401) In no case would I have given you anything without first consulting you.
('39', 341, 3, 21, 685474) I shall certainly want to know your choice whether now or after you have gone to the Ashram.
('39', 341, 3, 22, 685567) It is quite right your not having written to the Rao Saheb until you had the inspiration.
('39', 341, 3, 23, 685657) There is no hurry, and so long as the proper language does not come you need not write at all.
('39', 341, 3, 24, 685752) I just returned from touring this morning to find your letter.
('39', 341, 3, 25, 685815) The touring will be resumed on the 9th instant.
('39', 341, 3, 26, 685863) Then probably I shall be away for nearly 10 days.
('39', 341, 3, 27, 685913) But it would be safer to send your letter to Bangalore.
('39', 341, 3, 28, 685969) I said Bangalore City before, but I find that Bangalore brings your letters two hours earlier.
('39', 341, 3, 29, 686064) Kumara Park is not served from the City office but from the Central office.
('39', 341, 3, 30, 686140) With love, SRIMATI MIRABAI WARDHA

('39', 342, 6, 8, 686432) 337. LETTER TO MAHARAJA OF MYSORE
('39', 342, 7, 9, 686466) BANGALORE, August 5 [1927] 3
('39', 342, 8, 10, 686495) DEAR FRIEND, Next Monday 4 will be perhaps next to your coronation the happiest day in your life.
('39', 342, 8, 11, 686593) In what manner should I send you my felicitations?
('39', 342, 8, 12, 686644) Not by mere words of good wishes however well meant they may be.
('39', 342, 8, 13, 686709) But I feel that I could not as a true friend do less than suggest your doing for your poorest subjects what you seem so successfully to have done for the middle class, the town dwellers.
('39', 342, 8, 14, 686896) You may not be able to do anything striking so soon as Monday next.
('39', 342, 8, 15, 686964) But is it impossible to do away with the drink traffic?
('39', 342, 8, 16, 687020) It is ruining the people.
('39', 342, 8, 17, 687046) It has been a matter of deep joy to me to learn wherever I have gone nothing but praise of your benevolence and purity.
('39', 342, 8, 18, 687166) The drink curse under a rule so good appears to be so out of tune.
('39', 342, 8, 19, 687233) But I must not turn what is meant the heart wish of a friend into a lecture.
('39', 342, 8, 20, 687310) May you be long spared to give happiness to your people and to make yours a model State in every sense of the term.
('39', 342, 8, 21, 687426) I shall pray on Monday for a due fulfilment of all your noblest wishes.
('39', 342, 10, 22, 687498) Your Highnesss

('39', 343, 7, 11, 688396) 339. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS BY MOOLCHAND AGRAWAL [August 5, 1927] 2
('39', 343, 8, 12, 688462) [Q.] 1. Do you believe in the distinct existence of TrinityNature, Soul and
('39', 343, 9, 13, 688538) [A.] I do believe but the word distinct sticks in the throat, for though the three are separate in name they are one in substance.
('39', 343, 10, 14, 688669) 2. Whether soul is one or numerous?
('39', 343, 10, 15, 688705) Has it entirely its separate existence or is it a portion of the Great AtmanGod?
('39', 343, 10, 16, 688786) Souls seem to be many; but underneath the seeming variety, there is an essential oneness.
('39', 343, 11, 17, 688876) 3. If it is particle [of God] it ought to be all knowing, quite free from all evils and should possess all the qualities of God, as a particle of fire, water or gold possesses all the talents of the whole from which it is separated.
('39', 343, 11, 18, 689109) In its essence the soul is free from all evil, but torn from its source it partakes of evil and all other limitations even as drop of water torn from its source and found as part of a dirty pool seems for the time being to partake of the pools dirt.
('39', 343, 12, 19, 689359) 4. We often see that a man does evil deeds.
('39', 343, 12, 20, 689403) Whence that evil comes?
('39', 343, 13, 21, 689427) 1 Presumably written on the same date as the preceding item 2 Vide the succeeding item.
('39', 344, 0, 1, 689515) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 345
('39', 344, 1, 2, 689560) We should be satisfied to know that there is evil in the world and that it has got to be avoided.
('39', 344, 1, 3, 689658) If we knew its origin we should be God Almighty.
('39', 344, 1, 4, 689707) But at the present we are in the unfortunate position of that drop of water in the dirty pool, and whilst we are doers of evil deeds, we must suffer the consequences thereof.
('39', 344, 2, 5, 689882) 5. In the world we see different men.
('39', 344, 2, 6, 689920) Those who work and do right deeds are gifted; those who do wrong or bad deeds are punished and have to suffer.
('39', 344, 2, 7, 690031) This is all in accordance with the theory of karma.
('39', 344, 2, 8, 690083) When one suffersas a peasant or a labourer in India does at present, he suffers through his own past deeds, that is the Will of God.
('39', 344, 2, 9, 690216) Why should we interfere in the Will of God by helping him so that he may not suffer?
('39', 344, 2, 10, 690301) If the Indian peasant was isolated and was seated on some mountain top, we shall not be perhaps responsible for his state.
('39', 344, 2, 11, 690424) But seeing that he is part of the same society that we are, we cannot divest ourselves of responsibility for his even state as that drop of water in the pool cannot.
('39', 344, 2, 12, 690590) Why God suffers this evil to exist, I am thankful to feel that He alone knows.
('39', 344, 3, 13, 690669) 6. Instead of devoting our energies for the good of others should we not
('39', 344, 4, 14, 690742) devote our energies in acquiring knowledge or earning money for ourselves or at the most for our relatives and neighbours and that too because they may help us in time of need?
('39', 344, 4, 15, 690919) Precisely for the reason that we may help our relatives, must we help all others whom in our ignorance we refuse to recognize as relatives.
('39', 344, 4, 16, 691059) We are like the drop of water.
('39', 344, 4, 17, 691090) It enjoys even that dirty existence by the help of its neighbours at the farthest end; for, its near neighbours have to depend upon theirs and so on to the end.
('39', 344, 5, 18, 691251) 7. Yourself as well as others define swarajya as control over the self, reformation, betterment or improvement of the self, and also it is evident, that if one
('39', 344, 6, 19, 691411) controls and improves or reforms himself, the society or the nation will be reformed by itself as the nation is a composition of individuals.
('39', 344, 6, 20, 691553) It is a correct statement; self rule is home rule.
('39', 344, 7, 21, 691604) From a photostat : G.N. 765

('39', 345, 10, 12, 692153) I like your three rules about preservation of health.
('39', 345, 10, 13, 692207) The two I understand thoroughly.
('39', 345, 10, 14, 692240) For, I myself dont believe in worry and always try to snatch moments for sleep and possess a fair capacity for going off to sleep almost at will.

('39', 345, 10, 19, 692539) 10 or 15 days before each voyage.
('39', 345, 10, 20, 692573) This requires explanation.
('39', 345, 10, 21, 692600) 10 or 15 is a very vague number.
('39', 345, 10, 22, 692633) For, 10 days or 15 days make a great difference for a fasting man, at least such is my experience.
('39', 345, 10, 23, 692732) And what is this fasting?
('39', 345, 10, 24, 692758) Do you take nothing during the fast except water, not fruit, not milk?
('39', 345, 10, 25, 692829) Have you record of your weight before and after fast?
('39', 345, 10, 26, 692883) How often have you taken these fasts?
('39', 345, 10, 27, 692921) What is your weight now, and what is the meaning of each voyage?
('39', 345, 10, 28, 692986) What is its duration?
('39', 345, 10, 29, 693008) Do you fast, for instance, if you have to be at sea for one day only?
('39', 345, 10, 30, 693078) You say you take one meal about midday at a time of intense activity.
('39', 345, 10, 31, 693148) What does that meal consist of?
('39', 345, 10, 32, 693180) And, do you take no fruit, no milk, no other drink except water either in the morning or in the evening?
('39', 345, 10, 33, 693285) Then, again you say you fast only when you have too much weight.
('39', 345, 10, 34, 693350) Do you then say
('39', 345, 11, 35, 693366) 1 Gandhiji was in Bangalore on this date in 1927. 2 Vide the preceding item.

('39', 346, 1, 2, 693524) that you have always too much weight before each voyage?
('39', 346, 1, 3, 693581) And why do you ever have too much weight if you are a spare eater as you evidently seem to be?
('39', 346, 1, 4, 693676) When you are not intensely active, how many meals do you take?
('39', 346, 1, 5, 693739) Then you say that you use at least 20 quarts of water to clear your bowels every day, until the water is returned clean and transparent and this you do when you have too much weight.What do you mean by use of water?
('39', 346, 1, 6, 693955) Is it enema, or do you drink 20 quarts, even whilst you are taking your one meal per day?
('39', 346, 1, 7, 694045) If you drink it, do you work it out through the kidneys or through the bowels?
('39', 346, 1, 8, 694124) The experience of myself and all my friends who have fasted for long lengths of time is that when we have fasted for long lengths of time is that when we have fasted the water has to pass through the kidneys, never through the bowels unless we have taken the enema.
('39', 346, 1, 9, 694390) As you may know I am deeply interested in all experiments in fasting and dietetics whether merely for health or spiritual growth.
('39', 346, 2, 10, 694520) Yours sincerely, PROF.
('39', 346, 2, 11, 694543) W. LUTOSTAWSKI JAGIELLONSKA 7 m.

('39', 347, 13, 17, 695522) 345. DEATH OF A SATYAGRAHI
('39', 347, 14, 18, 695549) Perhaps all readers of Navajivan may not be familiar with the name of Shri Harilal Maneklal Desai.
('39', 347, 14, 19, 695648) He died a few days ago in Broach.
('39', 347, 14, 20, 695682) A friend who lived with him says in a letter that his face was lit up with an expression of joy till the very end.
('39', 347, 14, 21, 695797) Shri Harilal resigned from the Baroda High School at the time of the Non co operation movement.
('39', 347, 14, 22, 695893) He was the French teacher there.
('39', 347, 14, 23, 695926) From then until his death he retained unwavering faith in non co operation.
('39', 347, 14, 24, 696002) He strove to the best of his ability to follow truth as he understood it, and so I called him a satyagrahi.
('39', 347, 14, 25, 696110) His humility was an ornament to his love of truth.
('39', 347, 14, 26, 696161) He toured with me for a while in the early days of the Non co operation movement and I was struck at that time by his clean method of work, his thoroughness and alertness.
('39', 347, 14, 27, 696333) During those days it was he who replied to many of the letters I received, and helped me in other ways.
('39', 347, 14, 28, 696437) During that period of my
('39', 347, 15, 29, 696462) 1 In reply to her telegram received on August 6, 1927, which read : Dear Bapu even risking your health do visit Gujarat.
('39', 347, 15, 30, 696583) Your presence essential.
('39', 347, 15, 31, 696608) Give moral succour and solace in terrible distress.
('39', 347, 15, 32, 696660) All friends join me this request.

('39', 348, 1, 2, 696739) association with him, I could see that he took great pains to understand satyagraha and non co operation.
('39', 348, 1, 3, 696845) He started khadi work in Kapadwanj by his unaided efforts and made a success of it.
('39', 348, 1, 4, 696929) During the last years of his life, he helped the Broach Education Society and did whatever teaching work came his way.
('39', 348, 1, 5, 697048) Among the names which I have mentally noted of those who can be relied upon to plunge into a civil disobedience movement if such an auspicious occasion arises, Haribhais was one.
('39', 348, 1, 6, 697227) Cruel fate has now erased that name.
('39', 348, 1, 7, 697264) A satyagrahi, however, does not feel sorry even for this.
('39', 348, 1, 8, 697322) A satyagrahi friend helps even in death as much as he does when alive.
('39', 348, 1, 9, 697393) To live on in death is the great mantra which inspires his life.

('39', 349, 1, 2, 698469) 347. LETTER TO GULZAR MOHAMAD AQUIL
('39', 349, 2, 3, 698505) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, August 7, 1927
('39', 349, 3, 4, 698544) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter and I am glad you have written to me.
('39', 349, 3, 5, 698614) I am indeed aware of the unfortunate controversy over the book Rangila Rasul.
('39', 349, 3, 6, 698692) You may not know that probably long before you knew the book or its contents, it came into my hands and I denounced it in strong language in the columns of Young India.
('39', 349, 3, 7, 698861) This happened three years ago.
('39', 349, 3, 8, 698892) I have not the Young India file before me.
('39', 349, 3, 9, 698935) But the book is not a recent publication.
('39', 349, 3, 10, 698977) If you are not a regular reader of Young India I shall be glad to ask the manager to send you the reference.
('39', 349, 3, 11, 699086) I have taken no part in the present controversy because I think that the Mussalman agitation is almost altogether wrong.
('39', 349, 3, 12, 699207) Their denunciation of the judge 1 is uncalled for.
('39', 349, 3, 13, 699258) Agitation for an amendment of the law is absolutely proper.
('39', 349, 3, 14, 699318) But whether there is agitation or not the Government will be bound to strengthen the law.
('39', 349, 3, 15, 699408) So far as the merits are concerned, there at least an equal num ber of equally scurrilous anti Hindu writings as anti Islamic.
('39', 349, 3, 16, 699535) All this has been stated by me in clear language in the pages of Young India.
('39', 349, 3, 17, 699613) I do not read all the newspapers.
('39', 349, 3, 18, 699647) The Hindu edited newspapers have not appeared to me to have vigorously or at all supported the action of the author of Rangila Rasul or in any other way disrespectful to the Prophet.
('39', 349, 3, 19, 699830) I shall thank you to let me have the newspapers you have in mind.
('39', 349, 3, 20, 699896) Or, is you will give me the number and names of the newspapers, I shall send for them myself.
('39', 349, 3, 21, 699990) I am sorry to know that you think that the communal taint has affected me.
('39', 349, 3, 22, 700065) So far as I know myself, I can give my assurance that I am the same to my Mussalman brethren that I was in 1920, and it is my constant prayer to God that I may be and remain the same up to the end of my life.
('39', 349, 3, 23, 700274) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI GULZAR MOHAMAD AQUIL, ESQ.

('39', 350, 9, 18, 701552) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, August 7, 1927
('39', 350, 10, 19, 701591) DEAR SATIS BABU, I have your letter.
('39', 350, 10, 20, 701628) You must take only that service from Dr. Ray which he can freely give from his heart.
('39', 350, 10, 21, 701714) Khadi has ultimately to stand on its own merits and legs.
('39', 350, 10, 22, 701772) It is well if we can get real co operation
('39', 351, 0, 1, 701815) 352 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 351, 1, 2, 701857) from our great men.
('39', 351, 1, 3, 701877) But it must be well also if we do not.
('39', 351, 1, 4, 701916) We must rely upon the eternal truth that nothing on this earth that is intrinsically sound and is represented by a living force can possibly die.
('39', 351, 1, 5, 702062) Your difficulties I can understand well.
('39', 351, 1, 6, 702103) And if I had a bagful of coins I could send them to you by express parcel in order to relieve your pecuniary distress; but I have not much hope of getting anything either.
('39', 351, 1, 7, 702275) What I am able to collect in these parts will have to be used for development here.
('39', 351, 1, 8, 702359) Therefore the only way to give pecuniary help to Bengal is for me to go to Bengal when you are ready and tour to collect.
('39', 351, 1, 9, 702481) This year is to go without, and the programme here will have to be carried over to next year, almost up to the end of March with an interval of a fortnight at the Ashram for Ramdas marriage.
('39', 351, 1, 10, 702672) I therefore want you to become accustomed to think that you must manage our business, as it may now be called, with what capital we have.
('39', 351, 1, 11, 702810) Therefore, I would like you, Kshitish Babu and others who are associated with you to confer together and evolve a programme which will save you from all worry and trouble.
('39', 351, 1, 12, 702982) Once we recognize our limitations we shall cease to fret.
('39', 351, 1, 13, 703040) From your letter, I gather that there will be no office in Calcutta proper and that all your work would be done as from Sodepur.
('39', 351, 1, 14, 703169) Will there be a store in Calcutta, or not even that?
('39', 351, 1, 15, 703222) Personally, I would not mind if you thought that there should be no store in Calcutta, that is to say, that there should be none if it was not self supporting.
('39', 351, 1, 16, 703382) I am still keeping fit.
('39', 351, 1, 17, 703406) I shall be in and about Bangalore up to the 28th of this month, if there is no peremptory call from Gujarat owing to the floods.
('39', 351, 1, 18, 703535) Pressure is being put upon me to go there.
('39', 351, 1, 19, 703578) But till Vallabhbhai wants me, I shall resist the pressure.
('39', 351, 1, 20, 703638) For I know that I can do nothing by my mere presence if I cannot do active work.

('39', 355, 1, 2, 707472) 356. LETTER TO JAMINI BHUSHAN MITRA
('39', 355, 2, 3, 707508) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, August 9, 1927
('39', 355, 3, 4, 707547) DEAR JAMINI BABU, I have your letter.
('39', 355, 3, 5, 707585) I appreciate the confidence you repose in me.
('39', 355, 3, 6, 707631) But the attitude you have adopted is wrong.
('39', 355, 3, 7, 707675) Even if I was well, I should be powerless to do anything single handed.
('39', 355, 3, 8, 707747) But I am still more powerless seeing that I could take no part in the administrative work.
('39', 355, 3, 9, 707838) Surely, you and Satis Babu know each other much better than you and I. And if you cannot convince Satis Babu, how shall I be able to help?
('39', 355, 3, 10, 707977) But if you think that Satis Babu is prejudiced against you, you should have self confidence enough to be able to convince the Secretary of the Association and the members of the Council other than Satis Babu of his prejudice.
('39', 355, 3, 11, 708203) I can give you this assurance that Mr. Shankerlal Banker in the first instance and the other members of the Council in the second will consider all you might have to say quite impartially and independently of Satis Babu.
('39', 355, 3, 12, 708424) There is also Dr. Ray and he will surely listen to you as much as to Satis Babu.
('39', 355, 3, 13, 708505) For I know what affection he has for you.
('39', 355, 3, 14, 708547) For my own part I must also add that Satis Babu will not do any conscious injustice to you.
('39', 355, 3, 15, 708639) As a matter of fact, he wrote to me a kind letter about you and nothing will please me better than to find that you have met Satis Babu and become satisfied that he has no prejudice against you.
('39', 355, 3, 16, 708834) After all he has no ends of his own to serve by putting obstacles in your way.
('39', 355, 3, 17, 708913) He has exchanged a life of ease, comfort and honour for one of deprivation, pains, sorrows and self effacement.
('39', 355, 3, 18, 709025) If I am wrong you may correct me.
('39', 355, 3, 19, 709059) It grives me that self sacrificing workers cannot hold together and work away for a cause which is common to them all.
('39', 355, 4, 20, 709178) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('39', 355, 4, 21, 709200) JAMINI BHUSHAN MITRA KALISPUR ASHRAM P.O. BALIKHOLA KHALISPUR KHULNA (BENGAL)

('39', 356, 1, 2, 709353) 357. LETTER TO SWAMI
('39', 356, 2, 3, 709374) August 9, 1927 Your latest telegram.
('39', 356, 2, 4, 709411) 1 I have sent a reply by wire which you must have received.
('39', 356, 2, 5, 709471) Your telegram and your letter are full of your love and your sorrow.
('39', 356, 2, 6, 709540) I expect nothing else of you.
('39', 356, 2, 7, 709570) It is my duty to restrain excess of love.
('39', 356, 2, 8, 709612) I could not see from the figures you sent me that we are at the moment in a position to produce Rs. 25,000. I understand that at present we can somehow balance the two sides.
('39', 356, 2, 9, 709787) But if we have a saving of Rs. 25,000, does it not prove that we must be making a huge profit somewhere or that we do not pay enough to our workers?
('39', 356, 2, 10, 709936) It may or may not be as you say.
('39', 356, 2, 11, 709969) None the less I do feel that if we have the capacity to make this donation it could be done only anonymously.
('39', 356, 2, 12, 710079) If our small institution could make such a large donation, it would have an impact on others and this may arouse jealousy, obviously it could not be emulated.
('39', 356, 2, 13, 710238) Generally, a donation is announced so that others may follow suit.
('39', 356, 2, 14, 710305) Else it is merely showing off.
('39', 356, 2, 15, 710336) For us being in good shape means not being able to give away anything at all.
('39', 356, 2, 16, 710414) I see from your report that the tenements of our workers are in a state of disrepair.
('39', 356, 2, 17, 710500) If our resources permit we should utilize what we can spare for repairing their houses so that they would not be a burden on the public funds.
('39', 356, 2, 18, 710643) I would regard that as our substantial contribution.
('39', 356, 2, 19, 710696) No one here has understood fully the meaning of your telegram.
('39', 356, 2, 20, 710759) If you thought that the workers, etc., would accept minimum wages and pay up the remainder as monthly instalments, I would suggest that as they save up progressively, those savings should be utilized for the benefit of the Dheds and Bhangis and something permanent can thus be achieved.
('39', 356, 2, 21, 711046) I believe all will receive the help urgently needed and they will find their feet.
('39', 356, 2, 22, 711129) If we have earned our money honestly, I wish you to make the purest use of it.
('39', 356, 2, 23, 711208) But you may, if you like, treat all this as needless fuss.

('39', 364, 2, 11, 726699) 365. INDIAN SETTLERS IN SOUTH AFRICA
('39', 364, 3, 12, 726736) Indias first Ambassador has not allowed the grass to grow under his feet.
('39', 364, 3, 13, 726810) He is busily sowing seeds of true union by a seasonable word now addressed to the Europeans and now to the Indian settlers, and he seems to be having fair success with both.
('39', 364, 3, 14, 726984) Europeans gracefully acknowledge his splendid worth and exquisite impartiality.
('39', 364, 3, 15, 727064) Indians gratefully recognize the immense strength of character which backs every word that this great son of India utters.
('39', 364, 4, 16, 727187) He has now appealed to them to produce an army of social workers in the cause of public health and sanitation.
('39', 364, 4, 17, 727298) Let us hope that his appeal will not fall upon deaf ears, and that well to do and educated Indians will respond as zealously as they did when C. F. Andrews appealed to them for assistance for the scavenging work he did during the outbreak of smallpox in Durban some months ago.
('39', 364, 4, 18, 727576) Agent though he is of the Government, if Reuters report is correct, Sjt.
('39', 364, 4, 19, 727649) Sastri did not spare it over its criminal indifference about the sanitary and social welfare of the indentured Indians.
('39', 364, 4, 20, 727769) For the neglect of sanitation amongst the indentured Indians, three parties are really responsiblethe Government of India, the employers, and the Local
('39', 365, 0, 1, 727921) 366 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 365, 1, 2, 727963) Government.
('39', 365, 1, 3, 727975) If the Government of India had insisted upon a minimum standard, and if the employers had taken a human interest in the employees and the Local Government had considered the indentured Indians as future citizens of South Africa, they would have learnt, during their five years indenture, habits of modern sanitation.
('39', 365, 1, 4, 728292) For during the five years of indenture they had to live like soldiers in barracks and they could have been made to conform to any reasonable sanitary regulations that might have been framed, even as they were made to conform to labour regulations which were often even harsh and severe.
('39', 365, 1, 5, 728579) But this is past history.
('39', 365, 1, 6, 728605) There is no more indentured emigration now.
('39', 365, 2, 7, 728649) The questions is now to make of the existing Indian population model citizens, and if the Government and the Indian settlers co operate, it is not at all impossible to set a better tone, and create a healthy Indian public opinion that would not tolerate any insanitation or ugliness.
('39', 365, 2, 8, 728933) Let the Indian settlers do their part of forming sanitation brigades, cleaning up latrines and streets and instructing ignorant people in the elementary laws of sanitation, even as they did in 1897 in Durban.
('39', 365, 2, 9, 729142) Sastris work will be frutiless unless he is willingly, intelligently and whole heartedly helped by the Indian settlers.
('39', 365, 2, 10, 729262) They must conform to the wholesome maxim of law that those who seek justice or equity must come with clean hands.
('39', 365, 2, 11, 729376) Let the settlers be clean in body, mind and soul, and thus make the best use of the golden opportunity they have of having an Ambassador who has got the ability to serve them and who has in a remarkable measure the ear of the European inhabitants of South Africa.
('39', 365, 2, 12, 729640) Young India, 11 8 1927
('39', 365, 3, 13, 729663) 366. THE HAVOC IN GUJARAT
('39', 365, 4, 14, 729689) The destruction wrought by the heavy floods in Gujarat appears to be of an unprecedented character.
('39', 365, 4, 15, 729789) The meagre accounts I have seen in the Press supplemented by two telegrams from Vallabhbhai Patel and one from the Ashram gave me but a faint idea of the enormous damage done by the flood.
('39', 365, 4, 16, 729978) I am handicapped, too, as I am writing this in an out of the way place in Mysore where newspapers reach very late.
('39', 365, 4, 17, 730093) When communications are thoroughly established, the total extent of the damage done will probably be found to be much heavier than the estimates made by responsible workers.
('39', 365, 4, 18, 730267) Benevolent and wealthy gentlemen of Bombay and Gujarat have been as prompt in
('39', 366, 0, 1, 730345) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 367
('39', 366, 1, 2, 730390) their work of mercy as Nature has been furious in her work of destruction.
('39', 366, 1, 3, 730465) Vallabhbhai Patel has already issued an appeal.
('39', 366, 1, 4, 730513) I hope that there will be a liberal response to the appeal.
('39', 366, 1, 5, 730573) A private telegram tells me that Sir Purushottamdas Thakordas has also, as is his wont on such occasions, started relief work.
('39', 366, 1, 6, 730700) On occasions of such calamities when deepest emotions are stirred,many relief agencies are brought into being to render help.
('39', 366, 1, 7, 730826) They must be all welcome.
('39', 366, 1, 8, 730852) Not one agency can hope to overtake the whole work of relief over such a vast area.
('39', 366, 1, 9, 730936) However, it will be the duty of several agencies to co operate with one another, so as to avoid overlapping and so as to make every rupee go to the longest length and every grain of wheat find its way to the neediest hands.
('39', 366, 1, 10, 731160) Let those whom God has blessed with ability to give remember the proverb : He gives twice who gives the quickest. Young India, 11 8 1927
('39', 366, 2, 11, 731297) 367. WELCOME GOOD SAMARITAN
('39', 366, 3, 12, 731325) Someone gave C. F. Andrews the affectionate title of Dinabandhu.
('39', 366, 3, 13, 731390) It certainly fits him.
('39', 366, 3, 14, 731413) His overpowering ambition in life is to be friend of those in need, and the way he helps is by utter self effacement.

('39', 366, 3, 20, 731991) For his very few belongings he needs a caretaker.
('39', 366, 3, 21, 732041) He never keeps anything for himself.

('39', 367, 2, 5, 733134) 368. UNITY IN VARIETY
('39', 367, 3, 6, 733156) The Polish professor 1 whose earnest questions I endeavoured to answer a few months back, having read my answer 2, sends me the following further questions:
('39', 367, 4, 7, 733313) 1. Men are not equal.
('39', 367, 4, 8, 733335) Do you also admit that there is a vast inequality between nations?
('39', 367, 5, 9, 733402) 2. If this is true, do you think that representative elective bodies, called parliaments, which have brought Europe to the Great War, are really suitable for India?
('39', 367, 6, 10, 733567) 3. Do you think that India may become one nation in a similar sense as Italy or France?
('39', 367, 7, 11, 733655) 4. Is it right to suppose that the future of Asia depends on this unification of India, which alone could overrule the materialistic tendencies of Japan and China?
('39', 367, 8, 12, 733819) 5. Is this not the real alternative for Asia, either superficial Europeani zation as in Japan, or going back to ancient Aryan tradition which seems to be the rule for great Indian masters?
('39', 367, 9, 13, 734008) 6. Has this recalling of original Aryan tradition also an importance for Europe?
('39', 367, 10, 14, 734089) 7. Do you not see in European civilization, with all its faults, a new power which goes beyond all Hindu experience?
('39', 367, 11, 15, 734206) 8. Is there, in all India, a single little town, like many French little towns, in which everybody is really free to follow his aspirations, all people are well to do, all have a very high level of education and sociability, and representatives of opposite tendencies meet in friendly intercourse?
('39', 367, 11, 16, 734504) I know such towns in France and also in England.
('39', 367, 11, 17, 734553) I wonder whether such a thing exits in India.
('39', 367, 11, 18, 734599) My correspondent has stated only a half truth when he says, Men are not equal.
('39', 367, 11, 19, 734678) The other half is that they are equal.
('39', 367, 12, 20, 734717) 1 W. Lutostawski 2 Vide Truth is One, 21 4 1927.
('39', 368, 0, 1, 734766) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 369
('39', 368, 1, 2, 734811) though they are not all of the same age, the same height, the same skin, and the same intellect, these inequalities are temporary and superficial, the soul that is hidden beneath this earthy crust is one and the same for all men and women belonging to all climes.
('39', 368, 1, 3, 735075) It would therefore be, perhaps, more accurate to say, that there is a real and substantial unity in all the variety that we see around us.
('39', 368, 1, 4, 735214) The word Inequality has a bad odour about it, and it has led to arrogance and inhumanities, both in the East and the West.
('39', 368, 1, 5, 735337) What is true about men is also true about nations, which are but groups of men.
('39', 368, 1, 6, 735417) The false and rigid doctrine of inequality has led to the insolent exploitation of the nations of Asia and Africa.
('39', 368, 1, 7, 735532) Who knows that the present ability of the West to prey upon the East is a sign of Western superiority and eastern inferiority?
('39', 368, 1, 8, 735659) I know that the East meekly, and all too hastily, submits to this pernicious doctrine, and then makes an ineffectual attempt to imitate the West.
('39', 368, 1, 9, 735805) There is, after all, a world of truth in the poetic statement, Things are not what they seem..
('39', 368, 1, 10, 735900) The second question does not seem to follow from the first.
('39', 368, 1, 11, 735960) And seeing that I reject the doctrine of inequality in the sense used by the writer, I am unable to admit that the representative elective bodies are really unsuitable for India.
('39', 368, 1, 12, 736139) But for the reasons, which I have stated in the Indian Home Rule and which in the main I have found no occasion during the past 20 years to revise, I should be extremely sorry, if India entirely copies the Western model.
('39', 368, 1, 13, 736360) Representative elective bodies were not unknown to India before the European advent.
('39', 368, 1, 14, 736445) But the contents of the words representation and election were, so far as I can see, far different from the European.
('39', 368, 1, 15, 736563) In my opinion, India is today one nation, even as Italy or France is; and this I maintain in spite of a vivid and painful knowledge of the fact, that Hindus and Mussalmans are murdering one another, that Brahmins and non Brahmins are preparing for a similar battle, and that both Brahmins and non Brahmins exclude from their purview the classes which both have left no stone unturned to suppress.
('39', 368, 1, 16, 736960) But I have known similar quarrels in families and in other nations.
('39', 368, 1, 17, 737028) It has often seemed to me that a family connection is necessary to establish a good ground for a quarrel.
('39', 368, 1, 18, 737134) But it flatters me to be able heartily to endorse the proposition that the future of Asia depends upon a proper and demonstrable unification of India.
('39', 368, 1, 19, 737285) I do not, however, think that the alternative to superficial Europeanization consists in a complete reversion to the ancient Aryan
('39', 369, 0, 1, 737416) 370 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 369, 1, 2, 737458) tradition.
('39', 369, 1, 3, 737469) I hold with that great thinker, the late Justice Ranade, that there is no such thing as a literal complete revival of ancient tradition possible, even if it were desirable.
('39', 369, 1, 4, 737642) In the first place, no one knows authoritatively what the ancient Aryan tradition was or is.
('39', 369, 1, 5, 737735) It is difficult to state unerringly the period which can be described as the Golden Age and then to give a categorical description of that age.
('39', 369, 1, 6, 737879) And I am humble enough to admit that there is much that we can profitably assimilate from the West.
('39', 369, 1, 7, 737979) Wisdom is no monopoly of one continent or one race.
('39', 369, 1, 8, 738031) My resistance to Western civilization is really a resistance to its indiscriminate and thoughtless imitation based on the assumption that Asiatics are fit only to copy everything that comes from the West.
('39', 369, 1, 9, 738236) I do believe that if India has patience enough to go through the fire of suffering and to resist any unlawful encroachment upon its own civilization which, imperfect though it undoubtedly is, has hitherto stood the ravages of time, she can make a lasting contribution to the peace and solid progress of the world.
('39', 369, 1, 10, 738550) I gladly admit that a new power for good is slowly but surely arising in the West.
('39', 369, 1, 11, 738633) Whether it will transcend all Hindu experience or not, I do not know.
('39', 369, 1, 12, 738703) But I should welcome every fresh contribution to the enrichment of humanity, no matter where it comes from.
('39', 369, 1, 13, 738811) Lastly, I am unable to say anything about the glowing tribute that the learned professor pays to the self contained French and English little towns.
('39', 369, 1, 14, 738960) I know so little about English towns, and still less about the French.
('39', 369, 1, 15, 739031) I own I have my doubts.
('39', 369, 1, 16, 739055) But I know that if the professor could stand the almost forbidden exterior of Indian villages, I would undertake to take him to some of them where he would see a culture of a high order, and though he will miss the literary polish he will not miss the human heart and the human touch, and where, if he can accommodate himself to the strange Indian ways about exclusive eating and drinking, he will see amazing tolerance of opposite ideas and friendliest intercourse of the mind and the soul.
('39', 369, 1, 17, 739547) Let me also remind the professor that the English and the French prosperity and amenities which such prosperity brings depend upon, what I must again repeat and what I would gladly avoid if I could, namely, exploitation.

('39', 370, 1, 2, 739836) 369. HUMANIZING WAR
('39', 370, 2, 3, 739856) I extract the following interesting paragraphs from an article headed War in the March number of the Brotherhood :
('39', 370, 3, 4, 739971) Last time the women and children were only starvedit was done by a process cunningly disguised as economic pressurebut next time they are to be gassed to death.
('39', 370, 3, 5, 740132) Aeroplanes will drop penetrating poisons which will exterminate civil populationEdison says that it should not be difficult to dispose of Londons millions in three hours.
('39', 370, 3, 6, 740303) In every civilized country the chemists are at work searching for some particularly deadly poisons.
('39', 370, 3, 7, 740403) In England, says Truth, our Government is busy experimenting with
('39', 370, 4, 8, 740469) improvements in poison gas and killing animals at the rate of two a day in the process.
('39', 370, 4, 9, 740557) It obtained in one year 689 cats, guinea pigs, goats, mice, monkeys, rabbits and rats, and killed 618 of them with poison gas in search of improvements.
('39', 370, 5, 10, 740710) Some idea of the horrors of the next war may be gathered from the fact that the range of guns has been doubled since the Armistice 1, and that machine guns are now available which fire 1,500 shots a minute.
('39', 370, 5, 11, 740917) An automatic cannon will fire one and a quarter pound shells at the rate of 120 a minute, and there is a sixteen inch gun which hurls a missile weighing more than a ton for a distance of twenty seven miles.
('39', 370, 5, 12, 741124) The Chemical Warfare Service in America has discovered a liquid three drops of which applied to any part of the skin will cause a mans death.
('39', 370, 5, 13, 741266) One aeroplane, carrying two tons of this liquid, could kill the whole population over miles of territory.
('39', 370, 5, 14, 741372) General Swinton, of the British Army, says : The great future weapon of war will be deadly germs.
('39', 370, 5, 15, 741470) We have since the war discovered and developed germs which, dropped down upon cities and armies, will slaughter a nation in a day.
('39', 370, 6, 16, 741601) If anyone is ever in danger of becoming unduly optimistic, let him remember that we spent in 1924 forty millions in education, a hundred and twenty one millions on armaments, and three hundred and sixteen millions on drink.
('39', 370, 6, 17, 741825) The business of scientific killing is very expensive, and I told that enough nitrogen was thrown away in one small and indecisive battle in France to save India from a famine.
('39', 370, 6, 18, 742001) The great world powers are still pouring out an incredible amount of their treasure upon armaments, although history so plainly teaches that increasing armaments do nothing but increase the likelihood of wars.
('39', 370, 6, 19, 742211) Peace loving America voted eighty five million dollars for aviation expansion in a few minutes, and no one took the slightest notice of this forward movement in the race for armaments.
('39', 370, 6, 20, 742396) The irony of the situation
