('39', 373, 1, 2, 747191) 371. TEST OF FIDELITY
('39', 373, 2, 3, 747213) A study of the chart of membership of the All India Spinners Association discloses a painful fact.
('39', 373, 2, 4, 747312) Out of 1,980 members of the A Class, 1,255 have been found to be unsteady in their fidelity to their promise regularly to send their yarn quota.
('39', 373, 2, 5, 747457) Let no one think that if it was an insignificant monetary contribution rather than that of self spun yarn, the result would have been very different.
('39', 373, 2, 6, 747607) Somehow or other people are neglectful in the performance of self imposed duties, whose breach does not carry with it an immediate punitive consequence.
('39', 373, 2, 7, 747760) But unless a nation contains a large enough number of men and women who would carry out their voluntary obligations, although their breach may not entail any felt punishment, it can make slow progress.
('39', 373, 2, 8, 747962) Forfeiture of rights of membership of an organization which carried with it no pecuniary or other earthly loss is lightly regarded by the members, and some even consider that by belonging to such an institution they confer on it a patronage which should be treasured by the institution in question.
('39', 373, 2, 9, 748261) But I warn the members, if there are any, against harbouring such notions about the All India Spinners Association.
('39', 373, 2, 10, 748377) To belong to the Association should be considered a rare privilege, because by contributing half an hours free and intelligent labour capable of being easily performed by any ordinary man, woman or child, a member becomes a partaker in the tremendous aggregate effect of the contributions.
('39', 373, 2, 11, 748667) I would therefore urge the defaulting members to be as punctual in sending their quota as they would be in keeping the time for catching their train or attending their offices.
('39', 373, 2, 12, 748844) Let them remember that apart from the intrinsic value of spinn ing, there is no less value in cultivating regularly a daily remembrance of the condition of the dumb millions and a daily concentration over drawing an even strong thread as much for themselves as for the rest of the 300 millions of India.
('39', 373, 2, 13, 749148) I understand that each one of the members has been sent a reminder.
('39', 373, 2, 14, 749216) Let the defaulters please realize that each reminder costs at least half an anna over and above the salaries of men employed in attending to the writing and despatch of reminder cards.
('39', 373, 2, 15, 749401) It has been suggested that some postpone sending their quota till several months contributions are collected, so as to save postage.
('39', 373, 2, 16, 749534) The saving of postage is a proper consideration.
('39', 373, 2, 17, 749583) But those who would save postage should send their contributions in advance.
('39', 373, 2, 18, 749660) To spin 12,000 yards in a months time is not a very great strain as must be abundantly clear to every reader of
('39', 374, 0, 1, 749772) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 375
('39', 374, 1, 2, 749817) these pages.
('39', 374, 1, 3, 749830) And if after having sent one lot in advance, the spinners continue to give 30 minutes regularly to the wheel, they will never be in arrears, and they will never feel the strain of the work, no matter how busy they may be otherwise.
('39', 374, 1, 4, 750062) And if punishment has any appeal to them, let them remember that at the end of the first five years of the existence of the All India Spinners Association, it will descend surely and swiftly upon them, when the time comes for revising the constitution and conferring further privileges upon members.

('39', 374, 2, 6, 750385) 372. NOTES
('39', 374, 3, 7, 750396) TRUE SACRIFICE Two young men only the other day presented themselves before me and placed into my hands Rs. 10 being the commission they had earned in terms of the rules of the All India Spinners Association for hawking khadi.
('39', 374, 3, 8, 750623) They were entitled to keep this money themselves.
('39', 374, 3, 9, 750673) But they did not wish to retain this commission; for they felt the force of the argu ment that there were millions who were much worse off than themselves.
('39', 374, 3, 10, 750829) The young men went away promising to bring me more such refunds.
('39', 374, 3, 11, 750894) Whilst I mention this instance in appreciation of the self sacrifice of these young men, no khadi hawker is to infer from it that he is also expected to refund his commission, in other words, that every khadi hawker is expected to hawk without any charge.
('39', 374, 3, 12, 751150) I know that it is not possible for everyone to do so, and khadi work requires as many honest, industrious and intelligent hawkers as can be had.
('39', 374, 3, 13, 751295) To recommend for all the standard that the two young men have chosen for themselves would be to restrict the number of khadi hawkers, whereas the object is to attract as many young men for the work as possible.
('39', 374, 3, 14, 751506) After all the commission to be had out of khadi sales is not much and is not easily earned because it is not possible to command sales of khadi simply by 1 exhibiting it for sale.
('39', 374, 3, 15, 751686) I know that hawkers have to go from door to door often even without any response whatsoever, and seeing that the commission is given only on actual sales, khadi hawking means earning ones bread by the sweat of ones brow.
('39', 374, 3, 16, 751907) Let the example of these young men therefore spur those who
('39', 374, 4, 17, 751967) 1 The source has for.
('39', 375, 0, 1, 751989) 376 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 375, 1, 2, 752031) are doing nothing for khadi to some effort, and let the example result in adding to the number of hawkers without their being expected to refund their hard earned commission.
('39', 375, 1, 3, 752206) There are no doubt many young men and young women who have plenty of leisure and do not need any pecuniary reward.
('39', 375, 1, 4, 752321) They may follow the example of these young men and offer their services for hawking.
('39', 375, 1, 5, 752406) Let would be khadi hawkers however understand that they cannot get khadi to hawk unless they are able to produce certificates of character, and are able to furnish security for the amount of khadi they may receive for sale.

('39', 376, 5, 21, 755688) HAND SPINNING IN ALMORA A correspondent sends me an interesting report of the progress that hand spinning of wool has made in the schools conducted by the District Board of Almora.
('39', 376, 5, 22, 755869) The following should prove both interesting
('39', 377, 0, 1, 755913) 378 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 377, 1, 2, 755955) and instructive to those who believe in the introduction of takli spinning in municipal schools : 1
('39', 377, 2, 3, 756055) The elections of 1925 to the Almora District Board returned the Swarajists in a majority.
('39', 377, 2, 4, 756145) Since then the Swarajist members have in various ways tried to give a national stamp to the institution, particularly its educational side.
('39', 377, 2, 5, 756285) The most important work in that direction has been the introduction of national songs, national sentiments, khadi uniform and wool spinning into the village schools.
('39', 377, 3, 6, 756451) The village teachers of a number of District Board schools purchased wool at their own cost and thus spinning came into being.
('39', 377, 3, 7, 756578) The Board, seeing the popularity of these voluntary and spontaneous efforts, constitued a spinning and weaving sub committee and granted Rs. 3,000 at the beginning of 1926 for purchasing wool to be spun at District Board schools in the district.
('39', 377, 3, 8, 756824) Some nineteen maunds of wool was purchased and distributed throughout the district in village schools.
('39', 377, 3, 9, 756927) The boys everywhere welcomed the takli or katuna, and
('39', 377, 4, 10, 756981) the village schoolmasters did their best to make wool spinning successful.
('39', 377, 4, 11, 757056) The Board deserves congratulations for giving this support, in spite of the opposition of conservatives.
('39', 377, 4, 12, 757161) The Board has ordered spinning classes to be held after school hours as the curriculum has no provision for this type of education.
('39', 377, 4, 13, 757293) In order to enthuse the masses and to encourage the village students, several katua dangals (spinning matches) have been arranged at
('39', 377, 5, 14, 757426) different centres of the district during fairs.
('39', 377, 5, 15, 757474) Prizes (including khadi, khadi caps, national flags and national books) have been awarded to the best spinners.
('39', 377, 5, 16, 757586) This feature has been very much appreciated by the people and has been of great educative and demonstrative value.
('39', 377, 5, 17, 757701) Seeing the spinning of young schoolboys, the villages have been conscience stricken and at many places the long forgotten art of spinning is undergoing a revival.
('39', 377, 5, 18, 757864) The villagers at several places have established their own looms to weave their hand spun wool yarn.
('39', 377, 5, 19, 757965) So the spinning in schools is touching the masses as well.
('39', 377, 6, 20, 758024) Our experiments in wool spinning convinced us that there was nothing better than katua or takli for wool spinning simple, light, inexpensive and practical.
('39', 377, 6, 21, 758180) So Katua or takli is reigning supreme in the Boards schools as well.
('39', 377, 6, 22, 758249) A small boy can make his own katua without any trouble or expense and
('39', 377, 7, 23, 758319) play it at any time or any place whenever or wherever he likes.
('39', 377, 7, 24, 758383) If this experiment is continued and spinning is properly super vised, it can not only become self supporting but be even profitable.
('39', 377, 7, 25, 758516) For if hand weaving is not also done by the boys, spun wool should find a ready market; or it can be woven on behalf of the Board or the

('39', 382, 3, 10, 766457) 379. LETTER TO JAYANTI August 11, 1927
('39', 382, 4, 11, 766496) JAYANTI, Your letter.
('39', 382, 4, 12, 766518) The flood has disturbed all time[ schedules]; so it is not possible that my blessings would reach you on your birthday itself.
('39', 382, 4, 13, 766645) But take it that they have reached you on that very day.
('39', 382, 4, 14, 766702) May you live long and become a pure worker and may your exalted hopes bear fruit!
('39', 382, 4, 15, 766784) One thing you and all other pupils should do is to make your handwriting beautiful like pearls.
('39', 382, 4, 16, 766880) This can be done easily.
('39', 382, 4, 17, 766905) Just as singing out of tune is not music, so too bad handwriting is no writing.
('39', 382, 4, 18, 766985) I am not competent to proffer this advice because I know that my own handwriting is no good.
('39', 382, 4, 19, 767078) But just as a drowning mans warning not to go to a particular spot is heeded by the wise, I hope all of you wise pupils will take this warning from me.
('39', 382, 4, 20, 767230) Words must be written separa tely.
('39', 382, 4, 21, 767265) There must be some space between the lines.
('39', 382, 4, 22, 767309) A line ought to run straight and every letter must be delineated as an artist draws a picture.
('39', 382, 4, 23, 767404) Now about the Ramayana.
('39', 382, 4, 24, 767428) I would certainly pay more respect to Tulsis Ramayana as a religious work.
('39', 382, 4, 25, 767503) Valmikis may excel in art, but I have not the slightest doubt that Tulsidas is richer in devotional spirit.
('39', 382, 4, 26, 767611) Moreover, at present Valmikis Ramayana is available in Sanskrit only.
('39', 382, 4, 27, 767681) I have so far come across no Gujarati translation which re creates the interest of the original.
('39', 382, 4, 28, 767778) You must know that neither of the works is historical.
('39', 382, 4, 29, 767833) True, Valmiki has portrayed a few historical men and women, but these are not clearly defined.
('39', 382, 4, 30, 767928) I firmly believe that one cannot infer historical facts from them.
('39', 382, 4, 31, 767995) But in the case of Tulsidas the question of historicity does not arise.
('39', 382, 4, 32, 768067) We might say that he adapted Valmiki to suit his own age, but while doing so, having come under the spell of bhakti, he took such liberties as he wished to
('39', 383, 0, 1, 768223) 384 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 383, 1, 2, 768265) and thereby he has done no harm but only done good to Hindu society.
('39', 383, 1, 3, 768334) With the passage of time men and women of divine glory become gods and goddesses and are ultimately worshipped as such.
('39', 383, 1, 4, 768454) This will always happen and that is right.
('39', 383, 1, 5, 768497) A man being embodied can never worship God in any other form.
('39', 383, 1, 6, 768559) It being so, whatever Tulsidas writes about Lord Ramachandra are only his own feelings.
('39', 383, 1, 7, 768647) Tulsidas has portrayed God as beyond description, as inapprehensible by mere sense organs and as also beyond attributes.
('39', 383, 1, 8, 768768) If therefore we cannot swallow the killing of Vali, we should leave aside that passage or believe that while depicting it Tulsidas acted only in conformity with the beliefs of his own age and could not transcend them.
('39', 383, 1, 9, 768986) As man progresses, his idea of God necessarily becomes subtle and pure, inevitably so.
('39', 383, 1, 10, 769073) Therefore, we should regard the Ramayana rather as a devotional work than a historical record and while we read its fiction part we should ignore whatever we find contrary to morality.
('39', 383, 1, 11, 769258) Tulsidas himself describes his work Ramacharitamanasa as full of faults.
('39', 383, 1, 12, 769331) He gives a different reason for it but that he has regarded it as not without fault should suffice for us.
('39', 383, 1, 13, 769438) Moreover, in his well known verse beginning, God created the world full of animate and inanimate objects with good qualities as well as bad, Tulsidas has taught us the art of looking at things.
('39', 383, 1, 14, 769632) Since all human action is partly good and partly bad, we should, like the proverbial swan 1, take in the essence in the form of good qualities and leave alone the defects that spoil it.
('39', 383, 1, 15, 769818) This is the golden rule that should apply to the reading of all books.
('39', 383, 1, 16, 769889) We should humbly ask the teacher what we do not understand and we should leave aside what nevertheless we fail to understand; we shuld however never let our reason be clouded or our mind be corrupted.
('39', 383, 1, 17, 770090) Whatever appears contrary to truth, non violence and so on, should be rejected as unauthoritative although it may have been printed in an avowedly scriptural work.
('39', 383, 1, 18, 770254) Although this letter is written for you alone, regard it as meant for all of you and let them read it; and let the seniors too read it.
('39', 383, 1, 19, 770390) For, I do not remember having written my thoughts on the Ramayana so clearly and concisely anywhere else, though I have explained them often here and there.

('39', 386, 5, 8, 774016) 383. LETTER TO BAL KALELKAR
('39', 386, 6, 9, 774044) August 12, 1927 It is not enough merely to say that you do not like Kaka saheb turning a recluse.
('39', 386, 6, 10, 774142) When I wrote to you that ones son attaining the age of 16 becomes ones friend, I also meant that you had acquired the capacity to think independently and one who thinks independently should be able to give strong reasons for ones opinions whether to convince himself or others.
('39', 386, 6, 11, 774420) He must give reasons why he likes one thing and does not like another.
('39', 386, 6, 12, 774491) Having developed such faculty from their very childhood some men have become great such as the sage Dayananda, Chaitanya, Ramakrishna Paramahamsa and other historic figures.
('39', 386, 6, 13, 774665) Let us leave aside Hinduism and consider sannyasa independently.
('39', 386, 6, 14, 774730) Sannyasa is a mental state and it is reflected in a mans actions.
('39', 386, 6, 15, 774796) But if another man imitates these actions without the mental state, that will not be sannyasa.

('39', 392, 2, 5, 787516) 388. TO VOLUNTEERS
('39', 392, 3, 6, 787535) A calamity such as that which has befallen Gujarat can be put to good or bad use.
('39', 392, 3, 7, 787617) From such terible floods godfearing men learn humility, simplicity, compassion and similar virtues.
('39', 392, 3, 8, 787717) They realize that one would do well, in this transitory world, to live with as much self denial and self control as one can.
('39', 392, 3, 9, 787842) The wicked go out stealing at such times, rob people and indulge their evil propensities in all manner of ways.
('39', 392, 3, 10, 787954) Very often money given for help is also misused.
('39', 392, 3, 11, 788003) A large number of volunteers is required for distributing relief over a large area.
('39', 392, 3, 12, 788087) If they are greedy, they pocket the money which is entrusted to them.
('39', 392, 3, 13, 788157) It would be foolish to expect Gujarat to be completely free from such malpractices.
('39', 392, 3, 14, 788241) But it can certainly be expected of volunteers that they will have no greedy thoughts and, working wholly in a spirit of service, will win credit for themselves.
('39', 392, 3, 15, 788403) Volunteers are subject to weaknesses of another kind.
('39', 392, 3, 16, 788457) They do not steal like thieves; but they feel some pride in being volunteers and, though in fact they are servants of the people, expect service from others as if they were their benefactors.
('39', 392, 3, 17, 788649) They look after themselves before they help others and get angry with people who do nto carry out their instructions promptly.
('39', 392, 3, 18, 788776) I hope that every volunteer will keep himself free from such weaknesses.
('39', 392, 3, 19, 788849) The volutneers should know that even the poor are contributing, at some personal sacrifice, towards the fund which is being collected.
('39', 392, 3, 20, 788984) I am certain that we shall not be short of money.
('39', 392, 3, 21, 789034) If, however, the money is not properly used, all our work will have been wasted.
('39', 392, 3, 22, 789115) Moreover, we should also guard against the danger of the really poor getting nothing and the assertive getting a lions share.
('39', 392, 3, 23, 789241) I have already had heartening reports of instances of persons not accepting help though they were in real difficulty, but I know from my previous experience that there are always people who will grab at whatever help is offered.
('39', 392, 3, 24, 789470) It is as necessary that we do not, out of false compassion or
('39', 393, 0, 1, 789532) 394 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 393, 1, 2, 789574) fear or weakness, give to people who do not need help as that we should see at any cost that help reaches those who really need it.
('39', 393, 1, 3, 789706) At a time of such terrible calamity, one becomes very generous and is inclined to give help to anyone who asks for it.
('39', 393, 1, 4, 789825) I do not think that such undiscriminating help really benefits the people.
('39', 393, 1, 5, 789900) The common rule is that everyone should bear the hardships which befall him.
('39', 393, 1, 6, 789977) If all of us shoulder our own burdens, we would find very few in this world who are really helpless.
('39', 393, 1, 7, 790078) But large numbers become a burden on others in various ways: they enjoy a greater share than is theirs by right, and that is why we see a great number of helpless and poor people in the world.

('39', 393, 1, 9, 790477) Afterwards, what is necessary is to help everyone to find a means of livelihood; there should be no need, by and large, of giving money to those who are sound in limbs.

('39', 404, 1, 2, 807021) 398. LETTER TO MANILAL AND SUSHILA GANDHI
('39', 404, 2, 3, 807063) August 14, 1927
('39', 404, 3, 4, 807079) MANILAL AND SUSHILA,
('39', 404, 4, 5, 807100) Your letters still arrive after many wanderings.
('39', 404, 4, 6, 807149) I should get faithful account of Sastris visit, but have not received one so far.
('39', 404, 4, 7, 807231) Sushila has asked a question about social service.
('39', 404, 4, 8, 807282) Any work which we do for peoples welfare and with sincere motives is social service.
('39', 404, 4, 9, 807367) If in your family life you merely aim at enjoyment and do not think of society, that will be serving self interest; if, on the other hand, you adopt simplicity for the sake of society, take care not to set a bad example to others and, when buying anything, consider whether it is morally right or wrong to do so, then that is social service.
('39', 404, 4, 10, 807709) Going further, if your aim in helping in the press work is merely to save money, that is service of self.
('39', 404, 4, 11, 807815) If, however, your aim is to learn that work and spend the money saved by your work for some public purpose, if it is that you should bring out the paper even at the cost of hardship to yourself, that is social service.
('39', 404, 4, 12, 808034) Go a step further still; if, finding that your neighbour is ill, you sacrifice your comforts in order to nurse him and learn nursing work, that is social service.
('39', 404, 4, 13, 808197) From these examples you can think of any number of others and extend the field of social service within the limits of your capacity.
('39', 404, 4, 14, 808330) If, tired of India, Manilal lives in South Africa to enjoy the pleasures which that country offers, that is selfishness.
('39', 404, 4, 15, 808451) If, believing that the paper conducted by his father was good and that his country stood to gain by his continuing to run it, he lives and forces you to live in exile without the aim of amassing wealth, he is rendering a great social service and you, too, are making a contribution to it.
('39', 404, 4, 16, 808740) Today we have come to a far off place in Mysore State.
('39', 404, 4, 17, 808795) About sixty miles from here is a waterfall like the Inanda Falls, but much bigger than that, which we are all going to see tomorrow.
('39', 404, 4, 18, 808928) Devdas has stayed back in Bangalore.
('39', 404, 4, 19, 808965) He will arrive here this evening with others.
('39', 404, 4, 20, 809011) We shall remain here and collect contributions for about four days and then return to Bangalore.
('39', 404, 4, 21, 809108) At the end of this month, we shall cross the boundary of Mysore State and enter Tamilnad.
('39', 404, 4, 22, 809198) My health continues to improve.
('39', 404, 4, 23, 809230) I do not think we shall get back to the Ashram by the end of December.
('39', 404, 4, 24, 809301) We positively wish to

('39', 409, 9, 26, 815919) We tolerate many things in the Ashram, but would not permit them if our permission was sought.
('39', 409, 9, 27, 816014) There are also many things for which we would not give permission and which we would not

('39', 410, 1, 2, 816425) tolerate.
('39', 410, 1, 3, 816435) We should think in which category to place this idea of a fast.

('39', 410, 1, 5, 816566) I cannot guide you from here, because in order to express an opinion it is necessary that I must talk things over with Bhai Bhansali and let the effect of the talk sink into my mind.

('39', 410, 1, 10, 817300) But it is necessary in any case that he look to the convenience of the Committee.
('39', 410, 1, 11, 817382) I also believe that we cannot decide this matter without consulting the absent members of the Committee too.
('39', 410, 1, 12, 817491) This is so because, on the one hand, dharma suggests that even if we are not able to keep pace with an aspirant for moksha and a seeker after knowledge like Bhansali and we disapprove of a step contemplated by him, we should let him proceed, that is to say, we must keep him in the Ashram; on the other hand, dharma tells us that it is perhaps our obligation not to tolerate his proposed step in the Ashram even if we consider it not as immoral but merely as thoughtless and dangerous.
('39', 410, 1, 13, 817977) We have thus to discover the point of balance between social conformity and individual freedom, and we cannot do this in a hurry.
('39', 410, 1, 14, 818107) Explain our difficulties to Shri Bhansali and request him to respect our honest efforts, if for no other reason, at least in order that he may then more easily have the vision for which he is so eager.
('39', 410, 1, 15, 818309) Keep me informed about this from time to time and, if necessary, even send me a telegram.
('39', 410, 1, 16, 818399) If Lala Mohanlal of Lahore is there and if he has been quietly and honestly doing physical work, let him do so and live there till I arrive.
('39', 410, 1, 17, 818540) But this is my opinion only.
('39', 410, 1, 18, 818569) Having observed his behaviour or having regard to the other arrangements in the Ashram, if you think that you cannot keep him, ask him to leave.
('39', 410, 1, 19, 818714) Give him the accompanying letter.

('39', 411, 1, 2, 818851) 405. LETTER TO BALKRISHNA
('39', 411, 2, 3, 818877) August 15, 1927
('39', 411, 3, 4, 818893) BALKRISHNA, I cannot help writing to you today.
('39', 411, 3, 5, 818941) I do not like to interfere much in your course of thinking or way of work because you arrange your thoughts with great care.
('39', 411, 3, 6, 819066) But very often the experience of elders helps even one who arranges ones thoughts carefully.
('39', 411, 3, 7, 819159) I sometimes get into an argument with you with a view to helping you.
('39', 411, 3, 8, 819229) I think we needs must stay in society in order to build up our character and we have even to bear with our leaders temper.
('39', 411, 3, 9, 819352) New principles do not come up every day before a philosopher; but conflicts of duty do crop up every dayponder over the difference between the two.
('39', 411, 3, 10, 819500) It is when duties conflict that a soldier obeys his general and he puts his own reason aside.
('39', 411, 3, 11, 819594) The intelligence of one who always indulges in its exercise obstructs his self realization.
('39', 411, 3, 12, 819686) When a leader is not deliberately immoral, it is non violence to submit to his intelligence.
('39', 411, 3, 13, 819779) Non violence is humbler that even a mango tree.
('39', 411, 3, 14, 819827) It is said that a mango tree bends as it grows up.
('39', 411, 3, 15, 819878) When non violence grows fully, it acts like a cipher.
('39', 411, 3, 16, 819932) Instead of attempting to prove its own point, non violence lets everyone else prove his.
('39', 411, 3, 17, 820021) Hence it has been sung : When non violence is established, in its vicinity all hatred is given up. 1 Who can hate a cipher and how?
('39', 411, 3, 18, 820153) You will lose nothing by subordinating yourself to Maganlal.
('39', 411, 3, 19, 820214) Both yourself and Maganlal will benefit by submitting to his mistaken orders, whatever they be, because we have in doing so accepted a principle.
('39', 411, 3, 20, 820360) Your subordinating yourself to him will be a means of correcting his error.
('39', 411, 3, 21, 820436) I have experienced this thing myself many times.
('39', 411, 3, 22, 820485) I have corrected the errors of my associates by subordinating myself to them and who knows how many errors of mine my associates daily correct by subordinating themselves to me?
('39', 411, 3, 23, 820663) But what if they were to analyse my errors before me every day and annoy me?
('39', 411, 3, 24, 820740) If that were so, where would they and I be today?
('39', 411, 3, 25, 820790) Think deeply over this letter.
('39', 411, 3, 26, 820821) Do not again come back impatiently running to me.
('39', 411, 3, 27, 820871) I wish and I pray that you may have peace.
('39', 411, 3, 28, 820914) [From Gujarati]
('39', 411, 4, 29, 820930) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desais Diary.
('39', 411, 4, 30, 820975) Courtesy : Narayan Desai
('39', 411, 5, 31, 821000) 1 Yogasutra by Patanjali
('39', 412, 0, 1, 821025) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 413
('39', 412, 1, 2, 821070) 406. LETTER TO RAMDAS GANDHI August 15, 1927 These smaller floods come to warn us.
('39', 412, 1, 3, 821153) There will surely be the final deluge.
('39', 412, 1, 4, 821192) None need doubt it.
('39', 412, 1, 5, 821212) The magic of this illusory world makes a man forget all his sorrows.
('39', 412, 1, 6, 821281) This is doubtless an advantage but that man wins who, mindful of the deluge and persuaded of the transience not only of himself but of the world, lives his life in a detached way.
('39', 412, 1, 7, 821461) To gain this mastery constitutes mans highest achievement.
('39', 412, 1, 8, 821520) Truly speaking, all of us are condemned to death the moment we are born, and yet why do we allthe young, the old and the children drown ourselves in sensual pleasures?
('39', 412, 1, 9, 821688) It is obvious that we do revel in them, but we should ask it with all the more earnestness.
('39', 412, 1, 10, 821780) Then, one day, the answer even today: Oh man, give up all trace of passion. But as long as the call does not come from the heart, the poor intellect is ineffectual.
('39', 412, 1, 11, 821945) [From Gujarati]
('39', 412, 2, 12, 821961) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desais Diary.

('39', 413, 1, 3, 823023) Do not many cultured Indians hate the British people as wicked?
('39', 413, 1, 4, 823087) If somebody wrote a learned treatise today describing the relations between ourselves and the British and had not a boundless spirit of charity, would he not describe the British a dasyus or atatayis fit only to be destroyed at sight, and if that treatise [should] survive some periodic upheaval and afterwards become religious literature, posterity is likely to indulge in the same error that we do and say that those atatayis and dasyus of these times were not political exploiters but were wicked people as you now interpret the term wicked people, or would you say even now that the British as a people, are really wicked?
('39', 413, 1, 5, 823714) Or take another instance : I know as the author of non co operation that many so called non co operators hated co operators as if they were wicked monsters and if the former had been allowed, they would have drawn these poor co operators and certainly would have made short work of them.
('39', 413, 1, 6, 824002) Supposing that some very learned non co operator of the type I described wrote a treatise, he would of course describe co operators as wicked men.
('39', 413, 1, 7, 824149) Would you accept that verdict or take to a free fight like the one that took place between Shwetambars and Digambars, first cousins as they might be called.
('39', 413, 1, 8, 824306) Was not each wicked in the sight of the other?
('39', 413, 1, 9, 824353) The fact is that immediately you accept the doctrine of slaying people whom you consider to be wicked, you really surrender the whole case and come under the same category as the writer or the writings on the Koran.
('39', 413, 1, 10, 824569) I do not need to cite any history in support of what I am saying but I can supplement it if necessary.

('39', 414, 1, 2, 825417) 408. THE GUJARAT FLOODS 1
('39', 414, 2, 3, 825443) GOOD IF TRUE On reading the reports of flood relief operations as well as Swami Anands article in Navajivan 2 I hesitated, and still hesitate, to believe in the examples there given of the peoples heroism, solidarity and humanity, as false praise, exaggeration and self deception are the order of the day in the country.
('39', 414, 2, 4, 825764) But I have no reason to disbelieve these reports.
('39', 414, 2, 5, 825814) Exaggeration, untruth and the like are studiously eschewed in Navajivan.
('39', 414, 2, 6, 825887) The Swami knows this ever since the paper was started, and indeed it is this policy of the paper which induces him to interest himself in and work for it.
('39', 414, 2, 7, 826042) Therefoe so long as I have not any reason to consider the Navajivan reports as erroneous, I must take them to be true.
('39', 414, 2, 8, 826161) And I tender my congratulations to Gujarat and the Gujaratis.
('39', 414, 2, 9, 826223) For a moment one is almost tempted to welcome a disaster which has been the occasion for the people to display such virtues.
('39', 414, 2, 10, 826348) Catastrophes and calamities will now and then overtake the country.
('39', 414, 2, 11, 826416) Wealth may be in our possession today and be lost tomorrow.
('39', 414, 2, 12, 826476) We construct houses and make farms and gardens, and when these are destroyed, we can remake them.
('39', 414, 2, 13, 826574) The distress will soon be forgotten.
('39', 414, 2, 14, 826611) But what if Gujarat along with the distress also forgets the virtues which she has realized in herself on the present occasion?
('39', 414, 2, 15, 826739) We are everywhere familiar with momentary fits of heroism and renunciation.
('39', 414, 2, 16, 826815) If Gujarats present heroism proves to be only a temporary fit, the lesson of the floods will have been lost upon her.
('39', 414, 2, 17, 826933) Let the Gujaratis, men as well as women, beware.
('39', 414, 2, 18, 826982) Let us convert the virtues of courage, patience and humanity in us, of which we have had a sudden glimpse, into a possession forever.
('39', 414, 2, 19, 827116) Hindus and Mussalmans embraced one another as brothers.
('39', 414, 2, 20, 827172) The higher classes sheltered and succoured the suppressed like blood brothers.
('39', 414, 2, 21, 827251) If we now give up these relations as only suited for the days of adversity, our last state will be worse than the first, and we will have passed in vain through this calamity, which is really the throes of a

('39', 415, 1, 3, 827697) And such calamities there will be, so long as we have not experienced a true rebirth.
('39', 415, 1, 4, 827783) Gujarats doings on this occasion amount in my view to pure swaraj.
('39', 415, 1, 5, 827850) If the virtues now manifested by the people become a permanent feature of their daily life, Gujarat may be said to have acquired the fitness for, as well as the power to win, swaraj.
('39', 415, 1, 6, 828033) The havoc worked by the floods was of a most unprecedented character; before which even Dyerism pales into insignificance.

('39', 415, 1, 19, 828713) If we had feared the floods, if we had wasted precious time in abusing them, if we had engaged in violent struggle with them, we would only have multiplied our troubles.
('39', 415, 1, 20, 828883) All honour to Gujarat for the proof she has given of her greatness.

('39', 415, 2, 22, 828971) But has a Gujarati, who is away from the scene of danger and of achievement, the right thus to bestow praise and tender congrat ulations?
('39', 415, 2, 23, 829109) I received three wires and a letter asking me to come and lead the relief opeations in Gujarat.
('39', 415, 2, 24, 829205) The letter was Swami Anands and the wires were from Sarojini Devi, Chandulal, whom I mistook for Dr. Chandulal, and Devchand Parekh.
('39', 415, 2, 25, 829338) But I did not give myself to anxiety.
('39', 415, 2, 26, 829376) I was fully confident of Gujarats self reliance, I had not the shadow of a doubt that monetary help would be forthcoming in an adequate measure.
('39', 415, 2, 27, 829521) I whole heartedly trusted Vallabhbhai to do the needful.

('39', 416, 2, 3, 830225) A TRAVESTY
('39', 416, 3, 4, 830236) The voluntary repatriation described by Dr. Malan, the Union Minister 1, is anything but voluntary.
('39', 416, 3, 5, 830336) It is stimulated, aided or induced.
('39', 416, 3, 6, 830372) And if the process continues unchecked, it may presently become compulsory.
('39', 416, 3, 7, 830448) A large number of men repatriated are said to be colonial born.
('39', 416, 3, 8, 830512) No colonial born Indian to whom India is only a geographical expression will voluntarily repatriate himself.
('39', 416, 3, 9, 830621) Again it is not voluntary repatriation when an agency is set up, probably paid by results, to collect repatriation recruits and when these recruits are detained in compounds pending repatriation.
('39', 416, 3, 10, 830817) It seems to me that this detention in compounds is likely to be declared illegal if it is tested in a court of law.
('39', 416, 3, 11, 830933) For detention without a guard would be useless.
('39', 416, 3, 12, 830981) And placing a guard over free and innocent men would amount to wrongful confinement.
('39', 416, 3, 13, 831066) I know of no regulation in 1914 that permitted the Government to detain such men in guarded camps.
('39', 416, 3, 14, 831165) If repatriation is to be voluntary it must be free from the pestering attention of recruiting agents and there should be no detention in depots or camps.
('39', 416, 4, 15, 831319) THE TRUE GURU
('39', 416, 5, 16, 831333) In confirmation of my note on the definition of a guru, a correspondent sends the following interesting information:
('39', 416, 6, 17, 831450) In connection with your definition of a guru, I am reminded of the beautiful lines of the poet saint Ramadas.
('39', 416, 6, 18, 831560) He said:
('39', 416, 7, 19, 831569) You cannot find a better guru than viveka or the power of discriminating from untruth, right from wrong or good from evil.
('39', 416, 7, 20, 831692) There is no better disciple than chitta or mind, and no nobler friend than ones jeeva or soul. In fact, Ramadas points out that man need not go outside himself in search of a guru.
('39', 416, 7, 21, 831873) Be guided by your power of discrimination, derived from your implicit faith in God, keep your mind under control of such a power and nobly sacrifice the self. This in essence is the advice of the Maharashtrian saint.

('39', 417, 1, 15, 833559) Where this is present, every thing rights itself in the end.
('39', 417, 1, 16, 833620) This is a law to which there is no excep tion.
('39', 417, 1, 17, 833667) It would be very bad indeed that Gujarat or India should look up to me and sit with folded hands.
('39', 417, 1, 18, 833765) Let her worship Truth and Love, look up to that divine couple, employ servants like myself so long as they tread the straight and narrow path and check them when they swerve from it.
('39', 417, 1, 19, 833948) If I had come over to Gujarat, perhaps she would not have done what she has done and is still doing.
('39', 417, 1, 20, 834049) Invalided leaders or public servants should give up the hankering after active leadership or service.
('39', 417, 1, 21, 834151) There is no place for a sick man in these operations for relief, which require only such persons as are able bodied, can run up from place to place, and have the power of enduring hunger and thirst, heat and cold.
('39', 417, 1, 22, 834365) Those who do not reach this standard would only act as a drag on a quickly marching army.
('39', 417, 1, 23, 834455) Finally, a servant of the people should never fear or give way to
('39', 418, 0, 1, 834521) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 419
('39', 418, 1, 2, 834566) bitterness if he finds himself a victim of misunderstanding, whether unintentional or wilful.
('39', 418, 1, 3, 834660) The acts of men who have come out to serve or lead have always been misunderstood since the beginning of the world and none can help it.
('39', 418, 1, 4, 834797) To put up with these misrepresentations and to stick to ones guns come what mightthis is the essence of the gift of leadership.
('39', 418, 1, 5, 834925) Misunderstandings have been my lot ever since I entered public life, and I have got inured to them.
('39', 418, 1, 6, 835025) In short, let Gujarat ever be, as it has been on the present occasion, self reliant and self helpful and proceed from achievement to achievement.
('39', 418, 1, 7, 835171) Men like myself will come and go, but let Gujarat go on forever.
('39', 418, 1, 8, 835236) TO CO WORKERS A few words more to co workers.
('39', 418, 1, 9, 835282) 1. I take it that none of the workers will allow their pride to come in the way of their heartily co operating with their compatriots.
('39', 418, 1, 10, 835417) 2. Anyone who works for name and fame on an occasion like this incurs sin.
('39', 418, 1, 11, 835492) 3. There should be the fullest co operation between the various agencies at work.
('39', 418, 1, 12, 835574) 4. Where Government offers help on our own terms we should freely accept it, as it does not involve any breach of the principle of non co operation.
('39', 418, 1, 13, 835723) But all hair splitting is out of place where the question is one of serving the people and serving them in time and to the fullest extent possible.
('39', 418, 1, 14, 835871) If the money in the hand of the Government is available for good use, we should unhesitatingly ask for it and accept it.
('39', 418, 1, 15, 835992) 5. Let us not forget that organizations are meant for the service of the people, and not the people for the service of the organizations.
('39', 418, 1, 16, 836130) 6. I see that there are three agencies at work, the Provincial Congress Committee under Vallabhbhai, the Saurashtra Sevasamiti under Amritlal Sheth and the Servants of India Society under Sjt.
('39', 418, 1, 17, 836323) Devadhar.
('39', 418, 1, 18, 836333) Possibly there are others.
('39', 418, 1, 19, 836360) But in any case we must prevent any overlapping and insure the closest co operation among the agencies.
('39', 418, 1, 20, 836464) Workers who have not still reported themselves should join the centre of work which is nearest to them or which they like best.
('39', 418, 1, 21, 836592) Anyone who remains aloof either from angularity or from pride will dig his own grave.
('39', 418, 1, 22, 836678) The people will fail to benefit by his services and will think lightly of him.
('39', 418, 1, 23, 836757) 7. It would be really terrible if anyone in disregard of existing
('39', 419, 0, 1, 836823) 420 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 419, 1, 2, 836865) organizations tries to start a fresh one.
('39', 419, 1, 3, 836907) Seeing that time lost can never be regained, everyone should take his place at the point which he can reach the soonest.
('39', 419, 1, 4, 837028) Young India, 18 8 1927
('39', 419, 2, 5, 837051) 409. BACKWARD CLASSES
('39', 419, 3, 6, 837073) Our woes are numerous.
('39', 419, 3, 7, 837096) We have suppressed classes and we have also backward classes.
('39', 419, 3, 8, 837158) The distinction between the two is that the suppressed classes as a rule include only the so called untouchables, whereas, the backward classes refer to those who are mentally and morally behind the other classes.
('39', 419, 3, 9, 837372) I have made the acquaintance of one such class in Mysore.
('39', 419, 3, 10, 837430) They are the Lambanis.
('39', 419, 3, 11, 837453) Since the Belgaum Congress 1 one of them who has received a fair education has been exerting himself for their uplift.
('39', 419, 3, 12, 837572) They had even a Conference last year and the State contributed a small sum towards its expenses.
('39', 419, 3, 13, 837669) These appear originally to have come from Gujarat.
('39', 419, 3, 14, 837720) They are otherwise recognized as gypsies.
('39', 419, 3, 15, 837762) Their dialect corresponds to Gujarati.
('39', 419, 3, 16, 837801) The address 2 which they gave me whilst I was passing Arsikere on my way to Hassan was written in Devanagari.
('39', 419, 3, 17, 837911) The majority of the words in it were Gujarati.
('39', 419, 3, 18, 837958) The curious student will see the specimens from the address reproduced in Navajivan.
('39', 419, 3, 19, 838043) He will not fail to notice even the Gujarati grammar in the language of the address.
('39', 419, 3, 20, 838128) The customs of these people I find described as follows in the address of the President of the Conference :
('39', 419, 4, 21, 838236) I am told that the Lambanis are otherwise known as Vanjaris; and that they were the grain carriers of India when it had no good roads and railways; they worship to this day their queen Durga, a wealthy Lambani lady of the 13th century, who brought grain from Nepal, China and Burma, and saved many lives in a continuous famine that raged for twelve years in India; their chief God is Balaji and Goddess Tulaja Bhavani, and their principal feast is Gokulashtami, the day of the birth of Shri Krishna.
('39', 419, 4, 22, 838736) They long respected cows
('39', 419, 5, 23, 838761) and Brahmins, and to this day they abjure animal food and liquor at death dinners; they cremate the married dead and bury the unmarried.
('39', 419, 5, 24, 838898) They were as a rule a robust and well built class, and peaceful and well behaved.
('39', 419, 6, 25, 838980) But, alas!
('39', 419, 6, 26, 838991) their carrying trade has practically ceased since the opening of
('39', 419, 7, 27, 839056) roads and railways.
('39', 419, 7, 28, 839076) Some of them now deal in cattle; some have settled as
('39', 419, 8, 29, 839130) 1 Of 1924 2 Vide Speech to Lambanis, Arsikere Junction, 2 8 1927.
('39', 420, 0, 1, 839196) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 421
('39', 420, 1, 2, 839241) husbandmen, a few live by driving carts, a few others spin coarse hem tag and
('39', 420, 2, 3, 839319) sell grass and fuel and work as labourers; some are under police surveillance,
('39', 420, 3, 4, 839398) some are reputed to be robbers, cattle lifters, kidnappers of women and
('39', 420, 4, 5, 839470) children, manufacturers of false coin and distillers of illicit liquor.
('39', 420, 4, 6, 839542) But these
('39', 420, 5, 7, 839552) sinners can be reclaimed and should be reclaimed.
('39', 420, 5, 8, 839602) I understand that workers in their midst are now carrying on propaganda to combat the evil customs.
('39', 420, 5, 9, 839702) Like all backward classes the Lambani womenfolk are heavily laden with cheap and tawdry ornaments devoid of all art.
('39', 420, 5, 10, 839819) Like the Raniparaj, the reform amongst these people has gone side by side with the introduction of the spinning wheel.
('39', 420, 5, 11, 839938) The yarn which they presented to me of their own spinning was fairly good and fine.
('39', 420, 5, 12, 840022) These Lambanis number roughly 45,740 in Mysore State alone, and there are many also in British Karnatak.
('39', 420, 5, 13, 840127) There is work here for many a reformer.

('39', 421, 1, 2, 840527) 411. SPEECH AT BHADRAVATI 1
('39', 421, 2, 3, 840555) August 18, 1927 Your kind invitation, your purse and the iron casket remind me very strongly of my visit to Jamshedpur.
('39', 421, 2, 4, 840675) But one thing that strikes me most here is that the whole undertaking is from top to bottom a self contained one.
('39', 421, 2, 5, 840789) The originator is a Mysorean, the staff and labourers are mostly Mysorean, at any rate entirely South Indians.
('39', 421, 2, 6, 840900) That is a thing of which you and India may will be proud.
('39', 421, 2, 7, 840958) You have given the lie to the statement made in some quaters that India has intellect but no practical genius.
('39', 421, 2, 8, 841069) I hope and pray that the Iron Works may grow and add to the prosperity of the State from day to day.
('39', 421, 2, 9, 841170) In a country rich in mineral resources we have a place for such undertakings and it is our duty to use these resources for the welfare of the people.
('39', 421, 2, 10, 841320) I am sorry Sir M. Vishveshwarayya is not here, but his telegam of cordial welcome shows that his spirit is here.
('39', 421, 2, 11, 841433) A word now to you workers here, just as I did to those at Jamshedpur.
('39', 421, 2, 12, 841503) There is as I have said need for your undertaking, but there is greater need for the work for which you have given your purse.
('39', 421, 2, 13, 841630) Undertakings such as yours are necessary for the middle class and the rich, but you may not afford to neglect the helpless poor.
('39', 421, 2, 14, 841759) There are two ways in which you can helpby contributing money for khadi, and by wearing it yourselves.
('39', 421, 2, 15, 841862) Just as your works would have to stop if there was no market for iron, even so the khadi movement would be unprogressive if you did not wear the product of the poor mans labour.
('39', 421, 2, 16, 842040) I appeal to the capitalist not to neglect the poor, whilst he may go on with his undertaking.
('39', 421, 2, 17, 842134) In conclusion I hope that the relations between the officials and the workmen are sweet and friendly, and that care is taken to keep the liquor house and the gambling den miles away from your quarters.
('39', 421, 2, 18, 842336) Young India, 1 9 1927

('39', 422, 1, 2, 842439) 412. APPEAL TO TAMIL NADU
('39', 422, 2, 3, 842465) August 18, 1927 1
('39', 422, 3, 4, 842483) God willing, I expect to enter upon the long deferred tour in Tamil Nadu in the beginning of September.
('39', 422, 3, 5, 842587) Had there been no programme already fixed, I would have prolonged the rest and not undertaken any touring.
('39', 422, 3, 6, 842694) But under Dr. Subbaraos advice, I took the risk of trying gentle touring in Mysore and though I am by no means as strong as I felt five months ago, the result of the tour in Mysore emboldens me to take up the Tamil Nadu tour.
('39', 422, 3, 7, 842920) But it will be impossible to keep to the original programme which was both intensive and extensive.
('39', 422, 3, 8, 843020) It is necessary now to reduce the engagements in each place to the minimum as also the number of places to be visited.
('39', 422, 3, 9, 843139) I have therefore asked Mr. Rajagopalachariar to confine the tour to principal centres in the hope that the neighbouring places that may have been omitted will bring their purses and send as many villagers as possible to the centers to be visited.
('39', 422, 3, 10, 843386) It is a matter of no small grief to me that I cannot personally deliver the message of the wheel at all the places that had been fixed.
('39', 422, 3, 11, 843522) But I can only do what is humanly possible.
('39', 422, 3, 12, 843566) Indeed, if it was possible, I should love to visit every one of the seven hundred thousand villages of the motherland.
('39', 422, 3, 13, 843685) But I have humility enough to recognize my very grave limitations and be content with what little God permits me to do.
('39', 422, 3, 14, 843805) I seek the co operation, however, of all the lovers of khadi in order that its life giving message can reach the remotest village.
('39', 422, 3, 15, 843936) I hope that those who have the means will give, for and in the name of Daridranarayana, the most that they can, so that the organization which is slowly but surely growing in our villages and the revival the spinning wheel has brought about may not die a lingering death.
('39', 422, 3, 16, 844208) I appeal to the Reception Committees in the places which are to be visited to cut down all unnecessary items, especially those of show, and also reduce the demonstrative expenditure to a minimum.
('39', 422, 3, 17, 844404) Let every pie that the Committee may have to spend on ceremonial be saved and gained for the cause of the voiceless millions.

('39', 423, 1, 2, 844634) 413. LETTER TO S. D. NADKARNI
('39', 423, 2, 3, 844664) AS AT BANGALORE, August 19, 1927
('39', 423, 3, 4, 844697) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter with very carefully written articles on untouchability.
('39', 423, 3, 5, 844785) I have expected them to be up to your usual standard.
('39', 423, 3, 6, 844839) I gave them for type copying at once so that I could send the typed copies for any correction that you may want to make.
('39', 423, 3, 7, 844960) But before sending them I had intended to read the articles, which I have now done, and whilst, as I have said, they are very carefully written, they are neither original nor as closely reasoned as I have known your writings to be.
('39', 423, 3, 8, 845192) I havent the time to give you a detailed criticism; but I would just point out the defect in your definition, which, in any case, seems to me to be ponderous.
('39', 423, 3, 9, 845351) Untouchability is no avoidance but it is being untouchable on acount of certain characteristics of birth.
('39', 423, 3, 10, 845457) In the other paragraph you have not kept close to the sub heading which from the opening paragraphs one expects to be accurate and exclusive.
('39', 423, 3, 11, 845599) In the second article the texts do not seem to disprove untouchability, but seem to attack an excessive observance of it.
('39', 423, 3, 12, 845721) If you will deal with the Shastras, it is really necessary to enter upon a deeper examination.
('39', 423, 3, 13, 845816) When did the idea of untouchability arise and what is its extent?
('39', 423, 3, 14, 845882) I wonder if you have read Pandit Satavalekars treatise on this subject.
('39', 423, 3, 15, 845954) In a way it is fairly exhaustive.
('39', 423, 3, 16, 845988) If you will write for Young India on this subject in a learned way, I would like you to study it more carefully, if you have the time, and produce something original, or write something popular and original ridiculing the extravagance of the practice as it obtains todayextravagance both in the manner and the extent of its application, even assuming that there is a warrant for untouchability in Hinduism pure and undefiled.
('39', 423, 3, 17, 846414) I return your articles.
('39', 423, 3, 18, 846438) Yours sincerely,

('39', 424, 1, 2, 846530) 414. LETTER TO K. P. PADMANABHA IYER
('39', 424, 2, 3, 846567) AS AT BANGALORE, August 19, 1927
('39', 424, 3, 4, 846600) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('39', 424, 3, 5, 846633) You have told me nothing new.
('39', 424, 3, 6, 846663) My question was simple, whether you had made any experiments yourself, and, if so, with what result.
('39', 424, 3, 7, 846764) 1 You have instead of answering that question given me a thesis of which I was not in need.
('39', 424, 3, 8, 846856) People write to me giving me advice on all sorts of matters of which they have no personal knowledge.
('39', 424, 3, 9, 846958) I had thought that you had perhaps some knowledge, being a qualified man.
('39', 424, 3, 10, 847032) I have read almost all the Western books on food reform.
('39', 424, 3, 11, 847089) They are good only up to a point.
('39', 424, 3, 12, 847123) Many of the observations have to be taken with the greatest caution, because of our different habits of life.
('39', 424, 3, 13, 847233) The results obtained by experiments under Western conditions will not be the result necessarily to be obtained here.
('39', 424, 3, 14, 847350) And then, I have also noticed that the experiments are not in every case faithfully described.
('39', 424, 3, 15, 847445) Many data are omitted.
('39', 424, 3, 16, 847468) The majority of us whether in the medical line or any other do not take a scientific interest in our professions, our only concern being to make money or somehow to get on in life.
('39', 424, 3, 17, 847649) Hence is there an utter dearth of original research work.
('39', 424, 3, 18, 847707) Being unable now to make experiments myself, I would gladly receive aid from the experience of others.
('39', 424, 3, 19, 847810) But it must be real experience and not book knowledge.
('39', 424, 3, 20, 847865) Perhaps the typed matter is your only copy, and I therefore return it to you.

('39', 426, 4, 9, 850221) 417. A LETTER
('39', 426, 5, 10, 850235) AS AT THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, August 19, 1927
('39', 426, 6, 11, 850280) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('39', 426, 6, 12, 850313) All my sympathies are with you.
('39', 426, 6, 13, 850345) Your last state is simply due to excessive self abuse.
('39', 426, 6, 14, 850400) The vital fluid is evidently now passed even without stimulation.
('39', 426, 6, 15, 850466) My advice to you is not to go to your wife at all at least for one year and not till you have acquired mastery of yourself, whether it is inside of the year or even beyond.
('39', 426, 6, 16, 850639) You must not hesitate to tell your parents the reason for your abstention.
('39', 426, 6, 17, 850714) When they understand how you have weakened yourself and become diseased, if they are at all wise, they will know the reason and trouble you no more in your attempt to rebuild your constitution.
('39', 426, 6, 18, 850908) You must learn cooking for yourself, so that you may regulate your diet.
('39', 426, 6, 19, 850981) Give up cycling.
('39', 426, 6, 20, 850998) Walk to your college, seek the company only of good boys.
('39', 426, 6, 21, 851056) Do not be in a hurry to pass your examination.
('39', 426, 6, 22, 851103) Take your own time.
('39', 426, 6, 23, 851123) Retire to bed early, and at that time of retiring, think good thoughts and pray to God for help with an implicit faith that there is a high power ruling our destination and responsive to our innermost cravings for betterment.
('39', 426, 6, 24, 851349) Take gentle walks before retiring to bed, but without overfatiguing yourself.
('39', 426, 6, 25, 851427) Jump out of the bed as soon as you are awake no matter when, and do not go to bed again before the next bed time unless you fell so giddy that you must sleep, in which case you will take as much sleep as may be necessary.
('39', 426, 6, 26, 851649) Repeat the practice from night to night till you have won long sweet undisturbed sleep from 9 to 4. At 4 o clock you will get up, have your mouth washed, and even a full bath if you can get your bowels to move at that time
('39', 427, 0, 1, 851872) 428 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 427, 1, 2, 851914) and are not too weak to have the bath so early, and then read the Bhagavad Gita or any other religious book or simply utter Ramanama for half an hour or at least for five minutes if you cannot concentrate longer and for five minutes you will [pray] 1, whether with or without concentration, always trying to concentrate.
('39', 427, 1, 3, 852235) After this religious practice, you will take at least half an hours walk out in the open.
('39', 427, 1, 4, 852325) And then a cup full of fresh milk, boiled without sugar and you may have some fresh fruit if it is available, otherwise twenty dried raisins.
('39', 427, 1, 5, 852467) Wash the raisins and chew them well.
('39', 427, 1, 6, 852504) You will take no other food till 10 o clock or 12 o clock or whatever the time is when you may take a little chapati and some clean boiled vegetable without salt and nothing more.
('39', 427, 1, 7, 852684) In the evening, before dark the same quantity of milk as in the morning and chapati with or without vegetable.
('39', 427, 1, 8, 852795) If you dont take vegetable, you may take raisins or fresh fruit.
('39', 427, 1, 9, 852860) If you do not know how to make chapati, you must learn it.
('39', 427, 1, 10, 852919) Any green vegetable can be taken.
('39', 427, 1, 11, 852953) Not starchy ones if possible.
('39', 427, 1, 12, 852983) But when you cannot get green stuff, you may have potatoes or any other starchy vegetable and add to it fresh lemons juice.
('39', 427, 1, 13, 853107) Dont take any sugar or condiments.
('39', 427, 1, 14, 853142) Keep your bowels in good order.
('39', 427, 1, 15, 853174) And at the time of retiring at night take an earth bandage.
('39', 427, 1, 16, 853234) You may read with profit, perhaps, my Guide to Health and the booklet Self Restraint v.
('39', 427, 1, 17, 853322) Self Indulgence.
('39', 427, 1, 18, 853339) If you have discharges either in night or in the day time you must immediately have a cold hip bath.
('39', 427, 1, 19, 853440) On no account must you practise self abuse.
('39', 427, 1, 20, 853484) On the approach of the least sensation, you must get up and walk briskly keeping your fist closed so tight as if you were about to hit anybody.
('39', 427, 1, 21, 853628) Sit at the spinning wheel for half an hour at least concentrating yourself on your work to God and do the spinning in a proper humble sacrificial spirit.

('39', 428, 1, 2, 854218) 418. LETTER TO B. GOPALACHAR CHIKMAGALUR, August 19, 1927
('39', 428, 2, 3, 854276) DEAR FRIEND, Here are the answers to your questions: 1. In my opinion State aid should not be asked and should not be given except on the following conditions: Every school in which the head master is or teachers are prepared to learn carding and spinning and submit to an examination should receive Rs. 5 per month as an increase in the existing salary of the head master or the teacher in question, provided that he guarantees manufacture of five tolas of yarn of at least 6 counts per boy or girl per month, the increase to be drawn only upon certificates by the inspector of the required amount of yarn and a capital expense of annas four per boy or girl for spinning outfit.
('39', 428, 2, 4, 854956) Note: Unless some such provision is made, my experience is that expense incurred over the introduction of hand spinning in schools becomes a mere waste.
('39', 428, 2, 5, 855109) And it would be wrong to introduce spinning in schools unless there is a staff of qualified inspectors and itinerant teachers for teaching these school masters, and, if necessary, in the preliminary stages even the boys and girls.
('39', 428, 2, 6, 855340) 2. Spinning should be made compulsory only in such primary and middle schools where the majority of municipal or local board voters consent.
('39', 428, 2, 7, 855481) Compulsion would be useless where there is no public opinion in favour of hand spinning.
('39', 428, 2, 8, 855570) 3. The unfortunate experience just now is that boys take to spinning more quickly than girls.
('39', 428, 2, 9, 855664) Therefore, I would make no distinction, and it is wrong to introduce the idea amongst boys and girls that spinning is essentially meant for girls and not for boys.
('39', 428, 2, 10, 855828) It is to be treated as a national duty and it is to be prized for its cultural advantages so far as the boys and girls are concerned.
('39', 428, 2, 11, 855962) 4. The question of cotton growing tracts is irrelevant to the consideration of introducing spinning in schools and cotton trees (that is, the devkapas variety) can be planted anywhere.
('39', 428, 2, 12, 856147) 5. As I do not know the incidence of the education cess in Mysore, I am unable to answer the question.
('39', 429, 0, 1, 856250) 430 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 429, 1, 2, 856292) 6. Public sympathy and support can only be obtained by propaganda on behalf of the Industrial Department just as was done and is still being done in the matter of co operation.
('39', 429, 1, 3, 856469) Hand spinning is really the greatest aid to co operation.
('39', 429, 1, 4, 856527) 7. As there are weaving sheds in the Adi Karnataka workshop conducted by the Government, all yarn manufactured in the schools should be sent to these sheds for weaving and a stipulated price should be paid by these institutions to the schools manufacturing yarn.
('39', 429, 1, 5, 856790) If you are serious about this matter and are convinced as to the absolute necessity of spinning becoming universal, you should give some attention to the study of the technique of hand spinning, which you can easily do in a months time if you devote a whole month to it, or in three months time if you devote at least one hour per day before taking up questions.
('39', 429, 1, 6, 857153) Merely putting questions in the Assembly and throwing the blame or the burden upon the Government is to damage the cause.
('39', 429, 1, 7, 857275) For, after all the Government can only respond to the atmosphere around it.
('39', 429, 1, 8, 857351) And Government after all is what the people make it.
('39', 429, 1, 9, 857404) It has no power or capacity apart from the people.
('39', 429, 2, 10, 857455) Yours sincerely,
('39', 429, 3, 11, 857472) B. GOPALACHAR R. A. MEMBER TIRTHAHALLI SHIMOGA DISTRICT
('39', 429, 4, 12, 857528) From a microfilm : S. N. 19805

('39', 431, 7, 12, 859782) We do not know what Shri Krishnas life means for us, we do not read the Gita, we make no attempt to teach it to our children.
('39', 431, 7, 13, 859908) The Gita is such a transcendental book that men of every creed, age and clime may read it with respect, and find in it the principles of their respective religions.
('39', 431, 7, 14, 860073) If we thought of Krishna on every Janmashtami day and read the Gita and resolved to follow its teachings, we should not be in our present sorry plight.
('39', 431, 7, 15, 860225) Shri Krishna served the people all his life; he was a real servant of the people.

('39', 431, 7, 17, 860394) His whole life was one unbroken Gita of karma.
('39', 431, 7, 18, 860441) He refused proud Duryodhanas sweets and preferred humble Viduras spinach.
('39', 431, 7, 19, 860515) As a child he was a cowherd and we still know him by the name of Gopala.
('39', 431, 7, 20, 860588) But we, his worshippers, have neglected the cow today; the Adi Karnatakas slaugthter cows and eat beef, and our infants and invalids have to go without cows milk.
('39', 431, 7, 21, 860751) Krishna knew no sleep or idleness.

('39', 435, 1, 2, 866675) 427. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL JOSHI August 22, 1927 I have both your letters.
('39', 435, 1, 3, 866749) As Kaka has gone to see the gold mines today, I could not show them to him.
('39', 435, 1, 4, 866825) He will write to you as soon as he returns and thereafter he or I shall return the letters to you.

('39', 435, 1, 8, 867069) I destroyed that letter as it was not worth preserving.
('39', 435, 1, 9, 867125) My idea in destroying it was that the fewer the people who read it the better it would be.
('39', 435, 1, 10, 867216) I already knew the first part of what you wrote.
('39', 435, 1, 11, 867265) That is to say, I knew the matter up to Maganlals fast 1. What was news to me was the breach of pledges by both even after the fast as also the experience of Ramdas.
('39', 435, 1, 12, 867431) Indeed that has aroused my suspicion but my opinion is not based on it.
('39', 435, 1, 13, 867503) It is based solely on the frequent violation of truthfulness.
('39', 435, 1, 14, 867565) Even if one who commits such a breach is good in other respects, the Ashram which lays stress on satya cannot accommodate him.
('39', 435, 1, 15, 867692) Moreover, the Ashram provides maintenance to a great extent.
('39', 435, 1, 16, 867753) It is not our duty nor do we have the right to extend that maintenance to one who cannot serve the Ashram.
('39', 435, 1, 17, 867860) The reason for this decision is therefore only the proved faults of Chi.
('39', 435, 1, 18, 867933) Kashi in telling lies.
('39', 435, 1, 19, 867956) But it is only if all of you can come to the same decision calmly that you should give effect to my advice.
('39', 435, 1, 20, 868064) I am and am not in a hurry.
('39', 435, 1, 21, 868092) I am not because in these matters we must act with full circumspection.
('39', 435, 1, 22, 868164) I am in a hurry to the extent that once a decision is taken it is adharma to delay putting it into effect.
('39', 435, 1, 23, 868271) The Managing Committee ought certainly to read and understand this letter.
('39', 435, 1, 24, 868346) It may, if it wants to, ask me anything.
('39', 435, 1, 25, 868387) Certainly get from me whatever you need to in order to reach a decision.

('39', 437, 1, 2, 870340) 429. LETTER TO GANGABEHN August 22, 1927 I have your letter; Kakasaheb too read to me the one you wrote to him.
('39', 437, 1, 3, 870452) I can understand your wish to tour with me and at the same time serve Kakasaheb, but I shall not encourage you in it.
('39', 437, 1, 4, 870570) 1. Kakasaheb ought not to stand in need of so much service and Chandrashankar should make up for your absence.
('39', 437, 1, 5, 870681) If that is not possible Kakasaheb should become too dependent.
('39', 437, 1, 6, 870744) 2. If Ba needs the services of anyone, she should go to the Ashram.
('39', 437, 1, 7, 870812) If one who serves me needs to be served by someone else such a ones service will not be service at all and I must give up such service.
('39', 437, 1, 8, 870948) 3. Instead of benefiting by tours you would only suffer harm.
('39', 437, 1, 9, 871010) With me one has to move from place to place, no studies will therefore be possible.
('39', 437, 1, 10, 871094) It will be good indeed if I have with me some woman attendant, but she should have completed her studies.
('39', 437, 1, 11, 871200) I see if Manibehn too remains longer, she would stand to lose.
('39', 437, 1, 12, 871263) Her studies have already suffered.
('39', 437, 1, 13, 871298) Deep in her heart she desired to stay.
('39', 437, 1, 14, 871337) She is yet a child.
('39', 437, 1, 15, 871357) As she had come here on business, she was allowed to stay.
('39', 437, 1, 16, 871416) You should of course be engrossed in your studies.
('39', 437, 1, 17, 871467) When Kakasaheb gets settled, you may certainly stay with him, serve him and learn from him.
('39', 437, 1, 18, 871559) Now you should give up your reserve and learn reading and writing from anyone who can teach and offers to do it.
('39', 437, 1, 19, 871672) Self knowledge can be had only from saints.

('39', 443, 7, 14, 881064) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('39', 443, 7, 15, 881097) I know that many girls are now tending might be considered too simple.
('39', 443, 7, 16, 881168) Let me however make my meaning clear.
('39', 443, 7, 17, 881206) I do not by any means consider simplicity as synonymous with shabbiness, shoddiness or slovenliness; nor need a devotee of simplicity be devoid of a sense of taste or decency.
('39', 443, 7, 18, 881382) What I have found is that the simplest things are the neatest possible and this neatness that comes from simplicity can be the common heritage of all mankind instead of the manufactured taste which has become the exclusive property of the monied few.
('39', 443, 7, 19, 881633) If you are sincere about your desire to go to the Ashram and earnest and yet gentle in your effort, you will certainly bear down the opposition of your parents.

('39', 451, 2, 7, 895013) 447. STUDENTS AND THE GITA
('39', 451, 3, 8, 895040) The other day, in the course of a conversation, a missionary friend asked me, if India was really a spiritually advanced country, why it was that he found only a few students having any knowledge of their own religion, even of the Bhagavad Gita.
('39', 451, 3, 9, 895286) In support of the statement, the friend who is himself an educationist told me that he had made it a point to ask the students he met whether they had any knowledge of their religion or of the Bhagavad Gita.
('39', 451, 3, 10, 895494) A vast majority of them were found to be innocent of any such knowledge.
('39', 451, 3, 11, 895567) I do not propose to take up at the present moment the inference that because certain students had no knowledge of their own religion, India was not a spiritually advanced country, beyond saying that the ignorance on the part of the students of religious books did not necessarily mean absence of all religious life or want or spirituality among the people to which the students belonged.
('39', 451, 3, 12, 895955) But there is no doubt that the vast majority of students who pass through the Government educational institutions are devoid of any religious instruction.
('39', 451, 3, 13, 896110) The remark of the missionary had reference to the Mysore students, and I was somewhat pained to observe that even the students of Mysore had no religious instruction in the State schools.
('39', 451, 3, 14, 896298) I know that there is a school of thought which believes in only secular instruction being given in public schools.
('39', 451, 3, 15, 896413) I know also that in a country like India, where there are most religions of the world represented and where there are so many denominations in the same religion, there must be difficulty about making provision for religious instruction.
('39', 451, 3, 16, 896650) But if India is not to declare spiritual bankruptcy, religious instruction of its youth must be held to be at least as necessary as secular instruction.
('39', 451, 3, 17, 896803) It is true that knowledge of religious books is no equivalent of that of religion.
('39', 451, 3, 18, 896886) But if we cannot have religion we must be satisfied with providing our boys and girls with what is next best.
('39', 451, 3, 19, 896996) And whether there is such instruction given in the schools or not, grown up students must cultivate the art of self help
('39', 452, 0, 1, 897117) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 453
('39', 452, 1, 2, 897162) about matters religious as about other.
('39', 452, 1, 3, 897202) They may start their own class just as they have their debating and now spinners clubs.
('39', 452, 1, 4, 897290) Addressing the Collegiate High School students at Shimoga, I found upon enquiry at the meeting that out of a hundred or more Hindu boys, there were hardly eight who had read the Bhagavad Gita.
('39', 452, 1, 5, 897483) None raised his hand in answer to the question, whether of the few who had read the Gita there was any who understood it.
('39', 452, 1, 6, 897605) Out of five or six Mussalman boys all raised their hands as having read the Koran.
('39', 452, 1, 7, 897688) But only one could say that he knew its meaning.
('39', 452, 1, 8, 897737) The Gita is, in my opinion, a very easy book to undestand.
('39', 452, 1, 9, 897796) It does present some fundamental problems which are no doubt difficult of solution.
('39', 452, 1, 10, 897880) But the general trend of the Gita is in my opinion unmistakable.
('39', 452, 1, 11, 897945) It is accepted by all Hindu sects as authoritative.
('39', 452, 1, 12, 897997) It is free from any form of dogma.
('39', 452, 1, 13, 898032) In a short compass it gives a complete reasoned moral code.
('39', 452, 1, 14, 898092) It satisfies both the intellect and heart.
('39', 452, 1, 15, 898135) It is thus both philosophical and devotional.
('39', 452, 1, 16, 898181) Its appeal is universal.
('39', 452, 1, 17, 898206) The language is incredibly simple.
('39', 452, 1, 18, 898241) But I nevertheless think that there should be an authoritative version in each vernacular, and the translations should be so prepared as to avoid technicalities and in a manner that would make the teaching of the Gita intelligible to the average man.
('39', 452, 1, 19, 898492) The suggestion is not intended in any way to supplement the original.
('39', 452, 1, 20, 898562) For I reiterate my opinion that every Hindu boy and girl should know Sanskrit.
('39', 452, 1, 21, 898641) But for a long time to come, there will be millions without any knowledge of Sanskrit.
('39', 452, 1, 22, 898728) It would be suicidal to keep them deprived of the teachings of Bhagavad Gita because they do not know Sanskrit.
