('39', 452, 3, 24, 898863) 448. NOTES
('39', 452, 4, 25, 898874) INSOLENT REMINDERS The trial of two young men in Madras, one a Hindu aged about 30 and the other a Mussalman aged 25, on a charge of having attempted to disfigure a statue in Mount Road, Madras, of General Neill of the Mutiny fame, has a deep significance.
('39', 452, 4, 26, 899131) Their attempt reminds one of the abortive effort made in Lahore during the heyday of Non co operation to have the Lawrence statue, or at least the highly offensive inscription the pen or the sword, removed.
('39', 452, 4, 27, 899338) The Lahore attempt was on the part of the general populace.
('39', 452, 4, 28, 899398) The Madras attempt was confined to two young men who went about their work with quiet
('39', 453, 0, 1, 899484) 454 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 453, 1, 2, 899526) determination and without any fuss.
('39', 453, 1, 3, 899562) The following statement made by the accused according to The Hindu report will be read with great interest:
('39', 453, 2, 4, 899670) The first accused stated that he was born in Tinnevelly but lived in Madura.
('39', 453, 2, 5, 899747) He knew what kind of punishment he would get before doing this act.
('39', 453, 2, 6, 899815) They were prepared to undergo any thing for this.
('39', 453, 2, 7, 899865) From his study of history he knew that Neill had done much harm to the country, and thought that his statue should not be there, and he (the accused) determined to destroy it.
('39', 453, 2, 8, 900041) They had brought the hammer and the axe as they came from their place.
('39', 453, 2, 9, 900112) They did not bring the hammer and axe for this particular purpose.
('39', 453, 2, 10, 900179) After coming to Madras they went round the city for sight seeing in the course of which they saw the statue.
('39', 453, 2, 11, 900288) They remembered his history and so attempted to destroy it this morning.
('39', 453, 2, 12, 900361) But the statue was neither bronze nor marble as they thought.
('39', 453, 2, 13, 900423) As it was copper only some parts broke.
('39', 453, 2, 14, 900463) After that the sergeant took them to the police station.
('39', 453, 2, 15, 900520) For that offence they were prepared to take any punishment His Worship might think fit to impose.
('39', 453, 2, 16, 900618) Asked as to whether they pleaded guilty, they said that they were guilty if they were bound by the law of the Government, but in their own opinion they do not feel guilty.
('39', 453, 2, 17, 900790) It is impossible to withhold sympathy from these brave young men, alike for the motive which prompted the act and for the dignity with which they approached their trial.
('39', 453, 2, 18, 900960) The report before me adds that the accused were unrepresented and did not even cross examine the prosecution witness.
('39', 453, 2, 19, 901078) There seems to be no doubt that as national consciousness grows, the resentment over the insolent reminders, which such statues are, of abused British prowess and British barbarity will grow in strength.
('39', 453, 2, 20, 901282) A wise Government, however powerful it may be, will remove every such offensive reminder, and not goad infuriate public opinion into acts which, however regrettable and reprehensible they may be in themselves, will be held justifiable as a fitting answer to the criminal indifference to legitimate national sentiment.
('39', 453, 2, 21, 901600) And every abortion of attempts to remove these running sores only adds to the bitterness, and widens the gulf that separates us and the British.
('39', 453, 2, 22, 901745) Surely the Municipality of Madras which owns the statue should remove it.
('39', 453, 3, 23, 901819) TOO GOOD TO BE TRUE Swami Anand has collected, in the issue of Navajivan of 7th August 1927, information about the heroic deeds of people all over Gujarat.
('39', 453, 3, 24, 901975) In the sketches are given instances of Hindus and Mussalmans helping one another as if they had never quarrelled, also
('39', 454, 0, 1, 902094) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 455
('39', 454, 1, 2, 902139) of suppressed and suppressors living together under the same roof and sharing the same food, people saving one another at great personal risk.
('39', 454, 1, 3, 902282) Whilst I was reading the sketches I was wondering if they could be all true.
('39', 454, 1, 4, 902359) Then I remembered that it was Navajivan I was reading, and unauthenticated stories were inadmissible in its columns, and that Swami himsellf was, if it was possible, more careful than I about admitting anything doubtful.
('39', 454, 1, 5, 902580) The sketches show from Bhavnagar to Broacha wide enough area of distressstories of unexampled self help, self reliance and mutual help.
('39', 454, 1, 6, 902716) As Swami well remarks, for the moment the people exhibited every quality that makes a nation great and self governing.
('39', 454, 1, 7, 902835) There was no fear, no panic, but grim determination to battle with death.
('39', 454, 1, 8, 902909) If the account is true,I must still be cautiousit reflects the highest credit on all concerned.
('39', 454, 1, 9, 903005) All were leaders and all were led.
('39', 454, 1, 10, 903040) It was a spontaneous organization that came into being on the advent of distress.
('39', 454, 1, 11, 903122) The thing for the leaders to see to is, whether the lessons of the mighty deluge can be made permanent.
('39', 454, 1, 12, 903226) Will the Hindu Muslim friendship outlast the immediate need?
('39', 454, 1, 13, 903287) Will the yoke of the suppressed be lifted for ever?
('39', 454, 1, 14, 903339) Will the self be used to subserve the benefit of all in everyday transactions?
('39', 454, 1, 15, 903418) Will the predeluge avarice remain under check in the face of the charity that is freely flowing Gujarat ward?
('39', 454, 1, 16, 903528) Will the stewards in charge of relief funds resist the temptation to steal or misappropriate trust funds?
('39', 454, 1, 17, 903634) Will there be no feigning of distress and no needless applications for relief?
('39', 454, 1, 18, 903713) The answers to these many such questions can only be satisfactorily given, if the many leaders who are now operating will be good as gold.
('39', 454, 1, 19, 903852) That would mean real change of heart and real penitence and purification.
('39', 454, 1, 20, 903926) It is said that there is always, after a deluge of any magnitude, a reformation of life among the survivors.
('39', 454, 1, 21, 904035) It may be that, extensive as the calamity was, it may not be classed as a real deluge warranting a sweeping reformation.
('39', 454, 1, 22, 904156) Mankind is notoriously too dense to read the signs that God sends from time to time.
('39', 454, 1, 23, 904241) We require drums to be beaten into our ears, before we would wake from our trance and hear the warning and see that to lose oneself in all is the only way to find oneself.
('39', 454, 1, 24, 904413) Will Gujarat show enough advance to regard the recent floods as an all sufficing warning to us to write a new and brilliant chapter in the history of this afflicted land of ours?
('39', 454, 1, 25, 904592) Posterity will have every reason to distrust the contemporary accounts of heroism, self reliance and mutual help, if the people of Gujarat are unable to show any lasting and demonstrable reformation.

('39', 455, 1, 2, 904857) 449. THE LAW OF CONTINENCE
('39', 455, 2, 3, 904884) A friend sends me relevant extracts from The Science of a New Life by Dr. Cowen.
('39', 455, 2, 4, 904965) I have not read the book.
('39', 455, 2, 5, 904991) But the advice contained in the extracts 1 is certainly sound.
('39', 455, 2, 6, 905054) I have omitted from the extracts certain paragraphs about food which are not of much value to the Indian reader.
('39', 455, 2, 7, 905167) Let no one desirous of leading a pure and chaste life think that the practice of it is not worth pursuing because the expected result is not attained in a moment.
('39', 455, 2, 8, 905330) And let no one expect perfection of body after successful practice of continence even for a long time.
('39', 455, 2, 9, 905433) The majority of us who endeavour to follow the rules laid down for observing continence labour under three handicaps.
('39', 455, 2, 10, 905551) We have inherited imperfect bodies and weak wills from our parents, and by an incorrect life we find ourselves to have further debilitated both our bodies and wills.When a writing advocating purity of life attracts us, we begin the reformation.
('39', 455, 2, 11, 905796) Such reformation is never too late.
('39', 455, 2, 12, 905832) But we must not expect the results described in such writings; for those results are to be expected only from a regulated life from early youth.
('39', 455, 2, 13, 905977) And the third handicap we labour under is that in spite of the exercise of all the artificial and outward restraint we find ourselves unable to restrain and regularize our thoughts.
('39', 455, 2, 14, 906159) And let every aspirant after a pure life take from me that an impure thought is often as powerful in undermining the body as an impure act.
('39', 455, 2, 15, 906299) Control over thought is a long, painful and laborious process.
('39', 455, 2, 16, 906362) But I am convinced that no time, no labour and no pain is too much for the glorious result to be reached.
('39', 455, 2, 17, 906468) The purity of thought is possible only with a faith in God bordering on definite experience.
('39', 455, 3, 18, 906561) Young India, 25 8 1927

('39', 456, 1, 2, 906651) 450. THE BLIND SPINNERS
('39', 456, 2, 3, 906675) On reading an account of the blind spinner at the recently held Khadi Exhibition in Bangalore, a correspondent has sent me the following beautiful lines by Helen Hunt Jackson:
('39', 456, 3, 4, 906851) Like a blind spinner in the sun I tread my day; I know that all the threads will run The appointed way; I know each day will bring its task And, being blind, no more I ask.
('39', 456, 3, 5, 907024) I do not know the use or name Of what I spin; I only know that someone came And laid within My hand the thread and said, Sir you Are blind, but one thing you can do, Sometimes the threads so rough and fast And tangled fly, I know wild storms are sweeping past, And fear that I Shall fall, but dare not fly to find A safer place, since I am blind.
('39', 456, 3, 6, 907371) I know not why, but I am sure That tint and place, In some great fabric to endure Past time and race, My threads will have; so from the first, Though blind, I never felt accurst.
('39', 456, 4, 7, 907550) What a transformation there would be in our country, if all who canwho cannot?
('39', 456, 4, 8, 907629) will spin with the faith of the blind spinner.
('39', 456, 4, 9, 907676) Can we not feel that every thread we spin will have place in some great fabric to endure?
('39', 456, 5, 10, 907766) Young India, 25 8 1927

('39', 457, 1, 2, 907831) 451. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('39', 457, 2, 3, 907855) KUMARA PARK, BANGALORE, August 26, 1927
('39', 457, 3, 4, 907895) MIRA I have your letters.
('39', 457, 3, 5, 907921) Pray do not worry about the possibility of my straining myself to write to you.
('39', 457, 3, 6, 908001) When I write I do so because I must, and what I must do always gives me pleasure in the doing.
('39', 457, 3, 7, 908096) When I become an instrument to pure and sensitive that it would react and respond to every circumstance around it, I shall cease to write or speak and yet my thoughts will work their way to hearts of those who need my guidance or assistance.
('39', 457, 3, 8, 908338) But till that time is reached, I must make use of the less reliable and imperfect instrument of the pen and the tongue.
('39', 457, 3, 9, 908458) I still feel that you have unnecessarily excited yourself over the segregation.
('39', 457, 3, 10, 908538) Why do you call it compulsory?
('39', 457, 3, 11, 908569) For you it would be an act of purest love on your part.
('39', 457, 3, 12, 908625) You know 14 Romans.
('39', 457, 3, 13, 908645) There Paul, himself not a vegetarian, says to his congregation, If meat offend thy brother abstain from it. I am quoting from memory, 1 therefore the words may not be the same, but the substance is the same.
('39', 457, 3, 14, 908853) You will segregate yourself not because you feel yourself impure in any sense of the term, but you will do so for the same of your neighbours and for the sake of those women who belive in segregation from a right motive.
('39', 457, 3, 15, 909074) I do not know that I have made my meaning sufficiently clear.
('39', 457, 3, 16, 909136) The whole point is this.

('39', 462, 4, 6, 918109) 454. PROBLEM OF CHILDREN OF MIXED UNIONS
('39', 462, 5, 7, 918150) An Indian living in the city of Mabuki in French Africa has written a painful letter, the substance of which is as follows : There is a very large number of children of mixed unions in this country.
('39', 462, 5, 8, 918349) Both Hindus and Muslims are responsible for their birth.
('39', 462, 5, 9, 918406) Coming here for trade, they live with any Negro women whom they choose.
('39', 462, 5, 10, 918478) They do not look after the children which are born to these women.
('39', 462, 5, 11, 918545) The children grow up somehow.
('39', 462, 5, 12, 918575) When the traders who contract such unions return to India, they leave behind these women and their issue, making no provision even for their maintenance.
('39', 462, 5, 13, 918729) When a person like me tries to look after their maintenance and wishes to establish an institution for that purpose, no one helps him.
('39', 462, 5, 14, 918864) Will you not kindly tell us what is my duty and that of other Indians like me towards these children of mixed unions?
('39', 462, 5, 15, 918982) Do you believe that by supporting children born of sin we only encourage sin and, therefore, we owe no duty towards them?
('39', 462, 5, 16, 919104) If you do, consider this : These children will certainly get someone or other to look after them; God will not let them perish helplessly.
('39', 462, 5, 17, 919243) If that is so, will they not grow up to be our enemies, and if they do, can anyone blame them?
('39', 462, 5, 18, 919338) Can it not be said, rather, that those who bring such progeny into the world and leave it uncared for, bring into existence the instruments of their own and their communitys destruction?
('39', 462, 5, 19, 919525) I have with my own eyes seen in Delagoa Bay and other cities the conditions described by this correspondent, and I have heard still more from clients and friends.
('39', 462, 5, 20, 919688) There is no doubt that it is a painful state of affairs.
('39', 462, 5, 21, 919745) Muslim friends display human feeling in such matters.
('39', 462, 5, 22, 919799) Hindus become extremely hard hearted in the name or under the pretext of religion.
('39', 462, 5, 23, 919882) Muslims do not seem to consider it morally wrong to live with women professing other faiths than still form them.
('39', 462, 5, 24, 919996) Thus they are not afraid of gratifying their desires but shrink from
('39', 463, 0, 1, 920065) 464 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 463, 1, 2, 920107) accepting responsibility for the consequences.
('39', 463, 1, 3, 920154) They feel it pollution to have to live with their own progeny, so that in the end they hand over the children either to Muslims or to Christians or, likely enough, just run away without entrusting them to anyone or leaving a single pie for their maintenance.
('39', 463, 1, 4, 920413) The Negroes of Africa are simple minded and ignorant and, therefore, do not know what their rights are.
('39', 463, 1, 5, 920517) This state will certainly not last for ever.
('39', 463, 1, 6, 920562) Some of them are bound to get education; they will then fight with hatred in their hearts, tell the poor women of their rights, incite their children to fight for legitimate or illegitimate causes and, though they themselves observe no distinction between morality and immorality, will have the sympathy of the world on their side in their fight illustrating the law that, no matter how strong a person is, he will sooner or later meet his match.
('39', 463, 1, 7, 921009) There are many straightforward ways of preventing such a situation from arising.
('39', 463, 1, 8, 921090) The best course, certainly, is that a trader who cannot observe self control should take his wife with him.
('39', 463, 1, 9, 921198) If he goes alone and forms a union with a Negro woman, he should behave decently, treat her with love and accept the responsibility of providing for the children which may be born to her.
('39', 463, 1, 10, 921386) He should understand that, under the law, he is bound to provide for the maintenance both of the woman and her children.
('39', 463, 1, 11, 921507) But a lustful and shameless man has no thought of right and wrong and no sense of what is due to others; he lives like a man bereft of his senses, intoxicated with lust.
('39', 463, 1, 12, 921677) How is he, therefore, likely even to read such articles?
('39', 463, 1, 13, 921734) Even if he reads them, he will certainly not heed them.
('39', 463, 1, 14, 921790) Hence social reformers like this correspondent should consider what their duty is.
('39', 463, 1, 15, 921873) I am afraid society will have no choice but to shoulder the burden of the consequences of sin so long as there are wicked men and women in it, just as it eagerly reaps the benefit of the virtue of virtuous men and women.
('39', 463, 1, 16, 922094) There is no man or woman who is completely free from sin; we are all a band of sinners.
('39', 463, 1, 17, 922182) But society condones the sins of those who observe a certain decency in their conduct and regards them as virtuous people, whereas it looks upon those who cross the bounds of that decency as wicked.
('39', 463, 1, 18, 922381) Thus societys definitions of the wicked and the virtuous are dictated by practical considerations.In Gods court, however, all of us will be treated as sinners and will be punished in accordance with the nature of our sins.
('39', 463, 1, 19, 922604) Being in such a sorrowful plight, society must shoulder the burden of children of mixed unions.
('39', 463, 1, 20, 922700) Accordingly, reformers living in Africa have two courses open to them : one which seeks the help of
('39', 464, 0, 1, 922800) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 465
('39', 464, 1, 2, 922845) courts and another which is independent of such help.
('39', 464, 1, 3, 922899) They have a right to adopt both.
('39', 464, 1, 4, 922932) The second course consists in a reformer seeking the help of other like minded citizens and, without raising disputes about religion, establishing an institution to look after such progeny.
('39', 464, 1, 5, 923122) If the fathers of the children desire to take charge of them and bring them up in their own faiths and if they are ready to pay the institution the expenses incurred on the children up to the day of their removal, the children should be handed over to them.
('39', 464, 1, 6, 923380) Whenever the parents can be contacted, they should be requested to pay for the maintenance of the children and, if they refuse to pay though they have the means with which to pay, due legal steps should be taken against them.
('39', 464, 1, 7, 923606) Side by side with this, efforts should also be made to bring about moral reform.
('39', 464, 1, 8, 923687) If anyone who lives with a Negro woman is married and has a wife living in India, he should be persuaded to call her to Africa.
('39', 464, 1, 9, 923815) But the friend who has written the letter says :
('39', 464, 2, 10, 923864) 1Our countrymen do not wish to start any such institution.
('39', 464, 2, 11, 923923) In my view, 75 per cent of the money earned in this land comes from immoral sources and, therefore, it is not spent on worthy causes.
('39', 464, 2, 12, 924057) It is wasted in drinking or paying doctors bills or Government taxes, or in all three ways.
('39', 464, 2, 13, 924149) Even if this is a true picture of the state of affairs, I advise this friend to work patiently and quietly.

('39', 464, 3, 15, 924294) 455. WHO MAY TAKE DIKSHA 2
('39', 464, 4, 16, 924321) In the Jawra State there is a married woman of the Oswal community named Gulabbai.
('39', 464, 4, 17, 924404) She has got a pamphlet printed in Hindi and has distributed copies of it to people.
('39', 464, 4, 18, 924488) It seems from it that her husband, who is still young, has left his house with the intention of taking diksha, and written as follows to his sixteen year old wife : The desire to take diksha has grown upon me during the past two years or so.
('39', 464, 4, 19, 924730) I have been trying my best to obtain the permission of family members.
('39', 464, 4, 20, 924801) Even after coming here, I wrote five or six letters, but I have not received the permission.
('39', 464, 4, 21, 924894) Now I have decided to take diksha on my own responsibility.
('39', 464, 4, 22, 924954) This young man has a mother who is sixty years of age.
('39', 464, 4, 23, 925009) In reply
('39', 464, 5, 24, 925018) 1 Initiation; vow of asceticism
('39', 465, 0, 1, 925050) 466 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 465, 1, 2, 925092) to my request for more particulars, the gentleman who sent me this pamphlet has given the following information.
('39', 465, 1, 3, 925205) I translate the letter, which is in Hindi, into Gujarati : Gulabbai has had ordinary education.
('39', 465, 1, 4, 925301) She can read and write Hindi.
('39', 465, 1, 5, 925331) A friend drafted for her the pamphlet which expresses her feelings as she described them to him, and she has got it printed.
('39', 465, 1, 6, 925456) She herself went to the press, accompanied by her brother, and got it printed.
('39', 465, 1, 7, 925535) The husband can read and write Hindi fairly well.
('39', 465, 1, 8, 925585) Financially the familys condition is difficult.
('39', 465, 1, 9, 925633) No one has given him diksha so far.
('39', 465, 1, 10, 925669) I hope that no one will give diksha to this young man, and also that he himself will realize his duty.
('39', 465, 1, 11, 925772) A Buddha or a Shankaracharya may take diksha at a young age, and his action will be admired by the people.
('39', 465, 1, 12, 925879) If, however, every young man decides to follow the example of these great men, instead of shedding lustre on dharma and themselves they will disgrace both.
('39', 465, 1, 13, 926035) When people take diksha in these days, we see nothing but cowardice in their action, and this is why even sadhus, instead of being men of light and power, are a majority of them weak and ignorant like us.
('39', 465, 1, 14, 926240) Taking diksha is an act of courage, and it is the result either of very holy influences on a person in his or her previous life or wisdom born of experience in this life.
('39', 465, 1, 15, 926411) A man who decides to take diksha without thinking of what will happen to his old mother and young wife should be so disinterested towards the world that the people round him cannot but see and understand his detachment.
('39', 465, 1, 16, 926631) It does not seem that this young man who desires to take diksha is equipped for it in any such manner.
('39', 465, 1, 17, 926734) However, young men who feel very eager to take diksha, why should they not expand the meaning of the term diksha?
('39', 465, 1, 18, 926848) In these times, we see few people who observe even the householders dharma properly.
('39', 465, 1, 19, 926933) It requires no small measure of courage to live, while being a householder, as if one had taken diksha.
('39', 465, 1, 20, 927037) The real test lies in living so.
('39', 465, 1, 21, 927070) I know many who have taken diksha; they frankly admit that they have not overcome sloth nor subdued the five senses.
('39', 465, 1, 22, 927187) By taking diksha, these people have only acquired better means of meeting their needs of food and clothing.
('39', 465, 1, 23, 927295) To live with ones family in poverty and meet its needs contentedly and preserving ones purity, following truth, looking upon all women other than ones wife as either a mother or a sister, to be moderate even in enjoying conjugal pleasure, to study scriptures and other holy books and to serve the country to
('39', 466, 0, 1, 927603) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 467
('39', 466, 1, 2, 927648) the best of ones abilitythis is diksha of no mean order.
('39', 466, 1, 3, 927705) Diksha means self dedication.
('39', 466, 1, 4, 927735) This is not achieved through outward show; it is a state of the mind and, though certain outward modes of living may be necessary to express it, they are valued only if they are true signs of inward purity and detachment.
('39', 466, 1, 5, 927957) Without these, such outward modes are mere forms without life in them.

('39', 466, 7, 17, 928466) 457. SPEECH TO VOLUNTEERS, BANGALORE 1
('39', 466, 8, 18, 928505) August 28, 1927
('39', 466, 9, 19, 928521) The prayer over, each came one by one and received at Gandhijis hands a copy of the Bhagavad Gita with his autograph.
('39', 466, 9, 20, 928639) There was considerable tremor in
('39', 466, 10, 21, 928672) Gangadharraos voice as he interpreted the blessings sentence by sentence in Kannada.
('39', 466, 10, 22, 928757) It is not by accident that things happen in this world.
('39', 466, 10, 23, 928813) Why should we have met at this particular hour [4 a.m.], and on this particular day, and why should the Gita of all other books have been selected to be presented to you?
('39', 466, 10, 24, 928984) Why, too, should we have read the third chapter of the Gita on this occasion?
('39', 466, 10, 25, 929062) It was not for you that we selected this chapter; today was the day on which we read the third chapter.
('39', 466, 10, 26, 929166) But some agency conspired to combine all these things, and
('39', 466, 11, 27, 929225) 1 From Mahadev Desais article, The Leave taking
('39', 467, 0, 1, 929273) 468 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 467, 1, 2, 929315) we will see that it has been all in the fitness of things.
('39', 467, 1, 3, 929374) A true servant gets up before sunrise, performs his ablutions and starts the day with prayer.
('39', 467, 1, 4, 929468) Take it that your life of service begins from this auspicious hour.

('39', 477, 4, 7, 953041) SISTERS, I have your letter drafted by Ramaniklalbhai.
('39', 477, 4, 8, 953096) You have not caught my point.
('39', 477, 4, 9, 953126) There were several things implied in my letter.
('39', 477, 4, 10, 953174) It is always so in letters.
('39', 477, 4, 11, 953202) If they were all made explicit, this is what it would come to : When we are engaged in a particular task, we should not think of other fields of service so long as they are not urgent.
('39', 477, 4, 12, 953387) If we do, it must be regarded as moha 2. Here I am doing a necessary piece of service as well as a sick man can do it.
('39', 477, 4, 13, 953506) If at such a time I thought of Gujarat flood relief or of the Ashram problems and how I would solve them if I were there, it would be moha.
('39', 477, 4, 14, 953646) If you were in such a condition, it would be true of you too.
('39', 477, 4, 15, 953708) There is no question of ones being great or small.
('39', 477, 4, 16, 953759) You are engaged there in doing service in your own way.
('39', 477, 4, 17, 953815) Suppose I fall ill, very ill, or suppose there were floods here, as heavy as those in Gujarat, it would be madness for you to entertain a needless thought (of running down here), even though you are not considered as wise as I. That would not mean that you would have no feeling or sympathy for me or for the sufferers in the Madras floods.
('39', 477, 4, 18, 954156) Sympathy there will be and must be, in which your feeling for others finds expression.
('39', 477, 4, 19, 954243) But if you become restless about it, it is moha, and should be avoided.
('39', 477, 4, 20, 954315) It is of course a different question to decide when it becomes ones dharma to rush to the help of another at the sacrifice of ones own duty.
('39', 477, 4, 21, 954456) To do flood relief work, most of the members left the Ashram.
('39', 477, 4, 22, 954518) That was clearly our duty.
('39', 477, 4, 23, 954545) And yet, for those who could not go, there was no need to feel restless.
('39', 477, 4, 24, 954618) Ask me if you still do not understand what I say.

('39', 483, 3, 4, 965970) MR. CHAIRMAN AND FRIENDS,

('39', 483, 4, 6, 966070) It is really with Vellore that the khadi tour in Tamil Nadu commences.
('39', 483, 4, 7, 966141) Last week I went to Krishnagiri 2 and Hosur which are also in the Tamil province; but that may pass as part of the Mysore programme.
('39', 483, 4, 8, 966274) Coming to Vellore, I am reminded of my first visit to this place accompanied by Maulana Shaukat Ali.
('39', 483, 4, 9, 966375) And when I cast back my memory upon those times and now look at this assembly today, I cannot help feeling sadsad not because you have in any way misbehaved yourselves but because of what is going on in the North.
('39', 483, 4, 10, 966589) As a matter of fact my sadness is considerably reduced when I, on enquiry, discover that in your midst at any rate you have no such quarrels as are going on there, to distrub the even tenor of your life.
('39', 483, 4, 11, 966793) My irrepressible optimism is strengthened by living in your midst and discovering that you stand untouched and unruffled by the misdoings of our countrymen in the North.
('39', 483, 4, 12, 966963) For my hope will last as long as my faith in God lasts and even though Hindus and Mussalmans all over India were to fly at one anothers throats, which God forbid, I hope that I shall still have the same strength that I possess today to declare in my own person that the day is coming when Hindus and Mussalmans will stand shoulder to shoulder, fight for their countrys freedom and remain united for ever as brothers.
('39', 483, 4, 13, 967380) I want you people of Vellore, men and women, to share that faith with me.
('39', 483, 4, 14, 967454) I have no doubt that posterity will laugh at our barbarity and ask themselves how foolish and how mad we must have been that in the name God we should cut each other to pieces.
('39', 483, 4, 15, 967631) But as you know I hold of equal importance with Hindu Muslim unity the question of khaddar and the spinning wheel.
('39', 483, 4, 16, 967746) To spin for the sake of Daridranarayana and to use nothing but khadi for the same reason is as much an act of pleasing God as it is that Hindus and Mussalmans should remain united together.
('39', 483, 4, 17, 967936) Just as Hindu Muslim unity binds the two together so does the thread that is spun on the spinning wheel bind the millions of paupers of India to us, the middle class.
('39', 483, 4, 18, 968103) At the present moment it is true that we do not cut their throats but it is equally true that in a sense

('39', 488, 1, 2, 978139) 473. TRUE SHRADDHA
('39', 488, 2, 3, 978158) A friend sends from Rangoon rupees twenty five as donation for the propaganda of the spinning wheel and writes :
('39', 488, 3, 4, 978271) My father died on the 18th April 1927 at Tanjore (South India) while I was there on a short leave.
('39', 488, 3, 5, 978370) When I was confronted with the question of Sixteenth Day Ceremony, a slavish, meaningless imitation of shraddha, I
('39', 488, 4, 6, 978485) resolutely refused to abide by the desire of my relatives simply because I have no belief in it as it prevails today.
('39', 488, 4, 7, 978603) I do not believe in a departed soul waiting in Pitruloka or some such other unseen places for water or rice balls.
('39', 488, 4, 8, 978718) Nor can I
('39', 488, 5, 9, 978728) see any reason to attach any importance to the rites performed by a mercenary priest and in a language which is Greek both to me and the officiating priest.
('39', 488, 5, 10, 978885) In short the whole affair seems to be a hoax designed to be practised on the religious susceptibilities of the people.
('39', 488, 5, 11, 979004) But I can believe in shraddha as a
('39', 488, 6, 12, 979039) thing offered in piety and devotion with a charitable intention.
('39', 488, 6, 13, 979104) From a commonsense point of view the main principle and the original purpose of this ceremony ought to be charity.
('39', 488, 6, 14, 979219) As you say in Young India dated 24 2 
('39', 488, 7, 15, 979257) 1927, only two classes of people are entitled to charity and none elsethe Brahmin who possesses nothing and whose business it is to spread holy learning, and the cripple and the blind. Our great immortal sage, Thiruvalluvar has said : A Brahmin is that sannyasi who has an overflowing love towards all living creatures. Because I could not conceive of a man who has a better claim than you and a more charitable purpose than that of the spinning wheel, I have sent you this amount.
('39', 488, 7, 16, 979739) There is also another way of commemorating the memory of ones own parents.
('39', 488, 7, 17, 979814) The same sage Thiruvalluvar has again said : The gratitude of a son to his father must consist in the son conducting himself in the world in such a way as to excite from the world the approbation that his father must have performed a great tapasya to
('39', 488, 8, 18, 980065) beget this son. I may add that I have this ideal at my heart.
('39', 488, 8, 19, 980127) I have omitted from the letter several personal references.
('39', 488, 8, 20, 980187) Though I have performed shraddha ceremonies myself in my youth,I have not been able to understand their religious usefulness.
('39', 488, 8, 21, 980313) This letter is not the first of its kind I have received.
('39', 488, 8, 22, 980371) But not being able to understand the hidden meaning, if any, of the practices which are almost universal in Hinduism, I have hitherto refrained from dealing with them in these pages.
('39', 488, 8, 23, 980554) The rule that the correspondent has chosen has however appealed to me.
('39', 488, 8, 24, 980625) We do very often meekly submit to many conventional ceremonies although we may have no faith in them, and although they may have no meaning for us.
('39', 488, 8, 25, 980773) Submission to convention in trivial matters in which there is no danger of deceiving
('39', 489, 0, 1, 980858) 490 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 489, 1, 2, 980900) others or oneself is often desirable and even necessary.
('39', 489, 1, 3, 980957) But submission in matters of religion, especially where there is a positive repugnance from within and a danger of deceiving our neighbours and ourselves, cannot but be debasing.
('39', 489, 1, 4, 981136) There are today many religious ceremonies, which, whatever meaning and importance they might have had in ages gone by, have neither importance nor meaning for the rising generation.
('39', 489, 1, 5, 981318) There can be no doubt that it is necessary for this generation to strike out an original path by giving a new form and even meaning to many old ceremonies.
('39', 489, 1, 6, 981474) The idea of keeping green and of respecting the memory of ones parents is not to be given up.
('39', 489, 1, 7, 981568) But it is hardly necessary on that account to retain the old conventions and forms, which have lost their reality and therefore ceased to have any influence on us.
('39', 489, 1, 8, 981732) I therefore commend the example of the correspondent to those who are anxious to do only that which is right, and free themselves from self deception.
('39', 489, 1, 9, 981883) Young India, 1 9 1927
('39', 489, 2, 10, 981905) 474. HOW TO KEEP HEALTH
('39', 489, 3, 11, 981929) The Polish Professor with whom the reader is now familiar writing on my illness says :
('39', 489, 4, 12, 982016) As I have been reading in Young India about your illness and discussion
('39', 489, 5, 13, 982088) with jailors, let me tell you of my own experience how to prevent such
('39', 489, 6, 14, 982159) breakdowns.
('39', 489, 6, 15, 982171) Within the last nine monthsSeptember to MayI have visited
('39', 489, 7, 16, 982229) 40 towns all over Poland, and lectured for 100 days at the rate of 3 7 hours a
('39', 489, 8, 17, 982308) At the age of 64, I feel as young as 40 years ago whenever I stand before
('39', 489, 9, 18, 982382) the public.
('39', 489, 9, 19, 982394) My rules are :
('39', 489, 10, 20, 982409) 1. No worry whatever.
('39', 489, 10, 21, 982431) There is an an Almighty God who takes care of
('39', 489, 11, 22, 982477) all, and nothing happens without His permission.
('39', 489, 11, 23, 982526) I am not His chief steward, only a very humble servant with a clearly defined task, and have to look at that task, that small part of universal becoming.
('39', 489, 11, 24, 982680) If there is somewhere on earth an earthquake or a flood or a famine, no real harm can happen to immortal souls, nobody can suffer without some advantage to him designed by God, and everywhere God has His servants who help so far as He permits them.
('39', 489, 11, 25, 982929) Therefore worry is weakness of faith, and my faith being infinite I cannot worry.
('39', 489, 12, 26, 983011) 2. Much sleep in every moment when I am not at work, even for a few
('39', 489, 13, 27, 983079) minutes many times a day.
('39', 489, 13, 28, 983105) Before falling into sleep always praying : Lord Jesus enlighten me, give me strength and joy.
('39', 489, 13, 29, 983199) With this prayer a clear image
('39', 490, 0, 1, 983230) VOL. 39 : 4 JUNE, 1927 1 SEPTEMBER, 1927 491
('39', 490, 1, 2, 983275) of joy, light, strength flowing into me.
('39', 490, 1, 3, 983316) Such a sleep is prayer, is intercourse with the Highest and refreshing.
('39', 490, 1, 4, 983388) When I wake up from such a sleep, I know exactly what I have to do, and I do it gladly.
('39', 490, 1, 5, 983476) The professor adds a third rule which is about fasting and diet.
('39', 490, 1, 6, 983541) As it is incomplete, I have asked for further information before sharing it with reader.
('39', 490, 1, 7, 983630) But there is no doubt that the two rules above mentioned about absence of worry and necessity for sleep are golden rules.
('39', 490, 1, 8, 983752) There is nothing that wastes the body like worry and one who has any faith in God should be ashamed to worry about anything whatsoever.
('39', 490, 1, 9, 983888) It is a difficult rule no doubt for the simple reason, that faith in God with the majority of mankind is either an intellectual belief or a blind belief, a kind of superstitious fear of something indefinable.
('39', 490, 1, 10, 984097) But to ensure absolute freedom from worry requires a living utter faith which is a plant of slow, almost unperceived, growth and requires to be constantly watered by tears that accompany genuine prayer.
('39', 490, 1, 11, 984300) They are the tears of a lover who cannot brook a moments separation from the loved one, or of the penitent who knows that it is some trace of impurity in him that keeps him away from the loved one.
('39', 490, 1, 12, 984498) The ability to sleep during odd moments seems to be a necessity in old age.
('39', 490, 1, 13, 984574) Whilst the first rule is applicable to all, young and old, the rule about sleep is not to be copied by youngsters.
('39', 490, 1, 14, 984689) It is the privilege only of babies and old people.
('39', 490, 1, 15, 984740) And to induce such sweet innocent sleep, it is surely necessary to put oneself in tune with the Infinite at every step.
('39', 490, 1, 16, 984860) This sleep is not to be mistaken for the sleep of the sluggard or the opium eater.
('39', 490, 1, 17, 984943) But it is Natures sweet restorer, a tonic for a brain that gets easily fagged in old age.
('39', 490, 1, 18, 985033) Young India, 1 9 1927

('39', 492, 1, 5, 987157) Every yard of well spun yarn adds to the wealth of the country, be the addition ever so infinitesimal.
('39', 492, 1, 6, 987260) You know what the lawyers do so often whilst awaiting their turn in the law courts.

('39', 495, 3, 4, 992928) MY DEAR MOTI BABU,
('39', 495, 4, 5, 992947) Though I have thought of you [more times] 2 than I can count, I have not been able to make time for writing to you as I had nothing in particular to say to you.
('39', 495, 4, 6, 993108) But today, by accident I find before me the fourth number of the Standard Bearer.
('39', 495, 4, 7, 993190) I have according to my wont looked at the advertisements.
('39', 495, 4, 8, 993248) Of course you know my ideas about advertisements and in a serious journal devoted to religious research and drawing inspiration from you, I should like omission of all advertisements, but in any case if there should be any, they should be a selected assortment.
('39', 495, 4, 9, 993510) I was, therefore, distressed to find an advertise ment for spermatone.
('39', 495, 4, 10, 993581) The description of the medicine is not at all inviting and I do not know [whether] 3 you know that such advertise ments are partly responsible for enervating our youths.
('39', 495, 4, 11, 993751) There are others, too, which I dislike but I have called attention to the most glaring one.
('39', 495, 4, 12, 993843) You will now do what you think proper.
('39', 495, 4, 13, 993882) I hope that khadi work is being developed as you had expected and that you are keeping well and further that you have no trouble from the authorities.
('39', 495, 4, 14, 994033) I seem to have got over the collapse, at least for the time being and I have now seriously embarked upon a nearly four months tour in the South.
('39', 495, 4, 15, 994178) What was done in Mysore I do not count as anything.
('39', 495, 5, 16, 994230) Yours sincerely,
('39', 495, 6, 17, 994247) M. K. GANDHI SJT.
('39', 495, 6, 18, 994265) MOTILAL ROY PRAVARTAK SANGH CHANDRANAGAR

('39', 496, 2, 3, 994450) APPENDIX I
('39', 496, 3, 4, 994461) LETTER FROM BASIL MATHEWS
('39', 496, 4, 5, 994487) WORLD SERVICE TO THE FRIENDS OF BOYS UNDER THE GUIDANCE
('39', 496, 5, 6, 994543) OF THE WORLDS COMMITTEE OF Y.M.C.A.
('39', 496, 6, 7, 994579) January 5, 1927
('39', 496, 8, 8, 994595) To the boys of the world we addressed a general questionnaire in which we asked Who in your opinion is the greatest living man? Trained educationists and leaders of youth in over fifty countries aided us in this worldwide inquiry into the mind of boys.
('39', 496, 8, 9, 994848) The response of hundreds of boys from a large number of countries Asiatic, European, American and Africanshowed that they consider you the greatest man living.
('39', 496, 9, 10, 995008) We are publishing a magazine for leaders of boysThe Worlds Youth which
('39', 496, 10, 11, 995079) circulates in 59 countries.
('39', 496, 10, 12, 995107) It would be of unmeasured significance to them and to the boys they serve, to have direct from yourself, through the medium of this journal, a personal message as to the general principle that has guided your life.
('39', 496, 10, 13, 995322) We assure you that this is no mere journalistic stunt.
('39', 496, 10, 14, 995377) We are making the request sincerely believing that your compliance will mean very much for the advancement of what we both hope fora stronger, cleaner, more heroic youth throughout the world.
('39', 496, 11, 15, 995569) We are convinced that your intimate statement of 100 words or more will be a factor of profound influence in the lives of thousands of boys, and we will be glad to convey back to you responses we receive from them, in which we know you will be interested.
('39', 496, 11, 16, 995825) Yours faithfully, BASIL MATHEWS
('39', 496, 12, 17, 995857) From a photostat: S.N. 12476
('39', 496, 13, 18, 995886) APPENDIX II
('39', 496, 14, 19, 995898) GANDHIJI AT THE IMPERIAL DAIRY, BANGALORE
('39', 496, 15, 20, 995940) On being told that there are many dairies in Bangalore, Gandhiji has been
('39', 496, 16, 21, 996014) visiting one of them, the Imperial Dairy, for some days, trying to understand every
('39', 496, 17, 22, 996098) little detail of its working, inspecting the cattle, eliciting information about their
('39', 496, 18, 23, 996185) yield, the expenses of their upkeep, the nutrition given to them, the treatment and
('39', 496, 19, 24, 996269) annual value of their manure, etc., etc.
('39', 496, 19, 25, 996310) All this he thinks he must do in order to do
('39', 497, 0, 1, 996355) 498 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('39', 497, 1, 2, 996397) justice to his office as President of the All India Cow Protection Association.
('39', 497, 2, 3, 996477) The short course of lesson that Gandhiiji had in the Imperial Dairy, thanks to the courtesy of Mr. Smith, was made interesting as much by the readiness of those in charge to give Gandhiji the best they could, as by the presence of Pandit Malaviyaji during a couple of visits.
('39', 497, 2, 4, 996753) After giving a couple of days to the dairy processes, Gandhiji was shown the different cattle which are under the close observation of the expert, who measures every ounce of the nutrition that goes into their bodies, and every ounce of their droppings, to arrive at conclusions about the digestibility of different foods, their milking results, and so on.
('39', 497, 2, 5, 997110) Mr. Smith himself explained the most important and the most simple method of storing grass and fodder in silos.
('39', 497, 2, 6, 997222) It is going to solve the question of fodder for cattle, he said, It is most important and yet so simple, and because it is simple, people do not see its value. The different concrete and pit silos were shown, Mr. Smith going into minute detail and trying to show how, with a little carefulness, and irrespective of weather, the agriculturist can provide for his cattle against times of scarcity.
('39', 497, 2, 7, 997618) The interest with which he showed us his cows, and gave the history of some of them, spoke eloquently of his love for the cow.
('39', 497, 2, 8, 997745) I was born and bred among them, said the good Scotchman with pardonable pride.
('39', 497, 2, 9, 997824) My father was a farmer and for twenty years examiner of students going in for the Dairy Diploma, and my mother attended to our home dairy herself.
('39', 497, 2, 10, 997971) Let every agriculturist in India realize the value of cattle breeding and cattle protection.
('39', 497, 2, 11, 998064) Let us not export a single article of food for the cattlehe might have added the cattle alsoand let us realize that the increased milking capacity of the cows does not affect the quality of the draught animals.
('39', 497, 2, 12, 998275) On the contrary, put a number of bullocks before me, and I will show that the best of them are the progeny of the cows which have been your best milkers.
('39', 497, 3, 13, 998429) On the last day Mr. Smith expressed his desire to have a photograph of Pandit
('39', 497, 4, 14, 998507) Malaviyaji and Gandhiji with their best cow Jill, an Ayrshire and Montgomery
('39', 497, 5, 15, 998584) crossbreed which has calved sixteen times, and given all these years an average yield
('39', 497, 6, 16, 998670) of 10,000 lbs.
('39', 497, 6, 17, 998685) of milk.
('39', 497, 6, 18, 998694) She is naturally the pet of the Dairy.
('39', 497, 6, 19, 998733) She was born here, I
('39', 497, 7, 20, 998754) was present at her birth, said Mr. Smith, and have watched her growth all these
('39', 497, 8, 21, 998834) We have all kinds of cattle diseases here, but Jill has never had one.
('39', 497, 9, 22, 998905) Young India, 23 6 1927 and 30 6 1927
